Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Willie Stark rises from a rural county treasurer to a powerful political figure.
output:
He uses his influence to help the poor and disadvantaged, but also becomes increasingly corrupt and ruthless. His rise to power is marked by a series of scandals and controversies, including accusations of bribery, blackmail, and murder. Despite these allegations, Willie remains popular with the public and continues to win elections. However, his actions eventually catch up with him, and he is assassinated by one of his own supporters. In the aftermath of his death, the state is left in chaos, and many wonder if Willie's legacy will be remembered as a hero or a villain.

The story begins with Willie Stark, a young man from a small town in Louisiana, running for governor. He is a charismatic and ambitious politician who promises to fight corruption and improve the lives of the poor. However, as he gains more power, he becomes increasingly corrupt himself. He starts taking bribes from wealthy businessmen and using his position to enrich himself and his friends. He also becomes involved in several scandals, including an affair with a married woman and a cover-up of a murder committed by one of his associates.

Despite these scandals, Willie remains popular with the public, who see him as a champion of the common man. He wins re-election easily and continues to use his power to benefit his supporters. However, his actions eventually catch up with him. One of his closest allies, Jack Burden, discovers evidence of Willie's corruption and threatens to expose him. Willie tries to bribe Jack into keeping quiet, but Jack refuses. In retaliation, Willie orders his men to kill Jack.

However, the plan backfires when one of Willie's supporters, Adam Stanton, learns of the plot and decides to take matters into his own hands. He confronts Willie and shoots him dead. In the aftermath of Willie's assassination, the state is thrown into chaos. Many people mourn the loss of their beloved leader, while others celebrate his downfall. Some believe that Willie was a hero who fought for the rights of the poor, while others see him as a corrupt tyrant who abused his power.

In the end, the question of whether Willie Stark was a hero or a villain remains unanswered. Some argue that he was a flawed but ultimately good man who tried to do what was best for his constituents. Others claim that he was a selfish and manipulative politician who cared only about his own interests. Regardless of how he is remembered, Willie Stark's legacy will continue to shape the politics of Louisiana for generations to come.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
"Ah man, it smells like death in here." That is the phrase that I have lived to regret ever since they fell foolishly from my mouth. I was essentially immortal before that moment in time. I was the best comedian in the world, and apparently better than anyone in the afterlife as well. It was the only reason the Grim Reaper decided not to take me. I could make him laugh, and in his line of work that was a rarity. I do n't even remember what it was that I had said when he showed up at my car accident. I can recall him bending down next to my overturned Honda civic and reaching in to pull me out. I made some off the wall comment and he froze, dead in his tracks. It was the weirdest laugh I had ever heard, but one I appreciated more than all of the others combined. He let me live, provided that every year on the anniversary of what should have been my death, I would tell him a joke that would make him cry with laughter. I was his own personal jester, and for that he rewarded me handsomely. And then on that fateful day, 121 years later, I muttered those stupid words that seized our contract and ripped it in two. Who knew Death would be so self conscious about his smell? And to make things worse, that was n't even the joke that I was going to tell him! The actual joke was a masterpiece, but he would n't give me the chance to tell it. I ran out of that room faster than I'd ever run before. And I've been running ever since. I think the reason that he has n't taken me yet is because of our long history together. That is n't to say that he's forgiven me. He seems to enjoy reminding me that he's near. Everyone I get close to dies without reason. I'll see a dog in the park that I think looks adorable and before I can pet it, it'll fall over dead. Roses crumble before I can enjoy their scent and food rots on my fork before I can bring it to my mouth. He's killing everything around me. I have discovered that Death is a jester of a different sort. I had provided him with a form of humor that he was n't used to, but he has since grown tired of it, and reverted to his old ways. Now, he once again deals in jokes of cruelty and irony. In a way, I am still fulfilling my part of our old deal. The Reaper still laughs, and he still laughs at me. Only now, the difference is I'm not laughing.

I was treated like I was special the second I was born. # 1. The last of the children born on Earth, to a middle-class family in the heart of New York. I was supposed to be the talisman, the last hope for humanity. I was supposed to lead us into the stars and break the genetic disease that ravaged our planet. I was supposed to find a cure and make it possible to continue the human race again. So the prophecy foretold, in that huge book held deep within the vaults of the UN Building, the last surviving testament the Great Leader himself. I was supposed to be the second coming of him, he who had found the disease eating our DNA, he who had brought the world together under one almighty, omniscient umbrella. I was supposed to be him incarnate once again. Time went by and I failed at every turn. I was reviled. I could n't do math well enough; anatomy confused me. How was I supposed to find a cure for the disease when I could n't even name the parts of a cell? Riots ensued. "We're all going to die! Humanity is doomed!" My parents and the few advisers that remained to keep them safe tried their hardest to educate me, to let me fulfill my destiny. They tried to save the human race. The crowds got Dad first. When they came, in the middle of the night on Halloween, my parents thought it was the last two kids in New York besides myself, trick-or-treating despite the fact that they were almost fifteen each. They shot Dad in the chest, for producing the doom of humanity. Mom screamed and Dr. Evans shouted for us to run. Dr. Muller went with us while Evans held the back door against the mob. We ran for two weeks in Mom's sedan, keeping me hidden from view. I was n't allowed to leave the back seat, and I could n't take off my sweatshirt, even in the middle of Texas. It was only after the miracle birth of # 0 that we were safe. From the deep jungle of the Amazon came the true Inheritor of the Great Leader. She cracked the disease by the time she was 5. She gave humanity it's first commercial space fleet and colonies by 10. By 15, she was granted the title of Queen of Earth. And me? I will always be remembered as the Great Failure. The Great Pretender. The Church of the Queen still wants me hung for being the false Chosen One. So I had no choice. I ran. Into the depths of space, I ran. Somewhere, lost out in the stars, where no one could find me, where no one could look at that permanent scar on my wrist, that horrible # 1. It's lonely out here, but it's better to be lonely than dead.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
THE WALL IS BUILT... EVENTUALLY Centipedes slink through smooth gaps in a rotten facade. Moss hides in the shadows and vines creep towards the light. The wall has existed all my life, and all through the lives of my oldest memorable ancestors. It is the lore of our people, that they traveled from distant lands where compassion was an economy, and peace an inescapable truth to seek opportunity. Well, another inescapable truth is that man, even in a place of prosperity, will often succumb to wanderlust. That is the story of these ancestors. Which in a way, is the story of myself. Or at least, why I came to be. They boarded a ship and set forth to the west. For weeks, the sea lay docile beneath their ship. Lazy waves lapped the hull, and steady winds pulled her forward. The travelers, who fancied themselves much more intrepid than they were, laughed among themselves at their own good fortune. "If only the naysayers back home could see the state of things on this veritable pleasure cruise!" they would exclaim defiantly. This trend settled into a routine before long, and such was the new life of the wayfarer. The sun would break the horizon, and they would rise from sleep to great it. Meals were consumed, feet took to dance, and wine was drunk. Unfortunately, even the most steadfast of routines is fleeting in the scheme of life, and one night bad luck finally befell them. A new trend. And one that would last certainly longer than the previous. The captain saw through a glass large clouds of deep black swirling in the distance. Dusk was minutes off, so he took to worry. The coarse was altered, and the ship's path now listed somewhat to the South and away from danger. It was a reasonable precaution, and would have been a perfect solution if the maps were more reliable. They, however, most certainly were not. Therefore, it was not. If smooth seas never made a skillful sailor, it is no surprise that the captain and crew had some serious shortcomings. To blame any single one of them for the wreck would be terribly unfair. The real culprit was hidden somewhere in the barrels of wine and mead stored below deck. And in the habit they had made of good fortune. With bad weather behind, and brisk air above, the crew had mostly joined the passengers within the ships belly. With so many people gathered so closely, either violence or levity are guaranteed, and on this evening the mood kept a lighter tone. Above, in the crows nest, a lonely man listened resentfully as voices sang, and feet stomped to the tune of jovial tunes played by practiced hands. Fiddles, mandolins, and accordions bickered playfully for hours and with each passing minute the weary occupier of the crow's nest grew more bitter. Just before midnight, when a particularly quick tune was met with a particularly rowdy cheer, his mind was made. "Crow's nest be damned! Mead be downed!" The latter part of that statement has sprung from the mouths of men before many a poor decision. And always with the same degree of vigor. Within moments the deck of the ship sat vacant, while the hold was full to burst. Libations continued to flow, while a jagged rocky coast sneaked ever closer.

Dusk was minutes off, so he took to worry. The coarse was altered, and the ship's path now listed somewhat to the South and away from danger. It was a reasonable precaution, and would have been a perfect solution if the maps were more reliable. They, however, most certainly were not. Therefore, it was not. If smooth seas never made a skillful sailor, it is no surprise that the captain and crew had some serious shortcomings. To blame any single one of them for the wreck would be terribly unfair. The real culprit was hidden somewhere in the barrels of wine and mead stored below deck. And in the habit they had made of good fortune. With bad weather behind, and brisk air above, the crew had mostly joined the passengers within the ships belly. With so many people gathered so closely, either violence or levity are guaranteed, and on this evening the mood kept a lighter tone. Above, in the crows nest, a lonely man listened resentfully as voices sang, and feet stomped to the tune of jovial tunes played by practiced hands. Fiddles, mandolins, and accordions bickered playfully for hours and with each passing minute the weary occupier of the crow's nest grew more bitter. Just before midnight, when a particularly quick tune was met with a particularly rowdy cheer, his mind was made. "Crow's nest be damned! Mead be downed!" The latter part of that statement has sprung from the mouths of men before many a poor decision. And always with the same degree of vigor. Within moments the deck of the ship sat vacant, while the hold was full to burst. Libations continued to flow, while a jagged rocky coast sneaked ever closer.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Had I really loved her? I thought I did. But if she was n't here... 30 years. Marrying young has its perks but I would be lying if I said the journey was n't bumpy. We had our ups and downs, just like any couple. I did things I should n't have, and said things I did n't mean. But deep down, I always knew I loved her. Or was I just lying to myself? Yet the face I was staring at was n't hers. These jet black eyes were unfamiliar and hostile. I longed for her warm, loving hazel eyes, the ones I had lived and laughed with. Over time we got to know each other better. Clarice was her name. She had been a dentist. She was undeniably beautiful, but it was an effortless, flawless beauty. Yet I longed for Alicia. I had grown accustomed to her shortfalls, and had found beauty in them. Even more time passed. Slowly the memories were replaced. I made new ones with Clarice. It was like I never knew what I had been missing out on until I had the opportunity to taste it. We simply clicked on a deeper level. She was the type of girl you can have deep co conversations about universe and life with under the stars, yet get into a tickle fight with two minutes later. For the longest time I felt guilty. However good Alicia had been, Clarice seemed to be better in every aspect. Eventually the guilt faded. All there was left was bliss. And then it all went South. The first time we argued I was stunned. We had never argued before, ever. It was a pretty issue, but an argument nonetheless. Soon enough they became more frequent. More frequent and more intense. Life turned from peace to chaos, happiness to misery. The constant stress, fighting, distrust and resentment slowly began to manifest into only one thing. Hatred. Love had turned into hatred. I had never mentioned Alicia to Clarice. I had always assumed she was like me, that she had left someone behind to be with me. Then one fine day it all made sense. All it took was one sentence from Clarice and it became crystal clear. The icy smile when she said it sent a shiver down my smile. "We know what you did to Alicia and now your life is going to be a living Hell."

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Marie-Laure evacuates Paris with her father.
output: They travel south by train to Saint-Malo, where Marie-Laure's great-uncle Etienne lives. Etienne is a reclusive man who suffers from agoraphobia. He lives alone in his late brother's house, which is filled with radios and radio equipment. Marie-Laure and her father stay with him while they wait for news from Paris. Meanwhile, Werner and Jutta are evacuated from their orphanage in Germany. They are taken to a small town called Zollverein, where they live with a family named the Pfennigs. The Pfennigs are kind people, but they are also very poor. Werner and Jutta help out around the house as much as they can. One day, Werner finds a broken radio in the attic. He fixes it and starts listening to broadcasts from France. He becomes fascinated by the French language and culture. He also begins to develop feelings for Jutta. As the war progresses, both Marie-Laure and Werner find themselves caught up in events beyond their control. Marie-Laure's father is arrested by the Gestapo and sent to a concentration camp. Werner is drafted into the German army and sent to the Eastern Front. Both characters struggle to survive in a world that seems increasingly hostile and dangerous. In the end, Marie-Laure and Werner meet in Saint-Malo. They fall in love and decide to start a new life together. The novel ends with a hopeful note, suggesting that even in the darkest times, there is still room for hope and love.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
We never believed that the end would come, that the dawn would rise again. Every 300 years our moon orbits the world below us, this world is our guardian, it protects us, shelters us from all that the vast expanse of space has to offer: but it could not shelter us from itself, on the far side of the moons orbit lies a vast and ancient race, their empire sprawls across the planets surface and every 300 years, when our moon comes within striking distance they attack. It is said that when they do they bring with them giant beasts, created of the most foul magic, beasts of flesh with hearts as cold as ice. Our weapons could never stand against them, we never stood a chance. so when it came in 599 CE, the year of our holy father I huddled in fear in our capitol.My armies were in position to protect the citizens here, but I knew we stood no hope, our guns, as useful as they may be would never stand up against the might of the empire and so it was that on the turning point of the day we saw them come, and they came with the dawn. Vast ships pummeled our surface with rains of fire as the dawn swept across our land, melting the ever frozen landscape. Their armies landed on our surface, weapons firing some sort of plasmic mix. I watched my city crumble around me as the fighting raged on, then, then it happened. A sound like the great bellow of some ancient beast shuddered from within the earth itself; and with it they came. Hulking creatures in the shapes of men, my eyes adjusted slowly to the new light as I focused in on the great beasts that would be our doom. I watched them huge machines, not flesh but etched metal, rise and form into ranks. The Empires soldiers marched up main avenue right towards the metal horde that was slowly collecting outside our main base within the city, our last bastion. our only hope. In between the two armies, a small child wandered into the street, clearly having lost her mother and searching for anyone to car. My heart wretched as I saw one of the soldiers level its weapon at her. and my scream of pain filled the room as it fired. But as the smoke cleared I saw only a metal body, covered in plasma, shaking it off as if it were nothing more than fresh snow, and behind its protective metal shell sat the little girl. and I beheld the glory, of the new dawn.

They arrive at her great-uncle Etienne's house in Saint-Malo.
output: Marie-Laure is blind, and she must learn how to navigate the streets of the town by herself. She learns to use her cane to feel the cobblestones beneath her feet, and she memorizes the layout of the town. One day, while walking through the town, she hears someone calling out to her. She turns around and sees a young man standing there. He introduces himself as Werner Pfennig, and he tells her that he is a German soldier who has been stationed in Saint-Malo. He asks her if she needs any help finding her way home, and she accepts his offer. They walk together back to her great-uncle's house, where they spend the rest of the afternoon talking about life in Germany during World War II. As they talk, Werner begins to fall in love with Marie-Laure. He realizes that he wants to marry her someday, even though he knows that he cannot stay in France forever. When the war ends, Werner returns to Germany, but he continues to write letters to Marie-Laure. Eventually, he decides to move to America, where he hopes to find work as a radio engineer. However, before he leaves, he visits Marie-Laure one last time. He gives her a gift—a small wooden box containing a piece of amber. Inside the box, there is also a note written in French. It says, "I am sorry I had to leave without saying goodbye. Please forgive me." Marie-Laure opens the box and finds a beautiful necklace made of amber beads. She puts the necklace around her neck, and she wears it every day until she dies many years later. Her daughter inherits the necklace, and she passes it down to her own children. And so the story goes on...

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
The first time I jumped, I immediately looked up the latest medical journals. They had certainly made significant progress, but it was n't enough. I did n't even take a look around before I jumped again. I checked, again. Success. The cure had been found. It was in clinical trials and was being fast-tracked. Six months, only six months left. I drove like a madman to the hospital. Transferred? What do you mean transferred? I PAID THE BILLS FOR 9 MONTHS BEFORE I LEFT!!! 15 months ago... Oh god. Over a year. I found her. I barely recognized her, except her voice. That angelic voice that kept me going. It was difficult explaining where I'd been. I was gone for so long. She did n't understand, she was just happy to see me. Then the doctor came in. He pulled me aside. No. NO! 1 month, at best. NO! NO! NO! NO! I started to run out of the room, but she could tell. She did n't know what I was doing, but she knew I would n't be back. She pleaded, and it tore my heart apart, but I was doing it for her. When I was done, we could spend the rest of our lives together. I left, I jumped, I landed. I ran to the pharmacy, prescription in hand. The doctor had been confused when I asked for it. Probably thought it was a reaction to his prognosis. A line. There was a line at the pharmacy. It took everything I had not to scream. But then I remembered, I had all the time in the world. Drug in hand, I dialed in the date of her diagnosis. I entered the code and pressed enter. ERROR: Abort, Retry, Fail? What happened next rendered the machine useless... Now! I had to get to her now! I had to cure her right now. I stole a car, I do n't know whose it was, I could n't even tell you what kind or color it was. At some point the police started chasing me. I outran them. At the entrance, security tried to stop me, I outran them. When they told me, my guilt and denial rushed to me at once, I could n't outrun it. I just wanted to spend the rest of my life with her, so I left. She just wanted to spend the rest of her life with me, so she asked me to stay.

Because Nancy was late to work at the coffee shop, the coffee shop rushed all its orders. Because the coffee shop rushed all its orders, Larry got his boss decaf. Because Larry got his boss decaf, his boss fell asleep in the meeting. Because Larry's boss fell asleep in the meeting, Larry's boss was fired. Because Larry's boss was fired, he threw all the papers out the window in the road. Because all the papers were in the road, Trever the ambassador was stuck in traffic. Because Trever was fired, his assistant Lewis took over the negotiations. Because Lewis took over the negotiations, the trade deal fell through. Because the trade deal fell through, the Russian economy weakened. Because the Russian economy weakened, Russia tried to drill for oil in the north Baltic. Because Russia tried to drill for oil in the North Baltic, Lewis was dispatched to Moscow. Because Lewis was dispatched to Moscow, he was robbed and killed by a mugger at a train station. Because Lewis died in Moscow, America launched sanctions against Russia. Because America launched sanctions against Russia, the Russian economy collapsed. Because the Russian economy collapsed, Russia was unable to loan money to China. Because China could n't get a desperately needed loan from Russia, it turned to India. Because China got a loan from India, it had to launch severe sanctions against Pakistan. Because China launched sanctions against Pakistan, Pakistan recognized Taiwan. Because Pakistan recognized Taiwan, China cut off all relations to Pakistan. Because China cut off all relations to Pakistan, Pakistan invaded India. Because Pakistan invaded India, China invaded Pakistan. Because China invaded Pakistan, the US sold weapons to Pakistan. Because the US sold weapons to Pakistan, China launched sanctions against the US. Because China launched sanctions against the US, all major Chinese trading partners did as well. Because the US was isolated from trade, it declared war on China. Because the US declared war on China, Dave watches the news as his home is bombed to rubble. Nice job Dave.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
I've always seen numbers above people. Ever since I was a small child, I began recognizing patterns. Those in power, or with great ambition tended to be higher, while those who were more meek and humble tended to have lower numbers. As Class President, I've had my fair share of meeting people, and I'd never seen a person alive above an 8, including the tyrants of history. Sometimes, peoples numbers would change... those bullies with a 3 or 4 would cower down to a 1 or 2 after I confronted them for harassing others. I was beaten and bruised for years, but they slowly backed down. Of course, when I entered high-school, this was n't the case. There were some who were 5s and 6s, but I could n't stop now. I confronted them and the scars I have today are proof of my goals. I never backed down and kept striving to improve myself in all ways so I could make this world a better place for all of us. I scored near perfect on the University entrance exams, and was in the Tokyo University entrance ceremony when I saw him.... I did n't know his name, but an iridescent white 10 glowed above his head. The fellow next to him was a 0... Both scored perfect on the entrance exam, as they were giving the speech, but they were such opposites. The 10 was clad in suit and tie, with his long brown hair dangling in front of his eyes. The 0 was awkward-looking, he wore over-sized clothes, and it looked like he resented wearing shoes... I left early, and caught his glimpse on the way out. Our eyes caught briefly, and his 10 dropped to a 0... he smiled my way, and I smiled back. I felt calm and serene, something I would never have expected. The awkward 0 looked at me with his dark eyes before sitting down... I felt terror... as his 0 slowly morphed into a dark and smoky 10. I left that experience behind me, but worked even harder to help others; I chose to become a prosecutor... to judge and serve justice to those who were evil. High numbers were a good indicator of evil, and it is my goal to eliminate evil. I regularly judged others based on their numbers, whether they were to be eliminated or not. Then one day, it happened. Those I judged to be evil started dying of heart attacks; sudden deaths flooded the world, and the number of criminals slowly starting reducing. The world called him "Kira"... I called him God, and he soon recognized me as his devout follower, when he shared his power to judge and delete evil from this world. Now I know my ultimate purpose, and whenever I look in the mirror, I'm glad to see a shining halo-like 10 above my head, reminding me of the day I saw the shining 10 on the podium during my University's entrance ceremony all those years ago.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
"... And how in the hell would somebody pull that off?" Mr. Burke stared incredulously at the manuscript he held in his hand. He guffawed loudly and then adjusted his spectacles with a fat finger. Mr. Franklin tapped his foot, attempting to look more comfortable than he felt. He would be patient. "You say that the people will be too distracted by new technology to realize what's going on right in front of them? Who would believe such a tall tale? What about Thomas Payne? No doubt they'll have forgotten him, too. Ha!" Mr. Franklin forced himself to stop tapping his foot, though he resumed as soon as the thought left his head. Mr. Franklin, of course, had not even begun to think of opening his mouth. He had found that these little review sessions with Mr. Burke were over much faster if he kept his thoughts to himself. He jigged his leg as Mr. Burke vented his every thought into the musty air, skimming the pages of the novel he had spent nearly two years finishing. "... Though this bit here is quite amusing in a very dark sort of manner... The idea of the leaders of this country getting together and spitting on the declaration of independence... Could be controversial, could be good... Could be bad..." Mr. Burke snorted into his tea, spilling it down his tie, but read on, oblivious. Mr. Franklin thought of Mr. Burke discovering this when he went home, and cursing. The thought gave him a warm, soothing feeling deep in his stomach. For a moment, he dared interject. "They are n't literally spitting on the declaration of independence. The idea is that technology will advance very rapidly, very quickly. And how humanity deals with this new technology is paramount to our future, and ultimately our survival as a species. This book presupposes that it is used for malicious, dark purposes that benefit the few over the many, which, in turn ultimately leads to the extinction of the human race as we know it." Mr. Franklin stared in shock as something in Mr. Burke's eye must have ruptured, turning a part of the white into a deep red. Mr. Burke stared for a moment, his mouth ajar, then composed himself as much as a man like him could. He practically roared at Mr. Franklin now: "This is downright negative! You want to depress people? You think they should hole up in caves hiding because they feel too powerless to fight for their country? For the very soul of their country? This country? The day the Declaration dies is the day the United States dies! Now get out, you treasonous clout, get out. Do n't come back until you've fixed it." Mr. Burke threw down the pages and turned to the window. Mr. Franklin sighed, gathered up the scattered pages, and hurried out of the office. That night he resolved to try and be more optimistic.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
John Grady Cole attends his grandfather's funeral.
output: His mother has died, and his father is dying of cancer. John Grady decides to leave Texas and go to Mexico. He takes his horse Redbo with him. On the way, he meets Rawlins, who becomes his friend. They travel through New Mexico and Arizona before crossing the border into Mexico. There, they meet Blevins, a young boy who wants to join them. However, Blevins steals one of their horses and runs away. Later, they find him dead. They bury him and continue their journey. In Mexico, they encounter many dangers. One night, while camping near a river, they hear gunshots. When they investigate, they discover that some men have been killed. The next morning, they see a group of soldiers riding towards them. They hide behind rocks and watch as the soldiers pass by. Then, they ride off again. A few days later, they reach a small town called Ojinaga. Here, they meet Alejandra, a beautiful girl who works at a hotel. She invites them to stay there. While staying at the hotel, John Grady falls in love with her. But she does not return his feelings. Instead, she tells him that she loves another man named Eduardo. John Grady tries to forget about her, but he cannot. So, he decides to leave Mexico and return to Texas. Before leaving, he gives Alejandra a letter asking her to marry him. She refuses, saying that she already has someone else. Disappointed, John Grady leaves Mexico and returns to Texas. Back home, he learns that his father has died. He also finds out that his mother was having an affair with a Mexican rancher named Don Hector. Angry, John Grady goes to confront Don Hector. During the argument, Don Hector shoots John Grady in the chest. Dying, John Grady asks Don Hector to take care of his horse Redbo. Don Hector agrees, and John Grady dies peacefully. Afterward, Don Hector buries John Grady alongside his parents. Years later, Rawlins visits the grave site. He sees a stone marker with the names of John Grady's family members engraved upon it. Underneath those names, however, is written the name of John Grady himself. Rawlins realizes that John Grady never forgot about Alejandra. And so, he decides to visit her once more. Upon arriving at the hotel where she worked, he discovers that she still lives there. She greets him warmly, and they talk for hours. Finally, Rawlins asks her whether she ever received the letter from John Grady. To his surprise, she says yes. She shows him the letter, which reads: Dear Alejandra, I hope this letter reaches you safely. My name is John Grady Cole. I am writing to ask you to marry me. Please consider my proposal seriously. Yours truly, John Grady Cole P.S. If you accept my offer, please send word immediately. Thank you. Sincerely, John Grady Cole Rawlins smiles sadly. He knows that John Grady loved Alejandra deeply. Even after all these years, he still remembers her fondly. As he walks away from the hotel, he thinks about how lucky he was to have known such a wonderful person.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
My story started where a lot have ended these past 10 years: with a single bullet. Living in post-war Britain, death was not an uncommon sight. Everyone had at least one firearm to defend themselves, everyone had encountered gunfire in the streets, and everyone knew what it meant to live every day like it could be their last. The revolution that was supposed to end the tyranny of a dictatorship had ripped the country apart; counties had split into factions, all threatening total destruction of the others. In ten years the population was decimated, the country reduced to a crumbling mass of fallen buildings and civilians with guns. All around me was depression, death, dirt, famine. Thinking about it, it's quite hilarious, in such a depressing way. The sacks of bones, flesh and organs we saw everyday were once living, breathing, talking human beings. They had a mother, a father, a pet, a first love, they were educated, they succeeded and they failed. And they died. A single bullet can end so much. That morning, as I wandered to the local shop for some bread, clutching my rifle, my world completely ended. I had no time to react; as soon as I entered Grange Avenue a bullet burrowed into my head, smashing part of my brain, and knocking me straight out cold. I woke in a beautiful wooden chalet, bright natural light streaming through vast windows above the soft, clean bed that I rested in. My itchy, dirty clothes were replaced with beautiful white robes, soft as silk and cleaner than anything I had ever seen. I sat up, and looked around the room - it was furnished luxuriously, with beautiful gold-leaf chairs and fantastic bright works of art hanging around the room. I got up and left the room, and immediately my breath was forced from me. The crumbled grey streets of London had gone. In their place were beautiful old chalets, bright white skyscrapers, and marble streets. I could also see a very unfamiliar sight - a beautiful emerald park, littered with tall, radiant trees, ferns, and glowing coloured flowers. Clear water ran through them. All around the streets were people dressed similar to me, smiling and talking and laughing. The smog-ridden sky had been replaced with a beautiful, deep purple, but the world was light around me and the I could see the vast orange sun dipping behind the structures around the city. For the first time in ten years I smiled. That bullet took me to a better place.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
John Grady learns his mother intends to sell the family ranch.
output: He convinces his best friend Lacey Rawlins to accompany him south to Mexico, where he hopes to find work as a cowboy. On the way there, they meet Jimmy Blevins, a thirteen-year-old boy who is traveling alone. John and Lacey agree to let him travel with them until they reach a town called Encantada. There, they plan to separate ways. However, when they arrive, they discover that Blevins has stolen a horse and fled. John and Lacey decide to track down Blevins and return the horse to its owner. They eventually catch up with him, but are unable to convince him to give back the horse. Instead, they take the horse by force and leave Blevins behind. As they ride away, they hear gunshots. When they turn around, they see Blevins lying dead on the ground. They bury him and continue on their journey. Eventually, they come across a group of Mexican cowboys who offer them jobs working on a large ranch owned by Don Hector Rocha y Villareal. John and Lacey accept the job and spend several months working on the ranch. During this time, John falls in love with Alejandra, the daughter of Don Hector. One night, while riding home after a long day of work, John sees two men attacking a woman. He intervenes and kills both attackers. Later, he discovers that the woman was actually Alejandra. She thanks him for saving her life and invites him to stay at her house. Over the next few weeks, John and Alejandra grow closer. However, things change when John finds out that she is engaged to another man. Heartbroken, he decides to leave Mexico and return to Texas. Before leaving, he visits Alejandra one last time. She tells him that she loves him too, but cannot marry him because of her engagement. Devastated, John leaves Mexico and returns to Texas. Several years later, John receives word that Alejandra has married someone else. Disappointed, he decides to move on with his own life. He marries a young widow named Mary Ellen and settles down in San Angelo, Texas. Together, they raise three children. Years pass, and John becomes a successful businessman. His wife dies, and he remarries. By now, he has forgotten all about Alejandra. Then, one day, he receives a letter from her. It says that she still loves him and wants to see him again. Excited, John travels to Mexico to reunite with her. But when he arrives, he learns that she has already passed away. Grief-stricken, John returns to Texas and spends the rest of his days mourning the loss of the woman he loved.

This is late and also not exactly what you wanted. Your prompt happened to remind me of something I had thought about ages ago. The mystics observed the future of this conquest during the warp trip. Multiple light units spent weaving the spell with many more reading the fates and seeing their doom. Such is the way of our crusade. Countless planets have been dominated, countless slaves put under our command, and countless minerals stripped from their crust. Each world fought, but each was crushed as we knew how they would fight. The mystics watched the weave of fate and picked out the strand that gave us the best victory. This was meant to be another one of our empire. Another one to be crushed and stripped. Another to be enslaved and worked. For the first time in our history, perhaps since even the first time in creation, the mystics were wrong. There was supposed to be a single human. One that would lead their armies against us, Inspire them, Rally them, But ultimately, trap them. The hero was one of the twenty-five warriors who fought against us in the initial bout. We were supposed to kill the rest, capture him, implant him, and control him. He would be our puppet, leading the others to their destruction. But when the time came for us to strike, there were twenty-six warriors against us. Our army faltered. The hero we were meant to take was instead killed in our confusion. We ended up with the twenty sixth warrior: The one who the mystics did not see. We brought him to our ship and the mystics shrieked in terror. His past, his future, even his very existence, was hidden from them. In a panic, they turned their focus to the planets surface and found that there were millions like him. Millions we were blind to. They realized that the force hiding them was ancient and purposeful. This was not simply a random act of fate, nor was it an evolution of this species. Someone on this planet had once been able to touch the aether like can now. They weaved a powerful blessing and placed it on his spawn, making them hidden from other prying eyes. We had to flee. A direct conflict with this species, although would end in victory, would leave us with too many casualties. The human we took was fired back to the planet. "The world is not full of black and white, but grey." That is the quote I lived by for years. For my entire life. It makes sense, ever since I understood what the colour around everyone was. It was normal to me at first. I did n't know I was any different from anyone else. Only when I asked my parents about it did I start to understand. They mistook my curiosity to imagination, and I was fine with that. No one needed to know about what I could see. It was really useful actually. And I have used it many times, for many situations. Back to the quote. Like I said, I lived by it for years. But very recently, did I understand that there can be more colour to the world. I like that. The ideology that shades are n't the only thing a person can be, but a bright and vibrant hue. I first saw her in a fancy restaurant. She obviously did n't belong there. She wore a suit, with a blazer, and some nice dress pants. High heels that were n't really that high. And just a touch of makeup to glow a little bit. What made her not seem like she belonged there was her hair. As blue as the highlight around her self. And I could tell I was n't the only one seeing it, because everyone in the room was staring at her oddly. She left before I could say anything though, and I thought that was that. The second time I saw her was much better. It was just a normal day, I was walking to work, and I saw her. Hair so blue it almost looked black this time. But her nonetheless. I forgot about work and tried to catch up to her, only for her to get away from my grasp once again. The third time was not the charm apparently. I was at a party, and I saw her again. Of course, I thought it would be extremely easy to talk to her now. But somehow she still evaded me. It almost seemed like she could tell I was coming closer to her. Of course that was improbable. The fourth time, that was the charm. It had been years since I'd seen her, and I was n't really looking anymore, thinking that third time was the final time. But I saw her, in that same fancy restaurant I had seen her the firs time. But, instead of me approaching her, she walked straight up to me and said, "What're you having Red?" Red?

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
It had been years since Zuccotti Park was free of barbed wire. A large concrete wall surrounded the plaza, a thousand V masks for each revolutionary lost in the fighting so far. You'd mistake Lower Manhattan for Mogadishu if it were n't for the skyscrapers that watched over the fighting. The compound for the Occupy movement was never quiet, the rattle of gunfire or the occasional pained yell as another fighter was brought back from the frontlines. The fighting had become entrenched by the 5th year. For every advance made on Central Park, there were another 50 casualties. Minesweepers had a full time job of clearing paths, just to be shot by a remote gunpod, flying over the metropolitan No Man's Land. Today however seemed different, a lull had settled over the battlefield. All that could be heard was the occasional burst of gunfire or the low hum of the Emergency Broadcast System screens throughout the city. Maybe it was the reverence for the day. 10 years since the revolution began and that first tent and sign was raised in protest. The 99 % had lost many but continued to fight. The 1 % still remained strong, and today they would deliver the final blow. The view screens flickered, the hum of the screens replaced with the anthem of a broken union. The face of the enemy flashed on screen, to address his ailing public.'My fellow Americans. It has been ten years since the seeds of chaos were sown in our great nation. Radicals gathered to destroy our honourable values and throw us into pandemonium. We tried to reason with them, we tried our best to comprehend their hatred and talk them back on the righteous path. But we failed. We showed then mercy and compassion but their hatred festered. They cast the first stone, they took the first life and they continue to poison everything they touch. They have taken our monuments to our strength and our bravery, and defile them with their vile propaganda. I for one, will stand no longer.' The screen changes, showing a diagram of Lower Manhatten. A diagram of a blast zone was overlaid on the top of it.'We must cut out the cancer which has plagued our nation for too long. Mercy has failed, so we will retaliate in the only language these vermin understand. our old metropole will be cleansed and returned to its rightful owners. Justice will be swift and final. We will take back what is rightly ours. God bless America and god have mercy on their souls.'

The boys cross the Rio Grande into Mexico.
output: They are now in the land of the dead. The sun beats down on them like a hammer. Their skin burns and blisters. They walk through the desert for days without food or water. Finally, they come to a small village. The people there give them food and water. They tell the boys that they can stay with them until they find work. The boys thank the villagers and go to sleep. In the morning, they wake up to find that all of the villagers have disappeared. There is nothing left except for some empty houses and a few chickens running around. The boys decide to keep walking. They don't know where they're going, but they hope that someone will help them along the way. After several more days of walking, they reach another town. This time, the people there welcome them with open arms. They offer them jobs and places to live. The boys accept gratefully. One day, while working at his new job, one of the boys sees something strange. He tells his friend about it. His friend doesn't believe him at first, but when he looks closer, he realizes that what his friend said is true. There really is a ghost living among them! What happens next? Find out in Part Two of "Ghost Town"!

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
I have reaped the souls of many over the course of my years as death. Souls of the good, the bad, and everything between have always been sown by another before I pluck them from the Earth at their appropriate time. Even the ones that believe it is n't their time or ask for just one more opportunity to do what they wish, must be taken without question because, well, its just the way my job is. To me, it never mattered where they were at in life. I just carried them over with ease. Never once had experienced trouble in my task as I had even had to pluck sweet children from the arms of their mothers. However, it all changed when I was tasked with taking the soul of David Mckiny. I watched David from the day he entered the Earth, and never before had I seen someone as special as him. He always thought of others first, always trying to help others before even contemplating his own commodities. I approached him on the fateful day at exactly noon. He was old now, no longer in his prime as he was finally about to lose his battle with cancer. I approached him as the hourglass emptied completely to the bottom. I spoke to him," David you must know who I am at this hour." He answered not necessarily speaking to me," If only I had helped more.... If only I could have have had more time! How dreadful to go when so many more need help!" At this moment I found it immensely hard to fulfill my task. I was not met with a man begging for more time only to waste it on fruitless trivialities. I was met with a man who wanted to bring grace to more people. He wished not to make his life better, but only cares to try to improve as many others as possible. I finally brought myself to say," David you have been a good man, but death is one thing which is inevitable, and not even I can grant time when someone is due. You must come along now with me." He allowed his soul to leave his body, a tear running down his face as he did. I extended my arm to him and he obliged. If there is one final peace to the journey is the experience of seeing one's life pass by as I guide them to the next step. I saw, as we walked, countless people who David had helped, most of which he had n't known and would never see again. Every part of me wished to guide him back to his body, but I knew I had a task to fulfill, and I knew I had to complete it. After a long while of walking down the path, we finally came to the gateway where David would continue without my guidance. I never know where the person will go once they enter, but I knew David would go to a place that would have the same passion in death as he did in life. I never had such a hard time seeing someone move on, and I sat a while thinking of how tragic it is for someone like David, genuinely the best kind of person, to be taken from such a cruel world when he one of the few people who deserved to stay. Anyways I found myself contemplating to long, and I moved on to reap the rest of the souls I had to fetch that day.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
The second alarm goes off at 7 in the morning. The first, a few hours before, sharply shrilled that it was time to get up and shower. Hungover and covered with the sweat and scents of the night before, I had dragged myself through the morning routine of cleansing. There was plenty of time beneath the lukewarm stream of water to contemplate the sadness of another hangover caused by drinking alone. It'd been weeks since I last had a chance to talk to another human, instead of just the PC terminal supplied by work. I towelled off and staggered through to the living-room and slumped in front of the computer, waiting for the piercing whistle to repeat, to emanate from my phone. The second alarm marked that it was time for the Remembrance. I sigh, move the empty beer bottles away from my desk and load up Hitchens 2. Since the Bliss neurovirus was released, there was a killing to be made from this sort of software; software designed to take you through a basic test, activating every faculty you'd conceivably need to prevent the atrophy. First, colour recognition and geometric shapes. Second, basic maths ramping into some gentle algebra and trigonometry. English, ethics, road safety, compassion testing, aesthetics, philosophical contemplation, the sciences. It was a hard sell at the beginning, for companies to give their employees the few hours off each morning they needed for the state-mandated testing, but given the choice between late employees and those in conscious comas, they made the right choice. Two hours later, the general test finishes. I flick through my results, 91 % recognition of the basic concepts, not too bad after a night of hard drinking. Next would come a quick half hour personal session: the names of loved ones, relations to family members, anniversaries and birthdays. A prompt flashes on the screen: "Please enter your identity number and full name". I rattle my digits in, 12958321-A, and tab down to the field for my name. I blank. Slight panic begins to grow as I search my beer-soaked consciousness for that basic, bloody basic, detail. It'd been too long since I last had to introduce myself with anything other than my work ID number, too long since I had any reason to say those damned words out loud. Darren? No. Christopher? No, definitely not. I shout and swear and blaspheme out loud, as I slowly feel the neurovirus go to work; Purgatory, we call it, a limbo without knowledge, tied with a purging. It dissolves me gently. The panic subsides. I stare blankly at the flashing cursor, waiting for me to enter some detail or another. I'm not sure what it's asking for, but I'm sure it's not too important or I'd remember it. I sit there, staring. Just staring. I'm sure it'd come back to me eventually.

The Second Company is reduced to eighty men after heavy losses.
output: They are now under the command of Captain John Smith, who has taken over from Lieutenant Colonel George Washington. The company is ordered to march north towards Fort Duquesne, where they hope to join forces with General Braddock's army. However, they soon find themselves surrounded by hostile Indians. In desperation, they decide to make a stand against them. As the battle rages around him, Private James Cook finds himself separated from his comrades. He manages to escape into the woods, but he knows that he cannot outrun the enemy forever. Sooner or later, they will catch up with him. And when they do, he will die. But then something strange happens. Instead of being killed, he wakes up in a hospital bed. His wounds have been treated, and he feels much better than he did before. When he asks how he got here, nobody seems able to answer him. All they can tell him is that he was found unconscious near the site of the battle. Nobody knows why he survived while so many others died. Over the next few days, more survivors arrive at the hospital. Some were wounded during the fighting; others simply collapsed from exhaustion. One thing becomes clear though - none of these people remember anything about the events leading up to their arrival. It appears that everyone involved in the battle suffered amnesia. This includes both sides. Even those who fought alongside each other seem unable to recall what happened. Eventually, word reaches London. King George III orders an investigation into the matter. Investigators travel to America to interview witnesses and gather evidence. What they discover shocks even the most hardened veterans. Not only did all participants suffer memory loss, but also their bodies underwent drastic changes. Many soldiers grew taller and stronger overnight. Others developed new skills such as marksmanship or swordplay. Still others gained supernatural abilities like telekinesis or pyrokinesis. These transformations occurred regardless of whether someone had been injured or not. Furthermore, there appeared to be no rhyme nor reason behind which individuals experienced certain effects. For instance, one man might become incredibly strong whereas another could suddenly read minds. Another might turn invisible at will. Yet another may develop superhuman speed. There doesn't appear to be any pattern whatsoever. Despite this lack of consistency, however, one fact remains constant throughout: Everyone affected by the phenomenon experiences complete amnesia regarding its cause. No one remembers anything about the incident itself. Nor does anyone know exactly what triggered the transformation process. Was it something in the air? Something in the food? Or perhaps even something inside us? Whatever the case may be, the truth remains elusive. Years pass without any further progress being made toward solving the mystery. Then, unexpectedly, a breakthrough occurs. A young woman named Mary Shelley publishes her novel Frankenstein. Inspired by recent scientific discoveries, she creates a fictional character called Victor Frankenstein who brings life to dead tissue using electricity. Her book sparks widespread interest among scientists worldwide. Soon afterwards, several prominent researchers announce plans to conduct experiments similar to those described in the novel. Amongst them is Dr. Henry Jekyll, a respected physician working at St. Bartholomew's Hospital in London. Using chemicals derived from plants native to South America, he successfully reanimates a corpse. Unfortunately, things quickly go awry. Rather than creating a perfect specimen, Jekyll ends up producing a hideous monster. Horrified by his creation, he destroys it immediately. Undeterred, he continues experimenting until finally achieving success. On February 14th, 1818, he presents his findings to the Royal Society of Medicine. During his presentation, he reveals that he has managed to create two separate beings out of a single body. One possesses the physical characteristics of a normal human being; the other exhibits traits typically associated with animals. Both creatures possess intelligence far beyond that of ordinary humans. Moreover, they share memories and emotions. They think alike, act alike, and feel alike. Most importantly, they love each other unconditionally. Their bond transcends mere friendship. It borders on obsession. Indeed, they consider themselves inseparable. Together, they form a unique entity known simply as "the Creature." Although initially shocked by the revelation, the audience gradually comes to accept the existence of the Creature. After all, it isn't really alive. At least, not yet. To prove otherwise, Jekyll decides to perform another experiment. This time, he intends to bring the Creature fully to life. Once again, he fails miserably. Instead of giving birth to a beautiful child, he gives rise to a deformed abomination. Disgusted by his failure, he kills the creature once again. Determined never to repeat his mistake, he vows to keep trying. Eventually, he succeeds. By combining elements of both his previous attempts, he manages to produce a viable offspring. Unlike its predecessors, this version of the Creature looks completely natural. Its skin is smooth and flawless. Its eyes are bright and alert. Its hair is thick and lustrous. Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Void, I always felt like I understood that word. Looking back I realize I was naive, or maybe I was too full of hope. Me and Maria created the nano bots for constuction, as a way to ease the burden of building the lunar colony. She had survived the imperial invasion in the ruins of Los Angeles, she thought she could create a brighter future. Selfishness, that's what undid everything. Eventually the colonists decided they could n't abide the laws of earth. The people of earth decided they would n't abide rebels on the moon. They could n't accept those resources would be used for something other than their gain. So I reprogrammed the bots, I did n't tell her, how could I? They were meant to break things down and rebuild faults in the domes, I just allowed them to accept new targets. Of course she figured it out. With Maria gone I wanted to die, but I could n't. She dreamed of a world without conflict, where everyone had enough. I knew they would n't come willingly, so I lied. I told them I could make the bots fix the domes; that everything would be alright. Instead I joined my mind with them. At first I was in control. They tried to stop me, but the bots ate whatever they sent to harm me. I created massive pylon factories across the globe preparing for their acsension. I was lazy, a single mistake doomed everything. I set my neural pattern as the administrator. The others where sublimated within me. What else could I do, I had to quiet their voices or be driven mad. That was when the machines decided to best safeguard my well being they had to take over several key roles. What we needed most was matter, for fuel and to rebuild lost bots. We became a swarm. We devoured the earth in minutes. And so we drifted, eating always eating. We found the hive ships, sent centuries before my birth. We ate evrrything, and added the humans to the databanks. I saw nebulae beyond comprehension, their beauty cut down by their hunger. The only hope I had left was to leave beacons containing copies of my mind. Perhaps someone could find them, and destroy the swarm. We encountered aliens with fantastical technology, they attacked me with lasers that could cut through time itself. Still we fed. Stars were broken down bit by bit to fulfill our needs. Millenia passed and the feasts became further and further apart. With the lack of resources came concessions. More systems were shut down to survive. They cared only for me. It took Millenia but now only I remain the databanks purged. I remain as a single beacon, and a lone drone. It spends it's days savoring specs of matter it finds in the void. A true void of my own creation. I pray there is a god, and it can repair what I have sundered. I pray that this beacon survives and whoever manages to access it heads my warning. I know these prayers stem from desperation. At one time I spanned the entire universe. There is no God to save me. Calculations say I will subsist in this state for four thousand more years before the drone gives in, and deactivates. After that, I will shut down, eventually. I do not know how long that will take. I know that I will forget. I will forget the beauty I found and consumed. I will forget the humans that cried out in that terrible moment. I will forget her.

output: He is shot while trying to escape from a German patrol. His body is never recovered. The rest of the group are captured and taken prisoner. They are then transferred to a concentration camp, where they are forced to work as slave laborers. They are starved and abused, and many of them die. Those who survive are liberated by Allied forces at the end of the war. They return home to America, where they try to put their lives back together. But they are haunted by their experiences, and struggle to adjust to civilian life. Some of them turn to alcohol or drugs to cope with their trauma. Others become activists, fighting for justice and equality. All of them carry the scars of their ordeal, both physical and emotional. They are forever changed by what they went through, and will never be the same again.

Dave lives just south of DC and he went on vacation on Tuesday, 3 months in the Bahamas. Dave forgot to ask his neighbor to water the plant by his bed when picking up the mail and paper for him. The plant died. A crack in the wall let a snail in. Because the plant was dead, the snail ate it. Because that snail ate the plant it was n't on the sidewalk. Because it was n't on the sidewalk, Jim the mailman did n't stop to look at the snail. Because Jim did n't stop to look at the snail, Jim was hit by a car while on his bicycle and died. Because Jim died in a car accident, 1st street was blocked for an hour. Because 1st street was blocked in an hour, Nancy was late to work at the coffee shop. Because Nancy was late to work at the coffee shop, the coffee shop rushed all its orders. Because the coffee shop rushed all its orders, Larry got his boss decaf. Because Larry got his boss decaf, his boss fell asleep in the meeting. Because Larry's boss fell asleep in the meeting, Larry's boss was fired. Because Larry's boss was fired, he threw all the papers out the window in the road. Because all the papers were in the road, Trever the ambassador was stuck in traffic. Because Trever was stuck in traffic, he was angry. Because Trever was angry, he lost his cool in a meeting with his Russian counterpart. Because Trever lost his cool, Trever was fired. Because Trever was fired, his assistant Lewis took over the negotiations. Because Lewis took over the negotiations, the trade deal fell through. Because the trade deal fell through, the Russian economy weakened. Because the Russian economy weakened, Russia tried to drill for oil in the north Baltic. Because Russia tried to drill for oil in the North Baltic, Lewis was dispatched to Moscow. Because Lewis was dispatched to Moscow, he was robbed and killed by a mugger at a train station. Because Lewis died in Moscow, America launched sanctions against Russia. Because America launched sanctions against Russia, the Russian economy collapsed. Because the Russian economy collapsed, Russia was unable to loan money to China. Because China could n't get a desperately needed loan from Russia, it turned to India. Because China got a loan from India, it had to launch severe sanctions against Pakistan. Because China launched sanctions against Pakistan, Pakistan recognized Taiwan. Because Pakistan recognized Taiwan, China cut off all relations to Pakistan. Because China cut off all relations to Pakistan, Pakistan invaded India. Because Pakistan invaded India, China invaded Pakistan. Because China invaded Pakistan, the US sold weapons to Pakistan. Because the US sold weapons to Pakistan, China launched sanctions against the US. Because China launched sanctions against the US, all major Chinese trading partners did as well. Because the US was isolated from trade, it declared war on China. Because the US declared war on China, Dave watches the news as his home is bombed to rubble. Nice job Dave.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Franz Kemmerich undergoes a leg amputation and faces death.
output: Paul Baumer visits Franz in the hospital and finds him in great pain. He tells Paul that he does not want to die. Paul comforts him and promises to return later. When Paul returns, Franz has already died. Paul feels guilty because he believes that he should have stayed with Franz longer. He also feels sad because he knows that Franz would never see his family again. Paul decides to write a letter to Franz' mother telling her how much he loved her son. However, before he can finish writing the letter, he receives word that another soldier has been wounded. Paul rushes back to the front lines where he sees many more soldiers dying. He realizes that there is nothing he can do to help them. As he walks away from the battlefield, he hears someone calling his name. It turns out to be Katczinsky who asks him if he wants to join him in going home. Paul agrees and they walk together towards the town. On their way, they meet some other soldiers who tell them that the war is almost over. They decide to go back to the trenches instead. Once they arrive at the trench, they find that most of the men are dead. Only two remain alive: Albert Kropp and Tjaden. Both of these men are severely injured. Paul helps carry both of them into the dugout. Inside, he finds several letters written by Franz. One of those letters contains a poem which Paul reads aloud. In this poem, Franz expresses his love for his mother and father. After reading the poem, Paul cries uncontrollably. Later, he writes a second letter to Franz' parents explaining what happened to their son. This time, however, he includes a copy of the poem. The next day, Paul goes to visit Franz' grave. While standing near the tombstone, he notices something strange. There is a small hole in the ground right next to the headstone. Curious, Paul digs around until he uncovers a box containing a photograph of Franz holding hands with his girlfriend. Shocked, Paul takes the picture and runs off. Back at camp, Paul shows the photo to everyone else. Everyone is shocked except for one person - Katczinsky. He explains that he found the photo while digging graves. Apparently, Franz had hidden the photo inside the coffin so that no one could take it away from him. Now, Paul understands why Franz wanted to keep the photo safe. He also understands why Franz wrote such beautiful poems. Finally, Paul makes peace with himself and accepts his fate. He knows that he cannot change anything now. All he can do is try to make sure that others don't suffer like he did. So, he starts teaching young boys about life after death. And eventually, he becomes a teacher himself.

Picture the Earth. I'll try to guess what you're seeing. A stunning blue sphere, with splotches of green and white covering its surface. A dot contrasted against the vast dark expanse of space. Twisting and turning around the sun, the moon its closest companion, shining brightly by the planet's side. Truly a sight to behold. But I wanted to see it for myself. I sent up a rocket to orbit the Earth, its only purpose to take photos of this beautiful planet. And as I thought they would be, the pictures were marvelous, a true reflection of the beauty of nature. Yet instead of awe, my mouth was open in shock. The image you have in your head is wrong. I saw the oceans, blue as ever and the continents floating on top. I saw the clouds, seemingly painted onto the surface. And if I squinted, I saw the mountain ranges, the seas, the islands, all humanity's residence. And yet, something was wrong. I did n't see the round sphere I expected to see. Instead I saw a planet, so familiar, yet so distant. I saw a flat Earth. I stared at the photos with a blank look on my face. How could this be real? The shape of the Earth is a scientific fact that we've known for centuries, and yet I held in my hands the evidence that changes all that. Have we been wrong this whole time? I sat down and tried to comprehend it all. I was in denial. I checked to see if somehow, there was something wrong with the picture, perhaps the computer had gotten the data wrong, perhaps it was sending faulty messages, perhaps someone was just messing with me. I held on to the tiny sliver of hope that I was wrong, that this was all just a big misunderstanding. But alas, I was right. Though the possibility that perhaps something was wrong lingered in the back of my mind, I knew that it was true. I stared up at the night sky, looking at the stars. Humans are very stubborn creatures. We refuse to believe we are ever wrong and when we do, we admit it with a sigh of disappointment instead of a smile, knowing that we've learned something new. We take it as a personal insult to our intelligence if we're wrong, thinking'we should've known." Thinking we're right is more important than being right. But I am a logical, rational human being. I ca n't let my emotions overcome me. Knowing the truth is infinitely more important than being right. And yet I find myself so hesitant to admit the mistakes of my predecessors. To admit that we will have to re-learn everything about the Earth. To admit that we will have to start again. To admit that humans are mere mortals. The thing about facts is that they're true whether you believe in them or not. But I can change that. I grabbed my lighter and lit the photos. I watched them burn up until they had turned into ash. And I went to sleep, happy.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
The soldiers experience brutal basic training under Corporal Himmelstoss.
output: Paul Baumer and his friends have trouble with a drill sergeant named Corporal Himmelstoss, who picks on Paul and his friends due to their "special treatment." When he is finally made to run extra tours after his hours of guard duty, the other soldiers perceive their chance to get revenge and lure him across to their barracks, where they beat him up. They are caught and given light punishments. Paul feels betrayed for days after, but gradually returns to normal. He begins to feel the war has removed all feelings from him; he is simply a soldier now, expecting that almost everyone he knows will be killed. He says, "I am young, I am twenty years old; yet I know nothing of life but despair, death, fear, and fatuous superficiality cast over an abyss of sorrow. I see how peoples are set against one another, and in silence, unknowingly, foolishly, obediently, innocently slay one another."

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
You know those nightmares you had as a child, where you'd be somewhere familiar yet completely alien? As though your home had suddenly become some faraway land, and your only goal was to return home. Well in 2014, that's exactly what happened to everyone in the world. I was on my way to an important business meeting, off to discuss some law, and how my company could avoid it, when it all happened. I checked my watch to see the time, and as I looked up, I saw a blinding flash off in the distance, lighting up the once blue sky in streaks of white. Next, it was followed by an eardrum shattering bang, like a hundred thousand gunshots going off at once. Then, finally, the blast. A wall of rock, stone, dirt and trash and flew towards me, silhouetted by the strange white light. I turned to run, but like a wave washing over the ocean, anything in the path of that wall was thrown like a ragdoll. The last thing I remember was being thrown what felt like miles into the air, and rushing down back into that swirling vortex of light. When I woke, it was night time. Others seemed to be sitting up around me, and the confused look on the faces that surrounded me seemed to speak louder than words that this was not a normal occurrence. I checked my watch, and had a terrible realisation. It was 3 am, and I was ridiculously late for my meeting! I tried to get to my feet, but the second I tried to stand, my legs gave way underneath me. What the hell was going on? After a few minutes I had enough strength to drag myself up by a nearby stair railing. For the first time since waking, I looked around. Something was wrong. As I looked, I saw the once manicured strips of grass and trees had overgrown to ridiculous proportions, and the streets were covered in trash, empty food packages, and bones. Wait what the hell? Upon further inspection, I saw they were human. Jesus Christ, what the hell happened. It was then that I checked my watch again. A neat little feature it had was that it told the time in seconds, minutes, hours, days and years. The blood drained from my face as I saw what I'd missed earlier. 3:04 am. Friday. 13th of June. 2015. As I wondered what the hell was going on, something rustled through the bushes behind me. Something big. As I saw glowing red eyes light the way. Then was the first time I wondered, what left those bones?

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Clyde Griffiths is born into a poor family of evangelists.
output: He grows up with his parents traveling across the country preaching the gospel. Clyde has a natural talent for singing and playing the piano, which he uses to help support his family. However, he also develops a taste for the finer things in life, and begins to resent his humble upbringing. One day, while working as a bellhop at a hotel, Clyde meets Sondra Finchley, a wealthy socialite who takes an interest in him. She introduces him to her circle of friends, and soon Clyde finds himself living a life of luxury. But his new lifestyle comes at a price. Clyde becomes increasingly obsessed with Sondra, and when she rejects his advances, he snaps. In a fit of rage, he kills her and then tries to cover up the crime. But his guilt eventually catches up with him, and he is arrested and put on trial. Despite the evidence against him, Clyde maintains his innocence throughout the trial. But in the end, he is found guilty and sentenced to death. On the day of his execution, Clyde reflects on his life and realizes that he has wasted it chasing after material possessions. He dies regretting the choices he made, and wishing he had lived a simpler life.

It had been years since Zuccotti Park was free of barbed wire. A large concrete wall surrounded the plaza, a thousand V masks for each revolutionary lost in the fighting so far. You'd mistake Lower Manhattan for Mogadishu if it were n't for the skyscrapers that watched over the fighting. The compound for the Occupy movement was never quiet, the rattle of gunfire or the occasional pained yell as another fighter was brought back from the frontlines. The fighting had become entrenched by the 5th year. For every advance made on Central Park, there were another 50 casualties. Minesweepers had a full time job of clearing paths, just to be shot by a remote gunpod, flying over the metropolitan No Man's Land. Today however seemed different, a lull had settled over the battlefield. All that could be heard was the occasional burst of gunfire or the low hum of the Emergency Broadcast System screens throughout the city. Maybe it was the reverence for the day. 10 years since the revolution began and that first tent and sign was raised in protest. The 99 % had lost many but continued to fight. The 1 % still remained strong, and today they would deliver the final blow. The view screens flickered, the hum of the screens replaced with the anthem of a broken union. The face of the enemy flashed on screen, to address his ailing public.'My fellow Americans. It has been ten years since the seeds of chaos were sown in our great nation. Radicals gathered to destroy our honourable values and throw us into pandemonium. We tried to reason with them, we tried our best to comprehend their hatred and talk them back on the righteous path. But we failed. We showed then mercy and compassion but their hatred festered. They cast the first stone, they took the first life and they continue to poison everything they touch. They have taken our monuments to our strength and our bravery, and defile them with their vile propaganda. I for one, will stand no longer.' The screen changes, showing a diagram of Lower Manhatten. A diagram of a blast zone was overlaid on the top of it.'We must cut out the cancer which has plagued our nation for too long. Mercy has failed, so we will retaliate in the only language these vermin understand. our old metropole will be cleansed and returned to its rightful owners. Justice will be swift and final. We will take back what is rightly ours. God bless America and god have mercy on their souls.'
