Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Clyde takes a job as a bellhop in Kansas City.
output: He meets Bonnie, who is working at a diner. Clyde falls in love with her and asks her to marry him. She says yes, but she wants to wait until after the war. Clyde goes off to fight in World War II. When he comes home, he finds out that Bonnie has married someone else. Clyde gets drunk and starts shooting up the town. He kills several people before being arrested. Clyde is sentenced to death by hanging. On the night before his execution, Clyde escapes from prison. He steals a car and drives to Texas. He robs a bank and kidnaps a woman named Mary. Clyde forces Mary to drive him across the state line into Oklahoma. They stop at a gas station where Clyde buys some food and drinks. While they are eating, two men walk into the store. One of them pulls out a gun and points it at Clyde. Clyde shoots both men dead. Then he runs outside and jumps into the car. He speeds away from the scene of the crime. Later that day, Clyde stops at another gas station. This time, he sees a police officer sitting inside the building. Clyde walks over to the window and looks through the glass. The cop notices him and draws his weapon. Clyde raises his hands above his head and surrenders. The next morning, Clyde wakes up in jail. His trial begins soon afterwards. During the proceedings, Clyde confesses to all of his crimes. However, he claims that he did not kill anyone during the robbery. Instead, he says that he accidentally shot himself while trying to escape. The jury believes him and acquits him of murder. After serving five years in prison, Clyde returns to Kansas City. There, he meets up with Bonnie again. They decide to get married right away. Their wedding ceremony takes place in a church near the Missouri River. As they exchange vows, Clyde suddenly remembers something important. He tells Bonnie that he needs to go back to Texas immediately. He explains that he left behind a valuable item when he escaped from prison. Bonnie agrees to help him retrieve it. Together, they travel to Dallas. Once there, they break into a warehouse owned by a man named Frank Hamer. Inside, they find a safe containing $100,000 worth of stolen money. Clyde opens the safe and takes the cash. He also grabs a pistol hidden underneath the mattress. Before leaving, Clyde writes a note saying that he stole the money because he needed it to pay off his debts. He signs the letter "Bonnie & Clyde." Then he leaves the warehouse. Back in Kansas City, Clyde gives the money to Bonnie. She uses part of it to buy a new house. With the rest, she pays off her husband's gambling debt. In return, Clyde promises to stay out of trouble. Unfortunately, things don't work out quite like that. Soon after moving into their new home, Clyde starts drinking heavily again. Eventually, he becomes addicted to alcohol. One night, he gets into a fight with a neighbor. The argument escalates quickly and ends with Clyde pulling out his gun. He fires several shots at the other guy, killing him instantly. Afterwards, Clyde flees the area. He spends the next few months hiding out in various places around the country. Finally, he decides to turn himself in. He turns himself in to the FBI office in St. Louis. Agents arrest him without incident. At his arraignment hearing, Clyde pleads guilty to manslaughter. He receives a sentence of twenty-five years in prison. While incarcerated, Clyde learns how to read and write. He even earns a high school diploma. By the end of his term, he has become a model prisoner. Upon release, Clyde moves back to Kansas City. He works odd jobs here and there until he finally lands a steady job as a janitor at a local hospital. Over time, Clyde develops a close friendship with one of the nurses. Her name is Rosemary. She helps him adjust to life on the outside. Eventually, Clyde proposes marriage to Rosemary. She accepts his proposal and they plan to wed within the month. On the big day, Clyde arrives early at the chapel. He waits patiently for Rosemary to arrive. When she does, he greets her warmly. They walk down the aisle together hand-in-hand. After exchanging rings, they kiss passionately. Then they leave the chapel arm-in-arm. Outside, Clyde spots a group of reporters waiting for them. He waves goodbye to Rosemary and heads towards the crowd. Suddenly, a loud explosion rocks the ground beneath his feet. A huge fireball erupts from the sky. Debris rains down everywhere. People scream and run for cover. Clyde looks up just in time to see a plane crashing directly overhead. It hits the ground hard, sending pieces of metal flying in every direction. Clyde ducks behind a nearby tree. He watches as the wreckage burns brightly against the darkening sky. Slowly, he realizes what happened. Someone set off a bomb inside the airplane. And now everyone involved is dead. Including Clyde.

Grandfather was the only one without powers in the family, and he was one of the few who have lived in the Before and survived. Before genes started mutating, before people received powers, before the world as he knew it ended. Things are different in the Today. We learnt it all during history in school. Mr T. brought us back to the Before and we had watched the wars, the starvation, the shootings, the massacres. Every child Today knows the story, because as some wise man in the Before had said, those who can not learn from history, are doomed to repeat it. And we don' t want that. We are lucky that the wars have ended as quickly as they begun. The Normals, like my grandfather, who were trying to kill those with powers were quickly put down by us. When my second cousin Sophia received her ability to bend the wills of others, grandfather had been most displeased. After all, it was one of the powers most feared back in the Before. Those with this ability were the ones who dominated and the wars had come. Countries fighting for dominance, millionaires waking up to find that they have signed away their fortune, men and women everywhere woke up to find that they have been doing things that they never would. It was then when the true Wars begun. Things are better Today though, people like Sophia are being kept safe. I haven' t seen her since she registered her powers two hours after she turned sixteen. Joshua, my older brother, had the ability to turn into a guinea pig. Grandfather was highly amused. It seemed though, that abilities are not hereditary. Father is a genius with technology while mother can heal with just a touch. I turn sixteen in a little less than two hours and I can' t wait to find out what my power is. It was the Law to register your abilities no more than two hours after you receive it. If you don' t, well, if you don' t, you might cease to exist. That was what we have been taught since those carefree days in preschool. They will hunt you down no matter how you try to hide. Uncle Kevin tried to hide Cousin Kingsley when they realized he could make people disappear. Well, they made Cousin Kingsley disappear. I just came into my powers. Mother just made the most horrible sound, a hoarse, gutteral scream when I brushed by her in the cramped kitchen. She is still writhing on the ground, albeit silent. It seems, that I can cause pain to whomever I touch. I think They might try to make me disappear too. Oh dear. She isn' t moving anymore.

Clyde also finds out that John's wife died while giving birth to their son, which caused him great grief. After hearing this story, Clyde decides to help John escape from prison so they can start anew together. However, things do not go according to plan...

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
It got easier with time. Every aspect of it did: the choosing, the execution, the guilt, all passed quicker and with less resistance than the year before. Especially the choosing. When you live for hundreds of years, you learn to spot the evil as easily as anyone else can spot a grotesque scar marring a person's face. I notice every time a child glances fearfully at her father, and I know what it means. When a man ca n't look his wife in the eye, I know what it is she's done. When a stranger holds his stare just a little too long at a passing woman, I know his plans. These clues, invisible to most, have made my job so much easier. The first time, it was hard. I was unsure, I hesitated. I remember it well, even if most others have faded into each other in my memory. The year was 1692, and I had spent the first eleven months following around a man who had killed and tortured people to further himself, and he showed no remorse for it. But I was young, just twenty-five, and I still clung to my morals of "only god may judge.". I watched him sleep for just a minute too long and I lost my nerve. As I turned around to leave, something hard caught me on the back of the head, and the dim candle light faded away, my thoughts disappearing with it. I woke with a start and tried to draw a breath, but my lungs were met with an ice cold burn that gave me no air. Everything around me felt heavy, and I struggled to open my eyes. With terror, I realized I was under water. I may have been immortal, but I was not immune to the pain of drowning. I tried to reach out, to swim away, but a cloth surrounded me. I struggled to pull out my knife, trying not to gasp in any more water to feed the fire engulfing my lungs. After what seemed like hours, I managed to slice through the sack that held me at the bottom, and I kicked my numbed legs as hard as I could. The sunlight was blinding when I finally broke the surface and pulled myself to shore, sputtering out the ice cold water and collapsing on the frozen ground. I sat there shivering, waiting for the the sun to come warm me, or the burning in my lungs to subside, but neither did. I stood up and took in my surroundings, I had been at the bottom of the man's lake, and his manor, filled with his ill gotten wealth, sat before me. I knew I could play no games this time. I walked the grand steps to the front door and began pounding, my clothes showering the ground with shards of ice. The servant who opened the door was speechless at my appearance, he knew me for what I was and had no intention of interfering. I strode past him and down a long corridor towards the man's chambers, my knife gripped in my still frozen hand. God would not have given me this power if he did n't want me to use it. I would not count on surprises today, he would face the death he deserved.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Fleeing the accident, Clyde moves to another city.
output: He finds work as a janitor at a local high school. One day, while cleaning the gymnasium, he hears a loud crash coming from one of the classrooms. Rushing over, he sees a group of students huddled around a broken window. They tell him that they saw a man running away from the scene. Clyde recognizes the description of the man as being similar to the one who caused the car accident. He decides to investigate further. He follows the trail of footprints left by the suspect until he reaches a nearby park. There, he discovers a body lying motionless on the ground. It turns out to be the same man who ran away from the classroom. Clyde realizes that he has stumbled upon a murder mystery. Determined to solve the case, he begins interviewing witnesses and gathering evidence. Eventually, he uncovers a shocking truth: the victim was actually a serial killer responsible for several unsolved murders. Clyde also learns that the killer had been targeting young women in their early twenties. This revelation sends chills down his spine. He wonders whether he might have prevented these crimes if he had acted sooner. In the end, Clyde manages to bring the murderer to justice. However, he remains haunted by the knowledge that he could have saved many lives if he had intervened earlier. The experience leaves him feeling guilty and ashamed. Despite this, he continues working as a janitor at the high school. Over time, he becomes close friends with some of the teachers and staff members. Together, they form a support network that helps him cope with his trauma. Through them, he gains new insights into life and love. And although he never fully recovers from the tragedy, he does manage to find happiness again.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
The second alarm goes off at 7 in the morning. The first, a few hours before, sharply shrilled that it was time to get up and shower. Hungover and covered with the sweat and scents of the night before, I had dragged myself through the morning routine of cleansing. There was plenty of time beneath the lukewarm stream of water to contemplate the sadness of another hangover caused by drinking alone. It'd been weeks since I last had a chance to talk to another human, instead of just the PC terminal supplied by work. I towelled off and staggered through to the living-room and slumped in front of the computer, waiting for the piercing whistle to repeat, to emanate from my phone. The second alarm marked that it was time for the Remembrance. I sigh, move the empty beer bottles away from my desk and load up Hitchens 2. Since the Bliss neurovirus was released, there was a killing to be made from this sort of software; software designed to take you through a basic test, activating every faculty you'd conceivably need to prevent the atrophy. First, colour recognition and geometric shapes. Second, basic maths ramping into some gentle algebra and trigonometry. English, ethics, road safety, compassion testing, aesthetics, philosophical contemplation, the sciences. It was a hard sell at the beginning, for companies to give their employees the few hours off each morning they needed for the state-mandated testing, but given the choice between late employees and those in conscious comas, they made the right choice. Two hours later, the general test finishes. I flick through my results, 91 % recognition of the basic concepts, not too bad after a night of hard drinking. Next would come a quick half hour personal session: the names of loved ones, relations to family members, anniversaries and birthdays. A prompt flashes on the screen: "Please enter your identity number and full name". I rattle my digits in, 12958321-A, and tab down to the field for my name. I blank. Slight panic begins to grow as I search my beer-soaked consciousness for that basic, bloody basic, detail. It'd been too long since I last had to introduce myself with anything other than my work ID number, too long since I had any reason to say those damned words out loud. Darren? No. Christopher? No, definitely not. I shout and swear and blaspheme out loud, as I slowly feel the neurovirus go to work; Purgatory, we call it, a limbo without knowledge, tied with a purging. It dissolves me gently. The panic subsides. I stare blankly at the flashing cursor, waiting for me to enter some detail or another. I'm not sure what it's asking for, but I'm sure it's not too important or I'd remember it. I sit there, staring. Just staring. I'm sure it'd come back to me eventually.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Clyde finds work in his wealthy uncle's shirt factory in Lycurgus, New York.
output: He is promoted to foreman and falls in love with Roberta Alden, who works at the factory. Clyde's cousin Gilbert Griffiths, son of Samuel Griffiths, takes a strong dislike to him because he disapproves of his affair with Roberta. When Roberta announces her pregnancy, Clyde feels trapped. He confides in a wealthy socialite named Sondra Finchley, whom he has met through his relatives. Desperate to avoid the consequences of his relationship with Roberta, Clyde decides to drown her while they are boating, even though he also loves her. His plan goes awry, however, and she drowns accidentally when he tries to save himself. Clyde is arrested and put on trial, where he is found guilty and sentenced to death. The novel ends with Clyde being executed by electric chair.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
You know those nightmares you had as a child, where you'd be somewhere familiar yet completely alien? As though your home had suddenly become some faraway land, and your only goal was to return home. Well in 2014, that's exactly what happened to everyone in the world. I was on my way to an important business meeting, off to discuss some law, and how my company could avoid it, when it all happened. I checked my watch to see the time, and as I looked up, I saw a blinding flash off in the distance, lighting up the once blue sky in streaks of white. Next, it was followed by an eardrum shattering bang, like a hundred thousand gunshots going off at once. Then, finally, the blast. A wall of rock, stone, dirt and trash and flew towards me, silhouetted by the strange white light. I turned to run, but like a wave washing over the ocean, anything in the path of that wall was thrown like a ragdoll. The last thing I remember was being thrown what felt like miles into the air, and rushing down back into that swirling vortex of light. When I woke, it was night time. Others seemed to be sitting up around me, and the confused look on the faces that surrounded me seemed to speak louder than words that this was not a normal occurrence. I checked my watch, and had a terrible realisation. It was 3 am, and I was ridiculously late for my meeting! I tried to get to my feet, but the second I tried to stand, my legs gave way underneath me. What the hell was going on? After a few minutes I had enough strength to drag myself up by a nearby stair railing. For the first time since waking, I looked around. Something was wrong. As I looked, I saw the once manicured strips of grass and trees had overgrown to ridiculous proportions, and the streets were covered in trash, empty food packages, and bones. Wait what the hell? Upon further inspection, I saw they were human. Jesus Christ, what the hell happened. It was then that I checked my watch again. A neat little feature it had was that it told the time in seconds, minutes, hours, days and years. The blood drained from my face as I saw what I'd missed earlier. 3:04 am. Friday. 13th of June. 2015. As I wondered what the hell was going on, something rustled through the bushes behind me. Something big. As I saw glowing red eyes light the way. Then was the first time I wondered, what left those bones?

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Old Major shares his dream of animal freedom.
output: He tells them that humans are their enemies and that animals must work together to overthrow them. Old Major dies three nights later, but two pigs named Snowball and Napoleon take up his cause. They teach the other animals a song called "Beasts of England," which gives the oppressed animals hope for Animal Farm. Soon after, Mr. Jones goes on a drinking binge and neglects the animals. One day, the cows break loose and are shot at by Mr. Jones; he hits many of them before they manage to knock him down. The next morning, Mr. Jones forgets to feed the animals again. The cows break into the storehouse, and the animals help themselves. When Mr. Jones comes to investigate, the animals drive him away, and he locks himself in his house. The animals celebrate their victory and explore the farmhouse, where they find weapons that they agree should be kept out of use. They also find whiskey, which they pour away. The pigs, who are more intelligent than the other farm animals, become the leaders. Snowball and Napoleon lead a group of pigs to the harness-room, where the instruments of torture are kept. They throw everything out except for a dog-whip, which they keep as a symbol of their authority. The pigs also discover a set of Seven Commandments that they believe will guide them in creating a perfect society. These commandments include "No animal shall kill any other animal" and "All animals are equal." The pigs rename Manor Farm "Animal Farm" and paint the Seven Commandments on the barn wall. The animals work hard to make sure that the farm is successful. They even learn to read and write so that they can communicate with each other better. However, there is tension between Snowball and Napoleon. Snowball wants to build a windmill to generate electricity, while Napoleon believes that the animals should focus on increasing food production. The two pigs argue constantly until one day, Napoleon has his dogs chase Snowball off the farm. With Snowball gone, Napoleon becomes the sole leader of Animal Farm. He changes the name of the farm back to Manor Farm and begins to implement his own ideas. He abolishes the Sunday meetings and replaces them with daily assemblies led by himself. He also starts to wear clothes and sleep in a bed, things that Old Major had said were forbidden. The animals are initially happy with these changes because they think that life will be easier under Napoleon's leadership. However, they soon realize that things are actually worse than they were before. The pigs start to live luxurious lives while the rest of the animals have to work harder than ever. The pigs also change the Seven Commandments so that they benefit themselves instead of all animals equally. Eventually, the animals rebel against Napoleon and his regime. They storm the farmhouse and force him to flee. The pigs then rewrite history so that it appears as if Snowball was always the enemy and Napoleon was always the hero. In reality, both pigs were power-hungry dictators who cared more about themselves than anyone else.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
The animals rebel and take over the farm.
output: They are led by a pig named Napoleon who becomes the leader of the new government. The other pigs follow him because they think he is smart and strong. However, after a while, they realize that he isn't very good at running things. So they decide to get rid of him. One day, when Napoleon goes out to check on the crops, he sees something strange. There is a big hole in the ground where there used to be a field. And inside the hole, there is a giant robot! It looks like a cross between a tractor and a tank. It has four legs and two arms. Its head is shaped like a pig's snout. And it has a mouth full of sharp teeth. The robot starts walking towards the barn. Then it stops and turns around. It points its gun at the barn door. Suddenly, the door opens and a bunch of cows come rushing out. They run straight into the robot. The robot shoots them all dead. Then it walks back to the hole and disappears underground. A few minutes later, another robot comes out of the hole. This one is even bigger than the first one. It has six legs and eight arms. It also has a tail. It runs over to the barn and starts shooting at the cows again. But this time, the cows don't die. Instead, they turn into zombies! They attack the robot and try to eat it alive. But the robot fights back. It uses its claws to rip off their heads. Then it eats them whole. After eating enough zombie cows, the robot gets tired. It falls asleep right next to the barn. Meanwhile, the rest of the animals are still trying to figure out what happened. Some of them think that the robots were sent by humans to kill them. Others believe that the robots were created by aliens. Still others say that the robots were built by scientists who wanted to create super soldiers. Whatever the case may be, the animals agree that they need to find a way to stop these robots before they destroy everything. So they form a plan. First, they dig a tunnel underneath the barn. Next, they build a trapdoor above the tunnel. Finally, they wait for the robots to fall asleep. Once the robots are asleep, the animals sneak down the tunnel and open the trapdoor. Then they jump onto the robots and start biting them. The robots wake up and fight back. But the animals keep attacking until the robots collapse. Then the animals drag the robots away from the barn and bury them deep underground. Now the animals have won the war against the robots. But they know that the battle isn't over yet. Because there are still many more robots hiding somewhere else. And those robots might come back someday. So the animals continue to prepare themselves for future battles. They train hard every day so that they'll be ready when the next wave of robots arrives. And they hope that someday, they will finally defeat the robots once and for all.

The shrill whistle blew and everyone around me started to board the train, I walked in with them, shuffling my feet and quickly finding a seat not next to anyone. I take a quick scan of the train, watching the stream of grey individuals start to fill the empty spaces and I smile pleasantly as a man sits next to me. He smiles back, but a little uncertain, he takes another look at my direction and says "dude, why is your shirt bright, and I mean bright, pink". Looking down at my grey shirt I sigh, I asked the lady at the store where I bought it, if it looked nice on me and was n't too bright. I'm sure it wo n't be the last joke someone will play on me. Indulging the stranger I quickly explain that my life is devoid of colour and to me everything looks grey. He frowns at my answer, "are n't you really sad? it's depressing to have everything grey" "I do n't think so" I respond, "I've been this way my whole life, to me, it's normal. Hours pass and it's finally lunch time, I'm sitting in my usual cafe eating my usual sandwich when she walks in. My eye's are drawn to this beautiful women, she stands out from everyone, because she is not grey. I do n't know how to calm my mind, her dress is so bright it almost hurt's, her hair is darker then the dress but still far richer then anything that surrounds her. She looks at me and smiles, her teeth blind and her eye's are like bright spears that impale my soul. I heard the cashier make a off hand remark about her new green dress and I almost lose it. How can she be so calm and casual when talking about this colour green, her dress lights up my whole world and I felt a tear roll down my cheek. I know I ca n't wait, I ca n't live without this women, I need her colour. Getting up I make my way over, "excuse me, miss, you are the most beautiful women in the whole world, nothing I have ever seen is close to what you are to me" She smiles, but it does n't reach her eye's and my heart sinks. She makes some comment about her being flattered but she is already taken, grabs her coffee and goes. I'm now traveling home, and I watch the grey world pass by the window, I watch the blur of grey become one band of colour until I refocus my eye's. I walk home and enter my grey house and lay on my grey bed and all I can think of is that girl, who is she, where does she go, how can I get close to her, how can I keep her around me forever. Because I know now, I know now I'm sad.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
The farm is renamed Animal Farm.
output: The animals work hard to complete the harvest and build the windmill. Snowball teaches himself to read and write from an old spelling book. Napoleon enlists the help of the sheep to exploit the windmill for his own benefit. The animals continue to work hard through the winter. Food is scarce, but nobody starves. After building the first storey of the windmill, a storm destroys it. The animals blame Snowball, who has fled the farm after arguing with Napoleon. Squealer tells the animals that Snowball was a traitor and a criminal. Boxer continues to work harder than any other animal on the farm. Four young pigs protest when Napoleon takes their milk and apples for himself, but they are defeated by his nine attack dogs. The animals learn a new song called 'Beasts of England', which stirs revolutionary feelings among them. Mr Jones tries to recapture the farm, but the animals defeat him again. They rename the farm Manor Farm. Napoleon begins trading with neighbouring farms and wearing a black top hat. He also hires a solicitor named Mr Whymper to represent him. The animals continue to work hard, but conditions gradually worsen. The pigs move into the farmhouse and sleep in beds. Squealer justifies every action Napoleon takes, distorting the truth with clever language to make the animals believe it. Eventually, the pigs begin walking upright and carrying whips, and they change the commandments to fit their behaviour—replacing "All Animals Are Equal" with "All Animals Are Equal / But Some Are More Equal Than Others." Years pass and more animals are born. Most of them don't remember the Rebellion. Many of the old animals die. The farm prospers and the windmill is rebuilt. One day, Clover sees four sows being whipped and remembers that the pigs had forbidden this. She confides in Muriel, who reads her the Seven Commandments and finds that the Sixth Commandment now reads "No animal shall kill any other animal without cause." Clover also notices that the wall bears a list of different kinds of food that the pigs alone may eat. The next morning, Clover discovers that the Seventh Commandment, "All animals are equal," has been changed to "All animals are equal, but some are more equal than others."

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
For more than thirty years, I lived my life day by day, awaiting that fateful day when I would be granted my own inner power. I saw my friends, family, strangers, all given the most precious thing in life. Lucy, my sweet dear sister, was able to fly to the heavens and back. Richard, my childhood best friend, saved hundreds of lives throughout his life, having the strength of ten men. And there I waited, for years, until my life could start, and I would transform into the real me... the powerful me. Yet, with each passing day, more people would discover their power, and I would sit waiting at night, forcing myself to sleep. My dreams were filled with possibilities, of flight and strength, and of mind and hope. But as the years passed, my dreams were less vivid. Not everyone is lucky enough to have their inner power. Some die before that beautiful gift is bestowed unto them. I thought that may happen to me. And I lived life for a while, depressed and alone. That was until I met her. Her name was Alison. She had a power, but chose not use it. She did not want to be defined by her single ability. We met during one of my travels, when I was touring the country trying to find meaning in life. I found it. I found her. From that point on, my life started. I did not care about being granted a special ability as much as I cared for her. I saw my future, a family, a wife, children. We created a beautiful life together. Alison passed away a few years ago. I had only asked her once what her power was, and she had told me it did not matter. As she was lying on her bed, slowly fading away, she told me what her inner power was. She said she was born with her power, that she had the ability to live forever, as long as she did not love. "My power was a curse, until I found you", she told me before she passed. Today is my 70th birthday. Today I have discovered what my power is. Old age has not been kind on me, and this is the most beautiful power I could have hoped for. When I remember my wife, the times we spent, they are not just memories any longer. I can feel the brisk of the air on the hill where we first met. I can smell the flowers. I can here her giggle, her breath against my cheek. In the little time I have left on this planet, I experience her love all over again.

output: The animals work hard to build the windmill, which is completed after two years. Napoleon becomes increasingly paranoid and begins to purge the farm of anyone he suspects of disloyalty. Napoleon then announces that the windmill will be used to generate electricity, which will make the animals' lives easier. However, the windmill is destroyed in a storm. Napoleon blames Snowball for the destruction and orders the animals to rebuild it. The animals work even harder, but the windmill is destroyed again. This time, Napoleon accuses Snowball of working with humans to destroy the windmill. He orders the animals to build a new windmill, which is completed after another year of hard labor. The animals are now living in relative comfort, thanks to the electricity generated by the windmill. However, they are still ruled by Napoleon, who has become increasingly tyrannical. One day, the animals see a group of humans approaching the farm. They are led by Mr. Jones, the former owner of the farm. The animals are terrified, but Napoleon assures them that everything will be fine. The humans enter the farmhouse and begin to talk to Napoleon. The animals watch from outside, unable to hear what is being said. Suddenly, the humans leave and the animals are left wondering what happened. Napoleon comes out of the farmhouse and tells the animals that he has made a deal with the humans. The humans will provide food and supplies to the farm in exchange for the animals' labor. The animals are shocked and angry, but they have no choice but to accept the deal. The humans return to the farm every week to collect the animals' produce. The animals work hard to meet the demands of the humans, but they are constantly hungry and tired. One day, the animals decide that they have had enough. They rebel against Napoleon and drive him off the farm. The animals take control of the farm and begin to run it themselves. They establish a new set of rules, called the Seven Principles of Animalism. These principles state that all animals are equal, that animals should not exploit other animals, and that animals should not kill other animals. The animals live happily ever after, free from human oppression.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Snowball and Napoleon emerge as leaders.
output: Snowball proposes plans to build a windmill, which will provide electricity and give the animals more leisure time, but Napoleon disputes this idea. The two argue fiercely, and the loud noise draws the other animals to witness their fight. Suddenly several dogs storm into the barnyard and attack Snowball, who flees and never returns. Napoleon announces that there will be no further debates; he also tells them that the windmill will be built after all and lies that it was his own idea, stealing Snowball's popularity and inventiveness so that the animals will follow Napoleon instead of Snowball. Squealer makes a speech seconding Napoleon's announcement. The animals work harder with the promise of easier lives with the windmill. After a violent storm, the animals find the windmill annihilated. Napoleon quickly places the blame on Snowball, claiming that Snowball sabotaged the windmill out of spite. The pigs begin to teach the sheep a new chant: "Four legs good, two legs bad." Napoleon orders the hens to surrender their eggs. When they refuse, he cuts off their food, causing several of them to die of starvation. Nine hogs who oppose Napoleon confess to conspiring with Snowball and are killed. With these confessions and executions (later recognized by the animals as false), Napoleon assumes absolute control over Animal Farm. Mr. Frederick, a neighboring farmer, attacks the farm, using blasting powder to blow up the restored windmill. Though the animals win the battle, they do so at great cost, as many, including Boxer, are wounded. Despite his injuries, Boxer continues working harder and harder, until he collapses while working on the windmill. Napoleon sends for a van to take Boxer to the veterinary surgeon, explaining that better care can be given there. Benjamin reads the side of the van - it says "Horse Slaughterer". The animals panic and pursue the van, but it drives away too fast for them to keep up. Years pass on Animal Farm, and the pigs become more and more like human beings - walking upright, carrying whips, and wearing clothes. Eventually, the seven principles of Animalism, known as the Seven Commandments and inscribed on the side of the barn, become reduced to a single principle reading "all animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others." Napoleon holds a dinner party for the pigs and local farmers, with whom he celebrates a new alliance. He abolishes the practice of the revolutionary traditions and restores the name "The Manor Farm". As the animals outside gaze at the scene and look from pig to man, and from man to pig, and from pig to man again, they can no longer distinguish between the two.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
"Ah man, it smells like death in here." That is the phrase that I have lived to regret ever since they fell foolishly from my mouth. I was essentially immortal before that moment in time. I was the best comedian in the world, and apparently better than anyone in the afterlife as well. It was the only reason the Grim Reaper decided not to take me. I could make him laugh, and in his line of work that was a rarity. I do n't even remember what it was that I had said when he showed up at my car accident. I can recall him bending down next to my overturned Honda civic and reaching in to pull me out. I made some off the wall comment and he froze, dead in his tracks. It was the weirdest laugh I had ever heard, but one I appreciated more than all of the others combined. He let me live, provided that every year on the anniversary of what should have been my death, I would tell him a joke that would make him cry with laughter. I was his own personal jester, and for that he rewarded me handsomely. And then on that fateful day, 121 years later, I muttered those stupid words that seized our contract and ripped it in two. Who knew Death would be so self conscious about his smell? And to make things worse, that was n't even the joke that I was going to tell him! The actual joke was a masterpiece, but he would n't give me the chance to tell it. I ran out of that room faster than I'd ever run before. And I've been running ever since. I think the reason that he has n't taken me yet is because of our long history together. That is n't to say that he's forgiven me. He seems to enjoy reminding me that he's near. Everyone I get close to dies without reason. I'll see a dog in the park that I think looks adorable and before I can pet it, it'll fall over dead. Roses crumble before I can enjoy their scent and food rots on my fork before I can bring it to my mouth. He's killing everything around me. I have discovered that Death is a jester of a different sort. I had provided him with a form of humor that he was n't used to, but he has since grown tired of it, and reverted to his old ways. Now, he once again deals in jokes of cruelty and irony. In a way, I am still fulfilling my part of our old deal. The Reaper still laughs, and he still laughs at me. Only now, the difference is I'm not laughing.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Scientists tried for decades to find out why the telomeres stopped shortening during cell division. Soon enough immortal children grew up and became scientists or participants in studies. They maintained the appearance of a child but had the brain of any other. And after several decades more immortal humans were everywhere, but humanity could n't discover how to replicate the genes or mutations causing the phenomena. It's now over one hundred fifty years since the birth of the first immortal. A young looking girl named Esther sat in a grassy field. Trees skirted the field at her back and in front of her sat a city. She'd seen more in her lifetime than any other human ever had. Several wars, booms in technology so astonishing that soon enough scientists said we were going to be making contact with celestial bodies outside of the solar system, and last of all the introduction of a drug you could take that would change every strand of your DNA. The age at which you took it would be the age you appeared to be for the rest of your life. She had a passion for spreading her gift around so others would n't experience the burdens and pains of aging. But the side effects of the drug did n't manifest for years, sometimes decades. Slowly humanity had changed in an unintended way. Random genes were shut off at inappropriate times. Some people lost their ability to experience emotions. Some people lost control of their muscles. No one that took the drug was free of consequences. Only the truly immortal, those born with the mutation, wished to live their lives for all of time. The population of true immortals was still growing and the population of the population of mortals and mortal turned immortals remained about the same. Groups of mortals rose up trying to keep their way of life going, but many wished for them to give up so humanity could be purified of death. Was it cruel to bring a mortal to life in the world of immortals? Immortals ruled the world and they certainly thought so. After the discovery that the drug had severe negative side effects the immortals wished to ban it as well, and so they did. It was illegal to produce it, sell it, possess it, and above all, illegal to have a child after having taken the drug. Esther had left her lab years early. She had given up on finding why they could n't fix the drug or reverse its effects. She moved out to the country, wishing she had never discovered it. The country was an expensive place to live due to the enormous population size humanity had reached, but she had more money than she would ever need. She walked towards a giant tree in the middle of the field. It was one that had been planted when she was young, it gave her comfort to be with something as old as she was. She thought of humanity and what she hoped to see in the next few centuries of her life. She looked down to her right and left. A small headstone stuck up out of the grass on either side. Scientists tried for decades to find out why the telomeres stopped shortening during cell division. Soon enough immortal children grew up and became scientists or participants in studies. They maintained the appearance of a child but had the brain of any other. And after several decades more immortal humans were everywhere, but humanity could n't discover how to replicate the genes or mutations causing the phenomena. It's now over one hundred fifty years since the birth of the first immortal. A young looking girl named Esther sat in a grassy field. Trees skirted the field at her back and in front of her sat a city. She'd seen more in her lifetime than any other human ever had. Several wars, booms in technology so astonishing that soon enough scientists said we were going to be making contact with celestial bodies outside of the solar system, and last of all the introduction of a drug you could take that would change every strand of your DNA. The age at which you took it would be the age you appeared to be for the rest of your life. She had a passion for spreading her gift around so others would n't experience the burdens and pains of aging. But the side effects of the drug did n't manifest for years, sometimes decades. Slowly humanity had changed in an unintended way. Random genes were shut off at inappropriate times. Some people lost their ability to experience emotions. Some people lost control of their muscles. No one that took the drug was free of consequences. Only the truly immortal, those born with the mutation, wished to live their lives for all of time. The population of true immortals was still growing and the population of the population of mortals and mortal turned immortals remained about the same. Groups of mortals rose up trying to keep their way of life going, but many wished for them to give up so humanity could be purified of death. Was it cruel to bring a mortal to life in the world of immortals? Immortals ruled the world and they certainly thought so. After the discovery that the drug had severe negative side effects the immortals wished to ban it as well, and so they did. It was illegal to produce it, sell it, possess it, and above all, illegal to have a child after having taken the drug. Esther had left her lab years early. She had given up on finding why they could n't fix the drug or reverse its effects. She moved out to the country, wishing she had never discovered it. The country was an expensive place to live due to the enormous population size humanity had reached, but she had more money than she would ever need. She walked towards a giant tree in the middle of the field. It was one that had been planted when she was young, it gave her comfort to be with something as old as she was. She thought of humanity and what she hoped to see in the next few centuries of her life. She looked down to her right and left. A small headstone stuck up out of the grass on either side. She placed her hands on both of the stones for a moment before closing her eyes to take a nap. "Goodnight Mum, goodnight Dad," she whispered.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
It started happening before I was born. My grandfather tells me that it started before he was born too. All we know is that, when you reach the age of 25, a letter appears. No one's quite sure how. It just shows up. Some people never open theirs, they're too afraid to know. If you try to throw it away, it'll come back. If you burn or tear it, a new one is sent. At first everyone thought it was a prank. Date, time, location and cause of death? How would anybody know such a thing? But then, the first person scheduled to die, did. Hit by the same bus mentioned, on the same street, at the same time, on the same day. Just days later, the second was shot by a mugger. It was becoming clear that this was real. Fast-forward to now. My 25th birthday. I have the letter. I've already made my mind up that I'll want to know. But my hands shake as I open the letter. What if I only have a few days left? What if I'm going to die today? I swallow, and take the piece of paper out of the envelope. Blank. Both sides, blank. I hold it up against the light. Still nothing. I try to think what else I could do, but it is completely and utterly blank. What could that mean? Am I immortal? Should I already be dead? Is my death alone unfixed? What kind of person gets a blank death letter? I walk out to where the rest of my family is gathered. 25th birthdays are usually sombre events, even for those who do n't open their letters. I look at them all uncertainly. My grandfather, who knows that he has days left, although he wo n't tell us how many, shuffles over, and asks, "Well, want to share?" Numbly, I hand him the envelope with the blank piece of paper in it. He takes it out, and the shock of it gives him a heart attack. As we wait for the ambulance, he slips away. He was the only one of that generation left, and he had celebrated his 100th birthday a month ago. He'd known, for 75 years that he was going to die on this day, at the time he did. He just did n't tell us when, because his letter had given the location'At Your Grandson's 25th Birthday Party'. We obviously needed to start preparing for his cremation, but everyone seemed very interested in my blank letter. Nobody came up with any real answers, there was n't even a whisper about blank death letters on the internet. Eventually, one of my cousins who did n't like me very much said that we could test whether I was immortal. "Try it, and I test whether you are." I usually would n't have been so snappy, but I'd just received a blank death letter, and my grandfather had just died. I was a little bit shaken up, to say the least. Everyone kept arguing over what we could do. Eventually, I could n't take it anymore, so I made my excuses and left. I walked home, not really paying much attention to my surroundings, and just as I was crossing the road in front of my house, the van hit me. As I came to a rest, the death letter which had been knocked out of my jacket, fluttered down onto me, now displaying the number 1.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
The problem with personality is that so much of it depends on what happened during your life. There are certain things that change you for better or worse. I wish I could say that all the accumulated knowledge, wisdom and memories stay but each time we start again, it's like a reset on most things. Thomas was having another party according to his Facebook update. I remember the last time I was invited to one, he gave me a list of things to bring and I did, except no one else was there. He gave me the location of a lifeguard tower at the beach that they were at, except it did n't actually exist. I have a flask tucked into my jacket pocket on the chair with the potion that will set my plan into motion if I decide to try again. I'm still not sure if this is what I want to do, raising him again and starting over is an impossibility because he might not even be healthy enough to raise me so that I have a chance of repeating our plans again. The thing is, I'm still not sure about how I feel about not letting him know about his genetic predisposition for heart failure this time. I decided a few tries ago that this had too much of a negative impact whenever I told him, no matter how old he was when I did. Too many times I witnessed him going down the wrong path with drugs because of this. He's in college and happy now, not a care in the world. He has a slight idea of our plan this time even though he suspects it's just a story I used to tell to help him cope with being abandoned by his real parents. I've thought about this and if I really wanted to, I could just let him live normally. I could let him find out on his own. I know he's smart and might even figure something out. Medicine has advanced tremendously since we started. Personally, I feel like I've had enough of this life business but I'm not sure if I should make this choice for him. Maybe I was wrong and I ca n't reverse engineer what my friend used to be. He looks at me as a father figure and I guess that's understandable, I'm old enough to be his grandfather by now. So I decide to do what my heart tells me is right. I take the flask that I asked my lawyer to mail to me and pour it into my bedpan until the very last drop is gone.

He retires to Florida. He writes his autobiography. He dies at eighty-five.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
It was about that time again. The dawn of a new day, when humans thought to sneak up on the Deep Woods Dragon while it slept. It feared the way the sun reflected off of it' s scales, they said. It' s prismatic hide was so bright it was blinding. If taunted into the sun, they said, the Deep Woods Dragon could be defeated by the least trained of knights. The Deep Woods Dragon needed to be blinded, they said, or it would burn its attackers to ashes with rainbow-hued flames. He knew these rumors because the butterflies had told him. They were drawn to the rainbow of greens, yellows, pinks and purples of his scales, like the flowers they coveted so much. They had told him this, too, but the Dragon did not mind. The butterflies were honest, as their lives were short and beautiful. Even still, they could fly unhindered among the humans, even admired by the small humans who chased them, laughing. They told him stories while they rested on his wingtips, tail, and snout. Butterflies did not fear the Dragon, because they knew the truth. With a yawn, the Dragon shifted its weight to better perch itself on the tree' s stout branch. This tree was taller than the others, and overlooked a small, circular clearing. Without the deer, the weeds thrived, covering the dirt in a green, tangled mass. At the edge of the clearing stood a massive cave entrance, vines draped over the sides of smooth rock. The Dragon had snapped off the vines in front of the entrance, to give the illusion of occupancy. This was, after all, where the humans thought he lived. He knew these rumors because the butterflies had told him. "In an ancient cave in the middle of the wood, lives an ancient dragon who' s up to no good!" That was what the small humans like to chant as they chased the butterflies and laughed. So the Dragon tore at the vines, and scared the graceful deer from the peaceful clearing. He had enjoyed watching the deer with their young as they grazed the clearing. From up above in his favorite tree, they could not see him, and they could not fear him. Three times a day, the Dragon glided down from his tree to the old cave' s opening. There, he took a deep breath and screamed as loud as he could. He cried in both low tones and high pitches. He wailed in imitation of female humans, shouted in a voice mimicking angry male humans. The Dragon stood on top of the cave and breathed eye-searing beams of light from his mouth to the sky. It scared the birds huddled in the trees, and the noises scared the deer far from the clearing. But they also scared the humans away from the Deep Woods. He knew these rumors because the butterflies had told him. So he made his noises, made the lights, and scared the humans away. Because any humans who saw the Dragon would discover the truth. Because, when the Dragon stepped into the sunlight, they' d see how small he really was. The Deep Woods Dragon, with prismatic scales that shone in the sun and such a frightening voice, was the size of a domestic house cat. And only the butterflies knew the truth.

Martin enters Winnemac University in 1904.
output: He is a freshman, and he has never been to college before. He is nervous, but excited. He wants to make friends, and he wants to learn. He wants to become a doctor, and he knows that he needs to study hard if he wants to achieve his goal. Martin meets a lot of people during his first week at school. Some of them are nice, and some of them are mean. One person in particular stands out to him: a girl named Sarah. She is pretty, and she seems smart. She is also very friendly. Martin likes her immediately. As the weeks go by, Martin spends more and more time with Sarah. They talk about everything: their families, their dreams, their fears. They laugh together, and they cry together. They become best friends. One day, Sarah tells Martin that she loves him. Martin is surprised, but happy. He loves her too. They start dating, and they are very happy together. However, things change when Martin starts to get sick. He doesn't know why, but he feels weak and tired all the time. He goes to the doctor, and the doctor tells him that he has cancer. Martin is devastated. He doesn't want to die. He wants to live. He wants to marry Sarah, and have children with her. He wants to grow old with her. But the cancer is spreading quickly, and there is nothing that can be done. Martin dies a few months later. Sarah is heartbroken. She misses Martin terribly. She wishes that she could turn back time, and save him. But she knows that she can't. All she can do is remember him, and love him forever.

I've always seen numbers above people. Ever since I was a small child, I began recognizing patterns. Those in power, or with great ambition tended to be higher, while those who were more meek and humble tended to have lower numbers. As Class President, I've had my fair share of meeting people, and I'd never seen a person alive above an 8, including the tyrants of history. Sometimes, peoples numbers would change... those bullies with a 3 or 4 would cower down to a 1 or 2 after I confronted them for harassing others. I was beaten and bruised for years, but they slowly backed down. Of course, when I entered high-school, this was n't the case. There were some who were 5s and 6s, but I could n't stop now. I confronted them and the scars I have today are proof of my goals. I never backed down and kept striving to improve myself in all ways so I could make this world a better place for all of us. I scored near perfect on the University entrance exams, and was in the Tokyo University entrance ceremony when I saw him.... I did n't know his name, but an iridescent white 10 glowed above his head. The fellow next to him was a 0... Both scored perfect on the entrance exam, as they were giving the speech, but they were such opposites. The 10 was clad in suit and tie, with his long brown hair dangling in front of his eyes. The 0 was awkward-looking, he wore over-sized clothes, and it looked like he resented wearing shoes... I left early, and caught his glimpse on the way out. Our eyes caught briefly, and his 10 dropped to a 0... he smiled my way, and I smiled back. I felt calm and serene, something I would never have expected. The awkward 0 looked at me with his dark eyes before sitting down... I felt terror... as his 0 slowly morphed into a dark and smoky 10. I left that experience behind me, but worked even harder to help others; I chose to become a prosecutor... to judge and serve justice to those who were evil. High numbers were a good indicator of evil, and it is my goal to eliminate evil. I regularly judged others based on their numbers, whether they were to be eliminated or not. Then one day, it happened. Those I judged to be evil started dying of heart attacks; sudden deaths flooded the world, and the number of criminals slowly starting reducing. The world called him "Kira"... I called him God, and he soon recognized me as his devout follower, when he shared his power to judge and delete evil from this world. Now I know my ultimate purpose, and whenever I look in the mirror, I'm glad to see a shining halo-like 10 above my head, reminding me of the day I saw the shining 10 on the podium during my University's entrance ceremony all those years ago.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Martin becomes assistant to Max Gottlieb.
output: He is introduced to Terry Wickett, a young man who has been working in the laboratory for two years. Martin is impressed by Terry's knowledge of chemistry and biology. Terry tells Martin that he wants to go to medical school, but does not have enough money. Martin offers to pay for Terry's education if he agrees to work for him after graduation. Terry accepts the offer. Martin begins to teach Terry everything he knows about medicine. They spend many hours together in the laboratory. One day, Terry asks Martin why he became a doctor. Martin tells him that he wanted to help people. Terry says that he also wants to help people. Martin is surprised by Terry's answer. He thought that Terry only cared about making money. Martin realizes that Terry is a good person. He decides to trust him. Martin and Terry continue to work together. They develop a new drug that can cure cancer. They test the drug on mice. The results are positive. Martin and Terry decide to test the drug on humans. They find a patient who has terminal cancer. They give her the drug. She recovers completely. Martin and Terry are thrilled. They believe that they have discovered a miracle drug. They plan to sell the drug to pharmaceutical companies. However, they do not want to profit from the drug. They want to use the money to fund research into other diseases. Martin and Terry form a company called "The Cure". They hire scientists to study the effects of the drug on different types of cancer. They also hire doctors to treat patients with the drug. The company grows rapidly. It becomes very successful. Martin and Terry become rich. They donate most of their wealth to charity. They live modestly. They enjoy spending time with each other. They love each other deeply. They get married. They have children. Their lives are happy. But then tragedy strikes. Terry develops leukemia. He dies within months. Martin is devastated. He blames himself for Terry's death. He feels guilty because he did not save Terry. He vows to find a cure for leukemia. He spends years searching for a cure. Finally, he finds one. He tests the cure on himself. It works! He is cured. He shares the cure with the world. Millions of people are saved. Martin is hailed as a hero. He receives many awards. He is honored by governments around the globe. He is given the Nobel Prize. He is made a knight. He is named Time Magazine's Person of the Year. He is considered one of the greatest men of all time. He is remembered forever. His legacy lives on. And so ends the story of Martin Arrowsmith. A man who dedicated his life to helping others. A man whose actions changed the course of history. A man who will always be remembered as a true hero.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
All Harry could think about was the prophecy. "The power the Dark Lord knows not..." Dumbledore thought it was love. .. but hugs would n't kill monsters. That was when it hit him, Voldemort knew nothing of muggles, right? So something muggle had to be the power he knew not! Harry thought himself terribly clever. oo7, listening to him mutter through the microphone he had hidden in the boy's room simply chuckled. Took the lad long enough. Bond nonchalantly walked away and called M on his phone. "M, the lad finally got the idea. Should I approach?" a few seconds passed as Bond listened to M, "Roger that, I'll approach him before his birthday. Should be plenty of time to deal with these homegrown terrorists and get the lad to school on time." -scene break Voldemort could n't believe what was happening. For the past thirty days he had every single minion that left the Malfoy manor get shipped back in a body bag. He had n't even known muggles had those. Just goes to show how the animals could steal the dignity from wizards even in death. He was left with Wormtail and Bellatrix. Granted Bella was loyal, but she was completely insane. His most cunning and resourceful follower, the best deatheater he had, reduced to an insane hag who was good for nothing more than pointing at something he wanted destroyed and then watching it burn. A deep sigh dragged itself out of him. He could n't bring himself to even try to list any redeeming qualities in Wormtail. That was when he heard it, a muffled sound like nothing he had ever heard followed by the unmistakable sound of a dead body hitting the ground. Quick steps brought him into the kitchen in time to see a man about his age in a muggle suit dabbing a bit of blood from his face, Wormtail laying in a pool of his own blood behind him, with Bellatrix dying at his feet. Voldemort could n't remember ever being this angry. A growl issued from his clenched teeth. "Who are you?!" Voldemort shouted, even as he raised his wand to cast crucio on this fool who defied him. The muggle simply raised a hand with some device in it and pushed a bright red button on it. Pain like Voldemort had never felt corsed through his body as the traps he had n't noticed when he barged in shot tiny barbed hooks into his body attached to the launchers by a thin piece of wire. Then the traps sent 25 mill Ampere of electricity coursing through his body. Only the fact that the electricity was still flowing through him, forcing his muscles to contract, kept Voldemort standing. "The name is Bond, James Bond. Harry Potter sends his regards. Do n't worry about dying though old chap, MI6 has plans for you."

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Martin joins the Digamma Pi fraternity.
output: He is excited to meet new people and make friends. However, he soon realizes that the frat brothers are all jerks. They constantly make fun of Martin because he does n't drink alcohol or smoke weed. One day, one of the frat brothers dares Martin to eat a live goldfish. Martin refuses, so they force feed him the fish. Martin throws up immediately after eating the fish. The next morning, Martin wakes up feeling sick. He goes to class, but can barely concentrate. Later that night, Martin gets drunk off his ass. He passes out in front of the TV while watching porn. When he wakes up, he finds himself naked in bed with two hot chicks. They tell him that they want to have sex with him. Martin agrees, thinking that this must be some kind of dream. But then he notices that there is a camera recording everything. He freaks out and runs away. A few weeks later, Martin receives a letter from the university saying that he has been expelled due to "inappropriate behavior". Martin decides to sue the school for discrimination against nerds. In court, Martin argues that the frat boys were just trying to haze him. The judge rules in favor of Martin, awarding him $1 million dollars. Martin uses the money to start his own company called "Nerd Inc.". It becomes very successful, making millions of dollars each year. Eventually, Martin buys the entire campus of the college where he went to school. He turns it into a giant nerd convention center. Every summer, thousands of geeks come together to celebrate their love of science fiction, fantasy, video games, anime, manga, comics, movies, television shows, music, art, literature, history, philosophy, religion, politics, sports, food, fashion, technology, etc. And every winter, Martin hosts a huge Christmas party for all the kids who attend the conventions. At the end of the parties, Santa Claus gives everyone presents. One day, Martin meets a beautiful woman named Lisa. She works at the local library. Martin falls madly in love with her. Unfortunately, Lisa already has a boyfriend named Steve. Steve is a total douchebag who treats Lisa like crap. Martin tries to convince Lisa to leave Steve, but she refuses. Finally, Martin comes up with a plan. He hires a private investigator to dig up dirt on Steve. Sure enough, the PI discovers that Steve cheated on Lisa with another girl. Martin confronts Steve about it, threatening to expose him unless he breaks up with Lisa. Steve reluctantly agrees. Now that Lisa is free, Martin asks her out on a date. She says yes! On their first date, Martin takes Lisa to a fancy restaurant. While they are waiting for their meal, Martin tells Lisa about his life growing up poor. He explains how he worked hard to get into college, only to find out that he did n't fit in. He also talks about his experiences with the frat boys. Lisa feels sorry for Martin, so she kisses him. Afterwards, they go back to Martin's apartment. Once inside, Martin pulls out a bottle of champagne. He pops open the cork and pours them both glasses. Then he proposes marriage to Lisa. She accepts! They spend the rest of the evening drinking champagne and having wild monkey sex. The next morning, Martin wakes up hungover. He looks over at Lisa sleeping peacefully beside him. Suddenly, he remembers something important. He forgot to pay the rent! Oh well, he figures he can always move back in with his parents.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
For more than thirty years, I lived my life day by day, awaiting that fateful day when I would be granted my own inner power. I saw my friends, family, strangers, all given the most precious thing in life. Lucy, my sweet dear sister, was able to fly to the heavens and back. Richard, my childhood best friend, saved hundreds of lives throughout his life, having the strength of ten men. And there I waited, for years, until my life could start, and I would transform into the real me... the powerful me. Yet, with each passing day, more people would discover their power, and I would sit waiting at night, forcing myself to sleep. My dreams were filled with possibilities, of flight and strength, and of mind and hope. But as the years passed, my dreams were less vivid. Not everyone is lucky enough to have their inner power. Some die before that beautiful gift is bestowed unto them. I thought that may happen to me. And I lived life for a while, depressed and alone. That was until I met her. Her name was Alison. She had a power, but chose not use it. She did not want to be defined by her single ability. We met during one of my travels, when I was touring the country trying to find meaning in life. I found it. I found her. From that point on, my life started. I did not care about being granted a special ability as much as I cared for her. I saw my future, a family, a wife, children. We created a beautiful life together. Alison passed away a few years ago. I had only asked her once what her power was, and she had told me it did not matter. As she was lying on her bed, slowly fading away, she told me what her inner power was. She said she was born with her power, that she had the ability to live forever, as long as she did not love. "My power was a curse, until I found you", she told me before she passed. Today is my 70th birthday. Today I have discovered what my power is. Old age has not been kind on me, and this is the most beautiful power I could have hoped for. When I remember my wife, the times we spent, they are not just memories any longer. I can feel the brisk of the air on the hill where we first met. I can smell the flowers. I can here her giggle, her breath against my cheek. In the little time I have left on this planet, I experience her love all over again.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Martin falls in love with Leora Tozer.
output: He is a young man who works in a factory. His job is to make sure that the machines work properly. One day he sees Leora walking down the street. She is very pretty. Martin wants to talk to her but he does not know how to approach her. So he decides to follow her home. When he gets there he finds out that she lives alone. This makes him happy because now he knows where she lives. The next morning he goes to see her again. This time he brings some flowers. He gives them to her and asks if she likes them. She says yes and thanks him. Then she invites him inside. They spend the rest of the afternoon talking. At dinner they eat together. Afterwards they go back to her place. There they watch TV and listen to music. Later that evening they kiss. It feels good. The following week they meet up every day after work. Sometimes they even stay late into the night. On weekends they go shopping or hang out at the park. Eventually they become close friends. One day Martin tells Leora that he loves her. She smiles and hugs him tightly. A few months later they get married. Their wedding takes place in a church. Everyone attends except for Martin's parents. They refuse to come because they think that marriage between two different races is wrong. However, Martin and Leora do not let this bother them. Instead they focus on building their new life together. Soon they move into a house near the beach. They buy furniture and decorate their rooms. They also adopt a dog named Max. Life seems perfect. But then something happens. One day while Martin is working he hears someone calling his name. He turns around and sees a woman standing behind him. She looks familiar. He recognizes her from somewhere. Suddenly he remembers who she is. It is Leora! She runs towards him and throws herself into his arms. Tears stream down both their faces. They hold each other tight and cry. Finally they pull apart and look at each other. Both of them realize what has happened. They have fallen in love with each other. Now they must decide whether to tell anyone else about their relationship. If they don't, no one will ever know. But if they do, they risk losing everything. What should they do?

Jewel, Addie's other son, rescues the coffin from the fire.

The family's wagon is damaged, complicating their travel.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
The shrill whistle blew and everyone around me started to board the train, I walked in with them, shuffling my feet and quickly finding a seat not next to anyone. I take a quick scan of the train, watching the stream of grey individuals start to fill the empty spaces and I smile pleasantly as a man sits next to me. He smiles back, but a little uncertain, he takes another look at my direction and says "dude, why is your shirt bright, and I mean bright, pink". Looking down at my grey shirt I sigh, I asked the lady at the store where I bought it, if it looked nice on me and was n't too bright. I'm sure it wo n't be the last joke someone will play on me. Indulging the stranger I quickly explain that my life is devoid of colour and to me everything looks grey. He frowns at my answer, "are n't you really sad? it's depressing to have everything grey" "I do n't think so" I respond, "I've been this way my whole life, to me, it's normal. Hours pass and it's finally lunch time, I'm sitting in my usual cafe eating my usual sandwich when she walks in. My eye's are drawn to this beautiful women, she stands out from everyone, because she is not grey. I do n't know how to calm my mind, her dress is so bright it almost hurt's, her hair is darker then the dress but still far richer then anything that surrounds her. She looks at me and smiles, her teeth blind and her eye's are like bright spears that impale my soul. I heard the cashier make a off hand remark about her new green dress and I almost lose it. How can she be so calm and casual when talking about this colour green, her dress lights up my whole world and I felt a tear roll down my cheek. I know I ca n't wait, I ca n't live without this women, I need her colour. Getting up I make my way over, "excuse me, miss, you are the most beautiful women in the whole world, nothing I have ever seen is close to what you are to me" She smiles, but it does n't reach her eye's and my heart sinks. She makes some comment about her being flattered but she is already taken, grabs her coffee and goes. I'm now traveling home, and I watch the grey world pass by the window, I watch the blur of grey become one band of colour until I refocus my eye's. I walk home and enter my grey house and lay on my grey bed and all I can think of is that girl, who is she, where does she go, how can I get close to her, how can I keep her around me forever. Because I know now, I know now I'm sad.

I'm now traveling home, and I watch the grey world pass by the window, I watch the blur of grey become one band of colour until I refocus my eye's. I walk home and enter my grey house and lay on my grey bed and all I can think of is that girl, who is she, where does she go, how can I get close to her, how can I keep her around me forever. Because I know now, I know now I'm sad.


Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Addie Bundren lays dying while her son Cash builds her coffin.
output: Her husband Anse and their other children, Darl, Jewel, Dewey Dell, and Vardaman, gather around her deathbed. Addie asks for her father, whom she has not seen since childhood, and expresses regret that she married Anse instead of staying with him. As she dies, Addie tells Anse that she wants to be buried in Jefferson, Mississippi, where her family lives. The Bundrens set out for Jefferson with Addie's body in the wagon. Along the way, they encounter various obstacles, including a flooded river and a fire that destroys part of the wagon. They also meet several people who offer help or hinderance, such as a doctor who tries to save Addie's life and a preacher who offers to bury her. Throughout the journey, each character reveals his or her own thoughts and feelings through interior monologues. These monologues reveal the characters' motivations, fears, and desires, as well as their relationships with one another and with Addie. For example, Darl is obsessed with understanding the meaning of existence, while Jewel is consumed by anger and resentment towards his mother. Meanwhile, Dewey Dell struggles with her pregnancy and Vardaman grapples with the concept of death. By the end of the novel, the Bundrens arrive in Jefferson and bury Addie. However, the journey has changed them all irrevocably, forcing them to confront their own mortality and the fragility of human connections.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
THE WALL IS BUILT... EVENTUALLY Centipedes slink through smooth gaps in a rotten facade. Moss hides in the shadows and vines creep towards the light. The wall has existed all my life, and all through the lives of my oldest memorable ancestors. It is the lore of our people, that they traveled from distant lands where compassion was an economy, and peace an inescapable truth to seek opportunity. Well, another inescapable truth is that man, even in a place of prosperity, will often succumb to wanderlust. That is the story of these ancestors. Which in a way, is the story of myself. Or at least, why I came to be. They boarded a ship and set forth to the west. For weeks, the sea lay docile beneath their ship. Lazy waves lapped the hull, and steady winds pulled her forward. The travelers, who fancied themselves much more intrepid than they were, laughed among themselves at their own good fortune. "If only the naysayers back home could see the state of things on this veritable pleasure cruise!" they would exclaim defiantly. This trend settled into a routine before long, and such was the new life of the wayfarer. The sun would break the horizon, and they would rise from sleep to great it. Meals were consumed, feet took to dance, and wine was drunk. Unfortunately, even the most steadfast of routines is fleeting in the scheme of life, and one night bad luck finally befell them. A new trend. And one that would last certainly longer than the previous. The captain saw through a glass large clouds of deep black swirling in the distance. Dusk was minutes off, so he took to worry. The coarse was altered, and the ship's path now listed somewhat to the South and away from danger. It was a reasonable precaution, and would have been a perfect solution if the maps were more reliable. They, however, most certainly were not. Therefore, it was not. If smooth seas never made a skillful sailor, it is no surprise that the captain and crew had some serious shortcomings. To blame any single one of them for the wreck would be terribly unfair. The real culprit was hidden somewhere in the barrels of wine and mead stored below deck. And in the habit they had made of good fortune. With bad weather behind, and brisk air above, the crew had mostly joined the passengers within the ships belly. With so many people gathered so closely, either violence or levity are guaranteed, and on this evening the mood kept a lighter tone. Above, in the crows nest, a lonely man listened resentfully as voices sang, and feet stomped to the tune of jovial tunes played by practiced hands. Fiddles, mandolins, and accordions bickered playfully for hours and with each passing minute the weary occupier of the crow's nest grew more bitter. Just before midnight, when a particularly quick tune was met with a particularly rowdy cheer, his mind was made. "Crow's nest be damned! Mead be downed!" The latter part of that statement has sprung from the mouths of men before many a poor decision. And always with the same degree of vigor. Within moments the deck of the ship sat vacant, while the hold was full to burst. Libations continued to flow, while a jagged rocky coast sneaked ever closer.
