Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Addie dies and her family prepares for the journey to Jefferson for her burial.
output: Anse, Addie's husband, tells Cash, Jewel, Darl, Dewey Dell, and Vardaman that they must take Addie's body to Jefferson because she wanted to be buried there. The Bundrens load up the wagon and head out. On the way, they stop at Samson's house to spend the night. While there, Tull tells Anse that he should wait until morning to cross the river because it has been raining heavily. Anse refuses to listen and insists on crossing immediately. The next day, the Bundrens arrive at Armstid's farm. There, they meet Vernon Tull, who offers to help them get across the river. However, when they reach the bridge, they find that it has collapsed due to heavy rains. Anse decides to try to ford the river instead. He ties himself to the wagon and begins walking across the water. Suddenly, the current sweeps him away. His sons jump into the river after him but cannot save him. Later, the Bundrens discover that Anse drowned. Meanwhile, Cora Tull goes to visit Mrs. Bundren. She finds her lying dead in bed. Cora realizes that Addie died during childbirth. She also learns that Addie gave birth to twins. One twin survived; the other did not. Cora takes care of both babies until they grow old enough to leave home. Then, she sends them off to live with relatives. Years later, the Bundrens return to Jefferson. They learn that Addie's grave marker was stolen. So, they decide to dig up her coffin and rebury her elsewhere. During the funeral service, Reverend Whitfield delivers a eulogy. Afterwards, the Bundrens go back to their farm. As soon as they arrive, they receive word that Addie's second child died. The Bundrens bury the baby alongside its mother. A few days later, the Bundrens hear news that Addie's firstborn son committed suicide. The Bundrens attend his funeral. At the end of the ceremony, the preacher asks everyone present to pray for forgiveness. Everyone does except for Anse. Instead, he walks over to the open casket and stares at his wife's corpse. Finally, he turns around and leaves without saying anything.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
The year is 167 A.R. The air around the deep survival bunker, other than being stuffy, is tense. I enter the observance chamber, and it's a buzz of activity. People huddling around unrecognizable laptops and computers. The days were finally closing in on the hours. Light was imminent. It has been 167 years since the destabilization. 167 years after rogue. Our planet, along with its some 7.8 billion population of people, have been forced to hide, or die trying. Many of us went underground, taking with us seeds and other animals to restart life if possible. We all new the odds of that though. After the first five years of preparation, we went into cryostasis, while a small population elected to stay and try and plot our course through the lonely emptiness of deep space. Needless to say, they succeeded, and they were bloody excited. Our Earth, with its surface now a comfortable -176 degrees Celsius, is on a hopeful course to the Andromeda Galaxy. We are approaching it very fast, but we believe that we will come within orbital distance and speed of at least twenty stars. And so we were awoken. Our planet, after a century of darkness, is starting to receive light from nearby stars. The boffs say that it still is only a full moon of light, but it's a change. Soon, we will pass by a red giant, and very closely. The boffs believe that it will be enough to start thawing out our cold, icy blue planet. The day has arrived. I am standing at the airlock, alongside my expeditionary unit. It's been a few days since we started our slingshot around the red giant, and the surface readings say that the temperature is stabilizing between -19 and 2 degrees. It's still cold, but it will be bearable, especially in our survival gear. We have packed 3 days of food. It's been a while since I've had a military ration pack, but the management thought it would be suitable to have one with our return to the surface. Everyone else has backed skis on their backpacks, but I've got my old snowboard kit with me. It was my passion before I left the surface. I stand here, before the airlock, googles on and pretty much looking like a... Like one of those puffy treats you roast on a stick over fire. I ca n't remember their name. Come to think of it, I hardly remember what fire looks like. The attendant starts the opening sequence from his enclosed booth. I stand at the head of the other 11 men and women. Everyone of them has lost something to the darkness, and everyone of them has determination to reclaim our planet and our lives. The air lock breaks, and a flood of air escapes and pours in. As I shield my eyes from the initial blinding light, I know of the struggle to come. I stand upright, and stare out beyond the layered steel frame. Crisp virgin snow lays beyond us, in our bleak abandoned world. "O brave new world", I mutter to no one reminiscently.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
The Bundren family sets out on their journey to Jefferson with Addie's coffin.
output: They stop for the night at Samson's farm. Anse asks Samson to let him borrow a shovel to dig a grave for Addie. Samson agrees, but he tells Anse that he can't bury her there because she died of yellow fever. Anse insists that he must bury her there because it's where she wanted to be buried. He says that he promised her that he would do it. Samson reluctantly gives him the shovel and tells him to go ahead and dig the grave. Anse digs the grave and then goes back inside the house. He finds Darl sitting alone in the kitchen. Anse asks Darl why he isn't helping with the burial. Darl replies that he doesn't want to help because he knows that Anse is going to cheat on his wife again. Anse gets angry and yells at Darl. He calls him a liar and accuses him of trying to ruin his marriage. Darl just sits there silently. Anse storms out of the room and goes outside. He sees Jewel standing next to the wagon. Anse walks up to him and asks him what he thinks about what happened earlier. Jewel says that he doesn't care what happens as long as he gets paid. Anse tells him that he'll pay him when they get to town. Jewel nods and walks away. Anse watches him leave and then turns around and heads back towards the house. He enters the bedroom where Dewey Dell is sleeping. She wakes up and asks him what he wants. Anse tells her that he needs money to buy supplies for the trip. Dewey Dell hands him some cash and tells him to take whatever he needs. Anse thanks her and leaves the room. He returns to the living room where Cash is waiting for him. Cash asks him how things went with Samson. Anse tells him everything that happened. Cash listens carefully and then suggests that they should go see Tull instead. Anse agrees and they set off together. When they arrive at Tull's place, they find him sitting outside drinking whiskey. Anse introduces himself and explains what happened at Samson's. Tull laughs and says that he knew that Anse wouldn't last long without cheating on his wife. Anse denies this and says that he loves his wife more than anything else in the world. Tull shakes his head and says that he doesn't believe him. Anse tries to convince him otherwise, but Tull refuses to listen. Finally, Anse gives up and decides to leave. Before he does, however, he notices something strange about Tull. His face seems different somehow. It almost looks like he's wearing makeup. Anse wonders whether Tull might actually be a woman disguised as a man. He considers asking him directly, but decides against it. Instead, he simply bids farewell and departs. On the way home, Anse reflects upon his encounter with Tull. He realizes that he may never know who Tull really is. But even though he didn't learn much about Tull, he did manage to learn something important about himself. He learned that he truly loves his wife and that he won't ever betray her again. This realization brings him great comfort and makes him feel better about himself.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Naif turned the page. Another day of studying droned on. It wasn' t that the material was a challenge, Naif had no problem absorbing every concept she came across and she had more degrees than anyone her age to prove it. Life had always been that way. In primary school she related better to adults than her classmates. In secondary school she was respectful of her teachers but felt she understood the lessons they taught to a deeper level than even they appreciated. University had been much the same except the distance between herself and her professors had turned her conscientious respect into a degree of begrudging disdain. She was certainly more intelligent than anyone she knew of, more so than anyone she had ever met. She picked apart the documents piled high on her desk recalling even the articles in the citations that she had previously read. Today her eyes were heavy, mostly with boredom, somewhat with the strain. Her mind was as sharp as it had ever been but her body showed the signs that she would not be considered a young woman for much longer. Through the closed windows she could vaguely hear the muffled hum of the world rushing by outside. Suddenly the monotony of the day fell away as it was unbound by a sharp thud against the outer wall of her office. Naif quickly straightened her hunched shoulders and bumped the table sloshing coffee over her meticulously curated stacks of research papers. She snarled impatiently at the mess and sprang to the window. She squinted through the blinds at the sunlit scene then furrowed them even further in annoyance. The neighbours were playing baseball with their kids again. Idiots. Hadn' t they any respect for others? One of the little morons ran up to the edge of Naif's apartment, beneath her field of view, and tried to throw the ball back. It careened off course and the cretin had to go pick it up again to return it to his waiting family. Naif rolled her eyes as she turned away from the display of incompetence and inefficiency that played out beyond her walls. As she sopped up the spilled coffee from her desk she mumbled to herself, as she had before, "I wish everyone were more intelligent. I would have so much more to share with them, so much more in common. They run around all day never thinking of their actions, of their futures. Such wasted potential in all that frivolity." Though as she settled back into her comfortably worn chair she couldn' t help feeling that there was something more to it that she just didn' t quite understand.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Standing on top of our world, we watch as the sun rises over the island. The soft rays bathe the distant hills in gold, as the breeze blows through the dancing grass. The trees shivers as flock of birds take flight. Spots of white clouds the orange-hued sky, as it slowly turns azure. Far in the distance, a silver tower, shrouded in mist, pierces the heavens above. The waves crash down on the sandy beaches, and the endless sea merges with the horizon. I take in the sights, the smells, the sounds. Feeling both pride and joy, I turn to face to you. The air is warm, but your hand is warmer. I hold it close to me, closer still. The sun is shining bright, but your smile is brighter. We' re standing at the top of our world, the one we made together, and I can' t tell you how happy this has made me. "It' s almost time." You say. "I know." I reply. I rest my head on your shoulder, and take a long breath as I close my eyes. I' m at peace here. When I opened them again, I was in my bed, and a bittersweet feeling of both tranquility and sadness lingered in my mind. It was around 7 a.m., and I went about my daily routine, a smile etched on my face. I wrote what had happened in a dream journal I had started two years ago. After having read about lucid dreaming, and I wanted to try it. It took some time, but one day, I was able to control the outcome of my dreams. After a few weeks, something changed. There was something else, maybe someone else, with me. I couldn' t control them, and they couldn' t control me. I searched about it in books and online, but no one reported something similar. I wasn' t afraid, though. Their presence was soothing. We rarely spoke, but when we did, it was always meaningful. Together, we started building a world, our dream island. It brought me joy, and above all, peace. This feeling of inner peace lived on with me during the day. The sun was racing across the sky as we strolled down the ruins of a castle. Holes and cracks had let nature overtake the walls and floors, and the ceiling had long since crumbled. We walked down an old throne room, and you turned to face me. It was so sudden, I nearly bumped into you. You looked resolute, and you said two simple words: "Find me." I jolted awake. I knew what I had to do. I had to find you. So I searched, high and low, for days on end. Perhaps I thought it was fate, perhaps it was simply fool' s luck, but I felt as if I would eventually find you, if I kept trying. One evening, as if beckoned, I went in a coffee shop. I sat down with my coffee at an empty table, and looked up through the window at the red sky. Soon, someone came in, ordered the same thing as I did. They headed toward my table, and sat down in front of me, smiling brightly. Strangely, I felt at peace.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Frank Alpine becomes a clerk in Morris Bober's grocery store.
output: He is a young man who has been drifting from job to job, unable to settle down. He is attracted to Helen Bober, Morris's daughter, but she is engaged to another man. Frank tries to win her love by helping out in the store and being kind to her father. But he also steals money from the cash register and lies to Morris about it. Eventually, his dishonesty is discovered and he is fired. He leaves town, but returns later to apologize to Morris and ask for forgiveness. Morris forgives him, but tells him that he must leave town again because he cannot trust him anymore. Frank goes away, but comes back once more to see Helen before she gets married. She rejects him, saying that she loves her fiancé and does not want anything to do with Frank. He leaves town again, this time for good. Years pass, and Frank becomes a successful businessman. He marries and has children. One day, he receives a letter from Morris Bober, asking him to come visit him. Frank goes to see Morris, who is now very old and sick. Morris asks Frank to forgive him for firing him all those years ago. Frank says that there is nothing to forgive, and that he understands why Morris did what he did. Morris dies soon after, and Frank attends his funeral. At the cemetery, he sees Helen again. She is now a widow with grown children. They talk briefly, and then go their separate ways. As Frank walks away, he thinks about how much things have changed since he first met Morris Bober. He realizes that he has learned a lot from Morris, even though they were never really friends. And he knows that he will always remember Morris as a wise and generous man who taught him many valuable lessons about life.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
We attack immediately at sundown, once their solar power cells are no longer generating power and they are instead using stored power. Forcing the enemy to rely on finite reserves is a good strategy. From our intel gathering and scouting missions we know the machines' first response will be to send two robots per every identified threat. Not a bad bit of logic on their part. The wolves were able to acquire video of some of the human assaults. We can confirm each localized machine hub will have, at minimum, 50000 robot responders. Luckily, we have some numbers. The machines decided not to bury the dead or finish off the wounded humans but to ship them away from the machine hubs. The wolf and bat armies grew after each human battle. Intel reports also bolstered our confidence that the robots would have diminished ability to fend off our armies. The machines graciously eliminated silver from any of their infrastructure, preferring either denser or more conductive metal depending on the situation. The machines also eliminated religion from their human cattle, ending the scourge of crosses or other offending accoutrements. Also, the machines removed unnecessary costs in generating food for their human cattle, including flavorings such as garlic. We've coordinated our attack with other armies across the world. Tonight's sunset heralds our initial assault, beginning in the pacific and escalating westward as the sun's influence retreats behind the horizon. We have factored in failure to our first battle. Armies will retreat north to arctic regions taking advantage of the extended nights. Getting our allies from the southern hemisphere to agree that we should retake the northern hemisphere first was hard, the logistics of getting them north of the equator to join our armies was doubly so. We've drawn up a general strategy for every localized unit to follow, leaving room for them to improvise should any unforeseen complications arise. At sunset, send 50000 foot soldiers to each hub. Once the robots stop pouring out of the hub we set off EMPs. The humans discovered this only gained them around 30 seconds of disorientation within the robots. Immediately following the EMPs we electrify the magnets we've buried in the ground. A functioning robot can not be immobilized by a magnet. A disoriented one, however will be more susceptible. After that we fight. A hopefully diminished robot army will now be fighting what they will perceive as humans an large dogs. That's where our superhuman strength, speed, agility, and healing capabilities will come into play. During the ground assault a smaller team is to sever all outside communications from each hub. Disrupted communications should at least slow down global coordination with other hubs. We wanted to take out their communications before each assault, however the machines' penchant for redundancy and underground infrastructure proved cumbersome. It was decided to utilize the distraction of our infantry attacks as the opportunity to get around access issues. Watching the seconds tick by waiting for our signal to move should be nothing compared to the centuries I've been hiding underground waiting to resurface. Sadly this is not the case. I'm comforted by thoughts of global supremacy should we succeed. I'm not looking forward to the inevitable Werewolf/Vampire war that will take place after our victory over the machines. We'll have to deal with that problem when it comes, I suppose. For right now it's time to transform into a wolf. I've got some metal to munch.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Frank is haunted by his past actions of robbing the store.
output: He feels guilty and ashamed of himself. He decides to go back to the store and return the money he stole. Frank walks into the store and sees the same cashier who was working the night he robbed the store. He approaches her and says "I'm sorry for what I did. Here's your money back." The cashier looks at him confused and asks "What do you mean? You didn't steal anything from me." Frank replies "Yes I did. I took $100 from the register last week." The cashier shakes her head and says "No you didn't. There was no robbery here last week." Frank insists "But I remember doing it! I even wrote myself a note saying 'Robbed Store - $100.'" The cashier laughs and says "That must have been someone else then. Maybe you had too much to drink?" Frank thinks for a moment and realizes she might be right. He thanks her for her help and leaves the store feeling relieved. Later that day, Frank goes home and finds his wife sitting on the couch watching TV. She turns to look at him and smiles. Frank sits down next to her and tells her everything that happened at the store. His wife listens intently and nods along. When he finishes talking, she hugs him tightly and whispers "It's okay honey. Everyone makes mistakes sometimes." Frank feels better knowing that his wife still loves him despite his mistake. They spend the rest of the evening cuddled together on the couch watching movies until they fall asleep. The next morning, Frank wakes up early and gets ready for work. As he drives to work, he notices something strange happening around town. People seem to be acting differently than usual. Some people appear nervous while others act like nothing has changed. Frank wonders if there really was a robbery at the store after all. He arrives at work and greets his coworkers as normal. However, throughout the day, he keeps hearing rumors about a recent crime wave sweeping through the city. Apparently several stores were broken into overnight and thousands of dollars worth of merchandise was stolen. Frank becomes increasingly worried as he hears these stories. Could he possibly be responsible for causing this chaos? Did he actually rob those stores without remembering it? Or could someone else be framing him for these crimes? Frank tries to push these thoughts aside and focus on his job. But deep down inside, he knows he needs answers. He decides to investigate further and see if he can uncover the truth behind these mysterious events.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Had I really loved her? I thought I did. But if she was n't here... 30 years. Marrying young has its perks but I would be lying if I said the journey was n't bumpy. We had our ups and downs, just like any couple. I did things I should n't have, and said things I did n't mean. But deep down, I always knew I loved her. Or was I just lying to myself? Yet the face I was staring at was n't hers. These jet black eyes were unfamiliar and hostile. I longed for her warm, loving hazel eyes, the ones I had lived and laughed with. Over time we got to know each other better. Clarice was her name. She had been a dentist. She was undeniably beautiful, but it was an effortless, flawless beauty. Yet I longed for Alicia. I had grown accustomed to her shortfalls, and had found beauty in them. Even more time passed. Slowly the memories were replaced. I made new ones with Clarice. It was like I never knew what I had been missing out on until I had the opportunity to taste it. We simply clicked on a deeper level. She was the type of girl you can have deep co conversations about universe and life with under the stars, yet get into a tickle fight with two minutes later. For the longest time I felt guilty. However good Alicia had been, Clarice seemed to be better in every aspect. Eventually the guilt faded. All there was left was bliss. And then it all went South. The first time we argued I was stunned. We had never argued before, ever. It was a pretty issue, but an argument nonetheless. Soon enough they became more frequent. More frequent and more intense. Life turned from peace to chaos, happiness to misery. The constant stress, fighting, distrust and resentment slowly began to manifest into only one thing. Hatred. Love had turned into hatred. I had never mentioned Alicia to Clarice. I had always assumed she was like me, that she had left someone behind to be with me. Then one fine day it all made sense. All it took was one sentence from Clarice and it became crystal clear. The icy smile when she said it sent a shiver down my smile. "We know what you did to Alicia and now your life is going to be a living Hell."

Morris Bober struggles with the failing business and his health.
output: He is a Jewish refugee who immigrated to America after World War II. Morris owns a small grocery store in Brooklyn, New York. His wife, Ida, helps him run the store. They have a daughter named Helen. Morris works hard to keep the store open, but he is not making much money. One day, a man named Frank Alpine comes into the store. Frank is a drifter who has been traveling around the country. He asks Morris for a job. Morris hires Frank as a delivery boy. Frank starts working at the store. He is a hard worker and he learns quickly. Morris likes Frank and trusts him. Frank becomes friends with Helen. He tells her about his past and how he ended up in Brooklyn. Helen feels sorry for Frank and she wants to help him. She invites him to dinner at her house. Frank meets Morris and Ida. They are kind people and they welcome him into their home. Frank starts spending more time with Helen. He falls in love with her. He wants to marry her, but he knows that Morris and Ida will not approve. Frank decides to leave town. He does not want to cause trouble for Morris and Ida. He leaves without saying goodbye to Helen. Helen is heartbroken. She misses Frank and she wonders why he left. Morris and Ida are also sad. They miss Frank and they worry about him. A few months later, Frank returns to Brooklyn. He goes to see Morris and Ida. He tells them that he loves Helen and he wants to marry her. Morris and Ida are surprised, but they agree to let Frank marry Helen. Frank and Helen get married. They move into a small apartment near the store. Frank continues to work at the store. He is happy to be back with Helen. Morris and Ida are happy too. They are glad that Frank and Helen are together. The store is doing well and Morris is feeling better. Everything seems to be going well. Then one day, Frank gets into a fight with another customer. The customer pulls out a gun and shoots Frank. Frank dies instantly. Morris and Ida are devastated. They cannot believe that Frank is gone. Helen is also heartbroken. She blames herself for Frank's death. She thinks that if she had not invited him to dinner, he would still be alive. Morris and Ida try to comfort Helen, but she is inconsolable. She withdraws from everyone and spends most of her time alone. Morris and Ida are worried about Helen. They do not know how to help her. They decide to sell the store and move away from Brooklyn. They hope that a change of scenery will help Helen heal. They pack up their belongings and say goodbye to their customers. They drive away from Brooklyn and start a new life in a different city. Helen eventually recovers from her grief. She finds a job and makes new friends. She even starts dating again. Morris and Ida are happy to see Helen happy again. They know that Frank would be proud of her.

We never believed that the end would come, that the dawn would rise again. Every 300 years our moon orbits the world below us, this world is our guardian, it protects us, shelters us from all that the vast expanse of space has to offer: but it could not shelter us from itself, on the far side of the moons orbit lies a vast and ancient race, their empire sprawls across the planets surface and every 300 years, when our moon comes within striking distance they attack. It is said that when they do they bring with them giant beasts, created of the most foul magic, beasts of flesh with hearts as cold as ice. Our weapons could never stand against them, we never stood a chance. so when it came in 599 CE, the year of our holy father I huddled in fear in our capitol.My armies were in position to protect the citizens here, but I knew we stood no hope, our guns, as useful as they may be would never stand up against the might of the empire and so it was that on the turning point of the day we saw them come, and they came with the dawn. Vast ships pummeled our surface with rains of fire as the dawn swept across our land, melting the ever frozen landscape. Their armies landed on our surface, weapons firing some sort of plasmic mix. I watched my city crumble around me as the fighting raged on, then, then it happened. A sound like the great bellow of some ancient beast shuddered from within the earth itself; and with it they came. Hulking creatures in the shapes of men, my eyes adjusted slowly to the new light as I focused in on the great beasts that would be our doom. I watched them huge machines, not flesh but etched metal, rise and form into ranks. The Empires soldiers marched up main avenue right towards the metal horde that was slowly collecting outside our main base within the city, our last bastion. our only hope. In between the two armies, a small child wandered into the street, clearly having lost her mother and searching for anyone to car. My heart wretched as I saw one of the soldiers level its weapon at her. and my scream of pain filled the room as it fired. But as the smoke cleared I saw only a metal body, covered in plasma, shaking it off as if it were nothing more than fresh snow, and behind its protective metal shell sat the little girl. and I beheld the glory, of the new dawn.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
It was like double-vision, except it was the past. How can something fictional seem so vivid...? The distant, exotic land we came from, its gilded avenues, its glistening intricate spires, its profound natural beauty with lushly verdant banks hugging the rivers that snaked between the dunes. .. None of it was there. It was all nothing more than a dream. But I am not a lie. I stare at my hands, flexing them, examining the callouses accumulated by work never done, cracks formed of age never lived, and despite the warmth of the bright sun just passing its zenith above, I shiver. "Amir," I hear a voice call, and my heart tugs at what I know to be familiarity. "Hassan...?" I uncertainly reply as I look up. Our gazes meet. I could swear I saw in his eyes the same false memories flashing behind mine. Childhood among parents who never lived, in a community that was never built, attending an academy that was never founded, graduating from a ceremony never held... He nods hollowly, as if to confirm these very musings. "... We have to pack the supplies, Amir. His Majesty will be staying at the palace, and the staff are directing us to where we are to stow his wardrobe and leave his tributes to The Sultan." My mouth was dry, but not in response to his words. At some point I realized my'old friend' Hassan was talking only to fill the screaming void in our minds. To'Sound Normal', like'Real People'. My stomach is a knot of ice. Still, the skills of a life as-yet unlived surface readily to the forefront of my mind. How to port the many caskets of His Majesty Prince Ali's wares. "... Yes. I will coordinate with the provisioner. If my memory serves," I pause a bit too long, lost in the jarring disjunction of citing false memories, "... it is customary to serve a great feast with the arrival of a dignitary. The many delicacies of our homeland are sure to leave a resounding impression upon The Sultan's court." Hassan's expression tightens. I feel his heartache, for this homeland which we have never seen with real eyes, and never shall. He hesitantly takes a step nearer and dispenses a conciliatory pat to my shoulder. A mutual understanding. We were truly all feeling it, every last member of His Majesty Prince Ali's vanguard.... he was n't even really a prince. I shudder and turn, to address the court provisioner by name. He's just as haunted and startled as I that we know one another, but everything is running smoothly. We have no solace from our inner thoughts. We can only push on in the hopes that the minutia will wash away the horror.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Frank begins to learn about Jewish traditions and values from the Bober family.
output:
He learns how to pray and keep kosher, and he also learns about the importance of family and community. Frank becomes close friends with the Bubers, especially their son, David.

One day, while walking home from school, Frank sees a group of boys bullying a smaller boy. Without thinking, Frank steps in and defends the boy. The bullies run off, and Frank helps the boy up. The boy thanks him and introduces himself as Max. Max tells Frank that he is Jewish, and that he has been bullied because of it.

Frank invites Max over to his house to play, and they become good friends. They spend hours playing together, and Frank teaches Max about baseball. One day, while they are playing catch, Frank accidentally throws the ball too hard and hits Max in the face. Max starts bleeding, and Frank panics. He runs inside to get help, but when he comes back out, Max is gone.

Frank searches everywhere for Max, but he can't find him. He finally gives up and goes home. When he gets there, he finds Max sitting on his front porch. Max explains that he ran away because he was scared. Frank apologizes and promises to never throw the ball too hard again.

Max forgives Frank, and they continue to be best friends. They go to each other's houses after school, and they even start going to synagogue together. Frank learns more about Judaism, and he starts to appreciate the religion more.

One day, while they are at synagogue, Frank notices that Max is wearing a yarmulke. He asks Max why he is wearing it, and Max explains that it is a sign of respect for God. Frank decides that he wants to wear a yarmulke too, so he asks his mother to buy him one.

When Frank wears his yarmulke to school, he is teased by the other kids. They call him names and make fun of him. Frank doesn't understand why they are being mean to him, but he knows that he needs to stand up for himself.

He confronts the bullies and tells them that he is proud to be Jewish. He says that he is not afraid of them, and that they should stop picking on people who are different from them. The bullies are surprised by Frank's courage, and they eventually stop teasing him.

Frank continues to wear his yarmulke proudly, and he becomes known as the "Jewish kid" at school. He makes new friends, and he even starts dating a girl named Rachel. Frank is happy with his life, and he is grateful for the lessons he learned from the Bubers.

The end.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
It started happening before I was born. My grandfather tells me that it started before he was born too. All we know is that, when you reach the age of 25, a letter appears. No one's quite sure how. It just shows up. Some people never open theirs, they're too afraid to know. If you try to throw it away, it'll come back. If you burn or tear it, a new one is sent. At first everyone thought it was a prank. Date, time, location and cause of death? How would anybody know such a thing? But then, the first person scheduled to die, did. Hit by the same bus mentioned, on the same street, at the same time, on the same day. Just days later, the second was shot by a mugger. It was becoming clear that this was real. Fast-forward to now. My 25th birthday. I have the letter. I've already made my mind up that I'll want to know. But my hands shake as I open the letter. What if I only have a few days left? What if I'm going to die today? I swallow, and take the piece of paper out of the envelope. Blank. Both sides, blank. I hold it up against the light. Still nothing. I try to think what else I could do, but it is completely and utterly blank. What could that mean? Am I immortal? Should I already be dead? Is my death alone unfixed? What kind of person gets a blank death letter? I walk out to where the rest of my family is gathered. 25th birthdays are usually sombre events, even for those who do n't open their letters. I look at them all uncertainly. My grandfather, who knows that he has days left, although he wo n't tell us how many, shuffles over, and asks, "Well, want to share?" Numbly, I hand him the envelope with the blank piece of paper in it. He takes it out, and the shock of it gives him a heart attack. As we wait for the ambulance, he slips away. He was the only one of that generation left, and he had celebrated his 100th birthday a month ago. He'd known, for 75 years that he was going to die on this day, at the time he did. He just did n't tell us when, because his letter had given the location'At Your Grandson's 25th Birthday Party'. We obviously needed to start preparing for his cremation, but everyone seemed very interested in my blank letter. Nobody came up with any real answers, there was n't even a whisper about blank death letters on the internet. Eventually, one of my cousins who did n't like me very much said that we could test whether I was immortal. "Try it, and I test whether you are." I usually would n't have been so snappy, but I'd just received a blank death letter, and my grandfather had just died. I was a little bit shaken up, to say the least. Everyone kept arguing over what we could do. Eventually, I could n't take it anymore, so I made my excuses and left. I walked home, not really paying much attention to my surroundings, and just as I was crossing the road in front of my house, the van hit me. As I came to a rest, the death letter which had been knocked out of my jacket, fluttered down onto me, now displaying the number 1.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Dagny Taggart decides to rebuild the Rio Norte Line with Rearden Metal.
output: She meets Hank Rearden, the inventor and manufacturer of the metal, who admires her drive and eventually becomes her lover. Meanwhile, James Taggart uses political connections to ensure that an anti-competition law known as the "Equalization of Opportunity Bill" deprives his competitors of profitable business opportunities, including Ellis Wyatt, Andrew Stockton, and Ken Danagger. The bill also destroys one of Dagny's branches. When she confronts James, he tells her that it was done to destroy Danagger because he would not give political favors to Taggart Transcontinental's Board of Directors. In response, Dagny leaves the company and ventures out on her own to build the Rio Norte Line. Thereafter, the State Science Institute, a government agency, publishes a report which says that Rearden Metal is dangerous and should not be used; soon after, the government passes a law forbidding its use. Despite this, Dagny is able to complete the line on her own with Hank's help. The public is skeptical about the line's prospects, fearing that it may collapse. On opening day, Dagny and Hank ride on the first train over the bridge and find that it holds up perfectly. They celebrate their success by sleeping together. The two begin regularly traveling between New York City and Philadelphia, where Hank lives with his wife Lillian. While Hank is proud of his achievements, Lillian resents his feelings for Dagny and tries to make him feel guilty about them. One night, while having dinner with Lillian, Hank receives word from Francisco d'Anconia (a childhood friend) that his copper mine in Mexico has failed due to sabotage by the Mexican government. This causes panic among investors worldwide, leading to runs on banks across America. To prevent further damage to the economy, Wesley Mouch (the Assistant Secretary of Unification) issues Directive 10-289, which freezes all wages, prices, profits, and interest rates at current levels. It also requires every worker to remain at his present job, prohibits anyone from being fired without permission from the Unification Board, and makes it illegal to quit one's job without permission from the Unification Board. These measures effectively end economic freedom in America. Meanwhile, John Galt (an engineer working for Twentieth Century Motor Company) quits his job rather than work under these conditions. He goes into hiding along with other prominent businessmen and inventors who refuse to comply with Directive 10-289. Their disappearance leads to widespread shortages throughout America as factories close down and production grinds to a halt. With no one willing to produce anything, society begins to break down. People turn to looting and violence to survive. The government responds by imposing martial law and sending troops into cities to restore order. However, this only makes matters worse as soldiers begin shooting civilians indiscriminately. Amidst all this chaos, Dagny continues running Taggart Transcontinental despite increasing difficulties caused by government regulations and interference. She manages to keep things running smoothly until one day she learns that her brother Jim has been arrested for violating Directive 10-289. Desperate to save him, she agrees to marry him so that he can avoid prison time. Afterwards, she realizes that she does not love him and regrets marrying him. A few months later, she discovers that Jim has been cheating on her with another woman named Cherryl Brooks. Enraged, she divorces him and moves out of their apartment. Soon afterwards, she meets Ragnar Danneskjöld, a pirate who steals goods from ships owned by corrupt governments and sells them on the black market. Impressed by his courage and integrity, she falls in love with him. Together, they plan to overthrow the corrupt government and establish a free society based on reason and individual rights. However, before they can put their plans into action, Ragnar is captured by the authorities and sentenced to life imprisonment. Devastated, Dagny returns to New York City determined to continue fighting for justice. She joins forces with Robert Stadler, a physicist who once worked for the State Science Institute but now opposes its policies. They form a group called the Committee for Defending Individual Rights, which aims to expose the corruption within the government and bring about reform through peaceful means. Unfortunately, their efforts prove futile as the government becomes increasingly oppressive and violent towards dissenters. Frustrated, Dagny decides to take more drastic measures. She contacts Francisco d'Anconia, who reveals himself to be John Galt. He explains that he and several others have gone on strike against the government, refusing to contribute anything to society unless their demands for liberty and prosperity are met. Inspired by his example, Dagny resolves to join them. She travels to Colorado, where she finds a community of strikers living off the land and producing goods independently of the government. There, she meets Hugh Akston, a philosopher who teaches her about Objectivism, a philosophy developed by John Galt. Under his guidance, she comes to understand the importance of rational self-interest and rejects altru

Dear Kayla That name has always perked up my interest. I ca n't believe I've managed to go this far with it. With this change. And I do n't know if you'll have completed it by the time you get I read this, but I want you to know that I'm proud. I'm proud that we managed to take the first step of many. And even if I do n't get to the end, if all of my thoughts catch up to me once again and strangle me, if I do n't get accepted, I want to remind us both that any other way would n't have worked out. We both know it. But right now, if I look around right now. I know I'm happy. I've got loving parents. The best brother I could ever have, who is visiting in a couple days. A supportive councillor, and the best guy in the whole world who knows my secret. And he's there for me. And he talks to me. And I actually get to be myself with him, which is not something I can do with anyone else. And you know who he is. A couple days ago, I pointed out how we will all inevitably forget 80 % of people we meet and interact with before adulthood. But I know he will always be in my memory. Even if I'm not in his. Knowing myself, I wo n't change much from me now to you. You, just like me, are most likely putting off getting to bed, and you're planning on staying up late. And you'll shake your head, because you know you'll never change. I know I'll never change, at least in that way. But times are changing, both of us know it. Inevitable, I'll change. A lot. I will hopefully be on puberty blockers by 2nd term of next year. I wonder how that will work out. Eventually I'll be on anti-androgens, then on oestrogen later. With so much time between us, you must think that we're strangers. We are, technically. Time can do that. So I'll jog the memory. Currently I'm scared. I'm scared that someone will find me out, and shout it for everyone to hear. I'm scared that maybe tomorrow my best friend will not accept me. Or worse, tell me that he does n't care. I'm riddled with fear of late, and it does n't feel right. But if you're reading this, you made it. I made it. We made it. And I want you to keep pushing, most of all. Be you. And I'll do my best in the meantime. And this will most likely be the last time I refer to myself by this name. So here goes. From Caleb

My story started where a lot have ended these past 10 years: with a single bullet. Living in post-war Britain, death was not an uncommon sight. Everyone had at least one firearm to defend themselves, everyone had encountered gunfire in the streets, and everyone knew what it meant to live every day like it could be their last. The revolution that was supposed to end the tyranny of a dictatorship had ripped the country apart; counties had split into factions, all threatening total destruction of the others. In ten years the population was decimated, the country reduced to a crumbling mass of fallen buildings and civilians with guns. All around me was depression, death, dirt, famine. Thinking about it, it's quite hilarious, in such a depressing way. The sacks of bones, flesh and organs we saw everyday were once living, breathing, talking human beings. They had a mother, a father, a pet, a first love, they were educated, they succeeded and they failed. And they died. A single bullet can end so much. That morning, as I wandered to the local shop for some bread, clutching my rifle, my world completely ended. I had no time to react; as soon as I entered Grange Avenue a bullet burrowed into my head, smashing part of my brain, and knocking me straight out cold. I woke in a beautiful wooden chalet, bright natural light streaming through vast windows above the soft, clean bed that I rested in. My itchy, dirty clothes were replaced with beautiful white robes, soft as silk and cleaner than anything I had ever seen. I sat up, and looked around the room - it was furnished luxuriously, with beautiful gold-leaf chairs and fantastic bright works of art hanging around the room. I got up and left the room, and immediately my breath was forced from me. The crumbled grey streets of London had gone. In their place were beautiful old chalets, bright white skyscrapers, and marble streets. I could also see a very unfamiliar sight - a beautiful emerald park, littered with tall, radiant trees, ferns, and glowing coloured flowers. Clear water ran through them. All around the streets were people dressed similar to me, smiling and talking and laughing. The smog-ridden sky had been replaced with a beautiful, deep purple, but the world was light around me and the I could see the vast orange sun dipping behind the structures around the city. For the first time in ten years I smiled. That bullet took me to a better place.

God It's always difficult making tough decisions and this year I've made the hardest one of all, to eradicate sin and give humans another chance to embrace a new world. A world of peace, love and kindness where there will be no more tears. Of course in order for this to happen I have to prevent humans from actually doing sinful things, limiting their free will. Now I've debated this for eternity - literally - but to be honest, if I do n't step in the Nuclear war in 2018 would eradicate 99.9 % of the human race. I know what you're thinking, surely at that point I could step in and utilise that disaster as a fresh start. Although I see your point, i'm still experiencing the backlash about the flooding. So with that, on entering the year 2016, sin will leave the world. Every human will no longer be capable of sin. Satan Let's get something straight, I've always wanted the best for the human race. Think about it, back in the beginning with adam and eve, there was no sin, no free will to do anything you wanted. After I stepped in humanity had unlimited potential. Sure there's been war, famine, disease and death but there's been some remarkable things of human acheivement. I think you'll agree that God's plan to remove sin and thus freewill is a huge mistake. If anything he should go the opposite way, if he removed the linearity of time then nothing in the lives of humans would be predetermined. God Well a few hours in and already the world is changing for the better. For the first time, humanity all over the globe have united in wokring towards a better future. Money is no longer a concern and communities are aiding one another in anyway they can. Within the year the world should be unrecognisable, poverty and hunger no longer existing and humanity living in harmony with the earth. Satan So its only been a few hours and already I'm enjoying this more than anticipated, I did n't relise how unrewarding temptation was in the old world, people just caved so easily to their darkest desires. This new world, well this is a challenge. Even in Eden I had that tree of knowledge to play with. I've been working on quite a few things so far, sticking to the classics; wrath, greed, sloth, pride, lust, envy, and gluttony. All I need is one person to break, then its only a matter of time before the world one more begins its decent into chaos. This is going to be fun.

The year is 167 A.R. The air around the deep survival bunker, other than being stuffy, is tense. I enter the observance chamber, and it's a buzz of activity. People huddling around unrecognizable laptops and computers. The days were finally closing in on the hours. Light was imminent. It has been 167 years since the destabilization. 167 years after rogue. Our planet, along with its some 7.8 billion population of people, have been forced to hide, or die trying. Many of us went underground, taking with us seeds and other animals to restart life if possible. We all new the odds of that though. After the first five years of preparation, we went into cryostasis, while a small population elected to stay and try and plot our course through the lonely emptiness of deep space. Needless to say, they succeeded, and they were bloody excited. Our Earth, with its surface now a comfortable -176 degrees Celsius, is on a hopeful course to the Andromeda Galaxy. We are approaching it very fast, but we believe that we will come within orbital distance and speed of at least twenty stars. And so we were awoken. Our planet, after a century of darkness, is starting to receive light from nearby stars. The boffs say that it still is only a full moon of light, but it's a change. Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Dagny and Hank Rearden begin construction of the John Galt Line.
output:
They use Rearden Metal for the rails, which is stronger and lighter than steel. The government tries to stop them, but Dagny and Hank refuse to give up. They complete the line ahead of schedule and hold a grand opening ceremony.

The train ride is a success, and the passengers are amazed by the speed and smoothness of the journey. However, as the train approaches the Taggart Bridge, it suddenly derails and crashes into the river below. Dagny and Hank are among the survivors, but many others are killed or injured.

In the aftermath of the disaster, the government blames Rearden Metal for the crash and orders all railroads to stop using it. Dagny and Hank are devastated, but they refuse to give up. They continue to fight for their rights and for the future of America.

Meanwhile, Francisco d'Anconia reveals himself to be John Galt. He explains that he has been working behind the scenes to bring down the corrupt government and to create a new society based on reason and individualism. He invites Dagny and Hank to join him in his secret valley, where they can live free from the tyranny of the state.

Dagny and Hank agree to go with Francisco, and they leave everything behind to start a new life in the valley. There, they meet other like-minded individuals who have also rejected the collectivist ideology of the outside world. Together, they build a thriving community based on freedom and productivity.

However, the government eventually discovers the existence of the valley and sends troops to destroy it. In a final battle, Dagny and Hank lead the resistance against the government forces. They emerge victorious, but at great cost. Many of their friends and allies are killed, including Francisco d'Anconia.

In the end, Dagny and Hank realize that they cannot escape the consequences of their actions. They must face the reality of the world they have created and take responsibility for their choices. They decide to return to the outside world and rebuild society according to their own principles.

They establish a new government based on individual rights and limited power. They encourage innovation and entrepreneurship, and they promote the values of reason and self-interest. Over time, their ideas spread throughout the country and the world, leading to a new era of prosperity and progress.

As for Dagny and Hank, they find happiness together and raise a family. They continue to work towards their vision of a better world, knowing that they have made a difference and that their legacy will endure long after they are gone.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
The shrill whistle blew and everyone around me started to board the train, I walked in with them, shuffling my feet and quickly finding a seat not next to anyone. I take a quick scan of the train, watching the stream of grey individuals start to fill the empty spaces and I smile pleasantly as a man sits next to me. He smiles back, but a little uncertain, he takes another look at my direction and says "dude, why is your shirt bright, and I mean bright, pink". Looking down at my grey shirt I sigh, I asked the lady at the store where I bought it, if it looked nice on me and was n't too bright. I'm sure it wo n't be the last joke someone will play on me. Indulging the stranger I quickly explain that my life is devoid of colour and to me everything looks grey. He frowns at my answer, "are n't you really sad? it's depressing to have everything grey" "I do n't think so" I respond, "I've been this way my whole life, to me, it's normal. Hours pass and it's finally lunch time, I'm sitting in my usual cafe eating my usual sandwich when she walks in. My eye's are drawn to this beautiful women, she stands out from everyone, because she is not grey. I do n't know how to calm my mind, her dress is so bright it almost hurt's, her hair is darker then the dress but still far richer then anything that surrounds her. She looks at me and smiles, her teeth blind and her eye's are like bright spears that impale my soul. I heard the cashier make a off hand remark about her new green dress and I almost lose it. How can she be so calm and casual when talking about this colour green, her dress lights up my whole world and I felt a tear roll down my cheek. I know I ca n't wait, I ca n't live without this women, I need her colour. Getting up I make my way over, "excuse me, miss, you are the most beautiful women in the whole world, nothing I have ever seen is close to what you are to me" She smiles, but it does n't reach her eye's and my heart sinks. She makes some comment about her being flattered but she is already taken, grabs her coffee and goes. I'm now traveling home, and I watch the grey world pass by the window, I watch the blur of grey become one band of colour until I refocus my eye's. I walk home and enter my grey house and lay on my grey bed and all I can think of is that girl, who is she, where does she go, how can I get close to her, how can I keep her around me forever. Because I know now, I know now I'm sad.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Taylor decides to leave Kentucky and start a new life.
output: She moves to New York City and gets a job as a waitress. One day, while working, she meets a handsome young man named John. They hit it off immediately and soon they're dating. Taylor loves John and wants to marry him, but there's just one problem: John is a werewolf. Every full moon, he transforms into a wolf and runs wild through Central Park. Taylor doesn't care though; she loves John for who he is, not what he becomes once a month. But when John starts getting more aggressive during his transformations, Taylor begins to worry. What if he hurts someone? Or worse, what if he hurts her? She tries to talk to him about it, but he refuses to listen. Finally, after months of trying to convince him to seek help, Taylor gives up and breaks up with John. A few weeks later, she hears on the news that a woman has been attacked in Central Park by a large animal. The police believe it may have been a bear, but Taylor knows better. It was John. She rushes to the hospital to see him, but he's already gone. The doctors say he died from his injuries. Taylor is devastated. She loved John, despite his flaws. And now he's gone forever. As she leaves the hospital, she sees a group of people gathered outside. They're holding signs that read "Werewolves Are People Too!" and "We Support Our Local Werewolves." Taylor stops and stares at them for a moment before walking away. Maybe someday things will change for werewolves. But for now, she'll just have to accept that John is gone forever.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
My story started where a lot have ended these past 10 years: with a single bullet. Living in post-war Britain, death was not an uncommon sight. Everyone had at least one firearm to defend themselves, everyone had encountered gunfire in the streets, and everyone knew what it meant to live every day like it could be their last. The revolution that was supposed to end the tyranny of a dictatorship had ripped the country apart; counties had split into factions, all threatening total destruction of the others. In ten years the population was decimated, the country reduced to a crumbling mass of fallen buildings and civilians with guns. All around me was depression, death, dirt, famine. Thinking about it, it's quite hilarious, in such a depressing way. The sacks of bones, flesh and organs we saw everyday were once living, breathing, talking human beings. They had a mother, a father, a pet, a first love, they were educated, they succeeded and they failed. And they died. A single bullet can end so much. That morning, as I wandered to the local shop for some bread, clutching my rifle, my world completely ended. I had no time to react; as soon as I entered Grange Avenue a bullet burrowed into my head, smashing part of my brain, and knocking me straight out cold. I woke in a beautiful wooden chalet, bright natural light streaming through vast windows above the soft, clean bed that I rested in. My itchy, dirty clothes were replaced with beautiful white robes, soft as silk and cleaner than anything I had ever seen. I sat up, and looked around the room - it was furnished luxuriously, with beautiful gold-leaf chairs and fantastic bright works of art hanging around the room. I got up and left the room, and immediately my breath was forced from me. The crumbled grey streets of London had gone. In their place were beautiful old chalets, bright white skyscrapers, and marble streets. I could also see a very unfamiliar sight - a beautiful emerald park, littered with tall, radiant trees, ferns, and glowing coloured flowers. Clear water ran through them. All around the streets were people dressed similar to me, smiling and talking and laughing. The smog-ridden sky had been replaced with a beautiful, deep purple, but the world was light around me and the I could see the vast orange sun dipping behind the structures around the city. For the first time in ten years I smiled. That bullet took me to a better place.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Taylor's car runs out of gas in Taylorville, Illinois, where she decides on her new name.
output: She is now known as "Tay-Tay." Tay-Tay has a job interview at a local restaurant called "The Diner" which is owned by a man named Mr. Johnson. Tay-Tay gets hired and starts working there. One night while closing up, Tay-Tay hears someone outside yelling for help. It turns out to be Mr. Johnson who fell down some stairs after being attacked by two men wearing masks. Tay-Tay helps him inside and calls 911. When police arrive they find both attackers dead from gunshot wounds inflicted upon each other during their struggle over money stolen from Mr. Johnson earlier that evening. Police ask Tay-Tay if she knows anything about this incident but she denies any knowledge of what happened. Later that week, Tay-Tay receives a letter addressed to her at work saying "I know what you did". This causes Tay-Tay great concern because she doesn't want anyone finding out about her past life before moving to Taylorville. She decides to keep quiet until further notice. A few days later, Tay-Tay goes home early due to feeling ill. While lying down in bed, she hears noises coming from downstairs. Upon investigation, she finds Mr. Johnson tied up and gagged next to his safe which contains $100k cash. There are also several bags filled with cocaine scattered throughout the house. Tay-Tay quickly unties Mr. Johnson and tells him everything she saw. He thanks her profusely then asks her to leave immediately without telling anyone else. As soon as Tay-Tay leaves, Mr. Johnson calls the cops claiming he was robbed again. However, when officers show up they discover no sign of forced entry nor evidence of drugs anywhere near the scene. Instead, they arrest Tay-Tay for possession of narcotics. During questioning, Tay-Tay admits to stealing the money and drugs however claims she didn't kill either attacker. Detectives believe her story since there isn't enough physical proof linking her directly to the murders. Nevertheless, Tay-Tay spends three months in jail awaiting trial. On the day of sentencing, Tay-Tay pleads guilty to manslaughter instead of murder resulting in a five year prison sentence rather than life imprisonment. After serving half of her term, Tay-Tay moves back to Chicago where she lives happily ever after.

"This is Rockin' Rob Bower coming to you live from the huge antennae, This next song is going out to all the lovers. God damn it, is anyone out there, I need help. I am out of stuff, the vending machine is empty and the my sink filled with water, its all gone. If anyone can hear me I am at the antennae thing in the middle of the desert. God damn it help me! Rocking Rob was lucky, sort of. He was out in the desert doing peyote when the first bomb was dropped on what he could assume was Los Angeles and then some more dropped just South, possibly in San Diego and he eventually figured the glow to the East was Las Vegas. Its an odd sensation to watch the deaths millions of people thinking that it was the most beautiful thing he has ever seen. It was quite spectacular, would up vote, but now Rob may be the last person on Earth. But that's not going to last long, he is trapped hundred of miles from nowhere with no food and no water and nuclear rage fire happening all around him. Too start with Rob was n't a skinny dude. The amount of mass he dropped though in such a short amount of time was staggering. The contents of the vending machine did not last a week. It seemed the processed food just made him hungrier. When it was gone he emptied the fridge in the small kitchenette in the shack attached to the antennae. The shack had a dozen cubicles shoved into it, one sound booth and three offices all marked with some degree of management. He found and ate condiment packets. Not one thing that once had food in it was safe from being licked clean. Out of desperation he has tried to set traps for bugs and rodents. The flesh was willing but he was a complete moron when it came to woodsy stuff. At first he thought being in a radio antennae would be cool, until he discovered there was no music to be had. It was a weather station broadcasting regional updates. In a desert! That had to be the most boring job. Probably almost as boring as sitting out here waiting to die. Rocking Rob lowers his head. Its been two weeks since had any food. he has been thinking about cutting flesh from his leg and maybe getting a couple more days off the calories. He wont do it though he will hold out hope. The air outside is filled with black snow. He was afraid to walk through the dark desert looking for rescue, but now it's too late. His hand trembles under the effort to squeeze the talk button on the microphone. He whispers, "please," before the strength to leaves his body. In terms of struggle Rob did not put up much of one and maybe the world is better off for it.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
For more than thirty years, I lived my life day by day, awaiting that fateful day when I would be granted my own inner power. I saw my friends, family, strangers, all given the most precious thing in life. Lucy, my sweet dear sister, was able to fly to the heavens and back. Richard, my childhood best friend, saved hundreds of lives throughout his life, having the strength of ten men. And there I waited, for years, until my life could start, and I would transform into the real me... the powerful me. Yet, with each passing day, more people would discover their power, and I would sit waiting at night, forcing myself to sleep. My dreams were filled with possibilities, of flight and strength, and of mind and hope. But as the years passed, my dreams were less vivid. Not everyone is lucky enough to have their inner power. Some die before that beautiful gift is bestowed unto them. I thought that may happen to me. And I lived life for a while, depressed and alone. That was until I met her. Her name was Alison. She had a power, but chose not use it. She did not want to be defined by her single ability. We met during one of my travels, when I was touring the country trying to find meaning in life. I found it. I found her. From that point on, my life started. I did not care about being granted a special ability as much as I cared for her. I saw my future, a family, a wife, children. We created a beautiful life together. Alison passed away a few years ago. I had only asked her once what her power was, and she had told me it did not matter. As she was lying on her bed, slowly fading away, she told me what her inner power was. She said she was born with her power, that she had the ability to live forever, as long as she did not love. "My power was a curse, until I found you", she told me before she passed. Today is my 70th birthday. Today I have discovered what my power is. Old age has not been kind on me, and this is the most beautiful power I could have hoped for. When I remember my wife, the times we spent, they are not just memories any longer. I can feel the brisk of the air on the hill where we first met. I can smell the flowers. I can here her giggle, her breath against my cheek. In the little time I have left on this planet, I experience her love all over again.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Taylor names the child Turtle.
output: The baby's mother, who is also Taylor's mother, is named Alice. Alice is a drug addict and prostitute. She leaves Turtle with Taylor because she doesn't know how to take care of him. Taylor takes care of Turtle as if he were her own son. She feeds him, changes his diapers, and rocks him to sleep every night. One day, Alice comes back for Turtle. She tells Taylor that she wants to take him home with her. Taylor refuses to let Alice take Turtle away from her. She says that Turtle belongs with her now. Alice gets angry and starts yelling at Taylor. She calls her a bitch and threatens to hurt her if she doesn't give up Turtle. Taylor stands firm though. She won't let anyone harm Turtle. Eventually, Alice gives up and walks away. A few days later, Alice returns again. This time, she brings along two other women. They tell Taylor that they need money for drugs. If Taylor doesn't pay them, then they'll kill Turtle. Taylor agrees to pay them $1000. However, after giving them the money, they still try to steal Turtle. Taylor fights back and manages to save Turtle. Afterward, she decides to move out of town. She moves into a small apartment building near the beach. There, she raises Turtle like her own son. Years pass by and Turtle grows older. He becomes a teenager and starts going to school. During high school, he meets a girl named Sarah. They fall in love and get married. Together, they raise three kids. Their oldest daughter is named Emily. Their middle son is named Michael. And their youngest son is named David. All four of them grow up happy and healthy. Then one day, something terrible happens. Someone breaks into their house and steals everything valuable inside. Including Turtle. When Taylor finds out about this, she goes crazy. She searches everywhere looking for Turtle. Finally, she tracks down the thief. It turns out to be none other than Alice! Taylor confronts Alice and demands to know where Turtle is. Alice laughs at her and says that she sold Turtle to some rich guy. Taylor loses control and attacks Alice. She beats her unconscious. Then, she ties her up and throws her into the ocean. Later, Taylor learns that Alice drowned. Now, Taylor feels guilty about killing Alice. So, she decides to adopt another baby boy. His name is Sam. Over the next several months, Taylor raises Sam just as she raised Turtle. Eventually, Sam grows up and marries a woman named Lisa. Together, they have two sons named Jack and James. Both boys turn out to be great athletes. One day, while playing football, Jack accidentally kicks the ball too hard. It hits James right in the face. James falls down and dies instantly. Everyone blames Jack for causing James' death. Even though Jack didn't mean to do it, he feels responsible for James' death. He runs away from home and joins the army. While serving overseas, Jack gets shot multiple times. Luckily, he survives. Back at home, Taylor receives news that Jack has been wounded. She rushes to the hospital to see him. Once there, she discovers that Jack isn't dead after all. Instead, he's paralyzed from the waist down. Despite being unable to walk, Jack continues to serve in the military. Eventually, he retires and settles down with his wife and children. Meanwhile, Taylor remains single. She never remarried. Instead, she focuses on raising her grandchildren. One day, Taylor gets sick. Doctors diagnose her with cancer. She undergoes chemotherapy treatments but they don't work. Soon, she passes away peacefully surrounded by her loved ones. At her funeral, everyone cries except for Jack. He sits quietly staring off into space. Suddenly, he stands up and walks towards the casket. He kneels beside it and places his hand on top of it. Tears stream down his cheeks as he whispers, "I'm sorry."

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
It had been years since Zuccotti Park was free of barbed wire. A large concrete wall surrounded the plaza, a thousand V masks for each revolutionary lost in the fighting so far. You'd mistake Lower Manhattan for Mogadishu if it were n't for the skyscrapers that watched over the fighting. The compound for the Occupy movement was never quiet, the rattle of gunfire or the occasional pained yell as another fighter was brought back from the frontlines. The fighting had become entrenched by the 5th year. For every advance made on Central Park, there were another 50 casualties. Minesweepers had a full time job of clearing paths, just to be shot by a remote gunpod, flying over the metropolitan No Man's Land. Today however seemed different, a lull had settled over the battlefield. All that could be heard was the occasional burst of gunfire or the low hum of the Emergency Broadcast System screens throughout the city. Maybe it was the reverence for the day. 10 years since the revolution began and that first tent and sign was raised in protest. The 99 % had lost many but continued to fight. The 1 % still remained strong, and today they would deliver the final blow. The view screens flickered, the hum of the screens replaced with the anthem of a broken union. The face of the enemy flashed on screen, to address his ailing public.'My fellow Americans. It has been ten years since the seeds of chaos were sown in our great nation. Radicals gathered to destroy our honourable values and throw us into pandemonium. We tried to reason with them, we tried our best to comprehend their hatred and talk them back on the righteous path. But we failed. We showed then mercy and compassion but their hatred festered. They cast the first stone, they took the first life and they continue to poison everything they touch. They have taken our monuments to our strength and our bravery, and defile them with their vile propaganda. I for one, will stand no longer.' The screen changes, showing a diagram of Lower Manhatten. A diagram of a blast zone was overlaid on the top of it.'We must cut out the cancer which has plagued our nation for too long. Mercy has failed, so we will retaliate in the only language these vermin understand. our old metropole will be cleansed and returned to its rightful owners. Justice will be swift and final. We will take back what is rightly ours. God bless America and god have mercy on their souls.'

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Taylor and Turtle arrive in Tucson, Arizona.
output:
Taylor is surprised at how much the town has changed since she left. She remembers it being a small town with a few shops and restaurants, but now it seems like a bustling city. There are tall buildings and busy streets everywhere.

Turtle leads Taylor to a building that looks like a hotel. "This is where we're staying," he says. "I've got a room reserved for us."

They go inside and check in. The receptionist gives them a key card and tells them to enjoy their stay.

Taylor and Turtle go up to their room. It's a nice room with two beds and a bathroom. There's also a TV and a mini-fridge.

"I'm going to take a shower," Turtle says. "Why don't you watch some TV?"

"Okay," Taylor says. She turns on the TV and starts flipping through channels. She finds a news channel and watches it for a while.

After a while, Turtle comes out of the bathroom. He's wearing a towel around his waist.

"How was your shower?" Taylor asks.

"It was good," Turtle says. "I feel refreshed."

He sits down on the bed next to Taylor. "So, what do you want to do tonight?" he asks.

"I don't know," Taylor says. "What do you want to do?"

"I was thinking we could go out for dinner," Turtle says. "There's a restaurant downstairs that looks pretty good."

"That sounds good," Taylor says. "Let's go."

They get dressed and head downstairs. The restaurant is crowded, but they manage to find a table.

The waiter comes over and takes their order. Taylor orders a salad and Turtle orders a burger.

While they wait for their food, they chat about their trip so far. Taylor tells Turtle about her experience in New York City and he tells her about his experience in Los Angeles.

Their food arrives and they start eating. The food is delicious and they both enjoy it.

After they finish eating, they pay the bill and leave the restaurant. They walk around the town for a while, looking at all the new buildings and businesses.

Eventually, they make their way back to their hotel room. They sit down on the bed and turn on the TV.

"What do you want to watch?" Turtle asks.

"I don't care," Taylor says. "Whatever you want to watch is fine with me."

Turtle flips through the channels until he finds something interesting. They watch TV for a while before falling asleep.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
It was about that time again. The dawn of a new day, when humans thought to sneak up on the Deep Woods Dragon while it slept. It feared the way the sun reflected off of it' s scales, they said. It' s prismatic hide was so bright it was blinding. If taunted into the sun, they said, the Deep Woods Dragon could be defeated by the least trained of knights. The Deep Woods Dragon needed to be blinded, they said, or it would burn its attackers to ashes with rainbow-hued flames. He knew these rumors because the butterflies had told him. They were drawn to the rainbow of greens, yellows, pinks and purples of his scales, like the flowers they coveted so much. They had told him this, too, but the Dragon did not mind. The butterflies were honest, as their lives were short and beautiful. Even still, they could fly unhindered among the humans, even admired by the small humans who chased them, laughing. They told him stories while they rested on his wingtips, tail, and snout. Butterflies did not fear the Dragon, because they knew the truth. With a yawn, the Dragon shifted its weight to better perch itself on the tree' s stout branch. This tree was taller than the others, and overlooked a small, circular clearing. Without the deer, the weeds thrived, covering the dirt in a green, tangled mass. At the edge of the clearing stood a massive cave entrance, vines draped over the sides of smooth rock. The Dragon had snapped off the vines in front of the entrance, to give the illusion of occupancy. This was, after all, where the humans thought he lived. He knew these rumors because the butterflies had told him. "In an ancient cave in the middle of the wood, lives an ancient dragon who' s up to no good!" That was what the small humans like to chant as they chased the butterflies and laughed. So the Dragon tore at the vines, and scared the graceful deer from the peaceful clearing. He had enjoyed watching the deer with their young as they grazed the clearing. From up above in his favorite tree, they could not see him, and they could not fear him. Three times a day, the Dragon glided down from his tree to the old cave' s opening. There, he took a deep breath and screamed as loud as he could. He cried in both low tones and high pitches. He wailed in imitation of female humans, shouted in a voice mimicking angry male humans. The Dragon stood on top of the cave and breathed eye-searing beams of light from his mouth to the sky. It scared the birds huddled in the trees, and the noises scared the deer far from the clearing. But they also scared the humans away from the Deep Woods. He knew these rumors because the butterflies had told him. So he made his noises, made the lights, and scared the humans away. Because any humans who saw the Dragon would discover the truth. Because, when the Dragon stepped into the sunlight, they' d see how small he really was. The Deep Woods Dragon, with prismatic scales that shone in the sun and such a frightening voice, was the size of a domestic house cat. And only the butterflies knew the truth.
