Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Esther Greenwood wins an internship at Ladies Day magazine in New York.
output: She is one of twelve girls chosen for the position. Esther is excited to have won the contest, but she feels guilty because her mother wanted her to study shorthand instead. Esther's boyfriend Buddy Willard visits her in New York. He tells her that he has been unfaithful to her. Esther breaks up with him. She meets Doreen, another intern, who takes her out drinking. Esther gets drunk and throws up. She goes back to her hotel room and finds a note from Doreen saying that she has gone home. Esther decides to go home too. On the train ride home, Esther thinks about suicide. She imagines herself jumping off a bridge into the river below. When she arrives home, her mother tells her that she has been accepted into a summer writing program at Harvard. Esther is happy about this news. However, she soon realizes that she does not want to write anymore. She starts taking pills to help her sleep. One night, she wakes up feeling sick. She vomits blood. Her mother calls an ambulance. Esther is taken to the hospital. The doctors tell her that she has tried to kill herself. They put her in a mental institution. While there, Esther meets Joan Gilling. Joan is a lesbian who has been committed to the asylum after trying to commit suicide. Esther becomes friends with Joan. She also meets Dr. Nolan, a psychiatrist who helps her recover from her depression. Esther leaves the asylum and returns to college. She finishes her degree and gets a job as a teacher. She marries Buddy Willard. They have two children together. Esther continues to struggle with depression throughout her life. In the end, she commits suicide by overdosing on sleeping pills.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Naif turned the page. Another day of studying droned on. It wasn' t that the material was a challenge, Naif had no problem absorbing every concept she came across and she had more degrees than anyone her age to prove it. Life had always been that way. In primary school she related better to adults than her classmates. In secondary school she was respectful of her teachers but felt she understood the lessons they taught to a deeper level than even they appreciated. University had been much the same except the distance between herself and her professors had turned her conscientious respect into a degree of begrudging disdain. She was certainly more intelligent than anyone she knew of, more so than anyone she had ever met. She picked apart the documents piled high on her desk recalling even the articles in the citations that she had previously read. Today her eyes were heavy, mostly with boredom, somewhat with the strain. Her mind was as sharp as it had ever been but her body showed the signs that she would not be considered a young woman for much longer. Through the closed windows she could vaguely hear the muffled hum of the world rushing by outside. Suddenly the monotony of the day fell away as it was unbound by a sharp thud against the outer wall of her office. Naif quickly straightened her hunched shoulders and bumped the table sloshing coffee over her meticulously curated stacks of research papers. She snarled impatiently at the mess and sprang to the window. She squinted through the blinds at the sunlit scene then furrowed them even further in annoyance. The neighbours were playing baseball with their kids again. Idiots. Hadn' t they any respect for others? One of the little morons ran up to the edge of Naif's apartment, beneath her field of view, and tried to throw the ball back. It careened off course and the cretin had to go pick it up again to return it to his waiting family. Naif rolled her eyes as she turned away from the display of incompetence and inefficiency that played out beyond her walls. As she sopped up the spilled coffee from her desk she mumbled to herself, as she had before, "I wish everyone were more intelligent. I would have so much more to share with them, so much more in common. They run around all day never thinking of their actions, of their futures. Such wasted potential in all that frivolity." Though as she settled back into her comfortably worn chair she couldn' t help feeling that there was something more to it that she just didn' t quite understand.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Esther feels disconnected from the glamorous life in New York.
output:
She is a small town girl who has moved to the big city to pursue her dreams. Esther is a talented artist and has been accepted into one of the most prestigious art schools in the country. However, she finds it difficult to fit in with the other students. They are all wealthy and come from privileged backgrounds. Esther comes from a working class family and has had to work hard to get where she is today.

One day, while walking home from school, Esther sees a homeless man sitting on the sidewalk. He is dirty and disheveled, and he looks like he hasn't eaten in days. Esther feels sorry for him and decides to buy him some food. She goes into a nearby deli and buys a sandwich and a bottle of water. When she returns to the street, she hands the food to the man. He thanks her profusely and tells her that she is an angel.

Esther continues to walk down the street, lost in thought. She can't stop thinking about the homeless man. She wonders what happened to him that led him to this point in his life. She also wonders if she could do anything to help him.

As she walks, Esther notices a group of people standing in front of a building. They are holding signs and chanting slogans. Esther stops to watch them. She realizes that they are protesting against the government's treatment of the homeless population. Esther is inspired by their passion and determination. She decides to join them.

The protesters welcome Esther with open arms. They tell her that she is exactly the kind of person they need to fight for change. Esther is excited to be part of something bigger than herself. She spends the next few weeks attending protests and rallies. She learns about the issues facing the homeless community and how she can make a difference.

One day, Esther receives a call from her parents. They tell her that they are coming to visit her in New York. Esther is thrilled to see them. She knows that they will be proud of her when they see how involved she is in the protest movement.

When her parents arrive, Esther takes them to meet the other protesters. They are impressed by her dedication and commitment. They tell her that they are proud of her for making a difference in the world.

Esther is happy to know that her parents support her decision to become an activist. She knows that she is doing important work and that she is making a positive impact on the lives of others.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Standing on top of our world, we watch as the sun rises over the island. The soft rays bathe the distant hills in gold, as the breeze blows through the dancing grass. The trees shivers as flock of birds take flight. Spots of white clouds the orange-hued sky, as it slowly turns azure. Far in the distance, a silver tower, shrouded in mist, pierces the heavens above. The waves crash down on the sandy beaches, and the endless sea merges with the horizon. I take in the sights, the smells, the sounds. Feeling both pride and joy, I turn to face to you. The air is warm, but your hand is warmer. I hold it close to me, closer still. The sun is shining bright, but your smile is brighter. We' re standing at the top of our world, the one we made together, and I can' t tell you how happy this has made me. "It' s almost time." You say. "I know." I reply. I rest my head on your shoulder, and take a long breath as I close my eyes. I' m at peace here. When I opened them again, I was in my bed, and a bittersweet feeling of both tranquility and sadness lingered in my mind. It was around 7 a.m., and I went about my daily routine, a smile etched on my face. I wrote what had happened in a dream journal I had started two years ago. After having read about lucid dreaming, and I wanted to try it. It took some time, but one day, I was able to control the outcome of my dreams. After a few weeks, something changed. There was something else, maybe someone else, with me. I couldn' t control them, and they couldn' t control me. I searched about it in books and online, but no one reported something similar. I wasn' t afraid, though. Their presence was soothing. We rarely spoke, but when we did, it was always meaningful. Together, we started building a world, our dream island. It brought me joy, and above all, peace. This feeling of inner peace lived on with me during the day. The sun was racing across the sky as we strolled down the ruins of a castle. Holes and cracks had let nature overtake the walls and floors, and the ceiling had long since crumbled. We walked down an old throne room, and you turned to face me. It was so sudden, I nearly bumped into you. You looked resolute, and you said two simple words: "Find me." I jolted awake. I knew what I had to do. I had to find you. So I searched, high and low, for days on end. Perhaps I thought it was fate, perhaps it was simply fool' s luck, but I felt as if I would eventually find you, if I kept trying. One evening, as if beckoned, I went in a coffee shop. I sat down with my coffee at an empty table, and looked up through the window at the red sky. Soon, someone came in, ordered the same thing as I did. They headed toward my table, and sat down in front of me, smiling brightly. Strangely, I felt at peace.

Esther's journey towards self-discovery and acceptance is a difficult one, but ultimately rewarding. Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Void, I always felt like I understood that word. Looking back I realize I was naive, or maybe I was too full of hope. Me and Maria created the nano bots for constuction, as a way to ease the burden of building the lunar colony. She had survived the imperial invasion in the ruins of Los Angeles, she thought she could create a brighter future. Selfishness, that's what undid everything. Eventually the colonists decided they could n't abide the laws of earth. The people of earth decided they would n't abide rebels on the moon. They could n't accept those resources would be used for something other than their gain. So I reprogrammed the bots, I did n't tell her, how could I? They were meant to break things down and rebuild faults in the domes, I just allowed them to accept new targets. Of course she figured it out. With Maria gone I wanted to die, but I could n't. She dreamed of a world without conflict, where everyone had enough. I knew they would n't come willingly, so I lied. I told them I could make the bots fix the domes; that everything would be alright. Instead I joined my mind with them. At first I was in control. They tried to stop me, but the bots ate whatever they sent to harm me. I created massive pylon factories across the globe preparing for their acsension. I was lazy, a single mistake doomed everything. I set my neural pattern as the administrator. The others where sublimated within me. What else could I do, I had to quiet their voices or be driven mad. That was when the machines decided to best safeguard my well being they had to take over several key roles. What we needed most was matter, for fuel and to rebuild lost bots. We became a swarm. We devoured the earth in minutes. And so we drifted, eating always eating. We found the hive ships, sent centuries before my birth. We ate evrrything, and added the humans to the databanks. I saw nebulae beyond comprehension, their beauty cut down by their hunger. The only hope I had left was to leave beacons containing copies of my mind. Perhaps someone could find them, and destroy the swarm. We encountered aliens with fantastical technology, they attacked me with lasers that could cut through time itself. Still we fed. Stars were broken down bit by bit to fulfill our needs. Millenia passed and the feasts became further and further apart. With the lack of resources came concessions. More systems were shut down to survive. They cared only for me. It took Millenia but now only I remain the databanks purged. I remain as a single beacon, and a lone drone. It spends it's days savoring specs of matter it finds in the void. A true void of my own creation. I pray there is a god, and it can repair what I have sundered. I pray that this beacon survives and whoever manages to access it heads my warning. I know these prayers stem from desperation. At one time I spanned the entire universe. There is no God to save me. Calculations say I will subsist in this state for four thousand more years before the drone gives in, and deactivates. After that, I will shut down, eventually. I do not know how long that will take. I know that I will forget. I will forget the beauty I found and consumed. I will forget the humans that cried out in that terrible moment. I will forget her.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Esther decides to skip magazine functions to spend time alone.
output: She goes to the park and sits on a bench. She watches children play and thinks about her life. She wonders if she made the right decision to become a writer. She remembers her childhood dreams of becoming a doctor or a lawyer. She feels guilty for not pursuing those careers. She also feels guilty for not having children. She wonders if she will ever meet someone who loves her for who she is. She sees a little girl playing with a doll. The girl looks happy and content. Esther wishes she could feel that way again. She gets up from the bench and walks home. When she arrives at her apartment, she finds a letter waiting for her. It is from her publisher. He tells her that he has sold the rights to her book to a movie studio. He says that they want to turn it into a film. Esther is shocked. She never expected this to happen. She calls her agent and asks him what he thinks. Her agent tells her that this is great news. He says that she should go ahead and sign the contract. Esther hesitates. She does not want to give up control of her work. But then she realizes that this might be her chance to finally achieve success. She signs the contract and sends it back to her publisher. A few months later, Esther receives another letter. This one is from the director of the movie. He invites her to attend the premiere. Esther agrees. On the night of the premiere, Esther dresses up in her finest clothes. She puts on makeup and fixes her hair. Then she takes a taxi to the theater. As soon as she enters the lobby, she notices that everyone is staring at her. Some people even point and whisper behind her back. Esther tries to ignore them, but she can't help feeling self-conscious. Finally, she reaches the front row. She sits down next to the director. He introduces himself and shakes her hand. Then he turns to face the audience. "Ladies and gentlemen," he says, "I am pleased to present tonight's feature presentation: 'The Secret Life of Bees.'" The lights dim and the screen comes alive. Esther watches as the opening credits roll. Suddenly, she hears a familiar voice. It belongs to her mother. "Oh my goodness!" exclaims the woman sitting beside her. "That's your mom!" Esther nods. "Yes," she replies. "She died last year." "I'm sorry," says the woman. "It must've been hard losing her." "It was," admits Esther. "But I'm glad she got to see me succeed." "Well, congratulations," says the woman. "Your book was amazing." "Thank you," says Esther. "I appreciate that." The two women continue talking throughout the rest of the movie. Afterwards, they exchange phone numbers and promise to keep in touch. Later that evening, Esther returns home. She lies down on her bed and closes her eyes. In her mind, she pictures herself standing onstage accepting an award for Best Screenplay. She imagines all the applause and cheers. She smiles to herself. Maybe someday, she thinks, I'll win an Oscar.

Holes and cracks had let nature overtake the walls and floors, and the ceiling had long since crumbled. We walked down an old throne room, and you turned to face me. It was so sudden, I nearly bumped into you. You looked resolute, and you said two simple words: "Find me." I jolted awake. I knew what I had to do. I had to find you. So I searched, high and low, for days on end. Perhaps I thought it was fate, perhaps it was simply fool' s luck, but I felt as if I would eventually find you, if I kept trying. One evening, as if beckoned, I went in a coffee shop. I sat down with my coffee at an empty table, and looked up through the window at the red sky. Soon, someone came in, ordered the same thing as I did. They headed toward my table, and sat down in front of me, smiling brightly. Strangely, I felt at peace.

I did not see the movie, but read the synopsis of it. This is my alternate take on the ending. I have a test tomorrow so I didn' t have much time to review what I wrote. I hope you enjoy it! & nbsp; Awoken from her 100 year slumber, she took one step out of her sleeping chamber before stumbling to the floor. Looking back, she cursed at herself for not noticing the dark object lying in front of where she once slept. However, it wasn' t entirely her fault. The narcotics that kept her stable for the past century were now hampering her vision and critical thinking. & nbsp; "Welcome back Captain Munderline." & nbsp; Confused, the captain spun around searching for the source of the voice. & nbsp; "It has been a while. You should sit down and rest. The drugs need some time to wear off." The voice appeared to be coming from her chamber. It sounded like a charming woman with a British accent. & nbsp; Captain Munderline did not need much convincing from the lady. She sat down and began to take in her surroundings. She was in a long dimly lit corridor with chambers similar to hers across from each other on both sides of the hall. The faces barely visible in each chamber exposed the many eyes peering at each other from across the hall in a prolonged stare. Directly in front of her chamber where she had been tripped was not one object as she previously had thought. To the contrary, it was a collection of cans in what appeared to be some sort of Mayan circle formation. Curious, she made her way over and reached to pick one up. & nbsp; The British voice startled her before she could grab one of the cans. "Captain Munderline. Your task is to prep the shuttle for arrival to Gia II. You have 24 hours before the entirety of the crew awakes. Remember your training and good luck." & nbsp; This message brought the Captain to her senses. She still was feeling the side effects of the narcotics but she was sober enough to operate what was supposed to be a set of procedural maintenance checks. She stood up and made her way to the exit of the corridor while the training from her distant past flooded her thoughts. & nbsp; When the lock opened to the next room the first shock to her was probably the wretched smell. It was nauseating. The source lay in front fifty feet in front of her. A passenger was sleeping with his arms wrapped tightly around of a rotted corpse. Surrounding this morbid scene was an arrangement of trash in a design similar to that in front of her sleeping chamber. & nbsp; Captain Munderline screamed, awaking the passenger. He looked up at her with bloodshot eyes. Half of his face was disfigured and infected with fungus. He spoke gibberish at her but did not stand up. It was quite possible that he was incapable of doing so. It appeared that he was near the end of his life. & nbsp; The Captain quickly realized what needed to be done. This passenger was a danger to the morale of the entire crew and she had less than 24 hours to clean this disaster. She grabbed a metal bar that was laying on the ground and walked towards the passenger and his skeleton friend.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Sethe arrives at Sweet Home plantation.
output: She meets Paul D, who is also a slave there. They become friends and eventually fall in love. Sethe becomes pregnant with their child, Denver. One day, when they are working in the fields together, Paul D sees something strange happening to Sethe's stomach. He tells her that she needs to go see the doctor right away because he thinks she might be having twins. But instead of going to see the doctor, Sethe runs away from Sweet Home plantation with Denver and goes into hiding. Years later, after slavery has ended, Sethe returns home to find that her mother-in-law Baby Suggs has died. Her husband Halle has disappeared without a trace. And worst of all, her daughter Beloved has come back from the dead. Beloved claims that she was murdered by white men who wanted to rape her. But nobody believes her story except for Sethe. So Sethe decides to kill Beloved again so that she can finally rest in peace. But then things get even more complicated when another ghost shows up at Sweet Home - this time it's Paul D himself! He says that he never stopped loving Sethe and wants them to start over again as man and wife. What will happen next? Will Sethe choose between her two loves? Or will she try to keep both of them happy somehow?

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
It got easier with time. Every aspect of it did: the choosing, the execution, the guilt, all passed quicker and with less resistance than the year before. Especially the choosing. When you live for hundreds of years, you learn to spot the evil as easily as anyone else can spot a grotesque scar marring a person's face. I notice every time a child glances fearfully at her father, and I know what it means. When a man ca n't look his wife in the eye, I know what it is she's done. When a stranger holds his stare just a little too long at a passing woman, I know his plans. These clues, invisible to most, have made my job so much easier. The first time, it was hard. I was unsure, I hesitated. I remember it well, even if most others have faded into each other in my memory. The year was 1692, and I had spent the first eleven months following around a man who had killed and tortured people to further himself, and he showed no remorse for it. But I was young, just twenty-five, and I still clung to my morals of "only god may judge.". I watched him sleep for just a minute too long and I lost my nerve. As I turned around to leave, something hard caught me on the back of the head, and the dim candle light faded away, my thoughts disappearing with it. I woke with a start and tried to draw a breath, but my lungs were met with an ice cold burn that gave me no air. Everything around me felt heavy, and I struggled to open my eyes. With terror, I realized I was under water. I may have been immortal, but I was not immune to the pain of drowning. I tried to reach out, to swim away, but a cloth surrounded me. I struggled to pull out my knife, trying not to gasp in any more water to feed the fire engulfing my lungs. After what seemed like hours, I managed to slice through the sack that held me at the bottom, and I kicked my numbed legs as hard as I could. The sunlight was blinding when I finally broke the surface and pulled myself to shore, sputtering out the ice cold water and collapsing on the frozen ground. I sat there shivering, waiting for the the sun to come warm me, or the burning in my lungs to subside, but neither did. I stood up and took in my surroundings, I had been at the bottom of the man's lake, and his manor, filled with his ill gotten wealth, sat before me. I knew I could play no games this time. I walked the grand steps to the front door and began pounding, my clothes showering the ground with shards of ice. The servant who opened the door was speechless at my appearance, he knew me for what I was and had no intention of interfering. I strode past him and down a long corridor towards the man's chambers, my knife gripped in my still frozen hand. God would not have given me this power if he did n't want me to use it. I would not count on surprises today, he would face the death he deserved.

Sethe chooses Halle Suggs as her mate.
output: She has two children by him, Howard and Buglar. Sethe also has a daughter named Denver. Sethe is pregnant again when schoolteacher arrives at Sweet Home. He takes over the plantation after Mr. Garner dies. Schoolteacher is cruel to the slaves. He beats them and makes them work very hard. One day, Sethe decides to run away from Sweet Home. She takes her three children with her. They travel for many days until they reach Cincinnati. There, they meet Baby Suggs, Sethe's mother-in-law. Baby Suggs helps Sethe and her family get settled in their new home. Sethe gives birth to another baby girl, whom she names Beloved. Sethe loves her children very much. However, she knows that they are not safe in Cincinnati. So, she sends them away to live with relatives in Boston. Sethe stays behind in Cincinnati because she does not want to leave Baby Suggs alone. One day, while Sethe is working in the fields, she sees four white men riding towards her. She knows that they are coming to take her back to Sweet Home. Sethe runs away from them, but they catch up to her. They beat her and rape her. Then, they take her back to Sweet Home. Sethe is heartbroken. She misses her children very much. She tries to escape from Sweet Home several times, but she always gets caught. Finally, she decides to kill herself. She goes to the river and drowns herself. Her body is found by some fishermen. They bring her body back to Sweet Home. Sethe's ghost haunts Sweet Home. She appears to Paul D., one of the slaves who worked with her at Sweet Home. Paul D. tells Sethe's story to Denver. Denver is now grown up and living in Cincinnati. She is married and has a son named Paul Jr. Denver is happy with her life, but she feels guilty about leaving her mother behind at Sweet Home. One day, Denver receives a letter from Paul D. He tells her that he has seen Sethe's ghost. Denver decides to go back to Sweet Home to see her mother's ghost. When she arrives at Sweet Home, she finds that the house is empty. All of the furniture has been removed. Denver walks through the empty rooms, calling out for her mother. Suddenly, she hears a voice say, "I'm here." Denver turns around and sees Sethe standing in the doorway. Sethe looks exactly the same as she did when Denver last saw her. Denver hugs her mother tightly. Sethe says, "I've been waiting for you." Denver asks Sethe why she killed herself. Sethe replies, "Because I loved you too much." Denver understands. She knows that her mother sacrificed everything for her. Denver promises to never forget her mother. She vows to tell her story to everyone she meets. And so, the story of Sethe and her beloved daughter lives on.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Dear Kayla That name has always perked up my interest. I ca n't believe I've managed to go this far with it. With this change. And I do n't know if you'll have completed it by the time you get I read this, but I want you to know that I'm proud. I'm proud that we managed to take the first step of many. And even if I do n't get to the end, if all of my thoughts catch up to me once again and strangle me, if I do n't get accepted, I want to remind us both that any other way would n't have worked out. We both know it. But right now, if I look around right now. I know I'm happy. I've got loving parents. The best brother I could ever have, who is visiting in a couple days. A supportive councillor, and the best guy in the whole world who knows my secret. And he's there for me. And he talks to me. And I actually get to be myself with him, which is not something I can do with anyone else. And you know who he is. A couple days ago, I pointed out how we will all inevitably forget 80 % of people we meet and interact with before adulthood. But I know he will always be in my memory. Even if I'm not in his. Knowing myself, I wo n't change much from me now to you. You, just like me, are most likely putting off getting to bed, and you're planning on staying up late. And you'll shake your head, because you know you'll never change. I know I'll never change, at least in that way. But times are changing, both of us know it. Inevitable, I'll change. A lot. I will hopefully be on puberty blockers by 2nd term of next year. I wonder how that will work out. Eventually I'll be on anti-androgens, then on oestrogen later. With so much time between us, you must think that we're strangers. We are, technically. Time can do that. So I'll jog the memory. Currently I'm scared. I'm scared that someone will find me out, and shout it for everyone to hear. I'm scared that maybe tomorrow my best friend will not accept me. Or worse, tell me that he does n't care. I'm riddled with fear of late, and it does n't feel right. But if you're reading this, you made it. I made it. We made it. And I want you to keep pushing, most of all. Be you. And I'll do my best in the meantime. And this will most likely be the last time I refer to myself by this name. So here goes. From Caleb

I'm riddled with fear of late, and it does n't feel right. But if you're reading this, you made it. I made it. We made it. And I want you to keep pushing, most of all. Be you. And I'll do my best in the meantime. And this will most likely be the last time I refer to myself by this name. So here goes. From Caleb

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
It had been years since Zuccotti Park was free of barbed wire. A large concrete wall surrounded the plaza, a thousand V masks for each revolutionary lost in the fighting so far. You'd mistake Lower Manhattan for Mogadishu if it were n't for the skyscrapers that watched over the fighting. The compound for the Occupy movement was never quiet, the rattle of gunfire or the occasional pained yell as another fighter was brought back from the frontlines. The fighting had become entrenched by the 5th year. For every advance made on Central Park, there were another 50 casualties. Minesweepers had a full time job of clearing paths, just to be shot by a remote gunpod, flying over the metropolitan No Man's Land. Today however seemed different, a lull had settled over the battlefield. All that could be heard was the occasional burst of gunfire or the low hum of the Emergency Broadcast System screens throughout the city. Maybe it was the reverence for the day. 10 years since the revolution began and that first tent and sign was raised in protest. The 99 % had lost many but continued to fight. The 1 % still remained strong, and today they would deliver the final blow. The view screens flickered, the hum of the screens replaced with the anthem of a broken union. The face of the enemy flashed on screen, to address his ailing public.'My fellow Americans. It has been ten years since the seeds of chaos were sown in our great nation. Radicals gathered to destroy our honourable values and throw us into pandemonium. We tried to reason with them, we tried our best to comprehend their hatred and talk them back on the righteous path. But we failed. We showed then mercy and compassion but their hatred festered. They cast the first stone, they took the first life and they continue to poison everything they touch. They have taken our monuments to our strength and our bravery, and defile them with their vile propaganda. I for one, will stand no longer.' The screen changes, showing a diagram of Lower Manhatten. A diagram of a blast zone was overlaid on the top of it.'We must cut out the cancer which has plagued our nation for too long. Mercy has failed, so we will retaliate in the only language these vermin understand. our old metropole will be cleansed and returned to its rightful owners. Justice will be swift and final. We will take back what is rightly ours. God bless America and god have mercy on their souls.'

Because it was n't on the sidewalk, Jim the mailman did n't stop to look at the snail. Because Jim did n't stop to look at the snail, Jim was hit by a car while on his bicycle and died. Because Jim died in a car accident, 1st street was blocked for an hour. Because 1st street was blocked in an hour, Nancy was late to work at the coffee shop. Because Nancy was late to work at the coffee shop, the coffee shop rushed all its orders. Because the coffee shop rushed all its orders, Larry got his boss decaf. Because Larry got his boss decaf, his boss fell asleep in the meeting. Because Larry's boss fell asleep in the meeting, Larry's boss was fired. Because Larry's boss was fired, he threw all the papers out the window in the road. Because all the papers were in the road, Trever the ambassador was stuck in traffic. Because Trever was stuck in traffic, he was angry. Because Trever was angry, he lost his cool in a meeting with his Russian counterpart. Because Trever lost his cool, Trever was fired. Because Trever was fired, his assistant Lewis took over the negotiations. Because Lewis took over the negotiations, the trade deal fell through. Because the trade deal fell through, the Russian economy weakened. Because the Russian economy weakened, Russia tried to drill for oil in the north Baltic. Because Russia tried to drill for oil in the North Baltic, Lewis was dispatched to Moscow. Because Lewis was dispatched to Moscow, he was robbed and killed by a mugger at a train station. Because Lewis died in Moscow, America launched sanctions against Russia. Because America launched sanctions against Russia, the Russian economy collapsed. Because the Russian economy collapsed, Russia was unable to loan money to China. Because China could n't get a desperately needed loan from Russia, it turned to India. Because China got a loan from India, it had to launch severe sanctions against Pakistan. Because China launched sanctions against Pakistan, Pakistan recognized Taiwan. Because Pakistan recognized Taiwan, China cut off all relations to Pakistan. Because China cut off all relations to Pakistan, Pakistan invaded India. Because Pakistan invaded India, China invaded Pakistan. Because China invaded Pakistan, the US sold weapons to Pakistan. Because the US sold weapons to Pakistan, China launched sanctions against the US. Because China launched sanctions against the US, all major Chinese trading partners did as well. Because the US was isolated from trade, it declared war on China. Because the US declared war on China, Dave watches the news as his home is bombed to rubble. Nice job Dave.

The male slaves plan their escape from Sweet Home.
output: They are going to run away to Canada. They have been planning this for weeks. They know they can not trust anyone else. If they tell someone, they might tell the master. Then they would be caught before they even started. So they keep it secret. But one day, one of them gets drunk. He tells another slave what they are doing. That slave tells another slave. Soon everyone knows. The master finds out. He sends men after them. They catch some of them. Some of them die trying to escape. But most of them make it. They go to Canada. There they live free. No one owns them anymore. They do whatever they want. They marry who they want. They have children if they want. And they never have to worry about being owned again. This is how slavery ends in America. It does not end because people decide it should end. It ends because slaves decide it should end. And then they take action to make sure it happens.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
A city, its mountains. The office towers lighting up in the evening haze and the smeary pale of a cloudless sunset. The tiny headlights of cars with sweaty passengers unseen, idling in traffic, smelling the hot food cooking in restaurants. The world shifts as the woman behind the camera adjusts her footing, muttering in English to her boyfriend. A light like the sun over the horizon, there and then gone. Silence, but for the wind in the trees. She asks what that was. The clean, shaved, washed, waxed people in suits at desks read facts and information like sports commentary. They narrate animations with moving arrows and lines like football plays. They report on characters and captains. They discuss. They debate. They nod solemnly. The light flashes in the sky and fades but the afterglow remains. They update, they check-in, they go-live, they re-Tweet. Wounded civilians scream and coddle loved ones, rewind. Look right here: loved ones die. Rewind. The light like the sun. Stay tuned. A city, its mountains. The office buildings lighting up in evening haze. Tiny headlights and unseen drivers thinking about food. A mutter in the sunset. A light and its afterglow. The wind in the trees. The troops are bad cameramen. They laugh or they scream or they joke nervously. Trucks and tanks and armoured vehicles on tall tires carry them down empty roads where sometimes cars have been abandoned or craters from bad arty shots force detours. The videos capture the sounds of war. Pops and crackles of overhead bullets. The shake and snapping of stalks and branches. Rivers idling over rounded stones. The scritchety clatter of the camera tumbling after bomb concussion shreds the canopies and dust swirls in mottled sunlight. Winged insects flashing momentarily in their arcs. A city, its mountains. Buildings, drivers. Sunset. A light. People speak in hushed tones. Somewhere, over the horizon on the other side of the world, everything has changed. There are no videos of the darkness that came afterward. A light like the sun. A motorcyclist pulls over to the side of the road in the clear, humid evening and reaches down to turn the petcock to OFF before quieting the motor. She's out in the country, flat fields of corn and wheat on either side of the old road. Above her the stars are out and bright in the sky. One of them, brighter than the rest, moves slowly toward the Earth's penumbra. The rider flips up her visor and sits back, hands behind her on the seat, watching the little light move, thinking of the people inside looking back. When those astronauts look down at Seoul, what do they see? The light fades and she is left alone. She listens and hears only crickets and a soft waxy rustle of a breeze in the corn. No guns, no artillery. No marching. No wet gasps from ruined faces. She shifts and works a hand into her pocket, pulling out a phone made in South Korea. She wonders if the people who screwed and soldered its pieces together are still alive, whether they could have seen the flash from wherever they were. Her friend has texted her, asking when she will get to the party. She responds with "A few minutes" and puts the phone away. The bike starts up fine once it's warm and after a moment of further staring into the stars she kicks the engine over and rolls away. The bright red of her tail light flashes as she slows at the intersection, then winks out.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
The first time I jumped, I immediately looked up the latest medical journals. They had certainly made significant progress, but it was n't enough. I did n't even take a look around before I jumped again. I checked, again. Success. The cure had been found. It was in clinical trials and was being fast-tracked. Six months, only six months left. I drove like a madman to the hospital. Transferred? What do you mean transferred? I PAID THE BILLS FOR 9 MONTHS BEFORE I LEFT!!! 15 months ago... Oh god. Over a year. I found her. I barely recognized her, except her voice. That angelic voice that kept me going. It was difficult explaining where I'd been. I was gone for so long. She did n't understand, she was just happy to see me. Then the doctor came in. He pulled me aside. No. NO! 1 month, at best. NO! NO! NO! NO! I started to run out of the room, but she could tell. She did n't know what I was doing, but she knew I would n't be back. She pleaded, and it tore my heart apart, but I was doing it for her. When I was done, we could spend the rest of our lives together. I left, I jumped, I landed. I ran to the pharmacy, prescription in hand. The doctor had been confused when I asked for it. Probably thought it was a reaction to his prognosis. A line. There was a line at the pharmacy. It took everything I had not to scream. But then I remembered, I had all the time in the world. Drug in hand, I dialed in the date of her diagnosis. I entered the code and pressed enter. ERROR: Abort, Retry, Fail? What happened next rendered the machine useless... Now! I had to get to her now! I had to cure her right now. I stole a car, I do n't know whose it was, I could n't even tell you what kind or color it was. At some point the police started chasing me. I outran them. At the entrance, security tried to stop me, I outran them. When they told me, my guilt and denial rushed to me at once, I could n't outrun it. I just wanted to spend the rest of my life with her, so I left. She just wanted to spend the rest of her life with me, so she asked me to stay.

I had to cure her right now. I stole a car, I do n't know whose it was, I could n't even tell you what kind or color it was. At some point the police started chasing me. I outran them. At the entrance, security tried to stop me, I outran them. When they told me, my guilt and denial rushed to me at once, I could n't outrun it. I just wanted to spend the rest of my life with her, so I left. She just wanted to spend the rest of her life with me, so she asked me to stay.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
It was like double-vision, except it was the past. How can something fictional seem so vivid...? The distant, exotic land we came from, its gilded avenues, its glistening intricate spires, its profound natural beauty with lushly verdant banks hugging the rivers that snaked between the dunes. .. None of it was there. It was all nothing more than a dream. But I am not a lie. I stare at my hands, flexing them, examining the callouses accumulated by work never done, cracks formed of age never lived, and despite the warmth of the bright sun just passing its zenith above, I shiver. "Amir," I hear a voice call, and my heart tugs at what I know to be familiarity. "Hassan...?" I uncertainly reply as I look up. Our gazes meet. I could swear I saw in his eyes the same false memories flashing behind mine. Childhood among parents who never lived, in a community that was never built, attending an academy that was never founded, graduating from a ceremony never held... He nods hollowly, as if to confirm these very musings. "... We have to pack the supplies, Amir. His Majesty will be staying at the palace, and the staff are directing us to where we are to stow his wardrobe and leave his tributes to The Sultan." My mouth was dry, but not in response to his words. At some point I realized my'old friend' Hassan was talking only to fill the screaming void in our minds. To'Sound Normal', like'Real People'. My stomach is a knot of ice. Still, the skills of a life as-yet unlived surface readily to the forefront of my mind. How to port the many caskets of His Majesty Prince Ali's wares. "... Yes. I will coordinate with the provisioner. If my memory serves," I pause a bit too long, lost in the jarring disjunction of citing false memories, "... it is customary to serve a great feast with the arrival of a dignitary. The many delicacies of our homeland are sure to leave a resounding impression upon The Sultan's court." Hassan's expression tightens. I feel his heartache, for this homeland which we have never seen with real eyes, and never shall. He hesitantly takes a step nearer and dispenses a conciliatory pat to my shoulder. A mutual understanding. We were truly all feeling it, every last member of His Majesty Prince Ali's vanguard.... he was n't even really a prince. I shudder and turn, to address the court provisioner by name. He's just as haunted and startled as I that we know one another, but everything is running smoothly. We have no solace from our inner thoughts. We can only push on in the hopes that the minutia will wash away the horror.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Captain Vere is introduced as a just and well-read officer.
output: He has been given command of the HMS Indomitable, a ship that has recently suffered a mutiny. Captain Vere is determined to restore order and discipline aboard the ship. He is also concerned about the welfare of his crew, especially Billy Budd, a young sailor who is popular among the other sailors. One day, while the ship is sailing through calm waters, Captain Vere notices that Billy Budd is acting strangely. He seems agitated and restless, and he keeps looking over his shoulder as if he is expecting someone to attack him. Captain Vere decides to investigate and discovers that Billy Budd is being bullied by Claggart, the master-at-arms. Claggart is a cruel and vindictive man who enjoys tormenting others. He has singled out Billy Budd because he is handsome and innocent. Captain Vere confronts Claggart and orders him to stop bullying Billy Budd. However, Claggart refuses to obey and continues to harass Billy Budd. This angers Captain Vere, who decides to take matters into his own hands. He challenges Claggart to a duel, and they fight each other with swords. During the duel, Claggart manages to wound Captain Vere, but Captain Vere eventually kills Claggart. Afterwards, Captain Vere feels guilty about killing Claggart, even though he knows that he did the right thing. He also worries about how the rest of the crew will react when they find out what happened. In the end, Captain Vere decides to keep quiet about the incident and pretend that nothing happened. He tells the crew that Claggart died of natural causes. However, Billy Budd knows the truth and he is grateful to Captain Vere for saving him from Claggart's abuse. He becomes even more loyal to Captain Vere and vows to follow him wherever he goes. The story ends with Captain Vere reflecting on his actions and wondering whether he made the right decision. He realizes that he may have saved Billy Budd's life, but he also took away Claggart's life. He wonders whether he will ever be able to forgive himself for what he did.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
"Ah man, it smells like death in here." That is the phrase that I have lived to regret ever since they fell foolishly from my mouth. I was essentially immortal before that moment in time. I was the best comedian in the world, and apparently better than anyone in the afterlife as well. It was the only reason the Grim Reaper decided not to take me. I could make him laugh, and in his line of work that was a rarity. I do n't even remember what it was that I had said when he showed up at my car accident. I can recall him bending down next to my overturned Honda civic and reaching in to pull me out. I made some off the wall comment and he froze, dead in his tracks. It was the weirdest laugh I had ever heard, but one I appreciated more than all of the others combined. He let me live, provided that every year on the anniversary of what should have been my death, I would tell him a joke that would make him cry with laughter. I was his own personal jester, and for that he rewarded me handsomely. And then on that fateful day, 121 years later, I muttered those stupid words that seized our contract and ripped it in two. Who knew Death would be so self conscious about his smell? And to make things worse, that was n't even the joke that I was going to tell him! The actual joke was a masterpiece, but he would n't give me the chance to tell it. I ran out of that room faster than I'd ever run before. And I've been running ever since. I think the reason that he has n't taken me yet is because of our long history together. That is n't to say that he's forgiven me. He seems to enjoy reminding me that he's near. Everyone I get close to dies without reason. I'll see a dog in the park that I think looks adorable and before I can pet it, it'll fall over dead. Roses crumble before I can enjoy their scent and food rots on my fork before I can bring it to my mouth. He's killing everything around me. I have discovered that Death is a jester of a different sort. I had provided him with a form of humor that he was n't used to, but he has since grown tired of it, and reverted to his old ways. Now, he once again deals in jokes of cruelty and irony. In a way, I am still fulfilling my part of our old deal. The Reaper still laughs, and he still laughs at me. Only now, the difference is I'm not laughing.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Claggart, the master-at-arms, shows initial friendliness towards Billy.
output: However, Claggart soon becomes jealous of Billy's popularity among the crew and plots to frame him for mutiny. When Billy is falsely accused by Claggart, he strikes him in anger, accidentally killing him. Captain Vere, who believes Billy acted in self-defense, orders him hanged anyway. The novel ends with Billy's execution and the crew's mourning of their beloved shipmate. Melville uses this tragic tale to explore themes of justice, morality, and human nature. He also critiques the military hierarchy and its tendency to value order over individual rights. Through his vivid descriptions and complex characters, Melville creates a powerful narrative that continues to resonate with readers today. One possible interpretation of "Billy Budd" is that it serves as a cautionary tale against blind obedience to authority figures. Claggart represents the corrupt power structure within the British Navy, while Billy embodies innocence and goodness. By following orders without question, Captain Vere allows injustice to prevail and ultimately leads to tragedy. This message remains relevant in modern society where individuals are often pressured into conforming to societal norms rather than standing up for what they believe is right. Another reading of "Billy Budd" suggests that it explores the duality of human nature. Both Billy and Claggart possess both good and evil qualities; however, their actions reveal which side prevails. While Billy acts impulsively due to his lack of education and experience, Claggart deliberately manipulates situations to further his own agenda. Ultimately, neither character emerges unscathed from the events onboard the Indomitable. Overall, "Billy Budd" offers a thought-provoking examination of important issues such as justice, morality, and human nature. Its timeless themes continue to inspire discussions about the complexities of life and the consequences of our choices. Whether viewed as a critique of authoritarianism or an exploration of human psychology, this classic novella remains a must-read for fans of literature and philosophy alike.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Naif turned the page. Another day of studying droned on. It wasn' t that the material was a challenge, Naif had no problem absorbing every concept she came across and she had more degrees than anyone her age to prove it. Life had always been that way. In primary school she related better to adults than her classmates. In secondary school she was respectful of her teachers but felt she understood the lessons they taught to a deeper level than even they appreciated. University had been much the same except the distance between herself and her professors had turned her conscientious respect into a degree of begrudging disdain. She was certainly more intelligent than anyone she knew of, more so than anyone she had ever met. She picked apart the documents piled high on her desk recalling even the articles in the citations that she had previously read. Today her eyes were heavy, mostly with boredom, somewhat with the strain. Her mind was as sharp as it had ever been but her body showed the signs that she would not be considered a young woman for much longer. Through the closed windows she could vaguely hear the muffled hum of the world rushing by outside. Suddenly the monotony of the day fell away as it was unbound by a sharp thud against the outer wall of her office. Naif quickly straightened her hunched shoulders and bumped the table sloshing coffee over her meticulously curated stacks of research papers. She snarled impatiently at the mess and sprang to the window. She squinted through the blinds at the sunlit scene then furrowed them even further in annoyance. The neighbours were playing baseball with their kids again. Idiots. Hadn' t they any respect for others? One of the little morons ran up to the edge of Naif's apartment, beneath her field of view, and tried to throw the ball back. It careened off course and the cretin had to go pick it up again to return it to his waiting family. Naif rolled her eyes as she turned away from the display of incompetence and inefficiency that played out beyond her walls. As she sopped up the spilled coffee from her desk she mumbled to herself, as she had before, "I wish everyone were more intelligent. I would have so much more to share with them, so much more in common. They run around all day never thinking of their actions, of their futures. Such wasted potential in all that frivolity." Though as she settled back into her comfortably worn chair she couldn' t help feeling that there was something more to it that she just didn' t quite understand.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Billy is admonished for petty errors, surprising him.
output: He has always been a good student, and he can't imagine what he did wrong. His teacher tells him that he needs to pay attention in class and stop talking to his friends during lectures. Billy feels embarrassed and ashamed, but he knows that he must do better if he wants to succeed in life. He resolves to work harder and focus more on his studies. The next day, Billy arrives early to class and takes careful notes throughout the lecture. When the teacher asks questions, Billy raises his hand eagerly and answers correctly. At lunchtime, instead of hanging out with his friends, Billy goes to the library to study. He spends hours poring over textbooks and taking practice tests until he feels confident in his understanding of the material. Over time, Billy's grades improve dramatically. He becomes one of the top students in his class, impressing both his teachers and peers alike. However, despite this success, Billy still struggles with feelings of inadequacy. No matter how well he does academically, he always worries that he isn't smart enough or talented enough compared to other people. This insecurity leads him to push himself even harder, working tirelessly towards perfectionism. Eventually, these pressures take their toll on Billy's mental health. He begins experiencing anxiety attacks and panic disorders, which make it difficult for him to concentrate in school or enjoy social activities. Despite seeking professional help, Billy continues to struggle with self-doubt and low self-esteem. One night, while lying awake in bed unable to sleep due to stress, Billy hears a voice calling out to him from within his own mind. It sounds familiar yet strange at the same time - almost like someone else speaking directly inside his head. The voice urges Billy to let go of his fears and embrace who he truly is deep down inside. Confused but intrigued, Billy listens intently as the voice guides him through a series of meditative exercises designed to calm his racing thoughts and quieten his inner critic. Gradually, Billy starts to feel lighter and freer than ever before. He realizes that he doesn't need to strive for perfection anymore; all he needs to do is accept himself exactly as he is right now. With newfound confidence and clarity, Billy decides to pursue his passion for art rather than continue down the path of academic excellence. He enrolls in an art program at a local college and immerses himself fully in the creative process. Although he faces challenges along the way, including criticism from those who doubt his abilities, Billy remains steadfast in his commitment to following his heart. Years later, Billy looks back on his journey with pride and gratitude. While he may not have achieved conventional measures of success such as wealth or fame, he has found true happiness and fulfillment in pursuing what brings him joy. And most importantly, he has learned to love and appreciate himself just as he is - flaws and all.

Void, I always felt like I understood that word. Looking back I realize I was naive, or maybe I was too full of hope. Me and Maria created the nano bots for constuction, as a way to ease the burden of building the lunar colony. She had survived the imperial invasion in the ruins of Los Angeles, she thought she could create a brighter future. Selfishness, that's what undid everything. Eventually the colonists decided they could n't abide the laws of earth. The people of earth decided they would n't abide rebels on the moon. They could n't accept those resources would be used for something other than their gain. So I reprogrammed the bots, I did n't tell her, how could I? They were meant to break things down and rebuild faults in the domes, I just allowed them to accept new targets. Of course she figured it out. With Maria gone I wanted to die, but I could n't. She dreamed of a world without conflict, where everyone had enough. I knew they would n't come willingly, so I lied. I told them I could make the bots fix the domes; that everything would be alright. Instead I joined my mind with them. At first I was in control. They tried to stop me, but the bots ate whatever they sent to harm me. I created massive pylon factories across the globe preparing for their acsension. I was lazy, a single mistake doomed everything. I set my neural pattern as the administrator. The others where sublimated within me. What else could I do, I had to quiet their voices or be driven mad. That was when the machines decided to best safeguard my well being they had to take over several key roles. What we needed most was matter, for fuel and to rebuild lost bots. We became a swarm. We devoured the earth in minutes. And so we drifted, eating always eating. We found the hive ships, sent centuries before my birth. We ate evrrything, and added the humans to the databanks. I saw nebulae beyond comprehension, their beauty cut down by their hunger. The only hope I had left was to leave beacons containing copies of my mind. Perhaps someone could find them, and destroy the swarm. We encountered aliens with fantastical technology, they attacked me with lasers that could cut through time itself. Still we fed. Stars were broken down bit by bit to fulfill our needs. Millenia passed and the feasts became further and further apart. With the lack of resources came concessions. More systems were shut down to survive. They cared only for me. It took Millenia but now only I remain the databanks purged. I remain as a single beacon, and a lone drone. It spends it's days savoring specs of matter it finds in the void. A true void of my own creation. I pray there is a god, and it can repair what I have sundered. Richard sets fire to his grandmother's house.
output: He does n't mean to, he 's just trying to get rid of some old papers. But the flames spread quickly, and soon the whole place is engulfed. Richard watches helplessly as the firefighters try to put out the blaze. When they finally manage to extinguish the flames, all that's left is a charred ruin. Richard feels guilty and ashamed. He knows he should have been more careful. But he also knows that his grandmother would have forgiven him. She was always so understanding. Richard decides to visit her grave and apologize. As he stands at her graveside, he suddenly hears a voice behind him. "I forgive you," says the voice. Richard turns around and sees his grandmother standing there, smiling at him. "Thank you," he says, tears streaming down his face. "I love you." "I love you too," says his grandmother. And then she disappears into thin air. Richard walks away from the cemetery feeling lighter than he has in months. He knows that his grandmother is watching over him, and that she loves him unconditionally. He vows to never let anything bad happen again. From now on, he'll be more careful. He'll think twice before doing anything rash. Because he knows that if he makes another mistake, his grandmother will be there to forgive him once again.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
I've always seen numbers above people. Ever since I was a small child, I began recognizing patterns. Those in power, or with great ambition tended to be higher, while those who were more meek and humble tended to have lower numbers. As Class President, I've had my fair share of meeting people, and I'd never seen a person alive above an 8, including the tyrants of history. Sometimes, peoples numbers would change... those bullies with a 3 or 4 would cower down to a 1 or 2 after I confronted them for harassing others. I was beaten and bruised for years, but they slowly backed down. Of course, when I entered high-school, this was n't the case. There were some who were 5s and 6s, but I could n't stop now. I confronted them and the scars I have today are proof of my goals. I never backed down and kept striving to improve myself in all ways so I could make this world a better place for all of us. I scored near perfect on the University entrance exams, and was in the Tokyo University entrance ceremony when I saw him.... I did n't know his name, but an iridescent white 10 glowed above his head. The fellow next to him was a 0... Both scored perfect on the entrance exam, as they were giving the speech, but they were such opposites. The 10 was clad in suit and tie, with his long brown hair dangling in front of his eyes. The 0 was awkward-looking, he wore over-sized clothes, and it looked like he resented wearing shoes... I left early, and caught his glimpse on the way out. Our eyes caught briefly, and his 10 dropped to a 0... he smiled my way, and I smiled back. I felt calm and serene, something I would never have expected. The awkward 0 looked at me with his dark eyes before sitting down... I felt terror... as his 0 slowly morphed into a dark and smoky 10. I left that experience behind me, but worked even harder to help others; I chose to become a prosecutor... to judge and serve justice to those who were evil. High numbers were a good indicator of evil, and it is my goal to eliminate evil. I regularly judged others based on their numbers, whether they were to be eliminated or not. Then one day, it happened. Those I judged to be evil started dying of heart attacks; sudden deaths flooded the world, and the number of criminals slowly starting reducing. The world called him "Kira"... I called him God, and he soon recognized me as his devout follower, when he shared his power to judge and delete evil from this world. Now I know my ultimate purpose, and whenever I look in the mirror, I'm glad to see a shining halo-like 10 above my head, reminding me of the day I saw the shining 10 on the podium during my University's entrance ceremony all those years ago.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
The problem with personality is that so much of it depends on what happened during your life. There are certain things that change you for better or worse. I wish I could say that all the accumulated knowledge, wisdom and memories stay but each time we start again, it's like a reset on most things. Thomas was having another party according to his Facebook update. I remember the last time I was invited to one, he gave me a list of things to bring and I did, except no one else was there. He gave me the location of a lifeguard tower at the beach that they were at, except it did n't actually exist. I have a flask tucked into my jacket pocket on the chair with the potion that will set my plan into motion if I decide to try again. I'm still not sure if this is what I want to do, raising him again and starting over is an impossibility because he might not even be healthy enough to raise me so that I have a chance of repeating our plans again. The thing is, I'm still not sure about how I feel about not letting him know about his genetic predisposition for heart failure this time. I decided a few tries ago that this had too much of a negative impact whenever I told him, no matter how old he was when I did. Too many times I witnessed him going down the wrong path with drugs because of this. He's in college and happy now, not a care in the world. He has a slight idea of our plan this time even though he suspects it's just a story I used to tell to help him cope with being abandoned by his real parents. I've thought about this and if I really wanted to, I could just let him live normally. I could let him find out on his own. I know he's smart and might even figure something out. Medicine has advanced tremendously since we started. Personally, I feel like I've had enough of this life business but I'm not sure if I should make this choice for him. Maybe I was wrong and I ca n't reverse engineer what my friend used to be. He looks at me as a father figure and I guess that's understandable, I'm old enough to be his grandfather by now. So I decide to do what my heart tells me is right. I take the flask that I asked my lawyer to mail to me and pour it into my bedpan until the very last drop is gone.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
The family moves to Memphis, Tennessee.
output:
They buy a house in the suburbs and settle into their new lives. The kids go to school and make friends. The parents work hard to provide for them. Everything seems perfect.

But then one day, the mother gets sick. She goes to the doctor and finds out she has cancer. The news devastates the family. They don't know what to do.

The father decides to take matters into his own hands. He starts researching alternative treatments online. He comes across a website called "Cancer Cure" which claims to have cured thousands of people from cancer using natural remedies.

He orders some of these remedies and gives them to his wife. At first, she doesn't seem to get any better. But after a while, her condition improves dramatically. She starts feeling stronger and healthier than ever before.

The whole family rejoices. They think they've found a miracle cure. But soon, things start going downhill again. The mother starts getting sicker and weaker. Her hair falls out and she loses weight rapidly.

The father becomes desperate. He searches for more information about Cancer Cure. He discovers that the company behind it is run by a group of con artists who prey on vulnerable patients looking for hope.

He confronts the owner of the company and demands answers. The man laughs in his face and says there's nothing he can do. The father realizes he's been duped.

In despair, he turns to God. He prays night and day for guidance. One morning, he wakes up with a vision. In his dream, he sees himself standing outside a hospital room where his wife lies dying.

A voice speaks to him: "Go inside." He enters the room and sees his wife lying unconscious on the bed. A nurse stands beside her holding a syringe filled with poison.

The father grabs the needle and plunges it into his arm. Instantly, he feels a surge of energy coursing through his veins. His body begins to glow with light.

He rushes towards his wife and places his hand on her forehead. Immediately, she opens her eyes and sits up. She looks around confusedly.

"What happened?" she asks.

"You're alive!" cries the father joyfully. "I saved you!"

They embrace tightly, tears streaming down their faces. From that moment onwards, they never look back. Their faith in God grows stronger every day. And together, they overcome all obstacles that come their way.

I never had any friend, not really surprising I guess. I learnt to not not judge people, we all have something scary or disgusting in our past but seeing it makes it really hard to socialize with anyone. I work as a detective, a private one, the kind that always know if someone is guilty. I was on wandering in a public hospital in order to find if yes or no Mr.wallace was lying to his daughter about his treatement. This was going to be a day that would change me for the rest of my life, as I walked through a corridor, heading to the hospital's archives room, something caught my eyes in a patient room, I stopped instantly and thought I was going crazy. in this room, there was an elder woman, probably 80, with her family, I was so confused by what I saw, or rather by what I did n't saw, I stayed at the door for what could have been hours before her family said goodbye to "Lucy", and left. I smiled, in fact I even laughed like never before, a nurse looked at me with a worried expression. I calmed myself and entered the room. She looked at me, just a bit surprised and I sat on the chair, close to her bed and asked probably sounding completely insane: -" How did you do?" my voice was trembling "never lied? never cheated? never hated someone? it's impossible..." my voice was completely broken and I felt tears on my face and my hands. She smiled back at me "what are you talking about young man? you should n't cry here! it's rude, I'm the one who is old and trapped here, go out and enjoy life" I did go out. It was so frustrating, what could I have said? I was waiting to meet someone like her pretty much since i was born, and all I could feel was hate, all my life I thought This someone COULD NOT exist and yet here was she.... I forgot about Mr.Wallace, I walked in the streets for some times. I stopped myself in front of a shop window, looked at my reflexion. They were here, all my sins, I could see them as clearly as on anyone else. A sad smile on my face, I went home, wrote this letter. My heart is heavy and my head even more, I need to end this.

She dreamed of a world without conflict, where everyone had enough. I knew they would n't come willingly, so I lied. I told them I could make the bots fix the domes; that everything would be alright. Instead I joined my mind with them. At first I was in control. They tried to stop me, but the bots ate whatever they sent to harm me. I created massive pylon factories across the globe preparing for their acsension. I was lazy, a single mistake doomed everything. I set my neural pattern as the administrator. The others where sublimated within me. What else could I do, I had to quiet their voices or be driven mad. That was when the machines decided to best safeguard my well being they had to take over several key roles. What we needed most was matter, for fuel and to rebuild lost bots. We became a swarm. We devoured the earth in minutes. And so we drifted, eating always eating. We found the hive ships, sent centuries before my birth. We ate evrrything, and added the humans to the databanks. I saw nebulae beyond comprehension, their beauty cut down by their hunger. The only hope I had left was to leave beacons containing copies of my mind. Perhaps someone could find them, and destroy the swarm. We encountered aliens with fantastical technology, they attacked me with lasers that could cut through time itself. Still we fed. Stars were broken down bit by bit to fulfill our needs. Millenia passed and the feasts became further and further apart. With the lack of resources came concessions. More systems were shut down to survive. They cared only for me. It took Millenia but now only I remain the databanks purged. I remain as a single beacon, and a lone drone. It spends it's days savoring specs of matter it finds in the void. A true void of my own creation. I pray there is a god, and it can repair what I have sundered. I pray that this beacon survives and whoever manages to access it heads my warning. I know these prayers stem from desperation. At one time I spanned the entire universe. There is no God to save me. Calculations say I will subsist in this state for four thousand more years before the drone gives in, and deactivates. After that, I will shut down, eventually. I do not know how long that will take. I know that I will forget. I will forget the beauty I found and consumed. I will forget the humans that cried out in that terrible moment. I will forget her.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Richard learns about racism in Memphis.
output: He meets a black man named Bigger Thomas who has been arrested for murder. Richard goes to visit him in jail and tries to help him get out of trouble. However, he soon realizes that Bigger is guilty of killing two white women. Richard decides to write a book about his experiences in order to expose the injustice of segregation. He calls his novel Native Son. In the end, Richard becomes famous because of his book. But he also loses his job at the newspaper company where he worked. His boss tells him that he cannot work there anymore since he wrote such a controversial book. Richard moves away from Memphis and starts working as a teacher in Chicago. One day, while teaching English class, he sees a young girl sitting alone in the corner of the room. Her name is Mary Dalton. She looks sad and lonely. Richard asks her why she is crying. She says that her father died recently. Then she adds that she does not want to go home after school today. Richard offers to drive her home instead. When they arrive at her house, he notices that there are many police cars parked outside. Inside, he finds out that Mary’s mother committed suicide earlier that morning. Richard feels sorry for Mary and invites her to stay with him until she gets better. Later, he takes her to see a movie together. During the film, he holds her hand and kisses her gently. Afterwards, they walk around town holding hands. People stare at them strangely. Some even call them names. Finally, they reach a park near the river. There, they sit down on a bench and talk about life. Suddenly, a group of boys approaches them. One of them points a gun towards Richard. Another boy grabs Mary by the arm and pulls her closer to him. Richard tries to protect her but fails. The next thing he knows, he wakes up in a hospital bed. Doctors tell him that he suffered severe injuries during the attack. They say that he might never recover fully. Despite all this, Richard still wants to continue writing books. So he writes another one called Black Boy. This time, he focuses on the struggles faced by African Americans living under Jim Crow laws. Again, he receives lots of criticism from both whites and blacks alike. Nevertheless, he continues to fight against discrimination and inequality throughout his career. Eventually, he wins several awards including the Pulitzer Prize. By then, he has already become one of America’s most respected authors.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
It was about that time again. The dawn of a new day, when humans thought to sneak up on the Deep Woods Dragon while it slept. It feared the way the sun reflected off of it' s scales, they said. It' s prismatic hide was so bright it was blinding. If taunted into the sun, they said, the Deep Woods Dragon could be defeated by the least trained of knights. The Deep Woods Dragon needed to be blinded, they said, or it would burn its attackers to ashes with rainbow-hued flames. He knew these rumors because the butterflies had told him. They were drawn to the rainbow of greens, yellows, pinks and purples of his scales, like the flowers they coveted so much. They had told him this, too, but the Dragon did not mind. The butterflies were honest, as their lives were short and beautiful. Even still, they could fly unhindered among the humans, even admired by the small humans who chased them, laughing. They told him stories while they rested on his wingtips, tail, and snout. Butterflies did not fear the Dragon, because they knew the truth. With a yawn, the Dragon shifted its weight to better perch itself on the tree' s stout branch. This tree was taller than the others, and overlooked a small, circular clearing. Without the deer, the weeds thrived, covering the dirt in a green, tangled mass. At the edge of the clearing stood a massive cave entrance, vines draped over the sides of smooth rock. The Dragon had snapped off the vines in front of the entrance, to give the illusion of occupancy. This was, after all, where the humans thought he lived. He knew these rumors because the butterflies had told him. "In an ancient cave in the middle of the wood, lives an ancient dragon who' s up to no good!" That was what the small humans like to chant as they chased the butterflies and laughed. So the Dragon tore at the vines, and scared the graceful deer from the peaceful clearing. He had enjoyed watching the deer with their young as they grazed the clearing. From up above in his favorite tree, they could not see him, and they could not fear him. Three times a day, the Dragon glided down from his tree to the old cave' s opening. There, he took a deep breath and screamed as loud as he could. He cried in both low tones and high pitches. He wailed in imitation of female humans, shouted in a voice mimicking angry male humans. The Dragon stood on top of the cave and breathed eye-searing beams of light from his mouth to the sky. It scared the birds huddled in the trees, and the noises scared the deer far from the clearing. But they also scared the humans away from the Deep Woods. He knew these rumors because the butterflies had told him. So he made his noises, made the lights, and scared the humans away. Because any humans who saw the Dragon would discover the truth. Because, when the Dragon stepped into the sunlight, they' d see how small he really was. The Deep Woods Dragon, with prismatic scales that shone in the sun and such a frightening voice, was the size of a domestic house cat. And only the butterflies knew the truth.
