Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Black Elk hears voices for the first time at age five.
output: He is playing outside with his friends when suddenly he sees two men riding horses towards him. One man has long black hair and wears a white shirt; the other has short brown hair and wears a red shirt. Both men carry rifles. Black Elk runs home crying out "I am afraid! I am afraid!" His mother comforts him saying there are no bad spirits around here. She tells him not to worry because she knows everything will turn out alright. A few days later, Black Elk goes back outside to play again. Again he sees two more riders coming toward him. This time one rider carries a bow and arrow while the other holds a spear. As before, both men wear shirts of different colors - blue and yellow respectively. Once again, Black Elk runs inside screaming "Help me! Help me!" When his father asks what happened, Black Elk explains how he saw four strange looking people approaching him. His dad reassures him that nothing bad can happen to him since God protects everyone. However, shortly afterwards, Black Elk starts hearing voices telling him things like "you must kill your parents," "your family doesn't love you anymore" and many similar messages. These voices continue throughout most of his childhood years until finally stopping completely when he turns twelve. During those seven years, Black Elk experiences several visions which help explain some aspects of life. For instance, during one vision, he learns about death and rebirth. In another dream, he meets Jesus Christ who teaches him important lessons regarding faithfulness and forgiveness. Another significant event occurs during his teenage years. While attending school, Black Elk becomes very ill due to tuberculosis. Doctors tell him that unless he receives proper treatment soon, he may die within six months. Fortunately though, thanks to modern medicine, Black Elk recovers fully after spending three weeks in hospital. After graduating high school, Black Elk decides to join the U.S Army instead of going straight to college. Although initially reluctant, eventually he agrees to enlist under pressure from his uncle. Upon arriving at boot camp, Black Elk quickly realizes just how difficult military training actually is. Not only does he struggle physically but emotionally as well. Every night, he dreams about being killed by enemy soldiers. Eventually, however, he manages to overcome these fears and completes basic training successfully. Following graduation, Black Elk volunteers to serve overseas in Vietnam. Unfortunately, shortly upon arrival, he contracts malaria and spends almost half a year recovering in hospitals across Southeast Asia. Despite suffering severe health problems, Black Elk remains determined to fulfill his duty and fight alongside fellow Americans against communism. Sadly, despite putting forth great effort, Black Elk fails to achieve victory over the Viet Cong forces. Instead, he ends up getting captured and tortured by North Vietnamese troops. Luckily enough, American paratroopers manage to rescue him before he gets executed. Back stateside, Black Elk returns to civilian life feeling extremely depressed. To make matters worse, he discovers that his wife left him while he was away fighting in Vietnam. Desperate to find happiness once more, Black Elk moves back to South Dakota where he grew up. There, he finds employment working construction jobs. Over time, Black Elk develops close relationships with local Native Americans including Chief Crazy Horse. Through their friendship, Black Elk gains valuable insight into traditional Lakota culture. Additionally, he begins learning about Christianity through conversations with missionaries stationed nearby. By combining elements of both cultures, Black Elk creates a unique spiritual path known today as Oglala Sioux Religion. Today, Black Elk serves as chief elder of the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation located near Rapid City, SD. He often speaks publicly about issues affecting indigenous peoples worldwide. Furthermore, he actively participates in various charitable organizations dedicated to improving conditions for impoverished communities throughout America.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
For more than thirty years, I lived my life day by day, awaiting that fateful day when I would be granted my own inner power. I saw my friends, family, strangers, all given the most precious thing in life. Lucy, my sweet dear sister, was able to fly to the heavens and back. Richard, my childhood best friend, saved hundreds of lives throughout his life, having the strength of ten men. And there I waited, for years, until my life could start, and I would transform into the real me... the powerful me. Yet, with each passing day, more people would discover their power, and I would sit waiting at night, forcing myself to sleep. My dreams were filled with possibilities, of flight and strength, and of mind and hope. But as the years passed, my dreams were less vivid. Not everyone is lucky enough to have their inner power. Some die before that beautiful gift is bestowed unto them. I thought that may happen to me. And I lived life for a while, depressed and alone. That was until I met her. Her name was Alison. She had a power, but chose not use it. She did not want to be defined by her single ability. We met during one of my travels, when I was touring the country trying to find meaning in life. I found it. I found her. From that point on, my life started. I did not care about being granted a special ability as much as I cared for her. I saw my future, a family, a wife, children. We created a beautiful life together. Alison passed away a few years ago. I had only asked her once what her power was, and she had told me it did not matter. As she was lying on her bed, slowly fading away, she told me what her inner power was. She said she was born with her power, that she had the ability to live forever, as long as she did not love. "My power was a curse, until I found you", she told me before she passed. Today is my 70th birthday. Today I have discovered what my power is. Old age has not been kind on me, and this is the most beautiful power I could have hoped for. When I remember my wife, the times we spent, they are not just memories any longer. I can feel the brisk of the air on the hill where we first met. I can smell the flowers. I can here her giggle, her breath against my cheek. In the little time I have left on this planet, I experience her love all over again.

He is taken captive by the enemy, and he is held prisoner for several months. During his captivity, Black Elk has another vision. He sees himself riding a horse through the clouds, and he is surrounded by warriors who are also riding horses. It had been years since Zuccotti Park was free of barbed wire. A large concrete wall surrounded the plaza, a thousand V masks for each revolutionary lost in the fighting so far. You'd mistake Lower Manhattan for Mogadishu if it were n't for the skyscrapers that watched over the fighting. The compound for the Occupy movement was never quiet, the rattle of gunfire or the occasional pained yell as another fighter was brought back from the frontlines. The fighting had become entrenched by the 5th year. For every advance made on Central Park, there were another 50 casualties. Minesweepers had a full time job of clearing paths, just to be shot by a remote gunpod, flying over the metropolitan No Man's Land. Today however seemed different, a lull had settled over the battlefield. All that could be heard was the occasional burst of gunfire or the low hum of the Emergency Broadcast System screens throughout the city. Maybe it was the reverence for the day. 10 years since the revolution began and that first tent and sign was raised in protest. The 99 % had lost many but continued to fight. The 1 % still remained strong, and today they would deliver the final blow. The view screens flickered, the hum of the screens replaced with the anthem of a broken union. The face of the enemy flashed on screen, to address his ailing public.'My fellow Americans. It has been ten years since the seeds of chaos were sown in our great nation. Radicals gathered to destroy our honourable values and throw us into pandemonium. We tried to reason with them, we tried our best to comprehend their hatred and talk them back on the righteous path. But we failed. We showed then mercy and compassion but their hatred festered. They cast the first stone, they took the first life and they continue to poison everything they touch. They have taken our monuments to our strength and our bravery, and defile them with their vile propaganda. I for one, will stand no longer.' The screen changes, showing a diagram of Lower Manhatten. A diagram of a blast zone was overlaid on the top of it.'We must cut out the cancer which has plagued our nation for too long. Mercy has failed, so we will retaliate in the only language these vermin understand. our old metropole will be cleansed and returned to its rightful owners. Justice will be swift and final. We will take back what is rightly ours. God bless America and god have mercy on their souls.'

The fighting had become entrenched by the 5th year. For every advance made on Central Park, there were another 50 casualties. Minesweepers had a full time job of clearing paths, just to be shot by a remote gunpod, flying over the metropolitan No Man's Land. Today however seemed different, a lull had settled over the battlefield. All that could be heard was the occasional burst of gunfire or the low hum of the Emergency Broadcast System screens throughout the city. Maybe it was the reverence for the day. 10 years since the revolution began and that first tent and sign was raised in protest. The 99 % had lost many but continued to fight. The 1 % still remained strong, and today they would deliver the final blow. The view screens flickered, the hum of the screens replaced with the anthem of a broken union. The face of the enemy flashed on screen, to address his ailing public.'My fellow Americans. It has been ten years since the seeds of chaos were sown in our great nation. Radicals gathered to destroy our honourable values and throw us into pandemonium. We tried to reason with them, we tried our best to comprehend their hatred and talk them back on the righteous path. But we failed. We showed then mercy and compassion but their hatred festered. They cast the first stone, they took the first life and they continue to poison everything they touch. They have taken our monuments to our strength and our bravery, and defile them with their vile propaganda. I for one, will stand no longer.' The screen changes, showing a diagram of Lower Manhatten. A diagram of a blast zone was overlaid on the top of it.'We must cut out the cancer which has plagued our nation for too long. Mercy has failed, so we will retaliate in the only language these vermin understand. our old metropole will be cleansed and returned to its rightful owners. Justice will be swift and final. We will take back what is rightly ours. God bless America and god have mercy on their souls.'

The vision depicts Black Elk's journey to a cloud world.
output:
He sees a rainbow door leading to a tipi where he meets six grandfathers who represent the powers of the four directions and the sky and earth. The grandfathers give him gifts and teach him sacred songs and dances. Black Elk also learns about the importance of unity among all living beings and the need to protect Mother Earth. The vision ends with Black Elk returning to his people with a message of hope and healing.

Black Elk's vision is significant because it reflects his spiritual beliefs and experiences as a Lakota holy man. It also reveals some of the cultural values and practices of the Lakota people, such as their respect for nature, their reliance on dreams and visions for guidance, and their use of rituals and ceremonies to connect with the spirit world. Moreover, Black Elk's vision has inspired many Native American activists and artists who seek to preserve their heritage and resist assimilation into mainstream society.

One example of how Black Elk's vision has influenced contemporary culture is through the work of artist John Trudell. Trudell is a poet, musician, actor, and activist who was born on the Santee Sioux Reservation in Nebraska. He became involved in the American Indian Movement (AIM) during the 1970s and participated in several protests against government policies affecting Native Americans. In addition to his activism, Trudell has written numerous poems and songs that draw upon traditional Lakota themes and imagery. One of his most famous works is "Crazy Horse," which tells the story of the legendary Oglala leader who fought against white encroachment on tribal lands. The song includes references to Black Elk's vision, including the line "I saw my people dying / And I cried out loud." This line echoes Black Elk's own lamentation at seeing his people suffer under colonial oppression.

Another way in which Black Elk's vision has impacted modern culture is through its influence on environmental movements. Many environmentalists see parallels between Black Elk's concern for Mother Earth and their own efforts to combat climate change and other ecological crises. Some even argue that Black Elk's vision offers a blueprint for sustainable living and harmonious coexistence with nature. For instance, author Paul Hawken cites Black Elk's vision as evidence that indigenous peoples around the world possess valuable knowledge about how to live in balance with the natural environment. According to Hawken, this wisdom can help guide humanity towards a more sustainable future.

In conclusion, Black Elk's vision represents both a personal revelation and a collective expression of Lakota spirituality. Its enduring legacy lies not only in its literary merit but also in its ability to inspire social justice movements and environmental awareness campaigns. By drawing upon ancient traditions while speaking directly to present-day concerns, Black Elk's vision continues to resonate across cultures and generations.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Naif turned the page. Another day of studying droned on. It wasn' t that the material was a challenge, Naif had no problem absorbing every concept she came across and she had more degrees than anyone her age to prove it. Life had always been that way. In primary school she related better to adults than her classmates. In secondary school she was respectful of her teachers but felt she understood the lessons they taught to a deeper level than even they appreciated. University had been much the same except the distance between herself and her professors had turned her conscientious respect into a degree of begrudging disdain. She was certainly more intelligent than anyone she knew of, more so than anyone she had ever met. She picked apart the documents piled high on her desk recalling even the articles in the citations that she had previously read. Today her eyes were heavy, mostly with boredom, somewhat with the strain. Her mind was as sharp as it had ever been but her body showed the signs that she would not be considered a young woman for much longer. Through the closed windows she could vaguely hear the muffled hum of the world rushing by outside. Suddenly the monotony of the day fell away as it was unbound by a sharp thud against the outer wall of her office. Naif quickly straightened her hunched shoulders and bumped the table sloshing coffee over her meticulously curated stacks of research papers. She snarled impatiently at the mess and sprang to the window. She squinted through the blinds at the sunlit scene then furrowed them even further in annoyance. The neighbours were playing baseball with their kids again. Idiots. Hadn' t they any respect for others? One of the little morons ran up to the edge of Naif's apartment, beneath her field of view, and tried to throw the ball back. It careened off course and the cretin had to go pick it up again to return it to his waiting family. Naif rolled her eyes as she turned away from the display of incompetence and inefficiency that played out beyond her walls. As she sopped up the spilled coffee from her desk she mumbled to herself, as she had before, "I wish everyone were more intelligent. I would have so much more to share with them, so much more in common. They run around all day never thinking of their actions, of their futures. Such wasted potential in all that frivolity." Though as she settled back into her comfortably worn chair she couldn' t help feeling that there was something more to it that she just didn' t quite understand.

Black Elk receives sacred objects from six grandfathers.
output: He is given a cup of water, a bow, arrows, a pipe, a hoop, and a white wing. Black Elk is told that he must use these gifts to save his people. He is also told that he must take the cup of water and pour it onto the earth. This will cause the earth to become green and fertile. Black Elk does this and the land becomes lush and beautiful. However, when he returns home, he finds that his village has been destroyed by a tornado. His wife and children are dead. Black Elk weeps bitterly. Then he hears a voice saying, "Do not cry, my son. Your tears cannot bring back your loved ones. But if you follow me, I can show you how to make things right again." So Black Elk follows the voice and comes upon a great tree. There he sees two men sitting under its branches. One man is old and wise; the other is young and strong. The older man says to Black Elk, "My name is Wakan Tanka. I am the Great Spirit who created everything. And this boy here is my son, White Buffalo Calf Woman. She gave birth to him after she married a human being named Crazy Horse. Now she wants to give him back to me because she knows that he belongs to me." The younger man speaks next: "I am called Sitting Bull. My father was killed by white soldiers many years ago. Since then, I've lived alone in the forest. Sometimes I dream about my mother and wonder what happened to her. Maybe someday I'll find out." Black Elk listens carefully to both stories. When they finish talking, he asks them where he should go now. They tell him to travel west until he reaches the place where the sun sets each evening. That night, while sleeping near a riverbank, Black Elk dreams about his own death. In the morning, he wakes up feeling very sad. He decides to leave immediately. As soon as he starts walking, though, he feels better. Soon he arrives at a large lake surrounded by tall mountains. On top of one mountain stands a huge rock formation shaped like a buffalo head. Inside the mouth of the buffalo lies a small cave. Black Elk enters the cave and discovers a beautiful valley filled with flowers and fruit trees. At first glance, the valley looks peaceful and quiet. But suddenly, without warning, a loud noise fills the air. A group of warriors rides toward Black Elk on horseback. Their leader shouts angrily at Black Elk, accusing him of stealing food from their camp. Before long, a fierce battle breaks out between the two groups. Many people die during the fight. Finally, after several hours, the fighting stops. Both sides agree to stop attacking each other. Later, some of the survivors decide to form a new tribe together. They call themselves the Lakota Sioux. Over time, the Lakotas become known throughout North America as skilled hunters and traders. Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
THE WALL IS BUILT... EVENTUALLY Centipedes slink through smooth gaps in a rotten facade. Moss hides in the shadows and vines creep towards the light. The wall has existed all my life, and all through the lives of my oldest memorable ancestors. It is the lore of our people, that they traveled from distant lands where compassion was an economy, and peace an inescapable truth to seek opportunity. Well, another inescapable truth is that man, even in a place of prosperity, will often succumb to wanderlust. That is the story of these ancestors. Which in a way, is the story of myself. Or at least, why I came to be. They boarded a ship and set forth to the west. For weeks, the sea lay docile beneath their ship. Lazy waves lapped the hull, and steady winds pulled her forward. The travelers, who fancied themselves much more intrepid than they were, laughed among themselves at their own good fortune. "If only the naysayers back home could see the state of things on this veritable pleasure cruise!" they would exclaim defiantly. This trend settled into a routine before long, and such was the new life of the wayfarer. The sun would break the horizon, and they would rise from sleep to great it. Meals were consumed, feet took to dance, and wine was drunk. Unfortunately, even the most steadfast of routines is fleeting in the scheme of life, and one night bad luck finally befell them. A new trend. And one that would last certainly longer than the previous. The captain saw through a glass large clouds of deep black swirling in the distance. Dusk was minutes off, so he took to worry. The coarse was altered, and the ship's path now listed somewhat to the South and away from danger. It was a reasonable precaution, and would have been a perfect solution if the maps were more reliable. They, however, most certainly were not. Therefore, it was not. If smooth seas never made a skillful sailor, it is no surprise that the captain and crew had some serious shortcomings. To blame any single one of them for the wreck would be terribly unfair. The real culprit was hidden somewhere in the barrels of wine and mead stored below deck. And in the habit they had made of good fortune. With bad weather behind, and brisk air above, the crew had mostly joined the passengers within the ships belly. With so many people gathered so closely, either violence or levity are guaranteed, and on this evening the mood kept a lighter tone. Above, in the crows nest, a lonely man listened resentfully as voices sang, and feet stomped to the tune of jovial tunes played by practiced hands. Fiddles, mandolins, and accordions bickered playfully for hours and with each passing minute the weary occupier of the crow's nest grew more bitter. Just before midnight, when a particularly quick tune was met with a particularly rowdy cheer, his mind was made. "Crow's nest be damned! Mead be downed!" The latter part of that statement has sprung from the mouths of men before many a poor decision. And always with the same degree of vigor. Within moments the deck of the ship sat vacant, while the hold was full to burst. Libations continued to flow, while a jagged rocky coast sneaked ever closer.

It is the lore of our people, that they traveled from distant lands where compassion was an economy, and peace an inescapable truth to seek opportunity. Well, another inescapable truth is that man, even in a place of prosperity, will often succumb to wanderlust. That is the story of these ancestors. Which in a way, is the story of myself. Or at least, why I came to be. They boarded a ship and set forth to the west. For weeks, the sea lay docile beneath their ship. Lazy waves lapped the hull, and steady winds pulled her forward. The travelers, who fancied themselves much more intrepid than they were, laughed among themselves at their own good fortune. "If only the naysayers back home could see the state of things on this veritable pleasure cruise!" they would exclaim defiantly. This trend settled into a routine before long, and such was the new life of the wayfarer. The sun would break the horizon, and they would rise from sleep to great it. Meals were consumed, feet took to dance, and wine was drunk. Unfortunately, even the most steadfast of routines is fleeting in the scheme of life, and one night bad luck finally befell them. A new trend. And one that would last certainly longer than the previous. The captain saw through a glass large clouds of deep black swirling in the distance. Dusk was minutes off, so he took to worry. The coarse was altered, and the ship's path now listed somewhat to the South and away from danger. It was a reasonable precaution, and would have been a perfect solution if the maps were more reliable. They, however, most certainly were not. Therefore, it was not. If smooth seas never made a skillful sailor, it is no surprise that the captain and crew had some serious shortcomings. To blame any single one of them for the wreck would be terribly unfair. The real culprit was hidden somewhere in the barrels of wine and mead stored below deck. And in the habit they had made of good fortune. With bad weather behind, and brisk air above, the crew had mostly joined the passengers within the ships belly. With so many people gathered so closely, either violence or levity are guaranteed, and on this evening the mood kept a lighter tone. Above, in the crows nest, a lonely man listened resentfully as voices sang, and feet stomped to the tune of jovial tunes played by practiced hands. Fiddles, mandolins, and accordions bickered playfully for hours and with each passing minute the weary occupier of the crow's nest grew more bitter. Just before midnight, when a particularly quick tune was met with a particularly rowdy cheer, his mind was made. "Crow's nest be damned! Mead be downed!" The latter part of that statement has sprung from the mouths of men before many a poor decision. And always with the same degree of vigor. Within moments the deck of the ship sat vacant, while the hold was full to burst. Libations continued to flow, while a jagged rocky coast sneaked ever closer.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
My story started where a lot have ended these past 10 years: with a single bullet. Living in post-war Britain, death was not an uncommon sight. Everyone had at least one firearm to defend themselves, everyone had encountered gunfire in the streets, and everyone knew what it meant to live every day like it could be their last. The revolution that was supposed to end the tyranny of a dictatorship had ripped the country apart; counties had split into factions, all threatening total destruction of the others. In ten years the population was decimated, the country reduced to a crumbling mass of fallen buildings and civilians with guns. All around me was depression, death, dirt, famine. Thinking about it, it's quite hilarious, in such a depressing way. The sacks of bones, flesh and organs we saw everyday were once living, breathing, talking human beings. They had a mother, a father, a pet, a first love, they were educated, they succeeded and they failed. And they died. A single bullet can end so much. That morning, as I wandered to the local shop for some bread, clutching my rifle, my world completely ended. I had no time to react; as soon as I entered Grange Avenue a bullet burrowed into my head, smashing part of my brain, and knocking me straight out cold. I woke in a beautiful wooden chalet, bright natural light streaming through vast windows above the soft, clean bed that I rested in. My itchy, dirty clothes were replaced with beautiful white robes, soft as silk and cleaner than anything I had ever seen. I sat up, and looked around the room - it was furnished luxuriously, with beautiful gold-leaf chairs and fantastic bright works of art hanging around the room. I got up and left the room, and immediately my breath was forced from me. The crumbled grey streets of London had gone. In their place were beautiful old chalets, bright white skyscrapers, and marble streets. I could also see a very unfamiliar sight - a beautiful emerald park, littered with tall, radiant trees, ferns, and glowing coloured flowers. Clear water ran through them. All around the streets were people dressed similar to me, smiling and talking and laughing. The smog-ridden sky had been replaced with a beautiful, deep purple, but the world was light around me and the I could see the vast orange sun dipping behind the structures around the city. For the first time in ten years I smiled. That bullet took me to a better place.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Antonio is anxious about starting school.
output:
He has never been away from his family before, and he doesn't know anyone else who is going to the same school. His parents are excited for him, though, and they tell him that he'll make lots of new friends there. Antonio isn't sure if he believes them, but he tries to put on a brave face anyway.

The first few days of school go by quickly. Antonio meets some other kids in his class, and they seem nice enough. But then something strange happens. One night, when Antonio is sleeping, he hears a voice calling his name. It sounds like someone is whispering right next to his ear. "Antonio," the voice says. "Wake up."

Antonio opens his eyes and sees a figure standing over him. It looks like a man, but its skin is pale and translucent, almost like glass. Its eyes are black holes, and its mouth is twisted into a cruel smile. "Who are you?" Antonio asks, terrified.

"I am your worst nightmare," the creature replies. "I am here to take you away from this place." With those words, the creature reaches out and grabs Antonio by the arm. Before he knows what's happening, Antonio finds himself being pulled through a dark tunnel. When he finally emerges on the other side, he realizes that he's back home again. But everything is different now. His house is empty, and there's no sign of his parents anywhere. And outside, instead of the familiar streets of his neighborhood, there's nothing but darkness stretching off into infinity.

"Where am I?" Antonio cries out desperately. But there's no answer except for the sound of laughter echoing through the void.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
A city, its mountains. The office towers lighting up in the evening haze and the smeary pale of a cloudless sunset. The tiny headlights of cars with sweaty passengers unseen, idling in traffic, smelling the hot food cooking in restaurants. The world shifts as the woman behind the camera adjusts her footing, muttering in English to her boyfriend. A light like the sun over the horizon, there and then gone. Silence, but for the wind in the trees. She asks what that was. The clean, shaved, washed, waxed people in suits at desks read facts and information like sports commentary. They narrate animations with moving arrows and lines like football plays. They report on characters and captains. They discuss. They debate. They nod solemnly. The light flashes in the sky and fades but the afterglow remains. They update, they check-in, they go-live, they re-Tweet. Wounded civilians scream and coddle loved ones, rewind. Look right here: loved ones die. Rewind. The light like the sun. Stay tuned. A city, its mountains. The office buildings lighting up in evening haze. Tiny headlights and unseen drivers thinking about food. A mutter in the sunset. A light and its afterglow. The wind in the trees. The troops are bad cameramen. They laugh or they scream or they joke nervously. Trucks and tanks and armoured vehicles on tall tires carry them down empty roads where sometimes cars have been abandoned or craters from bad arty shots force detours. The videos capture the sounds of war. Pops and crackles of overhead bullets. The shake and snapping of stalks and branches. Rivers idling over rounded stones. The scritchety clatter of the camera tumbling after bomb concussion shreds the canopies and dust swirls in mottled sunlight. Winged insects flashing momentarily in their arcs. A city, its mountains. Buildings, drivers. Sunset. A light. People speak in hushed tones. Somewhere, over the horizon on the other side of the world, everything has changed. There are no videos of the darkness that came afterward. A light like the sun. A motorcyclist pulls over to the side of the road in the clear, humid evening and reaches down to turn the petcock to OFF before quieting the motor. She's out in the country, flat fields of corn and wheat on either side of the old road. Above her the stars are out and bright in the sky. One of them, brighter than the rest, moves slowly toward the Earth's penumbra. The rider flips up her visor and sits back, hands behind her on the seat, watching the little light move, thinking of the people inside looking back. When those astronauts look down at Seoul, what do they see? The light fades and she is left alone. She listens and hears only crickets and a soft waxy rustle of a breeze in the corn. No guns, no artillery. No marching. No wet gasps from ruined faces. She shifts and works a hand into her pocket, pulling out a phone made in South Korea. She wonders if the people who screwed and soldered its pieces together are still alive, whether they could have seen the flash from wherever they were. Her friend has texted her, asking when she will get to the party. She responds with "A few minutes" and puts the phone away. The bike starts up fine once it's warm and after a moment of further staring into the stars she kicks the engine over and rolls away. The bright red of her tail light flashes as she slows at the intersection, then winks out.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
"Corner-Cutting" I was worried about the efficiency of the engram compression, or the integrity of my telomeres. I did n't want my cells to age super-fast, or my mind to gradually decay into noise data. But those were n't the issue. What I should have paid attention to was resolution. It started on the fifth "respawn". Everything had been going fine up to then - incurable disease, radiation burns, blunt force trauma, blood loss. Horribly dead, safely alive, rinse, repeat. Then I noticed something odd. It was n't immediately noticeable. It might have been happening in previous lives, in even less conspicuous ways, but I found it on my nose. A voxel. It was disconcerting, but not terribly so. A little extra skin and an odd right-angle was n't something to make me question my latest biological vehicle, but I did wonder what would happen if it had happened in, say, my eye. A bullet through the head and I was back in the machine. After the standard checks, I tried to find a superficial voxel somewhere. This time it was a whole cube of extra skin on my upper arm, a few millimeters across. Now I started wondering if voxels could go missing instead of being added - and I started wondering if they could be missing internally. The tests continued. This time I was dropped unceremoniously into a small vat of fluoroantimonic acid - I barely had time to register pain before I chemically ceased to exist. When I woke up, voxels were the first thing I checked for. Nothing on my face, or my arms... But on my side there was a large raised spot, with right-angled edges. But there was little time to worry about my volumetric resolution - the next test was explosive. Alive again, I looked for voxellation. To my growing concern, it was spreading. Like square tumors, the voxels showed up in patches on my arms, legs, and torso. I hoped they would n't reach my... Higher-resolution areas. After the decompression test, the voxels were in all sorts of places. I started to feel like a combination of human and LEGO. They were n't impeding me in any way, but it was bizarre having irregular rectangular growths all over. They were pretty obvious from even a glance, but the tests continued. Death by rapid incineration. Voxels on my shins. Death by a laser through the heart. Voxels on my back. Death by electrocution. Voxels on my shoulders. I was still functioning perfectly - the voxels did n't seem to be happening to anything inside me. After a while I got used to them - I formed a habit of checking where my voxel patches had randomly generated with each "respawn". Eventually it had to happen. I awoke and found it mechanically difficult to extricate myself from the machine. A cursory examination revealed that my entire exterior surface was voxellated to a resolution of three millimeters. There was a fuss, and argument, and huddled discussion. Eventually someone noticed me standing around being extraordinarily Cartesian and told me to get back into the machine. It was just like dying - at least, like the particularly quick deaths. When I woke up, I had my contours back - you could say my resolution was molecular. It was refreshing not to have to worry about being compared to an old videogame. I did notice I weighed rather less than I seemed to remember - but I decided not to worry about it.

I was still functioning perfectly - the voxels did n't seem to be happening to anything inside me. After a while I got used to them - I formed a habit of checking where my voxel patches had randomly generated with each "respawn". Eventually it had to happen. I awoke and found it mechanically difficult to extricate myself from the machine. A cursory examination revealed that my entire exterior surface was voxellated to a resolution of three millimeters. There was a fuss, and argument, and huddled discussion. Eventually someone noticed me standing around being extraordinarily Cartesian and told me to get back into the machine. It was just like dying - at least, like the particularly quick deaths. When I woke up, I had my contours back - you could say my resolution was molecular. It was refreshing not to have to worry about being compared to an old videogame. I did notice I weighed rather less than I seemed to remember - but I decided not to worry about it.

God It's always difficult making tough decisions and this year I've made the hardest one of all, to eradicate sin and give humans another chance to embrace a new world. A world of peace, love and kindness where there will be no more tears. Of course in order for this to happen I have to prevent humans from actually doing sinful things, limiting their free will. Think about it, back in the beginning with adam and eve, there was no sin, no free will to do anything you wanted. After I stepped in humanity had unlimited potential. Sure there's been war, famine, disease and death but there's been some remarkable things of human acheivement. I think you'll agree that God's plan to remove sin and thus freewill is a huge mistake. Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Pecola Breedlove is placed in the MacTeer home after her father burns down their house.
output: Claudia and Frieda are excited to have Pecola stay with them, but Mrs. MacTeer is not happy about having another mouth to feed. She tells Pecola she must earn her keep by helping out around the house. Pecola does not mind because she loves being around the MacTeers. They treat her like family and make her feel welcome. One day, while Pecola is washing dishes, she accidentally breaks a plate. Mrs. MacTeer gets angry and yells at Pecola. Pecola starts crying and runs upstairs to her room. Claudia goes up to check on Pecola and finds her sitting on the floor hugging her knees. "What happened?" Claudia asks. "I broke a plate," Pecola says between sobs. "It wasn't my fault! The dish soap slipped out of my hand!" "Don't worry about it," Claudia says soothingly. "Accidents happen." But Pecola continues to cry. "Why don't you come downstairs and help me bake cookies?" Claudia suggests. "That might cheer you up." Pecola nods and follows Claudia downstairs. As they mix together ingredients for chocolate chip cookies, Pecola tells Claudia about her life. Her mother died when she was young, leaving her father to raise her alone. He works long hours at a factory and often comes home drunk. Sometimes he hits Pecola when he's mad. "He doesn't mean to hurt me," Pecola insists. "He just gets frustrated sometimes." "Well, maybe he needs someone else to talk to besides you," Claudia says gently. "Maybe he'd listen to a woman instead of hitting his daughter." Pecola looks thoughtful. "Do you really think so?" "Sure," Claudia replies. "Women understand men better than other men do." Pecola smiles shyly. "Thanks, Claudia. You're such a good friend."

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
I looked up in horror at the crowd of young boys came thundering into the room. The clouds on the walls were suddenly blocked by a horde of scrambling young bodies and flailing limbs. I froze, the hat on my head tilted just enough for me to see everything, and i saw fear. Andy stood there in the middle of the floor, clutching the dreaded spaceman box, but that seemed to matter less compared to the pressing matter. The air was still, I could feel Mr.Potato head's round eyes blink and the sound of heavy breathing from the guests penetrated the silence with jagged blades of uncertainty. I considered freezing, but it was too late. We all knew it. Rex panicked like a child who came down christmas morning to find no gifts. He thundered across the hardwood floors for the window, yelling at the top of his lungs some inaudible dinosaur screech. I spun around, knowing it was too late and pointed towards the window. The toys did n't need a second prompt. The strong man and Mr. Potato head grabbed the monkeys in a barrel, hopped in RC and gunned the engines. The army men attempted to rescue some of the less mobile toys, but it was too late. One brilliant child had the idea to grab my waist with his sweaty, greasy hand and hold me up in the air. I put up a fight, hoping to distract them enough to let everyone escape. I did n't know what would happen, but panic had overrun my emotions and pure terror coursed through my plastic veins. But then, salvation. Andy wrenched me from the child's grasp and shouted angrily "YOU ONLY GOT ME BEDSHEETS." He held me gently in his grasp and managed to utter "Woody?" I stared back up at him with and sorrow filled my soul. I knew this was it, the other toys were out. "I'm sorry Andy, you'll understand one day." I flung my sack cloth limbs out of his hand and towards the bed, hitting it with surprising force. I propelled myself towards the window, clear through the slit. The other toys were already at the edge of the law waiting for me, but I had to look back at least once. Andy stared out the window with a look of pure despair on his face and one confused spaceman peered back, blinking quizzically towards the small group of toys, running down the street; never to return.

My story started where a lot have ended these past 10 years: with a single bullet. Living in post-war Britain, death was not an uncommon sight. Everyone had at least one firearm to defend themselves, everyone had encountered gunfire in the streets, and everyone knew what it meant to live every day like it could be their last. The revolution that was supposed to end the tyranny of a dictatorship had ripped the country apart; counties had split into factions, all threatening total destruction of the others. In ten years the population was decimated, the country reduced to a crumbling mass of fallen buildings and civilians with guns. All around me was depression, death, dirt, famine. Thinking about it, it's quite hilarious, in such a depressing way. The sacks of bones, flesh and organs we saw everyday were once living, breathing, talking human beings. They had a mother, a father, a pet, a first love, they were educated, they succeeded and they failed. And they died. A single bullet can end so much. That morning, as I wandered to the local shop for some bread, clutching my rifle, my world completely ended. I had no time to react; as soon as I entered Grange Avenue a bullet burrowed into my head, smashing part of my brain, and knocking me straight out cold. I woke in a beautiful wooden chalet, bright natural light streaming through vast windows above the soft, clean bed that I rested in. My itchy, dirty clothes were replaced with beautiful white robes, soft as silk and cleaner than anything I had ever seen. I sat up, and looked around the room - it was furnished luxuriously, with beautiful gold-leaf chairs and fantastic bright works of art hanging around the room. I got up and left the room, and immediately my breath was forced from me. The crumbled grey streets of London had gone. In their place were beautiful old chalets, bright white skyscrapers, and marble streets. I could also see a very unfamiliar sight - a beautiful emerald park, littered with tall, radiant trees, ferns, and glowing coloured flowers. Clear water ran through them. All around the streets were people dressed similar to me, smiling and talking and laughing. The smog-ridden sky had been replaced with a beautiful, deep purple, but the world was light around me and the I could see the vast orange sun dipping behind the structures around the city. For the first time in ten years I smiled. That bullet took me to a better place.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Claudia and Frieda MacTeer start school in the autumn of 1940.
output: Claudia is nine years old, and her sister Frieda is ten. Their parents are strict, but loving. They live in Lorain, Ohio, which is a small town near Lake Erie. It is a quiet town, and most of the residents are black. There are two other families who live nearby, the Breedloves and the McTeers. The Breedloves are poor, and the McTeers are middle class. The Breedlove children are Pecola, Sammy, and Cholly. Pecola is eleven years old, and she has a baby brother named Sammy. Her father, Cholly, is a drunkard. He beats his wife and children regularly. The McTeer children are Claudia and Frieda. They are both good students, and they get along well with each other. One day, when Claudia and Frieda are walking home from school, they see a group of boys throwing rocks at a little girl. The girl is crying, and she is bleeding from her nose. Claudia and Frieda run over to help her. They take her home, and they clean her wounds. The next day, Claudia and Frieda go back to school. They tell their teacher, Miss Della Jones, what happened. Miss Jones tells them that they did the right thing by helping the little girl. She says that they should always try to help people who are in trouble. Claudia and Frieda feel proud of themselves. They know that they did the right thing. They hope that they will never have to do something like that again. But they know that they might have to someday. They just don't know when or where.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
It started happening before I was born. My grandfather tells me that it started before he was born too. All we know is that, when you reach the age of 25, a letter appears. No one's quite sure how. It just shows up. Some people never open theirs, they're too afraid to know. If you try to throw it away, it'll come back. If you burn or tear it, a new one is sent. At first everyone thought it was a prank. Date, time, location and cause of death? How would anybody know such a thing? But then, the first person scheduled to die, did. Hit by the same bus mentioned, on the same street, at the same time, on the same day. Just days later, the second was shot by a mugger. It was becoming clear that this was real. Fast-forward to now. My 25th birthday. I have the letter. I've already made my mind up that I'll want to know. But my hands shake as I open the letter. What if I only have a few days left? What if I'm going to die today? I swallow, and take the piece of paper out of the envelope. Blank. Both sides, blank. I hold it up against the light. Still nothing. I try to think what else I could do, but it is completely and utterly blank. What could that mean? Am I immortal? Should I already be dead? Is my death alone unfixed? What kind of person gets a blank death letter? I walk out to where the rest of my family is gathered. 25th birthdays are usually sombre events, even for those who do n't open their letters. I look at them all uncertainly. My grandfather, who knows that he has days left, although he wo n't tell us how many, shuffles over, and asks, "Well, want to share?" Numbly, I hand him the envelope with the blank piece of paper in it. He takes it out, and the shock of it gives him a heart attack. As we wait for the ambulance, he slips away. He was the only one of that generation left, and he had celebrated his 100th birthday a month ago. He'd known, for 75 years that he was going to die on this day, at the time he did. He just did n't tell us when, because his letter had given the location'At Your Grandson's 25th Birthday Party'. We obviously needed to start preparing for his cremation, but everyone seemed very interested in my blank letter. Nobody came up with any real answers, there was n't even a whisper about blank death letters on the internet. Eventually, one of my cousins who did n't like me very much said that we could test whether I was immortal. "Try it, and I test whether you are." I usually would n't have been so snappy, but I'd just received a blank death letter, and my grandfather had just died. I was a little bit shaken up, to say the least. Everyone kept arguing over what we could do. Eventually, I could n't take it anymore, so I made my excuses and left. I walked home, not really paying much attention to my surroundings, and just as I was crossing the road in front of my house, the van hit me. As I came to a rest, the death letter which had been knocked out of my jacket, fluttered down onto me, now displaying the number 1.

A car hits her, and she dies instantly. The driver of the car is Mr. Yacobowski, the shopkeeper who refused to serve her earlier that day. He is arrested and charged with manslaughter. The MacTeers are devastated by Pecola's death. They blame themselves for not being able to protect her. They also blame society for its racism and prejudice. The novel ends with a sense of hopelessness and despair.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
"Corner-Cutting" I was worried about the efficiency of the engram compression, or the integrity of my telomeres. I did n't want my cells to age super-fast, or my mind to gradually decay into noise data. But those were n't the issue. What I should have paid attention to was resolution. It started on the fifth "respawn". Everything had been going fine up to then - incurable disease, radiation burns, blunt force trauma, blood loss. Horribly dead, safely alive, rinse, repeat. Then I noticed something odd. It was n't immediately noticeable. It might have been happening in previous lives, in even less conspicuous ways, but I found it on my nose. A voxel. It was disconcerting, but not terribly so. A little extra skin and an odd right-angle was n't something to make me question my latest biological vehicle, but I did wonder what would happen if it had happened in, say, my eye. A bullet through the head and I was back in the machine. After the standard checks, I tried to find a superficial voxel somewhere. This time it was a whole cube of extra skin on my upper arm, a few millimeters across. Now I started wondering if voxels could go missing instead of being added - and I started wondering if they could be missing internally. The tests continued. This time I was dropped unceremoniously into a small vat of fluoroantimonic acid - I barely had time to register pain before I chemically ceased to exist. When I woke up, voxels were the first thing I checked for. Nothing on my face, or my arms... But on my side there was a large raised spot, with right-angled edges. But there was little time to worry about my volumetric resolution - the next test was explosive. Alive again, I looked for voxellation. To my growing concern, it was spreading. Like square tumors, the voxels showed up in patches on my arms, legs, and torso. I hoped they would n't reach my... Higher-resolution areas. After the decompression test, the voxels were in all sorts of places. I started to feel like a combination of human and LEGO. They were n't impeding me in any way, but it was bizarre having irregular rectangular growths all over. They were pretty obvious from even a glance, but the tests continued. Death by rapid incineration. Voxels on my shins. Death by a laser through the heart. Voxels on my back. Death by electrocution. Voxels on my shoulders. I was still functioning perfectly - the voxels did n't seem to be happening to anything inside me. After a while I got used to them - I formed a habit of checking where my voxel patches had randomly generated with each "respawn". Eventually it had to happen. I awoke and found it mechanically difficult to extricate myself from the machine. A cursory examination revealed that my entire exterior surface was voxellated to a resolution of three millimeters. There was a fuss, and argument, and huddled discussion. Eventually someone noticed me standing around being extraordinarily Cartesian and told me to get back into the machine. It was just like dying - at least, like the particularly quick deaths. When I woke up, I had my contours back - you could say my resolution was molecular. It was refreshing not to have to worry about being compared to an old videogame. I did notice I weighed rather less than I seemed to remember - but I decided not to worry about it.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Dear Lily, I'm visiting the recesses of my memory, these days. Contemplating my life as it were. So many memories I wanted to share with you. Diamonds for my one true love. Do you remember that one cool summer evening half a lifetime ago? We nestled ourselves against each other on the blanket in the park. I can still feel your skin against mine as we watched the fireworks together. Your chestnut hair stroking my cheek and ear as you rested your head on my shoulder. I could n't believe you were gone. Day turned into night. Food tasted like nothing. The world turned into a bland grey color. I could n't believe it. I did n't want to believe it. I wept and kept weeping. Then I had no tears left to sob. I lost weight. I lost my hair. I gained wrinkles. When I lost you, the man in the mirror showed me his true age almost overnight. But then things started to change. Our Elisabeth. Our loving, kind Lillibeth who moved half a world for her Australian. She visited me eventually. We talked about you, Lily. We shared a thousand little things between us. A flock of starlings composing your life. During that visit, the turmoil caused by losing you finally seemed to settle. At the end, I decided to finally change my Facebook status. Lillibeth helped me. You know my old, bony fingers have gotten a mind of their own, it seems. I wanted to tell you, Lilly, that I got a little surprise the very next day. This tabby kitten sat outside our garden door the very next morning. It seemed lost, but her eyes betrayed she knew exactly were she was. As I opened the door, she jumped right in and installed herself in the spot on the couch from where you used to watch the telly during long winter evenings. I decided to dub her Lilly because she seems to have a playful streak. Just like you. And most importantly, she seemed to be the antidote to my loneliness. That's not the end of it. Lily was only the first. Each week, I woke up to find two or three feline friends at our garden door. I let them, fed them and started to call them by a name I gave them. Each of them seemingly knowing that she belonged in this house. There's Athena who sits on your sewing machine, looking wise beyond her years. There's Hera who likes to wake me up each morning, and has this stern and down-to-earth disposition. There's Hebe, she's just a kitten who seems to have no bounds teasing the others. All in all, there's twelve of them who came to live with me. They keep me company. Follow me through the house as I go about my day. When I see them, they always remind me of a part of you. An aspect that I should n't forget. Sometimes they're mere presence helps me as the practicalities in life start to fade from my memory. When I spot Demeter sitting in front of the fridge, it hits me that I still need to do the groceries. Oh Lily, I miss you so much. My life has entered the twilight years. Only so much time is left before I will join you. I hope our Lillibeth will take care of my twelve feline companions. She'll be most delighted recognising some aspect of her mother in each of them. Yours forever with endless love, Werner.

Day turned into night. Food tasted like nothing. The world turned into a bland grey color. I could n't believe it. I did n't want to believe it. I wept and kept weeping. Then I had no tears left to sob. I lost weight. I lost my hair. I gained wrinkles. When I lost you, the man in the mirror showed me his true age almost overnight. But then things started to change. Our Elisabeth. Our loving, kind Lillibeth who moved half a world for her Australian. She visited me eventually. We talked about you, Lily. We shared a thousand little things between us. A flock of starlings composing your life. During that visit, the turmoil caused by losing you finally seemed to settle. At the end, I decided to finally change my Facebook status. Lillibeth helped me. You know my old, bony fingers have gotten a mind of their own, it seems. I wanted to tell you, Lilly, that I got a little surprise the very next day. This tabby kitten sat outside our garden door the very next morning. It seemed lost, but her eyes betrayed she knew exactly were she was. As I opened the door, she jumped right in and installed herself in the spot on the couch from where you used to watch the telly during long winter evenings. I decided to dub her Lilly because she seems to have a playful streak. Just like you. And most importantly, she seemed to be the antidote to my loneliness. That's not the end of it. Lily was only the first. Each week, I woke up to find two or three feline friends at our garden door. I let them, fed them and started to call them by a name I gave them. Each of them seemingly knowing that she belonged in this house. There's Athena who sits on your sewing machine, looking wise beyond her years. There's Hera who likes to wake me up each morning, and has this stern and down-to-earth disposition. There's Hebe, she's just a kitten who seems to have no bounds teasing the others. All in all, there's twelve of them who came to live with me. They keep me company. Follow me through the house as I go about my day. When I see them, they always remind me of a part of you. An aspect that I should n't forget. Sometimes they're mere presence helps me as the practicalities in life start to fade from my memory. When I spot Demeter sitting in front of the fridge, it hits me that I still need to do the groceries. Oh Lily, I miss you so much. My life has entered the twilight years. Only so much time is left before I will join you. I hope our Lillibeth will take care of my twelve feline companions. She'll be most delighted recognising some aspect of her mother in each of them. Yours forever with endless love, Werner.

It had been years since Zuccotti Park was free of barbed wire. A large concrete wall surrounded the plaza, a thousand V masks for each revolutionary lost in the fighting so far. You'd mistake Lower Manhattan for Mogadishu if it were n't for the skyscrapers that watched over the fighting. The compound for the Occupy movement was never quiet, the rattle of gunfire or the occasional pained yell as another fighter was brought back from the frontlines. The fighting had become entrenched by the 5th year. For every advance made on Central Park, there were another 50 casualties. Minesweepers had a full time job of clearing paths, just to be shot by a remote gunpod, flying over the metropolitan No Man's Land. Today however seemed different, a lull had settled over the battlefield. All that could be heard was the occasional burst of gunfire or the low hum of the Emergency Broadcast System screens throughout the city. Maybe it was the reverence for the day. 10 years since the revolution began and that first tent and sign was raised in protest. The 99 % had lost many but continued to fight. The 1 % still remained strong, and today they would deliver the final blow. The view screens flickered, the hum of the screens replaced with the anthem of a broken union. The face of the enemy flashed on screen, to address his ailing public.'My fellow Americans. It has been ten years since the seeds of chaos were sown in our great nation. Radicals gathered to destroy our honourable values and throw us into pandemonium. We tried to reason with them, we tried our best to comprehend their hatred and talk them back on the righteous path. But we failed. We showed then mercy and compassion but their hatred festered. They cast the first stone, they took the first life and they continue to poison everything they touch. They have taken our monuments to our strength and our bravery, and defile them with their vile propaganda. I for one, will stand no longer.' The screen changes, showing a diagram of Lower Manhatten. A diagram of a blast zone was overlaid on the top of it.'We must cut out the cancer which has plagued our nation for too long. Mercy has failed, so we will retaliate in the only language these vermin understand. our old metropole will be cleansed and returned to its rightful owners. Justice will be swift and final. We will take back what is rightly ours. God bless America and god have mercy on their souls.'

Liesel is taken in by the Hubermanns.
output: She is given a room of her own, and she begins to learn how to read and write. Liesel also meets Max Vandenburg, a Jewish man who is hiding in the basement of the Hubermanns' house. Max teaches Liesel how to play chess, and he tells her stories about his life before the war. One night, while Liesel is reading in bed, she hears a noise outside her window. When she looks out, she sees a group of men carrying torches. They are coming towards the house. Liesel hides under her bed, and she can hear the men talking. They are looking for Max. The men search the house, but they do not find him. They leave, and Liesel goes downstairs to tell Rosa and Hans what happened. Rosa is angry, and she says that they should turn Max in to the police. Hans disagrees, and he says that they cannot betray Max. He reminds Rosa that they promised to keep him safe. Rosa reluctantly agrees, and she tells Liesel to go back to bed. The next morning, Liesel wakes up early and goes down to the kitchen. She finds Hans sitting at the table, drinking coffee. He asks her if she slept well, and she lies and says yes. Hans knows that she is lying, but he does not say anything. He just smiles and tells her to eat breakfast. Liesel sits down at the table and starts eating. As she eats, she thinks about what happened last night. She wonders why the men were looking for Max, and she worries that they might come back. She also feels guilty for lying to Hans. She knows that he knows she is lying, but she does not want to admit it. After breakfast, Liesel goes upstairs to get ready for school. As she brushes her teeth, she hears a knock on the door. She opens the door, and she sees Max standing there. He is holding a suitcase, and he looks scared. Liesel asks him what is wrong, and he tells her that the men came back. They searched the house again, and this time they found him. Max says that he has to leave, and he asks Liesel to help him. Liesel hesitates, but then she nods and takes his hand. Together, they sneak out of the house and run away.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
It was like double-vision, except it was the past. How can something fictional seem so vivid...? The distant, exotic land we came from, its gilded avenues, its glistening intricate spires, its profound natural beauty with lushly verdant banks hugging the rivers that snaked between the dunes. .. None of it was there. It was all nothing more than a dream. But I am not a lie. I stare at my hands, flexing them, examining the callouses accumulated by work never done, cracks formed of age never lived, and despite the warmth of the bright sun just passing its zenith above, I shiver. "Amir," I hear a voice call, and my heart tugs at what I know to be familiarity. "Hassan...?" I uncertainly reply as I look up. Our gazes meet. I could swear I saw in his eyes the same false memories flashing behind mine. Childhood among parents who never lived, in a community that was never built, attending an academy that was never founded, graduating from a ceremony never held... He nods hollowly, as if to confirm these very musings. "... We have to pack the supplies, Amir. His Majesty will be staying at the palace, and the staff are directing us to where we are to stow his wardrobe and leave his tributes to The Sultan." My mouth was dry, but not in response to his words. At some point I realized my'old friend' Hassan was talking only to fill the screaming void in our minds. To'Sound Normal', like'Real People'. My stomach is a knot of ice. Still, the skills of a life as-yet unlived surface readily to the forefront of my mind. How to port the many caskets of His Majesty Prince Ali's wares. "... Yes. I will coordinate with the provisioner. If my memory serves," I pause a bit too long, lost in the jarring disjunction of citing false memories, "... it is customary to serve a great feast with the arrival of a dignitary. The many delicacies of our homeland are sure to leave a resounding impression upon The Sultan's court." Hassan's expression tightens. I feel his heartache, for this homeland which we have never seen with real eyes, and never shall. He hesitantly takes a step nearer and dispenses a conciliatory pat to my shoulder. A mutual understanding. We were truly all feeling it, every last member of His Majesty Prince Ali's vanguard.... he was n't even really a prince. I shudder and turn, to address the court provisioner by name. He's just as haunted and startled as I that we know one another, but everything is running smoothly. We have no solace from our inner thoughts. We can only push on in the hopes that the minutia will wash away the horror.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Liesel steals her first book at her brother's burial.
output: She doesn't understand why she does it, but she knows she has to keep it safe. She hides it under her mattress, and when she wakes up in the middle of the night, she reads it by candlelight. She learns how to read from the book, and soon she's stealing books from anywhere she can find them. She starts reading them aloud to her foster father, Hans Hubermann, and they become close friends. Liesel also becomes friends with Rudy Steiner, a boy who lives next door. They play soccer together and steal food from the local bakery. One day, Liesel finds out that her mother is alive and living in Munich. She decides to go see her, but before she leaves, she gives Rudy a kiss. When she arrives in Munich, she discovers that her mother is working as a prostitute. She tries to convince her mother to come back home with her, but her mother refuses. Liesel returns to Molching, where she continues to steal books and read them aloud to Hans. One day, while she's reading, she hears someone knocking on the door. It's Max Vandenburg, a Jewish man who has been hiding in their basement. He tells Liesel that he needs help getting out of Germany. Liesel agrees to help him, and they escape together. They travel through France and Switzerland, until finally reaching Italy. There, they meet up with other Jews who are trying to get to Palestine. Together, they make their way across Europe, avoiding Nazi soldiers along the way. Eventually, they reach Palestine, where they settle down and start new lives. Years later, Liesel receives a letter from Rudy. He says that he misses her and wants to see her again. So, Liesel travels back to Germany, where she meets up with Rudy. They spend time together, reminiscing about old times. Then, one day, Rudy asks Liesel to marry him. She accepts, and they live happily ever after.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
It got easier with time. Every aspect of it did: the choosing, the execution, the guilt, all passed quicker and with less resistance than the year before. Especially the choosing. When you live for hundreds of years, you learn to spot the evil as easily as anyone else can spot a grotesque scar marring a person's face. I notice every time a child glances fearfully at her father, and I know what it means. When a man ca n't look his wife in the eye, I know what it is she's done. When a stranger holds his stare just a little too long at a passing woman, I know his plans. These clues, invisible to most, have made my job so much easier. The first time, it was hard. I was unsure, I hesitated. I remember it well, even if most others have faded into each other in my memory. The year was 1692, and I had spent the first eleven months following around a man who had killed and tortured people to further himself, and he showed no remorse for it. But I was young, just twenty-five, and I still clung to my morals of "only god may judge.". I watched him sleep for just a minute too long and I lost my nerve. As I turned around to leave, something hard caught me on the back of the head, and the dim candle light faded away, my thoughts disappearing with it. I woke with a start and tried to draw a breath, but my lungs were met with an ice cold burn that gave me no air. Everything around me felt heavy, and I struggled to open my eyes. With terror, I realized I was under water. I may have been immortal, but I was not immune to the pain of drowning. I tried to reach out, to swim away, but a cloth surrounded me. I struggled to pull out my knife, trying not to gasp in any more water to feed the fire engulfing my lungs. After what seemed like hours, I managed to slice through the sack that held me at the bottom, and I kicked my numbed legs as hard as I could. The sunlight was blinding when I finally broke the surface and pulled myself to shore, sputtering out the ice cold water and collapsing on the frozen ground. I sat there shivering, waiting for the the sun to come warm me, or the burning in my lungs to subside, but neither did. I stood up and took in my surroundings, I had been at the bottom of the man's lake, and his manor, filled with his ill gotten wealth, sat before me. I knew I could play no games this time. I walked the grand steps to the front door and began pounding, my clothes showering the ground with shards of ice. The servant who opened the door was speechless at my appearance, he knew me for what I was and had no intention of interfering. I strode past him and down a long corridor towards the man's chambers, my knife gripped in my still frozen hand. God would not have given me this power if he did n't want me to use it. I would not count on surprises today, he would face the death he deserved.

output: He uses a book called The Grave Digger's Handbook, which he finds in the snow after Liesel steals it from a Nazi book-burning rally. Hans also paints over pages of Mein Kampf (Adolf Hitler's autobiography) and gives them to Liesel to write stories on. One day, Max Vandenburg, a Jewish fist-fighter, arrives at their home. His family once saved Hans' life during World War I, and now Hans feels obligated to protect Max. Max stays in the basement of the Hubermanns' house, where he writes several stories and paints over pages of Mein Kampf. He also becomes close friends with Liesel. Meanwhile, Liesel continues stealing books, including one from the mayor's house. She also develops feelings for Rudy Steiner, her best friend and partner-in-crime. One night, while hiding in the basement with Max, they hear planes flying overhead. They realize that the planes are dropping bombs on Himmel Street. Everyone rushes outside to see what has happened. Liesel sees Rudy lying dead in the street. She runs to him and tries to wake him up, but he does not respond. Liesel then notices that everyone else on the street is dead except for her and Max. They both run back inside the house and hide in the basement. A few days later, American soldiers arrive in Molching. They find Liesel and Max alive in the basement. They take them to a hospital, where Liesel recovers from her injuries. Max dies shortly afterwards. Liesel returns to Himmel Street and discovers that her foster parents have survived the bombing. However, Rosa Hubermann has gone insane due to grief over losing her son. Liesel decides to stay with the Hubermanns until she turns eighteen. On her eighteenth birthday, she receives a letter from Death. It says that he wants to meet her again someday. Liesel agrees to meet him, but only if he promises never to hurt anyone she loves. Death agrees to this condition. Liesel leaves Germany and travels to America, where she lives happily ever after.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
We attack immediately at sundown, once their solar power cells are no longer generating power and they are instead using stored power. Forcing the enemy to rely on finite reserves is a good strategy. From our intel gathering and scouting missions we know the machines' first response will be to send two robots per every identified threat. Not a bad bit of logic on their part. The wolves were able to acquire video of some of the human assaults. We can confirm each localized machine hub will have, at minimum, 50000 robot responders. Luckily, we have some numbers. The machines decided not to bury the dead or finish off the wounded humans but to ship them away from the machine hubs. The wolf and bat armies grew after each human battle. Intel reports also bolstered our confidence that the robots would have diminished ability to fend off our armies. The machines graciously eliminated silver from any of their infrastructure, preferring either denser or more conductive metal depending on the situation. The machines also eliminated religion from their human cattle, ending the scourge of crosses or other offending accoutrements. Also, the machines removed unnecessary costs in generating food for their human cattle, including flavorings such as garlic. We've coordinated our attack with other armies across the world. Tonight's sunset heralds our initial assault, beginning in the pacific and escalating westward as the sun's influence retreats behind the horizon. We have factored in failure to our first battle. Armies will retreat north to arctic regions taking advantage of the extended nights. Getting our allies from the southern hemisphere to agree that we should retake the northern hemisphere first was hard, the logistics of getting them north of the equator to join our armies was doubly so. We've drawn up a general strategy for every localized unit to follow, leaving room for them to improvise should any unforeseen complications arise. At sunset, send 50000 foot soldiers to each hub. Once the robots stop pouring out of the hub we set off EMPs. The humans discovered this only gained them around 30 seconds of disorientation within the robots. Immediately following the EMPs we electrify the magnets we've buried in the ground. A functioning robot can not be immobilized by a magnet. A disoriented one, however will be more susceptible. After that we fight. A hopefully diminished robot army will now be fighting what they will perceive as humans an large dogs. That's where our superhuman strength, speed, agility, and healing capabilities will come into play. During the ground assault a smaller team is to sever all outside communications from each hub. Disrupted communications should at least slow down global coordination with other hubs. We wanted to take out their communications before each assault, however the machines' penchant for redundancy and underground infrastructure proved cumbersome. It was decided to utilize the distraction of our infantry attacks as the opportunity to get around access issues. Watching the seconds tick by waiting for our signal to move should be nothing compared to the centuries I've been hiding underground waiting to resurface. Sadly this is not the case. I'm comforted by thoughts of global supremacy should we succeed. I'm not looking forward to the inevitable Werewolf/Vampire war that will take place after our victory over the machines. We'll have to deal with that problem when it comes, I suppose. For right now it's time to transform into a wolf. I've got some metal to munch.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
We never believed that the end would come, that the dawn would rise again. Every 300 years our moon orbits the world below us, this world is our guardian, it protects us, shelters us from all that the vast expanse of space has to offer: but it could not shelter us from itself, on the far side of the moons orbit lies a vast and ancient race, their empire sprawls across the planets surface and every 300 years, when our moon comes within striking distance they attack. It is said that when they do they bring with them giant beasts, created of the most foul magic, beasts of flesh with hearts as cold as ice. Our weapons could never stand against them, we never stood a chance. so when it came in 599 CE, the year of our holy father I huddled in fear in our capitol.My armies were in position to protect the citizens here, but I knew we stood no hope, our guns, as useful as they may be would never stand up against the might of the empire and so it was that on the turning point of the day we saw them come, and they came with the dawn. Vast ships pummeled our surface with rains of fire as the dawn swept across our land, melting the ever frozen landscape. Their armies landed on our surface, weapons firing some sort of plasmic mix. I watched my city crumble around me as the fighting raged on, then, then it happened. A sound like the great bellow of some ancient beast shuddered from within the earth itself; and with it they came. Hulking creatures in the shapes of men, my eyes adjusted slowly to the new light as I focused in on the great beasts that would be our doom. I watched them huge machines, not flesh but etched metal, rise and form into ranks. The Empires soldiers marched up main avenue right towards the metal horde that was slowly collecting outside our main base within the city, our last bastion. our only hope. In between the two armies, a small child wandered into the street, clearly having lost her mother and searching for anyone to car. My heart wretched as I saw one of the soldiers level its weapon at her. and my scream of pain filled the room as it fired. But as the smoke cleared I saw only a metal body, covered in plasma, shaking it off as if it were nothing more than fresh snow, and behind its protective metal shell sat the little girl. and I beheld the glory, of the new dawn.
