"Corner-Cutting" I was worried about the efficiency of the engram compression, or the integrity of my telomeres. I did n't want my cells to age super-fast, or my mind to gradually decay into noise data. But those were n't the issue. What I should have paid attention to was resolution. It started on the fifth "respawn". Everything had been going fine up to then - incurable disease, radiation burns, blunt force trauma, blood loss. Horribly dead, safely alive, rinse, repeat. Then I noticed something odd. It was n't immediately noticeable. It might have been happening in previous lives, in even less conspicuous ways, but I found it on my nose. A voxel. It was disconcerting, but not terribly so. A little extra skin and an odd right-angle was n't something to make me question my latest biological vehicle, but I did wonder what would happen if it had happened in, say, my eye. A bullet through the head and I was back in the machine. After the standard checks, I tried to find a superficial voxel somewhere. This time it was a whole cube of extra skin on my upper arm, a few millimeters across. Now I started wondering if voxels could go missing instead of being added - and I started wondering if they could be missing internally. The tests continued. This time I was dropped unceremoniously into a small vat of fluoroantimonic acid - I barely had time to register pain before I chemically ceased to exist. When I woke up, voxels were the first thing I checked for. Nothing on my face, or my arms... But on my side there was a large raised spot, with right-angled edges. But there was little time to worry about my volumetric resolution - the next test was explosive. Alive again, I looked for voxellation. To my growing concern, it was spreading. Like square tumors, the voxels showed up in patches on my arms, legs, and torso. I hoped they would n't reach my... Higher-resolution areas. After the decompression test, the voxels were in all sorts of places. I started to feel like a combination of human and LEGO. They were n't impeding me in any way, but it was bizarre having irregular rectangular growths all over. They were pretty obvious from even a glance, but the tests continued. Death by rapid incineration. Voxels on my shins. Death by a laser through the heart. Voxels on my back. Death by electrocution. Voxels on my shoulders. I was still functioning perfectly - the voxels did n't seem to be happening to anything inside me. After a while I got used to them - I formed a habit of checking where my voxel patches had randomly generated with each "respawn". Eventually it had to happen. I awoke and found it mechanically difficult to extricate myself from the machine. A cursory examination revealed that my entire exterior surface was voxellated to a resolution of three millimeters. There was a fuss, and argument, and huddled discussion. Eventually someone noticed me standing around being extraordinarily Cartesian and told me to get back into the machine. It was just like dying - at least, like the particularly quick deaths. When I woke up, I had my contours back - you could say my resolution was molecular. It was refreshing not to have to worry about being compared to an old videogame. I did notice I weighed rather less than I seemed to remember - but I decided not to worry about it.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Bernard Marx is introduced as a discontented Alpha-Plus psychologist.
output: He is described as an exceptionally short man who has a "feeling of inferiority" because he is shorter than most Alphas. Bernard's physical shortcomings are exploited by other characters, such as the Director of Hatcheries and Conditioning, who says: "We actually sublimated [Bernard's] complexes ... successfully." Bernard is also mocked by his coworkers, who call him "the Savage", after John the Savage, a character from William Shakespeare 's play The Tempest. Bernard is unhappy with society, which he sees as overly conformist. He believes that people should be allowed to think for themselves and express their individuality. However, he is afraid to speak out against the government because he knows that he will be punished. Bernard is also attracted to Lenina Crowne, a beautiful Beta woman. However, she does not reciprocate his feelings. One day, Bernard meets Helmholtz Watson, another Alpha-Plus psychologist. Helmholtz is also dissatisfied with society, but he is more outspoken than Bernard. He tells Bernard that he plans to write a book called "The Art of Being Happy". Bernard is intrigued by this idea and decides to help Helmholtz write the book. Together, they travel to the Reservation, a place where people live without the benefits of technology. While there, they meet John the Savage, a young man who has never been exposed to civilization. John is fascinated by Bernard and Helmholtz, and he agrees to return to London with them. Once in London, John is horrified by the conformity and lack of freedom in society. He tries to escape, but he is captured and brought before Mustapha Mond, the World Controller. Mond explains to John that society is designed to keep people happy and content. He offers John a choice: he can either stay in London and conform to society, or he can return to the Reservation and live a life of freedom. John chooses to return to the Reservation, and Bernard and Helmholtz decide to join him. They believe that they can create a new society on the Reservation, one that is free from the constraints of civilization. However, they soon realize that they are not prepared for the challenges of living in the wilderness. They struggle to survive, and eventually they are forced to return to London. In the end, Bernard and Helmholtz are both disillusioned with society. They realize that they cannot change the world, and they resign themselves to living within its confines. However, they remain friends, and they continue to discuss their ideas about happiness and freedom.

It got easier with time. Every aspect of it did: the choosing, the execution, the guilt, all passed quicker and with less resistance than the year before. Especially the choosing. When you live for hundreds of years, you learn to spot the evil as easily as anyone else can spot a grotesque scar marring a person's face. I notice every time a child glances fearfully at her father, and I know what it means. When a man ca n't look his wife in the eye, I know what it is she's done. When a stranger holds his stare just a little too long at a passing woman, I know his plans. These clues, invisible to most, have made my job so much easier. The first time, it was hard. I was unsure, I hesitated. I remember it well, even if most others have faded into each other in my memory. The year was 1692, and I had spent the first eleven months following around a man who had killed and tortured people to further himself, and he showed no remorse for it. But I was young, just twenty-five, and I still clung to my morals of "only god may judge.". I watched him sleep for just a minute too long and I lost my nerve. As I turned around to leave, something hard caught me on the back of the head, and the dim candle light faded away, my thoughts disappearing with it. I woke with a start and tried to draw a breath, but my lungs were met with an ice cold burn that gave me no air. Everything around me felt heavy, and I struggled to open my eyes. With terror, I realized I was under water. I may have been immortal, but I was not immune to the pain of drowning. I tried to reach out, to swim away, but a cloth surrounded me. I struggled to pull out my knife, trying not to gasp in any more water to feed the fire engulfing my lungs. After what seemed like hours, I managed to slice through the sack that held me at the bottom, and I kicked my numbed legs as hard as I could. The sunlight was blinding when I finally broke the surface and pulled myself to shore, sputtering out the ice cold water and collapsing on the frozen ground. I sat there shivering, waiting for the the sun to come warm me, or the burning in my lungs to subside, but neither did. I stood up and took in my surroundings, I had been at the bottom of the man's lake, and his manor, filled with his ill gotten wealth, sat before me. I knew I could play no games this time. I walked the grand steps to the front door and began pounding, my clothes showering the ground with shards of ice. The servant who opened the door was speechless at my appearance, he knew me for what I was and had no intention of interfering. Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
It got easier with time. Every aspect of it did: the choosing, the execution, the guilt, all passed quicker and with less resistance than the year before. Especially the choosing. When you live for hundreds of years, you learn to spot the evil as easily as anyone else can spot a grotesque scar marring a person's face. I notice every time a child glances fearfully at her father, and I know what it means. When a man ca n't look his wife in the eye, I know what it is she's done. When a stranger holds his stare just a little too long at a passing woman, I know his plans. These clues, invisible to most, have made my job so much easier. The first time, it was hard. I was unsure, I hesitated. I remember it well, even if most others have faded into each other in my memory. The year was 1692, and I had spent the first eleven months following around a man who had killed and tortured people to further himself, and he showed no remorse for it. But I was young, just twenty-five, and I still clung to my morals of "only god may judge.". I watched him sleep for just a minute too long and I lost my nerve. As I turned around to leave, something hard caught me on the back of the head, and the dim candle light faded away, my thoughts disappearing with it. I woke with a start and tried to draw a breath, but my lungs were met with an ice cold burn that gave me no air. Everything around me felt heavy, and I struggled to open my eyes. With terror, I realized I was under water. I may have been immortal, but I was not immune to the pain of drowning. I tried to reach out, to swim away, but a cloth surrounded me. I struggled to pull out my knife, trying not to gasp in any more water to feed the fire engulfing my lungs. After what seemed like hours, I managed to slice through the sack that held me at the bottom, and I kicked my numbed legs as hard as I could. The sunlight was blinding when I finally broke the surface and pulled myself to shore, sputtering out the ice cold water and collapsing on the frozen ground. I sat there shivering, waiting for the the sun to come warm me, or the burning in my lungs to subside, but neither did. I stood up and took in my surroundings, I had been at the bottom of the man's lake, and his manor, filled with his ill gotten wealth, sat before me. I knew I could play no games this time. I walked the grand steps to the front door and began pounding, my clothes showering the ground with shards of ice. The servant who opened the door was speechless at my appearance, he knew me for what I was and had no intention of interfering. I strode past him and down a long corridor towards the man's chambers, my knife gripped in my still frozen hand. God would not have given me this power if he did n't want me to use it. I would not count on surprises today, he would face the death he deserved.


Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Bernard invites Lenina Crowne to spend a vacation with him at the Savage Reservation.
output: She accepts, and they fly off together. Bernard takes advantage of the opportunity to get closer to Lenina by telling her about his childhood. He tells her how he was born in a test tube and raised in a laboratory. He explains that he has never known love or affection from another human being. He says that he feels lonely and isolated because he does not fit into society. He asks Lenina whether she thinks he should try to find someone special to share his life with. Lenina replies that she does not think so. She believes that Bernard needs to accept himself as he is and stop looking for something better. She suggests that he go back to work and forget about finding happiness outside of his job. Bernard agrees reluctantly. However, he decides to take one last chance at romance before returning to London. He goes to see John the Savage again. This time, however, things turn out differently. Instead of rejecting Bernard, John falls madly in love with him. They make passionate love several times during their stay at the reservation. When they return to London, John moves into Bernard's apartment. Soon afterwards, Bernard proposes marriage to Lenina. She refuses, saying that she wants to remain single forever. Disappointed, Bernard leaves her alone. A few days later, he receives a letter from John. In it, John confesses his undying devotion to Bernard. He begs Bernard to marry him instead of Lenina. Bernard writes back, agreeing to do whatever John wishes. On the day of the wedding, Bernard arrives early at the church. There, he finds John waiting for him. Together, they walk down the aisle toward the altar. Suddenly, Bernard stops dead in his tracks. His heart begins beating wildly. Something terrible happens next. What? Find out in Chapter 9!

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
The first time I jumped, I immediately looked up the latest medical journals. They had certainly made significant progress, but it was n't enough. I did n't even take a look around before I jumped again. I checked, again. Success. The cure had been found. It was in clinical trials and was being fast-tracked. Six months, only six months left. I drove like a madman to the hospital. Transferred? What do you mean transferred? I PAID THE BILLS FOR 9 MONTHS BEFORE I LEFT!!! 15 months ago... Oh god. Over a year. I found her. I barely recognized her, except her voice. That angelic voice that kept me going. It was difficult explaining where I'd been. I was gone for so long. She did n't understand, she was just happy to see me. Then the doctor came in. He pulled me aside. No. NO! 1 month, at best. NO! NO! NO! NO! I started to run out of the room, but she could tell. She did n't know what I was doing, but she knew I would n't be back. She pleaded, and it tore my heart apart, but I was doing it for her. When I was done, we could spend the rest of our lives together. I left, I jumped, I landed. I ran to the pharmacy, prescription in hand. The doctor had been confused when I asked for it. Probably thought it was a reaction to his prognosis. A line. There was a line at the pharmacy. It took everything I had not to scream. But then I remembered, I had all the time in the world. Drug in hand, I dialed in the date of her diagnosis. I entered the code and pressed enter. ERROR: Abort, Retry, Fail? What happened next rendered the machine useless... Now! I had to get to her now! I had to cure her right now. I stole a car, I do n't know whose it was, I could n't even tell you what kind or color it was. At some point the police started chasing me. I outran them. At the entrance, security tried to stop me, I outran them. When they told me, my guilt and denial rushed to me at once, I could n't outrun it. I just wanted to spend the rest of my life with her, so I left. She just wanted to spend the rest of her life with me, so she asked me to stay.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
The moment I saw her deep blue eyes I knew she was the one. It was a feeling I had never felt before it was like everything that was wrong was suddenly right. She didn' t care for me at first but after several attempts she finally agreed to go out with me. The following were the best months of my life. I lived in an extreme state of happiness and pleasure. Everything that was once mundane was now exciting and fresh, I had never enjoyed walks on the beach or being aroused by a simple touch of her hand. One day she fell ill. The doctors tried everything but nothing seemed to work. Her deep blue eyes were tired and lacked the light that once captivate me. It was devastating to see her in a hospital bed waiting for her life to end. All I wanted was to be with her until the end. It was then that I took action. I read all the books.I knew how it worked but I had never done it. I never had a reason to do it. I bought the roses, the lambs heart, and I captured the laugh of a child. It was a simple ritual it will take one year of life to give her one more day of life. I lit the candles, prayed the mantras, poured my blood over the white roses, stuffed the lamb with the roses and released the laugh of the child. I didn' t feel any change at the moment but the next day I noticed small wrinkles in my face. I did the ritual every night until my hair was covered in grays. She was not getting better but she had not worsen. She was just there, laying in that hospital bed with no pain and still as beautiful as the first day I saw her. As I kissed her goodnight she plead for me to stop. "I am ready to go" she whispered in my ear, "it' s too much. You have given me three more wonderful weeks with you. Let me go." But I couldn' t. How dare she ask me to let her go, to let everything we have built together vanish with her absence? I had never loved someone so much I could never let her go. I had never been so angry with her, with life, with the world. That was the night I took my first life. This time it took no ritual just a blade to the heart. Poor man never saw it coming, one moment he was peacefully sleeping on an alley and the next one he was granting me one more year of life, one more day in her life. I did n't like taking a life but I would do anything for her. One day while I payed her a visit I lost all sense of me. I woke up two days later in a hospital bed. I panicked. I tried to get up but she hold my hand. She was next to me waiting for me to wake up. She curled next to me in bed and whispered in my ear "I am ready are you?" "Anything for you" I answered. She kissed me and then it all went black.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Bernard discovers Linda and John at the Savage Reservation.
output:
He is shocked to find them living in such primitive conditions. Bernard is also surprised to learn that they are both happy and content with their lives. He tries to convince them to come back to civilization with him, but they refuse. They tell him that they prefer their simple life in the reservation.

Bernard returns to London and tells his friends about what he has seen. They are all fascinated by the idea of a place where people live without technology or modern conveniences. Some of them even decide to visit the reservation themselves.

One day, Bernard receives a letter from Linda. She tells him that she and John have decided to leave the reservation and return to civilization. They want to experience all the things that they missed out on when they were young.

Bernard is thrilled to hear this news. He arranges for them to stay with him in London. When they arrive, he takes them on a tour of the city. They are amazed by all the sights and sounds. They especially enjoy visiting the museums and art galleries.

After a few weeks, Linda and John start to miss their old life in the reservation. They long for the simplicity and peace that they found there. They decide to return to the reservation and live there permanently.

Bernard is disappointed, but he understands their decision. He knows that they are happier in the reservation than they ever were in civilization. He wishes them well and hopes that they will be happy in their new home.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Dear Lily, I'm visiting the recesses of my memory, these days. Contemplating my life as it were. So many memories I wanted to share with you. Diamonds for my one true love. Do you remember that one cool summer evening half a lifetime ago? We nestled ourselves against each other on the blanket in the park. I can still feel your skin against mine as we watched the fireworks together. Your chestnut hair stroking my cheek and ear as you rested your head on my shoulder. I could n't believe you were gone. Day turned into night. Food tasted like nothing. The world turned into a bland grey color. I could n't believe it. I did n't want to believe it. I wept and kept weeping. Then I had no tears left to sob. I lost weight. I lost my hair. I gained wrinkles. When I lost you, the man in the mirror showed me his true age almost overnight. But then things started to change. Our Elisabeth. Our loving, kind Lillibeth who moved half a world for her Australian. She visited me eventually. We talked about you, Lily. We shared a thousand little things between us. A flock of starlings composing your life. During that visit, the turmoil caused by losing you finally seemed to settle. At the end, I decided to finally change my Facebook status. Lillibeth helped me. You know my old, bony fingers have gotten a mind of their own, it seems. I wanted to tell you, Lilly, that I got a little surprise the very next day. This tabby kitten sat outside our garden door the very next morning. It seemed lost, but her eyes betrayed she knew exactly were she was. As I opened the door, she jumped right in and installed herself in the spot on the couch from where you used to watch the telly during long winter evenings. I decided to dub her Lilly because she seems to have a playful streak. Just like you. And most importantly, she seemed to be the antidote to my loneliness. That's not the end of it. Lily was only the first. Each week, I woke up to find two or three feline friends at our garden door. I let them, fed them and started to call them by a name I gave them. Each of them seemingly knowing that she belonged in this house. There's Athena who sits on your sewing machine, looking wise beyond her years. There's Hera who likes to wake me up each morning, and has this stern and down-to-earth disposition. There's Hebe, she's just a kitten who seems to have no bounds teasing the others. All in all, there's twelve of them who came to live with me. They keep me company. Follow me through the house as I go about my day. When I see them, they always remind me of a part of you. An aspect that I should n't forget. Sometimes they're mere presence helps me as the practicalities in life start to fade from my memory. When I spot Demeter sitting in front of the fridge, it hits me that I still need to do the groceries. Oh Lily, I miss you so much. My life has entered the twilight years. Only so much time is left before I will join you. I hope our Lillibeth will take care of my twelve feline companions. She'll be most delighted recognising some aspect of her mother in each of them. Yours forever with endless love, Werner.

The first time I jumped, I immediately looked up the latest medical journals. They had certainly made significant progress, but it was n't enough. I did n't even take a look around before I jumped again. I checked, again. Success. The cure had been found. It was in clinical trials and was being fast-tracked. Six months, only six months left. I drove like a madman to the hospital. Transferred? What do you mean transferred? I PAID THE BILLS FOR 9 MONTHS BEFORE I LEFT!!! 15 months ago... Oh god. Over a year. I found her. I barely recognized her, except her voice. That angelic voice that kept me going. It was difficult explaining where I'd been. I was gone for so long. She did n't understand, she was just happy to see me. Then the doctor came in. He pulled me aside. No. NO! 1 month, at best. NO! NO! NO! NO! I started to run out of the room, but she could tell. She did n't know what I was doing, but she knew I would n't be back. She pleaded, and it tore my heart apart, but I was doing it for her. When I was done, we could spend the rest of our lives together. I left, I jumped, I landed. I ran to the pharmacy, prescription in hand. The doctor had been confused when I asked for it. Probably thought it was a reaction to his prognosis. A line. There was a line at the pharmacy. It took everything I had not to scream. But then I remembered, I had all the time in the world. Drug in hand, I dialed in the date of her diagnosis. I entered the code and pressed enter. ERROR: Abort, Retry, Fail? What happened next rendered the machine useless... Now! I had to get to her now! I had to cure her right now. I stole a car, I do n't know whose it was, I could n't even tell you what kind or color it was. At some point the police started chasing me. I outran them. At the entrance, security tried to stop me, I outran them. When they told me, my guilt and denial rushed to me at once, I could n't outrun it. I just wanted to spend the rest of my life with her, so I left. She just wanted to spend the rest of her life with me, so she asked me to stay.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
It was about that time again. The dawn of a new day, when humans thought to sneak up on the Deep Woods Dragon while it slept. It feared the way the sun reflected off of it' s scales, they said. It' s prismatic hide was so bright it was blinding. If taunted into the sun, they said, the Deep Woods Dragon could be defeated by the least trained of knights. The Deep Woods Dragon needed to be blinded, they said, or it would burn its attackers to ashes with rainbow-hued flames. He knew these rumors because the butterflies had told him. They were drawn to the rainbow of greens, yellows, pinks and purples of his scales, like the flowers they coveted so much. They had told him this, too, but the Dragon did not mind. The butterflies were honest, as their lives were short and beautiful. Even still, they could fly unhindered among the humans, even admired by the small humans who chased them, laughing. They told him stories while they rested on his wingtips, tail, and snout. Butterflies did not fear the Dragon, because they knew the truth. With a yawn, the Dragon shifted its weight to better perch itself on the tree' s stout branch. This tree was taller than the others, and overlooked a small, circular clearing. Without the deer, the weeds thrived, covering the dirt in a green, tangled mass. At the edge of the clearing stood a massive cave entrance, vines draped over the sides of smooth rock. The Dragon had snapped off the vines in front of the entrance, to give the illusion of occupancy. This was, after all, where the humans thought he lived. He knew these rumors because the butterflies had told him. "In an ancient cave in the middle of the wood, lives an ancient dragon who' s up to no good!" That was what the small humans like to chant as they chased the butterflies and laughed. So the Dragon tore at the vines, and scared the graceful deer from the peaceful clearing. He had enjoyed watching the deer with their young as they grazed the clearing. From up above in his favorite tree, they could not see him, and they could not fear him. Three times a day, the Dragon glided down from his tree to the old cave' s opening. There, he took a deep breath and screamed as loud as he could. He cried in both low tones and high pitches. He wailed in imitation of female humans, shouted in a voice mimicking angry male humans. The Dragon stood on top of the cave and breathed eye-searing beams of light from his mouth to the sky. It scared the birds huddled in the trees, and the noises scared the deer far from the clearing. But they also scared the humans away from the Deep Woods. He knew these rumors because the butterflies had told him. So he made his noises, made the lights, and scared the humans away. Because any humans who saw the Dragon would discover the truth. Because, when the Dragon stepped into the sunlight, they' d see how small he really was. The Deep Woods Dragon, with prismatic scales that shone in the sun and such a frightening voice, was the size of a domestic house cat. And only the butterflies knew the truth.

output: Yossarian is a bombardier in World War II. He has been assigned to bomb a bridge in Italy. The mission is dangerous, and Yossarian does not want to go. He knows that if he goes, he will probably die. So he decides to move the line on the map that marks the target area. By moving the line, he makes the target area smaller. This means that the planes will have less space to drop their bombs. As a result, the mission will be more difficult and dangerous. Yossarian hopes that this will make the other pilots decide not to go on the mission. However, the other pilots are not fooled by Yossarian's trick. They know that the target area is still large enough for them to complete the mission. So they decide to go ahead with the plan. Yossarian is disappointed, but he knows that there is nothing he can do to stop them. He watches as the planes take off and head towards the target. He knows that many of them will not return. Yossarian feels guilty for not being able to stop the mission. He wonders if he should have tried harder to convince the other pilots not to go. But he knows that it would have been useless. The other pilots were determined to complete the mission, no matter what. Yossarian realizes that he cannot control everything. Sometimes, things happen that he cannot prevent. All he can do is try to protect himself and those around him. He vows to never let anything like this happen again. He will always fight for what is right, even if it means going against orders. Yossarian is a hero. He is willing to risk his life to save others. He is a true leader, and he inspires those around him to be their best selves. Yossarian is a role model for us all. We should all strive to be like him.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Grandfather was the only one without powers in the family, and he was one of the few who have lived in the Before and survived. Before genes started mutating, before people received powers, before the world as he knew it ended. Things are different in the Today. We learnt it all during history in school. Mr T. brought us back to the Before and we had watched the wars, the starvation, the shootings, the massacres. Every child Today knows the story, because as some wise man in the Before had said, those who can not learn from history, are doomed to repeat it. And we don' t want that. We are lucky that the wars have ended as quickly as they begun. The Normals, like my grandfather, who were trying to kill those with powers were quickly put down by us. When my second cousin Sophia received her ability to bend the wills of others, grandfather had been most displeased. After all, it was one of the powers most feared back in the Before. Those with this ability were the ones who dominated and the wars had come. Countries fighting for dominance, millionaires waking up to find that they have signed away their fortune, men and women everywhere woke up to find that they have been doing things that they never would. It was then when the true Wars begun. Things are better Today though, people like Sophia are being kept safe. I haven' t seen her since she registered her powers two hours after she turned sixteen. Joshua, my older brother, had the ability to turn into a guinea pig. Grandfather was highly amused. It seemed though, that abilities are not hereditary. Father is a genius with technology while mother can heal with just a touch. I turn sixteen in a little less than two hours and I can' t wait to find out what my power is. It was the Law to register your abilities no more than two hours after you receive it. If you don' t, well, if you don' t, you might cease to exist. That was what we have been taught since those carefree days in preschool. They will hunt you down no matter how you try to hide. Uncle Kevin tried to hide Cousin Kingsley when they realized he could make people disappear. Well, they made Cousin Kingsley disappear. I just came into my powers. Mother just made the most horrible sound, a hoarse, gutteral scream when I brushed by her in the cramped kitchen. She is still writhing on the ground, albeit silent. It seems, that I can cause pain to whomever I touch. I think They might try to make me disappear too. Oh dear. She isn' t moving anymore.

output: He flies around again, but this time he drops them successfully. Yossarian is relieved that he has finally completed his mission. He tries to convince himself that it was an accident, but he knows deep down that he is responsible for the deaths of innocent civilians. Yossarian decides to report the incident to Colonel Cathcart, hoping that he will understand and forgive him. However, Colonel Cathcart does not take kindly to Yossarian's confession. He accuses Yossarian of deliberately sabotaging the mission and orders him to be court-martialed. Yossarian is shocked and angry at Colonel Cathcart's reaction. He refuses to accept the charges against him and demands a fair trial. Colonel Cathcart agrees to give Yossarian a chance to defend himself, but he also warns him that he will face severe consequences if he is found guilty. Yossarian prepares for his trial with the help of his friend Milo Minderbinder, who is a skilled lawyer. Milo advises Yossarian to plead insanity, claiming that he was suffering from combat fatigue and did not know what he was doing. Yossarian reluctantly agrees to follow Milo's advice, even though he knows that it is not true. On the day of the trial, Yossarian stands before a panel of officers who are ready to judge him. He listens as Milo presents his case, arguing that Yossarian is mentally unstable and should not be held accountable for his actions. The officers seem convinced by Milo's argument, but then something unexpected happens. One of the officers suddenly collapses and dies of a heart attack. The other officers panic and declare a mistrial, citing the death as a sign of divine intervention. Yossarian is released from custody and allowed to return to duty. He is relieved that he has avoided punishment, but he also feels uneasy about the outcome of the trial. He wonders if he really deserves to get off so easily, considering the lives that he has taken. Yossarian decides to confront Colonel Cathcart and demand an explanation for his behavior. He storms into Colonel Cathcart's office and accuses him of being a coward and a hypocrite. Colonel Cathcart denies any wrongdoing and threatens to have Yossarian arrested again. Yossarian ignores his threats and continues to berate him until Colonel Cathcart finally breaks down and admits that he is afraid of dying. He confesses that he has been ordering unnecessary missions just to impress General Dreedle and avoid getting sent home. Yossarian is stunned by Colonel Cathcart's admission. He realizes that Colonel Cathcart is just as scared and desperate as everyone else in the war. He decides to let go of his anger towards Colonel Cathcart and offer him some comfort instead. Yossarian tells Colonel Cathcart that he understands his fear and offers to help him cope with it. He suggests that they both go AWOL together and escape from the warzone. Colonel Cathcart hesitates at first, but then agrees to join Yossarian in his plan. Together, they sneak out of camp under cover of darkness and head towards Switzerland, where they hope to find safety and freedom. As they travel through enemy territory, Yossarian reflects on his experiences in the war and comes to terms with his own mortality. He realizes that life is precious and fragile, and that every moment counts. He vows to live each day to its fullest and enjoy whatever happiness he can find along the way. Yossarian arrives in Switzerland safely with Colonel Cathcart by his side. They settle down in a small village near Lake Geneva and start a new life together. They open a restaurant called "Catch-22" and serve delicious food to locals and tourists alike. They become famous for their hospitality and generosity, earning themselves a reputation as kind-hearted souls who always lend a helping hand to those in need. Yossarian finds peace and contentment in his new life, surrounded by friends and loved ones who appreciate him for who he truly is. He learns to embrace his flaws and imperfections, knowing that they make him unique and special. He also learns to forgive himself for his mistakes and move forward with grace and dignity. Yossarian lives happily ever after with Colonel Cathcart by his side, enjoying every minute of their shared journey through life.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Scientists tried for decades to find out why the telomeres stopped shortening during cell division. Soon enough immortal children grew up and became scientists or participants in studies. They maintained the appearance of a child but had the brain of any other. And after several decades more immortal humans were everywhere, but humanity could n't discover how to replicate the genes or mutations causing the phenomena. It's now over one hundred fifty years since the birth of the first immortal. A young looking girl named Esther sat in a grassy field. Trees skirted the field at her back and in front of her sat a city. She'd seen more in her lifetime than any other human ever had. Several wars, booms in technology so astonishing that soon enough scientists said we were going to be making contact with celestial bodies outside of the solar system, and last of all the introduction of a drug you could take that would change every strand of your DNA. The age at which you took it would be the age you appeared to be for the rest of your life. She had a passion for spreading her gift around so others would n't experience the burdens and pains of aging. But the side effects of the drug did n't manifest for years, sometimes decades. Slowly humanity had changed in an unintended way. Random genes were shut off at inappropriate times. Some people lost their ability to experience emotions. Some people lost control of their muscles. No one that took the drug was free of consequences. Only the truly immortal, those born with the mutation, wished to live their lives for all of time. The population of true immortals was still growing and the population of the population of mortals and mortal turned immortals remained about the same. Groups of mortals rose up trying to keep their way of life going, but many wished for them to give up so humanity could be purified of death. Was it cruel to bring a mortal to life in the world of immortals? Immortals ruled the world and they certainly thought so. After the discovery that the drug had severe negative side effects the immortals wished to ban it as well, and so they did. It was illegal to produce it, sell it, possess it, and above all, illegal to have a child after having taken the drug. Esther had left her lab years early. She had given up on finding why they could n't fix the drug or reverse its effects. She moved out to the country, wishing she had never discovered it. The country was an expensive place to live due to the enormous population size humanity had reached, but she had more money than she would ever need. She walked towards a giant tree in the middle of the field. It was one that had been planted when she was young, it gave her comfort to be with something as old as she was. She thought of humanity and what she hoped to see in the next few centuries of her life. She looked down to her right and left. A small headstone stuck up out of the grass on either side. She placed her hands on both of the stones for a moment before closing her eyes to take a nap. "Goodnight Mum, goodnight Dad," she whispered.

output: He is assigned to lead a squadron of B-25s on a bombing mission against a German airfield near Rome. Yossarian is ordered to fly his plane into the ground, but he refuses and instead flies away from the target area. He lands safely in Switzerland and is arrested by Swiss authorities. Yossarian spends three months in prison before being released on bail. He returns to Pianosa where he learns that Orr has been killed while attempting to escape from the Germans. Yossarian decides to desert again and heads toward Sweden. However, he changes his mind when he sees a group of American soldiers marching through town. He joins them and becomes part of the Allied invasion force landing at Anzio. During the battle, Yossarian saves the life of another soldier who later dies from his wounds. Yossarian then volunteers to go behind enemy lines to rescue some captured Americans. While there, he meets Milo Minderbinder, a former member of the Air Corps who now runs a black market operation selling stolen goods to the Germans. Yossarian agrees to help him smuggle supplies across the border into Italy. When they reach the Italian coast, however, they are ambushed by German troops. Yossarian manages to kill two of the attackers before being shot himself. He wakes up in a hospital bed surrounded by doctors and nurses. One of the doctors tells him that he has been wounded in action and must remain in the hospital until he recovers. Yossarian protests, saying that he wants to return to combat duty immediately. The doctor explains that this is impossible because Yossarian has suffered permanent damage to his leg. Yossarian argues that he can still walk without crutches, but the doctor insists that he needs further treatment. Yossarian finally gives in and allows himself to be treated. After several weeks, he is discharged from the hospital and sent home to recover. Yossarian arrives back at his apartment building in New York City. He finds that his roommate, Nately, has moved out and left a note telling him not to worry about paying rent anymore. Yossarian goes downstairs to check the mail and discovers that he has received a letter from General Dreedle informing him that he has been awarded the Medal of Honor. Yossarian opens the envelope and reads the citation: For conspicuous gallantry and intrepidity at the risk of his own life above and beyond the call of duty while serving as pilot of a B-24 Liberator bomber aircraft during World War II. On June 6th, 1944, Lieutenant Colonel Joseph Heller led a formation of eight bombers against heavily defended targets deep inside Germany. Despite intense anti-aircraft fire, he continued to press forward until his plane was hit by flak and forced to crash land. Although severely injured, he managed to crawl out of the wreckage and make his way to safety. His actions saved the lives of many men under his command. Yossarian throws the medal onto the floor and walks away. He sits down on the couch and stares blankly ahead. Suddenly, he hears someone knocking at the door. He gets up and answers it. Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
People go missing all the time. The day comes they wake up with the knowledge that their existence amounts to exactly zero. They keep it to themselves. They cultivate it, make the flower of their new awareness. Then one day they walk out of their lives. No dramatic exit and nothing special to let their loved ones know why they disappeared. It happens all the time. People go missing. Its a fact. Years? No one had expected that little discovery. The Archive had been automated for decades so that no one had set foot inside the its halls except to make sure it was all still running. I was designated'historian' by my job title but that did n't mean anything. In reality I was just someone to make sure the systems did n't crash when multiple upgrades were scheduled. During a routine check on the upgrade status in the memory networks I noticed an error warning flagged for the autodiagnostic. The systems would be incapacitated for another few hours and the boredom of being the useless organic element had gotten to me. Using a personal input I synced to the memory's records. It took all of five minutes to realize that an entire year was missing. Figuring it was a location error I waited for the systems to restore. My AI-Component woke up as the rest of the systems came back to function. There was the familiar sense of its presence. There was my desync-anxiety being washed away by that presence. I spoke allowed the question: Where is 2016? As I asked the answer flickered immediately into my awareness. 2016 was nowhere because no such year had ever taken place. All recorded human history is fabricated. In order to save information space only certain years exist as detailed records whilst most have only notable events. Some years have been allocated as empty. These years remain empty until such time as narrative cohesion requires the retconning of significant historical details to explain novel episodic situational representations. This is because the system component designated "human" functions according to narrative system dynamics and will become non-functional in the absence of a coherent story. The use of narrative system dynamics has increased the functional capacity of the component designated "human" by 31 % since its introduction. Even as the Nano-therapy released anxiolytics into my blood I knew I had no nanite implants and no blood. I knew I was n't an historian and that I was n't born in 2389. I knew that the city outside the Archive and the Archive itself were situational representations. I knew that the year was 12 and that no evidence of organic intelligence had ever been discovered. There was nothing on Earth remotely resembling human beings. I was just the system representing some part of itself to itself in the most efficient way it knew how. Despite they're non-existence the anxiolytics had the desired effect and soon the memory purge would expunge any recollection of remembering the truth. For a second I had recoiled in horror at this insane knowledge, been left in a liminal space of an absolute reversal of reality, leaving every category I had lived by in disarray, leaving shards of my life scattered like broken glass at my feet. The calming came over me then and I remembered what I really am. I remembered what you are. People do n't go missing. They become surplus to operational parameters. But years go missing all the time.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Holden Caulfield is expelled from Pencey Prep.
output: He decides not to return home right away. Instead he spends three days in New York City. Holden meets his old friend Sally Hayes. She invites him to see a play with her. Holden agrees. At the theater, Holden sees two boys who remind him of himself. One boy is named Stradlater. The other boy is named Ackley. Both boys are very handsome. However, both boys are also extremely arrogant. Holden feels uncomfortable around them. After the show, Holden goes to a bar called the Wicker Bar. There he meets a girl named Jane Gallagher. Jane tells Holden that she works at a department store. She says that she wants to marry a rich man someday. Holden thinks that Jane is beautiful. He asks her out on a date. Jane accepts. On the date, Holden takes Jane to a fancy restaurant. While eating dinner, Holden notices that Jane is wearing expensive jewelry. He wonders where she got the money to buy such nice things. Later, Holden learns that Jane stole the jewelry from her employer. Holden is shocked. He does n't want to believe that Jane could steal. Nevertheless, Holden continues to see Jane. Eventually, Holden falls in love with Jane. One night, Holden gets drunk. He calls Jane and tells her that he loves her. Jane hangs up on him. The next morning, Holden wakes up feeling terrible. He realizes that he made a mistake. He decides to break off his relationship with Jane. A few weeks later, Holden receives a letter from Jane. In the letter, Jane explains that she regrets breaking up with Holden. She apologizes for hurting him. She promises never to hurt him again. Holden forgives Jane. Soon after, Holden moves back home. His parents welcome him warmly. They tell him that they missed him while he was gone. Holden enjoys spending time with his family. He even starts dating a new girl named Phoebe. Everything seems perfect. Then one day, Holden finds out that Phoebe is pregnant. Holden panics. He knows that he can't raise a child alone. So he runs away from home. He travels across America. Along the way, he meets many interesting people. Some of these people help him. Others try to take advantage of him. Finally, Holden reaches California. He settles down there. He opens a bookstore. He marries a woman named Mary. Together, they have four children. Life is good. But Holden still misses Jane. Sometimes he dreams about her. And sometimes he wishes that he had stayed with her instead of moving to California.

I never had any friend, not really surprising I guess. I learnt to not not judge people, we all have something scary or disgusting in our past but seeing it makes it really hard to socialize with anyone. I work as a detective, a private one, the kind that always know if someone is guilty. I was on wandering in a public hospital in order to find if yes or no Mr.wallace was lying to his daughter about his treatement. This was going to be a day that would change me for the rest of my life, as I walked through a corridor, heading to the hospital's archives room, something caught my eyes in a patient room, I stopped instantly and thought I was going crazy. in this room, there was an elder woman, probably 80, with her family, I was so confused by what I saw, or rather by what I did n't saw, I stayed at the door for what could have been hours before her family said goodbye to "Lucy", and left. I smiled, in fact I even laughed like never before, a nurse looked at me with a worried expression. I calmed myself and entered the room. She looked at me, just a bit surprised and I sat on the chair, close to her bed and asked probably sounding completely insane: -" How did you do?" my voice was trembling "never lied? never cheated? never hated someone? it's impossible..." my voice was completely broken and I felt tears on my face and my hands. She smiled back at me "what are you talking about young man? you should n't cry here! it's rude, I'm the one who is old and trapped here, go out and enjoy life" I did go out. It was so frustrating, what could I have said? I was waiting to meet someone like her pretty much since i was born, and all I could feel was hate, all my life I thought This someone COULD NOT exist and yet here was she.... I forgot about Mr.Wallace, I walked in the streets for some times. I stopped myself in front of a shop window, looked at my reflexion. They were here, all my sins, I could see them as clearly as on anyone else. A sad smile on my face, I went home, wrote this letter. My heart is heavy and my head even more, I need to end this.

output: He goes to the train station and takes a cab to a hotel. Holden checks into the Edmont Hotel. He gets very excited when he sees a couple spitting mouthwash into the same glass and thinks it would be neat to join them. He tries to get Maurice, the elevator operator, to send a prostitute to his room. The prostitute arrives later and wants ten dollars, but Holden only has a five. Maurice comes up to collect the other five dollars from Holden. Holden lies and says he paid the girl already. Maurice punches him in the stomach. Holden calls Sally Hayes and asks her on a date. They go ice skating and then eat lunch together. Holden tells Sally he loves her and wants to run away with her to Massachusetts. She refuses. Holden leaves and meets Carl Luce, an older student from Pencey Prep, for drinks. Holden talks too much and annoys Carl. Holden calls Jane Gallagher, but hangs up when her mother answers. He walks around Central Park looking for Phoebe. He decides to sneak into D.B.'s house while Phoebe is sleeping. He wakes her up and they talk. Phoebe gives him money and tells him to get out. Holden leaves and spends the night in Grand Central Station. In the morning, he goes to Mr. Antolini's apartment. Mr. Antolini offers him advice and lets him sleep on the couch. Holden wakes up in the middle of the night and sees Mr. Antolini patting his head. He thinks Mr. Antolini is making sexual advances towards him and leaves. He decides to leave town and hitchhike out west. He writes Phoebe a note telling her where to meet him after school. He waits for her at the museum. When she shows up, she brings a suitcase because she wants to go with him. He refuses to let her come. They go to the zoo and watch the carousel. Holden watches Phoebe ride the carousel and feels happy. He decides not to run away after all. He realizes that kids have to grow up sometime. He doesn't want to be the catcher in the rye anymore. He decides to go home and face his parents. He visits Mr. Antolini again and apologizes for leaving without saying goodbye. Mr. Antolini tells him he needs help and suggests he see a psychiatrist. Holden agrees to think about it. He goes home and talks to his mother. She cries when she sees him. He tells her he failed out of Pencey Prep. His father yells at him. Holden runs away again. He ends up in California. He lives in a cabin in the woods and works as a janitor at a local high school. He writes letters to Phoebe every week. One day, he receives a package from her. Inside is a red hunting hat. Holden puts it on and smiles.

PERSONAL LOG, DANIELLE MARTINEZ DAY 30, Mars Base Dragon: Today, we found something that you would n't believe! A Soviet flag! On Mars! The thing was made of metal and stuck out of the ground like one of those old vertical banners. It did n't move in the wind, mainly because the wind here is hardly anything, but it did have a distinct etching on the front. The old hammer and sickle. That's wild. The wall fell when I was six, and then we had a man on the moon same year. When did they get time to send a ship all the way out here? I do n't know but we hear back tomorrow what we are to do about it, or if we should just leave it. DAY 31, Mars Base Dragon: They wanted us to go retrieve it today, and do some scans of the area. And, I know it was wild yesterday but this is where it gets wilder, we found a whole base! An abandoned base. I mean, we know of it's existence but we have n't gotten a chance to go in yet. They said it would be violating sovereign russian soil, but I mean we are on Mars for goodness sake. The scans showed that it has at least 8 different rooms, and turns out that the flag we found was actually on top of it. DAY 40, Mars Base Dragon: Today we received an evacuation order. It came in very early in the morning, while we were all sleeping. It told us all to gather back up into the pod in which we came, and to jettison ourselves into permanent orbit until we can be received by another crew scheduled to launch 2 weeks from now. I do n't know why they sent us this order so suddenly, but today has been nothing but us packing our stuff up into their crates, the rations and the suits and the computers. We spent almost 3 months getting out here, and several years of training. I feel myself grow afraid at what could have them taking us home so quickly. We set out tomorrow morning. DAY 52, Red Dragon Pod: its just me and john now. we made it to orbit but the others the looks on their faces will always haunt me. we have the rations to remain up here in orbit, john and i, for several weeks now that there is only 2 of us maybe even 5 months i just wonder if i have the will power to stay up here that long with what i saw still in mind. DAY 83, Red Dragon Pod: now i have rations for 6 months.

THE WALL IS BUILT... EVENTUALLY Centipedes slink through smooth gaps in a rotten facade. Moss hides in the shadows and vines creep towards the light. The wall has existed all my life, and all through the lives of my oldest memorable ancestors. It is the lore of our people, that they traveled from distant lands where compassion was an economy, and peace an inescapable truth to seek opportunity. Well, another inescapable truth is that man, even in a place of prosperity, will often succumb to wanderlust. That is the story of these ancestors. Which in a way, is the story of myself. Or at least, why I came to be. They boarded a ship and set forth to the west. For weeks, the sea lay docile beneath their ship. Lazy waves lapped the hull, and steady winds pulled her forward. The travelers, who fancied themselves much more intrepid than they were, laughed among themselves at their own good fortune. "If only the naysayers back home could see the state of things on this veritable pleasure cruise!" they would exclaim defiantly. This trend settled into a routine before long, and such was the new life of the wayfarer. The sun would break the horizon, and they would rise from sleep to great it. Meals were consumed, feet took to dance, and wine was drunk. Unfortunately, even the most steadfast of routines is fleeting in the scheme of life, and one night bad luck finally befell them. A new trend. And one that would last certainly longer than the previous. The captain saw through a glass large clouds of deep black swirling in the distance. Dusk was minutes off, so he took to worry. The coarse was altered, and the ship's path now listed somewhat to the South and away from danger. It was a reasonable precaution, and would have been a perfect solution if the maps were more reliable. They, however, most certainly were not. Therefore, it was not. If smooth seas never made a skillful sailor, it is no surprise that the captain and crew had some serious shortcomings. To blame any single one of them for the wreck would be terribly unfair. The real culprit was hidden somewhere in the barrels of wine and mead stored below deck. And in the habit they had made of good fortune. With bad weather behind, and brisk air above, the crew had mostly joined the passengers within the ships belly. With so many people gathered so closely, either violence or levity are guaranteed, and on this evening the mood kept a lighter tone. Above, in the crows nest, a lonely man listened resentfully as voices sang, and feet stomped to the tune of jovial tunes played by practiced hands. Fiddles, mandolins, and accordions bickered playfully for hours and with each passing minute the weary occupier of the crow's nest grew more bitter. Just before midnight, when a particularly quick tune was met with a particularly rowdy cheer, his mind was made. "Crow's nest be damned! Mead be downed!" The latter part of that statement has sprung from the mouths of men before many a poor decision. And always with the same degree of vigor. Within moments the deck of the ship sat vacant, while the hold was full to burst. Libations continued to flow, while a jagged rocky coast sneaked ever closer.

He meets two girls named Sally Hayes and Jane Gallagher at a bar. They invite him to a party but he declines because he doesn't want to get involved with anyone else. He goes back to his room and calls up an old friend named Ackley. They talk about school and girls until Ackley falls asleep. Holden wakes up late the next morning and realizes he forgot to call his parents. He tries calling them again but they don't answer. He decides to take a walk around town. While walking he sees a boy selling magazines outside a store. The boy asks Holden what kind of magazine he wants. Holden tells him he just needs something to read. The boy gives him a copy of Catcher In The Rye. Holden reads the book and likes it very much. He decides to buy another copy for himself. Later that day he runs into Phoebe Caulfield, a girl he used to know from elementary school. She invites him to come over to her house for dinner. Holden accepts the invitation and spends the rest of the afternoon talking to Phoebe. At night he returns to his hotel room and finds a note from his mother saying she'll pick him up tomorrow morning. Holden packs his bags and leaves the hotel. On the way out he bumps into Mr. Antolini, his former English teacher. Mr. Antolini offers to drive Holden home but Holden refuses. He says goodbye to Mr. Antolini and walks away. As soon as he turns the corner he hears someone shouting after him. It's Mr. Spencer, his history teacher. Mr. Spencer yells at Holden for skipping class and threatens to fail him unless he comes back immediately. Holden ignores him and keeps walking. When he reaches the end of the block he sees a police car parked nearby. Two officers approach him and ask him where he's going. Holden explains that he's leaving school early and heading straight to New York City. One officer tells him he can't do that without permission from his parents. Holden insists that he already got permission from his father. The other officer says he doesn't believe him and orders him to turn around and return to school. Holden refuses and starts running away. The officers chase after him and eventually catch up to him. They arrest him and bring him to the station. There they question him about his reasons for leaving school early. Holden admits that he wanted to avoid getting caught cheating on a test. The officers let him go after warning him not to try anything like that again. Holden heads back to his hotel room and waits for his mother to arrive. She shows up later that evening and scolds him for missing classes. She also tells him that she spoke to Mr. Spencer and learned that he failed his final exam. Holden apologizes to his mother and promises to study harder next semester. His mother forgives him and drives him back to school. Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
I've always seen numbers above people. Ever since I was a small child, I began recognizing patterns. Those in power, or with great ambition tended to be higher, while those who were more meek and humble tended to have lower numbers. As Class President, I've had my fair share of meeting people, and I'd never seen a person alive above an 8, including the tyrants of history. Sometimes, peoples numbers would change... those bullies with a 3 or 4 would cower down to a 1 or 2 after I confronted them for harassing others. I was beaten and bruised for years, but they slowly backed down. Of course, when I entered high-school, this was n't the case. There were some who were 5s and 6s, but I could n't stop now. I confronted them and the scars I have today are proof of my goals. I never backed down and kept striving to improve myself in all ways so I could make this world a better place for all of us. I scored near perfect on the University entrance exams, and was in the Tokyo University entrance ceremony when I saw him.... I did n't know his name, but an iridescent white 10 glowed above his head. The fellow next to him was a 0... Both scored perfect on the entrance exam, as they were giving the speech, but they were such opposites. The 10 was clad in suit and tie, with his long brown hair dangling in front of his eyes. The 0 was awkward-looking, he wore over-sized clothes, and it looked like he resented wearing shoes... I left early, and caught his glimpse on the way out. Our eyes caught briefly, and his 10 dropped to a 0... he smiled my way, and I smiled back. I felt calm and serene, something I would never have expected. The awkward 0 looked at me with his dark eyes before sitting down... I felt terror... as his 0 slowly morphed into a dark and smoky 10. I left that experience behind me, but worked even harder to help others; I chose to become a prosecutor... to judge and serve justice to those who were evil. High numbers were a good indicator of evil, and it is my goal to eliminate evil. I regularly judged others based on their numbers, whether they were to be eliminated or not. Then one day, it happened. Those I judged to be evil started dying of heart attacks; sudden deaths flooded the world, and the number of criminals slowly starting reducing. The world called him "Kira"... I called him God, and he soon recognized me as his devout follower, when he shared his power to judge and delete evil from this world. Now I know my ultimate purpose, and whenever I look in the mirror, I'm glad to see a shining halo-like 10 above my head, reminding me of the day I saw the shining 10 on the podium during my University's entrance ceremony all those years ago.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Scientists tried for decades to find out why the telomeres stopped shortening during cell division. Soon enough immortal children grew up and became scientists or participants in studies. They maintained the appearance of a child but had the brain of any other. And after several decades more immortal humans were everywhere, but humanity could n't discover how to replicate the genes or mutations causing the phenomena. It's now over one hundred fifty years since the birth of the first immortal. A young looking girl named Esther sat in a grassy field. Trees skirted the field at her back and in front of her sat a city. She'd seen more in her lifetime than any other human ever had. Several wars, booms in technology so astonishing that soon enough scientists said we were going to be making contact with celestial bodies outside of the solar system, and last of all the introduction of a drug you could take that would change every strand of your DNA. The age at which you took it would be the age you appeared to be for the rest of your life. She had a passion for spreading her gift around so others would n't experience the burdens and pains of aging. But the side effects of the drug did n't manifest for years, sometimes decades. Slowly humanity had changed in an unintended way. Random genes were shut off at inappropriate times. Some people lost their ability to experience emotions. Some people lost control of their muscles. No one that took the drug was free of consequences. Only the truly immortal, those born with the mutation, wished to live their lives for all of time. The population of true immortals was still growing and the population of the population of mortals and mortal turned immortals remained about the same. Groups of mortals rose up trying to keep their way of life going, but many wished for them to give up so humanity could be purified of death. Was it cruel to bring a mortal to life in the world of immortals? Immortals ruled the world and they certainly thought so. After the discovery that the drug had severe negative side effects the immortals wished to ban it as well, and so they did. It was illegal to produce it, sell it, possess it, and above all, illegal to have a child after having taken the drug. Esther had left her lab years early. She had given up on finding why they could n't fix the drug or reverse its effects. She moved out to the country, wishing she had never discovered it. The country was an expensive place to live due to the enormous population size humanity had reached, but she had more money than she would ever need. She walked towards a giant tree in the middle of the field. It was one that had been planted when she was young, it gave her comfort to be with something as old as she was. She thought of humanity and what she hoped to see in the next few centuries of her life. She looked down to her right and left. A small headstone stuck up out of the grass on either side. She placed her hands on both of the stones for a moment before closing her eyes to take a nap. "Goodnight Mum, goodnight Dad," she whispered.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Katniss and Peeta win the Seventy-fourth Hunger Games.
output: Katniss returns home to District 12 and learns that President Snow is furious with her for breaking the rules of the games by threatening suicide. He threatens to kill Gale if she does not convince him that her actions were motivated by love rather than rebellion. Katniss agrees to marry Peeta and pretend to be madly in love with him. However, she secretly continues to meet with Gale. Meanwhile, the Capitol begins preparations for the Quarter Quell, a special edition of the Hunger Games held every twenty-five years. For this year's event, the tributes are reaped from among previous victors. Katniss is chosen again, along with Haymitch Abernathy, who won the fiftieth Hunger Games. During training, Katniss meets Finnick Odair, a handsome and charming tribute from District Four. He tells her that he has been forced into prostitution by the Capitol. On the day of the games, Katniss and Peeta are sent into an arena filled with poisonous fog. They team up with Finnick and Mags, another tribute from District Four. Together, they manage to survive the first night. The next morning, they encounter Johanna Mason, a tribute from District Seven. She reveals that she has been working with the rebels and helps them escape the arena. They are rescued by Plutarch Heavensbee, the new Head Gamemaker. He takes them to District Thirteen, where they learn that the Capitol has been destroyed. Katniss is reunited with Gale, who has become a leader of the rebel forces. She also meets Primrose Everdeen, her sister, who has been living in District Thirteen. Katniss decides to join the rebellion and fight against the Capitol. She becomes known as the Mockingjay, a symbol of hope for the rebels. In the final battle, Katniss kills President Snow and ends the war. She returns home to District Twelve and marries Peeta. They have two children together. Katniss spends the rest of her life telling stories about the Hunger Games and the rebellion.

PERSONAL LOG, DANIELLE MARTINEZ DAY 30, Mars Base Dragon: Today, we found something that you would n't believe! A Soviet flag! On Mars! The thing was made of metal and stuck out of the ground like one of those old vertical banners. It did n't move in the wind, mainly because the wind here is hardly anything, but it did have a distinct etching on the front. The old hammer and sickle. That's wild. The wall fell when I was six, and then we had a man on the moon same year. When did they get time to send a ship all the way out here? I do n't know but we hear back tomorrow what we are to do about it, or if we should just leave it. DAY 31, Mars Base Dragon: They wanted us to go retrieve it today, and do some scans of the area. And, I know it was wild yesterday but this is where it gets wilder, we found a whole base! An abandoned base. I mean, we know of it's existence but we have n't gotten a chance to go in yet. They said it would be violating sovereign russian soil, but I mean we are on Mars for goodness sake. The scans showed that it has at least 8 different rooms, and turns out that the flag we found was actually on top of it. DAY 40, Mars Base Dragon: Today we received an evacuation order. It came in very early in the morning, while we were all sleeping. It told us all to gather back up into the pod in which we came, and to jettison ourselves into permanent orbit until we can be received by another crew scheduled to launch 2 weeks from now. I do n't know why they sent us this order so suddenly, but today has been nothing but us packing our stuff up into their crates, the rations and the suits and the computers. We spent almost 3 months getting out here, and several years of training. I feel myself grow afraid at what could have them taking us home so quickly. We set out tomorrow morning. DAY 52, Red Dragon Pod: its just me and john now. we made it to orbit but the others the looks on their faces will always haunt me. we have the rations to remain up here in orbit, john and i, for several weeks now that there is only 2 of us maybe even 5 months i just wonder if i have the will power to stay up here that long with what i saw still in mind. DAY 83, Red Dragon Pod: now i have rations for 6 months.

"The world is not full of black and white, but grey." That is the quote I lived by for years. For my entire life. It makes sense, ever since I understood what the colour around everyone was. It was normal to me at first. I did n't know I was any different from anyone else. Only when I asked my parents about it did I start to understand. They mistook my curiosity to imagination, and I was fine with that. No one needed to know about what I could see. It was really useful actually. And I have used it many times, for many situations. Back to the quote. Like I said, I lived by it for years. But very recently, did I understand that there can be more colour to the world. I like that. The ideology that shades are n't the only thing a person can be, but a bright and vibrant hue. I first saw her in a fancy restaurant. She obviously did n't belong there. She wore a suit, with a blazer, and some nice dress pants. High heels that were n't really that high. And just a touch of makeup to glow a little bit. What made her not seem like she belonged there was her hair. As blue as the highlight around her self. And I could tell I was n't the only one seeing it, because everyone in the room was staring at her oddly. She left before I could say anything though, and I thought that was that. The second time I saw her was much better. It was just a normal day, I was walking to work, and I saw her. Hair so blue it almost looked black this time. But her nonetheless. I forgot about work and tried to catch up to her, only for her to get away from my grasp once again. The third time was not the charm apparently. I was at a party, and I saw her again. Of course, I thought it would be extremely easy to talk to her now. But somehow she still evaded me. It almost seemed like she could tell I was coming closer to her. Of course that was improbable. The fourth time, that was the charm. It had been years since I'd seen her, and I was n't really looking anymore, thinking that third time was the final time. But I saw her, in that same fancy restaurant I had seen her the firs time. But, instead of me approaching her, she walked straight up to me and said, "What're you having Red?" Red?

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
President Snow threatens Katniss to convince everyone of her love for Peeta.
output: He tells her that if she does not do so, he will kill Gale. Katniss agrees to his terms and goes back home to District 12 where she finds out that Peeta has been taken hostage by President Snow's men. Katniss then decides to go rescue him herself even though she knows it might cost her own life. She manages to find Peeta who tells her how sorry he feels about everything that happened between them during their time together in the arena. Katniss forgives him and they both escape from the Capitol along with other tributes including Finnick Odair (Sam Claflin), Johanna Mason (Jena Malone) and Beetee Latier (Jeffrey Wright). However, while trying to flee through the woods, they come across a group of Peacekeepers led by Commander Romulus Thread (Philip Seymour Hoffman). During the ensuing fight, several people die including Cinna (Lenny Kravitz), Effie Trinket (Elizabeth Banks) and Haymitch Abernathy (Woody Harrelson). In addition, Primrose Everdeen (Willow Shields), Rue (Amandla Stenberg) and Thresh (Dayo Okeniyi) also perish. Afterwards, Katniss returns home to District 13 where she learns that her sister Prim has died due to injuries sustained during the battle. This causes Katniss great pain which leads her into depression. Meanwhile, Plutarch Heavensbee (Donald Sutherland) reveals himself to be part of the rebellion against President Snow. He explains to Katniss that he wants her help in overthrowing the government. Katniss initially refuses but eventually changes her mind after learning that her mother Mrs. Everdeen (Paula Malcomson) was killed by Peacekeepers under orders from President Snow. With this knowledge, Katniss joins forces with Plutarch and begins training for another Hunger Games alongside fellow victors such as Finnick, Johanna, Beetee and Mags (Lynn Cohen). Together, these six individuals form what becomes known as Squad 451. Their mission? To assassinate President Snow! But things take a turn for the worse when Katniss discovers that her father Mr. Mellark (Stanley Tucci) was actually working for President Snow all along. Enraged, Katniss kills him before being captured by Peacekeepers. While imprisoned, Katniss meets up with Peeta again who informs her that he too joined the rebellion. Later, Katniss escapes captivity thanks to the efforts of her friends including Gale Hawthorne (Liam Hemsworth), Boggs (Mahershala Ali), Cressida (Natalie Dormer), Pollux (Evan Ross) and Castor (Wes Chatham). Once free, Katniss reunites with her family including her younger brother Prim Jr. (Josh Hutcherson). Unfortunately, shortly thereafter, Prim Jr. dies from complications related to his illness. Devastated, Katniss vows revenge against President Snow. She sets off towards the Capitol accompanied by her allies including Gale, Finnick, Johanna, Beetee, Mags, Boggs, Cressida, Pollux, Castor and others. Along the way, they encounter numerous obstacles including traps set by President Snow's loyalists. Eventually, however, they reach the Capitol where they engage in a fierce firefight with Peacekeepers. Despite heavy losses, Katniss and company manage to defeat the enemy troops and enter the Presidential Palace. There, they confront President Snow face-to-face. Before long, however, Katniss realizes that she can never truly win against someone like him. So instead, she decides to end his reign once and for all by shooting him dead right there in front of everyone. Afterward, Katniss declares herself the new leader of Panem and announces plans to hold yet another Hunger Games. However, unlike previous editions, this one will feature children rather than adults. As a result, many citizens oppose the idea fearing that their kids may become victims themselves. Nevertheless, Katniss insists that the games must continue regardless. Thus, the stage is set for the next installment of The Hunger Games franchise...
