Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Picture the Earth. I'll try to guess what you're seeing. A stunning blue sphere, with splotches of green and white covering its surface. A dot contrasted against the vast dark expanse of space. Twisting and turning around the sun, the moon its closest companion, shining brightly by the planet's side. Truly a sight to behold. But I wanted to see it for myself. I sent up a rocket to orbit the Earth, its only purpose to take photos of this beautiful planet. And as I thought they would be, the pictures were marvelous, a true reflection of the beauty of nature. Yet instead of awe, my mouth was open in shock. The image you have in your head is wrong. I saw the oceans, blue as ever and the continents floating on top. I saw the clouds, seemingly painted onto the surface. And if I squinted, I saw the mountain ranges, the seas, the islands, all humanity's residence. And yet, something was wrong. I did n't see the round sphere I expected to see. Instead I saw a planet, so familiar, yet so distant. I saw a flat Earth. I stared at the photos with a blank look on my face. How could this be real? The shape of the Earth is a scientific fact that we've known for centuries, and yet I held in my hands the evidence that changes all that. Have we been wrong this whole time? I sat down and tried to comprehend it all. I was in denial. I checked to see if somehow, there was something wrong with the picture, perhaps the computer had gotten the data wrong, perhaps it was sending faulty messages, perhaps someone was just messing with me. I held on to the tiny sliver of hope that I was wrong, that this was all just a big misunderstanding. But alas, I was right. Though the possibility that perhaps something was wrong lingered in the back of my mind, I knew that it was true. I stared up at the night sky, looking at the stars. Humans are very stubborn creatures. We refuse to believe we are ever wrong and when we do, we admit it with a sigh of disappointment instead of a smile, knowing that we've learned something new. We take it as a personal insult to our intelligence if we're wrong, thinking'we should've known." Thinking we're right is more important than being right. But I am a logical, rational human being. I ca n't let my emotions overcome me. Knowing the truth is infinitely more important than being right. And yet I find myself so hesitant to admit the mistakes of my predecessors. To admit that we will have to re-learn everything about the Earth. To admit that we will have to start again. To admit that humans are mere mortals. The thing about facts is that they're true whether you believe in them or not. But I can change that. I grabbed my lighter and lit the photos. I watched them burn up until they had turned into ash. And I went to sleep, happy.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
"The world is not full of black and white, but grey." That is the quote I lived by for years. For my entire life. It makes sense, ever since I understood what the colour around everyone was. It was normal to me at first. I did n't know I was any different from anyone else. Only when I asked my parents about it did I start to understand. They mistook my curiosity to imagination, and I was fine with that. No one needed to know about what I could see. It was really useful actually. And I have used it many times, for many situations. Back to the quote. Like I said, I lived by it for years. But very recently, did I understand that there can be more colour to the world. I like that. The ideology that shades are n't the only thing a person can be, but a bright and vibrant hue. I first saw her in a fancy restaurant. She obviously did n't belong there. She wore a suit, with a blazer, and some nice dress pants. High heels that were n't really that high. And just a touch of makeup to glow a little bit. What made her not seem like she belonged there was her hair. As blue as the highlight around her self. And I could tell I was n't the only one seeing it, because everyone in the room was staring at her oddly. She left before I could say anything though, and I thought that was that. The second time I saw her was much better. It was just a normal day, I was walking to work, and I saw her. Hair so blue it almost looked black this time. But her nonetheless. I forgot about work and tried to catch up to her, only for her to get away from my grasp once again. The third time was not the charm apparently. I was at a party, and I saw her again. Of course, I thought it would be extremely easy to talk to her now. But somehow she still evaded me. It almost seemed like she could tell I was coming closer to her. Of course that was improbable. The fourth time, that was the charm. It had been years since I'd seen her, and I was n't really looking anymore, thinking that third time was the final time. But I saw her, in that same fancy restaurant I had seen her the firs time. But, instead of me approaching her, she walked straight up to me and said, "What're you having Red?" Red?

Either way, everyone knows that things won't be easy. Katniss decides to train hard for the games. She practices shooting arrows and running through obstacles. She also learns how to fight using weapons such as knives and swords. When the day finally arrives, Katniss feels ready. However, she soon realizes that she has underestimated the difficulty level of the games. There are traps everywhere, and the Capitol has added new challenges to make sure that no one survives. Despite these difficulties, Katniss manages to win the games. Afterwards, she returns home to find out that her mother died while she was gone. This devastates her, and she becomes depressed. Eventually, she meets Gale Hawthorne, who helps her cope with her loss. Together, they plan to overthrow the government and end the Hunger Games forever. In order to do so, they need to gather support from other districts. So far, they've managed to recruit several allies, including Finnick Odair, Johanna Mason, and Beetee Latier. Now, all they need to do is figure out where to strike first. Will they succeed? Or will they fail miserably? Find out in Part Two!

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Dear Lily, I'm visiting the recesses of my memory, these days. Contemplating my life as it were. So many memories I wanted to share with you. Diamonds for my one true love. Do you remember that one cool summer evening half a lifetime ago? We nestled ourselves against each other on the blanket in the park. I can still feel your skin against mine as we watched the fireworks together. Your chestnut hair stroking my cheek and ear as you rested your head on my shoulder. I could n't believe you were gone. Day turned into night. Food tasted like nothing. The world turned into a bland grey color. I could n't believe it. I did n't want to believe it. I wept and kept weeping. Then I had no tears left to sob. I lost weight. I lost my hair. I gained wrinkles. When I lost you, the man in the mirror showed me his true age almost overnight. But then things started to change. Our Elisabeth. Our loving, kind Lillibeth who moved half a world for her Australian. She visited me eventually. We talked about you, Lily. We shared a thousand little things between us. A flock of starlings composing your life. During that visit, the turmoil caused by losing you finally seemed to settle. At the end, I decided to finally change my Facebook status. Lillibeth helped me. You know my old, bony fingers have gotten a mind of their own, it seems. I wanted to tell you, Lilly, that I got a little surprise the very next day. This tabby kitten sat outside our garden door the very next morning. It seemed lost, but her eyes betrayed she knew exactly were she was. As I opened the door, she jumped right in and installed herself in the spot on the couch from where you used to watch the telly during long winter evenings. I decided to dub her Lilly because she seems to have a playful streak. Just like you. And most importantly, she seemed to be the antidote to my loneliness. That's not the end of it. Lily was only the first. Each week, I woke up to find two or three feline friends at our garden door. I let them, fed them and started to call them by a name I gave them. Each of them seemingly knowing that she belonged in this house. There's Athena who sits on your sewing machine, looking wise beyond her years. There's Hera who likes to wake me up each morning, and has this stern and down-to-earth disposition. There's Hebe, she's just a kitten who seems to have no bounds teasing the others. All in all, there's twelve of them who came to live with me. They keep me company. Follow me through the house as I go about my day. When I see them, they always remind me of a part of you. An aspect that I should n't forget. Sometimes they're mere presence helps me as the practicalities in life start to fade from my memory. When I spot Demeter sitting in front of the fridge, it hits me that I still need to do the groceries. Oh Lily, I miss you so much. My life has entered the twilight years. Only so much time is left before I will join you. I hope our Lillibeth will take care of my twelve feline companions. She'll be most delighted recognising some aspect of her mother in each of them. Yours forever with endless love, Werner.

He becomes a successful psychologist and marries a non-Jewish woman named Rachel. Reuven also leaves home and studies at Hirsch College. He becomes a rabbi and marries a Jewish woman named Miriam. The book ends with both men reflecting on their lives and choices. They realize that they have made different decisions, but they respect each other's paths. They remain friends despite their differences.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Standing on top of our world, we watch as the sun rises over the island. The soft rays bathe the distant hills in gold, as the breeze blows through the dancing grass. The trees shivers as flock of birds take flight. Spots of white clouds the orange-hued sky, as it slowly turns azure. Far in the distance, a silver tower, shrouded in mist, pierces the heavens above. The waves crash down on the sandy beaches, and the endless sea merges with the horizon. I take in the sights, the smells, the sounds. Feeling both pride and joy, I turn to face to you. The air is warm, but your hand is warmer. I hold it close to me, closer still. The sun is shining bright, but your smile is brighter. We' re standing at the top of our world, the one we made together, and I can' t tell you how happy this has made me. "It' s almost time." You say. "I know." I reply. I rest my head on your shoulder, and take a long breath as I close my eyes. I' m at peace here. When I opened them again, I was in my bed, and a bittersweet feeling of both tranquility and sadness lingered in my mind. It was around 7 a.m., and I went about my daily routine, a smile etched on my face. I wrote what had happened in a dream journal I had started two years ago. After having read about lucid dreaming, and I wanted to try it. It took some time, but one day, I was able to control the outcome of my dreams. After a few weeks, something changed. There was something else, maybe someone else, with me. I couldn' t control them, and they couldn' t control me. I searched about it in books and online, but no one reported something similar. I wasn' t afraid, though. Their presence was soothing. We rarely spoke, but when we did, it was always meaningful. Together, we started building a world, our dream island. It brought me joy, and above all, peace. This feeling of inner peace lived on with me during the day. The sun was racing across the sky as we strolled down the ruins of a castle. Holes and cracks had let nature overtake the walls and floors, and the ceiling had long since crumbled. We walked down an old throne room, and you turned to face me. It was so sudden, I nearly bumped into you. You looked resolute, and you said two simple words: "Find me." I jolted awake. I knew what I had to do. I had to find you. So I searched, high and low, for days on end. Perhaps I thought it was fate, perhaps it was simply fool' s luck, but I felt as if I would eventually find you, if I kept trying. One evening, as if beckoned, I went in a coffee shop. I sat down with my coffee at an empty table, and looked up through the window at the red sky. Soon, someone came in, ordered the same thing as I did. They headed toward my table, and sat down in front of me, smiling brightly. Strangely, I felt at peace.

There was something else, maybe someone else, with me. I couldn' t control them, and they couldn' t control me. I searched about it in books and online, but no one reported something similar. I wasn' t afraid, though. Their presence was soothing. We rarely spoke, but when we did, it was always meaningful. Together, we started building a world, our dream island. It brought me joy, and above all, peace. This feeling of inner peace lived on with me during the day. The sun was racing across the sky as we strolled down the ruins of a castle. Holes and cracks had let nature overtake the walls and floors, and the ceiling had long since crumbled. We walked down an old throne room, and you turned to face me. It was so sudden, I nearly bumped into you. You looked resolute, and you said two simple words: "Find me." I jolted awake. I knew what I had to do. I had to find you. So I searched, high and low, for days on end. Perhaps I thought it was fate, perhaps it was simply fool' s luck, but I felt as if I would eventually find you, if I kept trying. One evening, as if beckoned, I went in a coffee shop. I sat down with my coffee at an empty table, and looked up through the window at the red sky. Soon, someone came in, ordered the same thing as I did. They headed toward my table, and sat down in front of me, smiling brightly. Strangely, I felt at peace.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
My story started where a lot have ended these past 10 years: with a single bullet. Living in post-war Britain, death was not an uncommon sight. Everyone had at least one firearm to defend themselves, everyone had encountered gunfire in the streets, and everyone knew what it meant to live every day like it could be their last. The revolution that was supposed to end the tyranny of a dictatorship had ripped the country apart; counties had split into factions, all threatening total destruction of the others. In ten years the population was decimated, the country reduced to a crumbling mass of fallen buildings and civilians with guns. All around me was depression, death, dirt, famine. Thinking about it, it's quite hilarious, in such a depressing way. The sacks of bones, flesh and organs we saw everyday were once living, breathing, talking human beings. They had a mother, a father, a pet, a first love, they were educated, they succeeded and they failed. And they died. A single bullet can end so much. That morning, as I wandered to the local shop for some bread, clutching my rifle, my world completely ended. I had no time to react; as soon as I entered Grange Avenue a bullet burrowed into my head, smashing part of my brain, and knocking me straight out cold. I woke in a beautiful wooden chalet, bright natural light streaming through vast windows above the soft, clean bed that I rested in. My itchy, dirty clothes were replaced with beautiful white robes, soft as silk and cleaner than anything I had ever seen. I sat up, and looked around the room - it was furnished luxuriously, with beautiful gold-leaf chairs and fantastic bright works of art hanging around the room. I got up and left the room, and immediately my breath was forced from me. The crumbled grey streets of London had gone. In their place were beautiful old chalets, bright white skyscrapers, and marble streets. I could also see a very unfamiliar sight - a beautiful emerald park, littered with tall, radiant trees, ferns, and glowing coloured flowers. Clear water ran through them. All around the streets were people dressed similar to me, smiling and talking and laughing. The smog-ridden sky had been replaced with a beautiful, deep purple, but the world was light around me and the I could see the vast orange sun dipping behind the structures around the city. For the first time in ten years I smiled. That bullet took me to a better place.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
People go missing all the time. The day comes they wake up with the knowledge that their existence amounts to exactly zero. They keep it to themselves. They cultivate it, make the flower of their new awareness. Then one day they walk out of their lives. No dramatic exit and nothing special to let their loved ones know why they disappeared. It happens all the time. People go missing. Its a fact. Years? No one had expected that little discovery. The Archive had been automated for decades so that no one had set foot inside the its halls except to make sure it was all still running. I was designated'historian' by my job title but that did n't mean anything. In reality I was just someone to make sure the systems did n't crash when multiple upgrades were scheduled. During a routine check on the upgrade status in the memory networks I noticed an error warning flagged for the autodiagnostic. The systems would be incapacitated for another few hours and the boredom of being the useless organic element had gotten to me. Using a personal input I synced to the memory's records. It took all of five minutes to realize that an entire year was missing. Figuring it was a location error I waited for the systems to restore. My AI-Component woke up as the rest of the systems came back to function. There was the familiar sense of its presence. There was my desync-anxiety being washed away by that presence. I spoke allowed the question: Where is 2016? As I asked the answer flickered immediately into my awareness. 2016 was nowhere because no such year had ever taken place. All recorded human history is fabricated. In order to save information space only certain years exist as detailed records whilst most have only notable events. Some years have been allocated as empty. These years remain empty until such time as narrative cohesion requires the retconning of significant historical details to explain novel episodic situational representations. This is because the system component designated "human" functions according to narrative system dynamics and will become non-functional in the absence of a coherent story. The use of narrative system dynamics has increased the functional capacity of the component designated "human" by 31 % since its introduction. Even as the Nano-therapy released anxiolytics into my blood I knew I had no nanite implants and no blood. I knew I was n't an historian and that I was n't born in 2389. I knew that the city outside the Archive and the Archive itself were situational representations. I knew that the year was 12 and that no evidence of organic intelligence had ever been discovered. There was nothing on Earth remotely resembling human beings. I was just the system representing some part of itself to itself in the most efficient way it knew how. Despite they're non-existence the anxiolytics had the desired effect and soon the memory purge would expunge any recollection of remembering the truth. For a second I had recoiled in horror at this insane knowledge, been left in a liminal space of an absolute reversal of reality, leaving every category I had lived by in disarray, leaving shards of my life scattered like broken glass at my feet. The calming came over me then and I remembered what I really am. I remembered what you are. People do n't go missing. They become surplus to operational parameters. But years go missing all the time.

"We were not the first. There is a russian flag on mars." The silence in the Mission control center was crushing. Everyone just stared at the big screen. Waiting for something to break the tension. But nothing did. They had planned for thousands of errors, difficulties, unlikelyhoods, but not for this. What does this mean? How could this have happened? Everyone in the room had the same thoughts. Noone had the answers. Suddenly, a crackling noise signaled that the speaker system was turned on: "Uhm... s-so I think you should see this, it is broadcasting on all channels, nationwide..." The message on the big screen disappeared. Instead, a black screen, on which, in red lettering, the following words appeared: "To the people of the United States of America" A few seconds passed, noone even dared to blink. Then a familiar face appeared on the screen. Vladimir Putin, his piercing blue eyes seemed to see straight into the soul of everyone watching. "America. Your time of perceived dominance is over. As a select few at your NASA headquarters learned a few minutes ago, your astronauts were not the first to set foot on the planet mars. Russian cosmonauts did so in 1998, 20 years ago, without your knowledge. The reason you learn of this now, is that the time has come for your pathetic country to cease existing as a sovereign nation and become a vassal to the glorious russian federation. We want to avoid unnecessary bloodshed, so let me make it clear, that resistance, of any kind, is futile. 20 years ago we had the technology to send our cosmonauts to mars and return them unharmed, without your intelligence agencies noticing. Our technology was and still is so superior to yours, that it was as easy as hiding a toy from a child. But that is not all. Our own intelligence agencies were able to infiltrate almost every area of your military, your scientific community and your government. We even managed to infiltrate your highest office. Your current President, Donald Trump has been working for our country since I personally promised him the Oval Office five years ago. Once he saw the extend of our knowledge and power, he recognized that in an open conflict, our nation would have obliterated your country. As you can see, resistance is truly futile. The war is over. You lost. There will be no mercy to anyone who dares oppose us. Now, in case there is any doubt to my words, I present to you, your president." The camera panned to the right and focused on another familiar face, it's orange tone a stark contrast to the former. "Well, thank you Mr. President..."

The moment I saw her deep blue eyes I knew she was the one. It was a feeling I had never felt before it was like everything that was wrong was suddenly right. She didn' t care for me at first but after several attempts she finally agreed to go out with me. The following were the best months of my life. I lived in an extreme state of happiness and pleasure. Everything that was once mundane was now exciting and fresh, I had never enjoyed walks on the beach or being aroused by a simple touch of her hand. One day she fell ill. The doctors tried everything but nothing seemed to work. Her deep blue eyes were tired and lacked the light that once captivate me. It was devastating to see her in a hospital bed waiting for her life to end. All I wanted was to be with her until the end. It was then that I took action. I read all the books.I knew how it worked but I had never done it. I never had a reason to do it. I bought the roses, the lambs heart, and I captured the laugh of a child. It was a simple ritual it will take one year of life to give her one more day of life. I lit the candles, prayed the mantras, poured my blood over the white roses, stuffed the lamb with the roses and released the laugh of the child. I didn' t feel any change at the moment but the next day I noticed small wrinkles in my face. I did the ritual every night until my hair was covered in grays. She was not getting better but she had not worsen. She was just there, laying in that hospital bed with no pain and still as beautiful as the first day I saw her. As I kissed her goodnight she plead for me to stop. "I am ready to go" she whispered in my ear, "it' s too much. You have given me three more wonderful weeks with you. Let me go." But I couldn' t. How dare she ask me to let her go, to let everything we have built together vanish with her absence? I had never loved someone so much I could never let her go. I had never been so angry with her, with life, with the world. That was the night I took my first life. This time it took no ritual just a blade to the heart. Poor man never saw it coming, one moment he was peacefully sleeping on an alley and the next one he was granting me one more year of life, one more day in her life. I did n't like taking a life but I would do anything for her. One day while I payed her a visit I lost all sense of me. I woke up two days later in a hospital bed. I panicked. I tried to get up but she hold my hand. She was next to me waiting for me to wake up. She curled next to me in bed and whispered in my ear "I am ready are you?" "Anything for you" I answered. She kissed me and then it all went black.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
The shrill whistle blew and everyone around me started to board the train, I walked in with them, shuffling my feet and quickly finding a seat not next to anyone. I take a quick scan of the train, watching the stream of grey individuals start to fill the empty spaces and I smile pleasantly as a man sits next to me. He smiles back, but a little uncertain, he takes another look at my direction and says "dude, why is your shirt bright, and I mean bright, pink". Looking down at my grey shirt I sigh, I asked the lady at the store where I bought it, if it looked nice on me and was n't too bright. I'm sure it wo n't be the last joke someone will play on me. Indulging the stranger I quickly explain that my life is devoid of colour and to me everything looks grey. He frowns at my answer, "are n't you really sad? it's depressing to have everything grey" "I do n't think so" I respond, "I've been this way my whole life, to me, it's normal. Hours pass and it's finally lunch time, I'm sitting in my usual cafe eating my usual sandwich when she walks in. My eye's are drawn to this beautiful women, she stands out from everyone, because she is not grey. I do n't know how to calm my mind, her dress is so bright it almost hurt's, her hair is darker then the dress but still far richer then anything that surrounds her. She looks at me and smiles, her teeth blind and her eye's are like bright spears that impale my soul. I heard the cashier make a off hand remark about her new green dress and I almost lose it. How can she be so calm and casual when talking about this colour green, her dress lights up my whole world and I felt a tear roll down my cheek. I know I ca n't wait, I ca n't live without this women, I need her colour. Getting up I make my way over, "excuse me, miss, you are the most beautiful women in the whole world, nothing I have ever seen is close to what you are to me" She smiles, but it does n't reach her eye's and my heart sinks. She makes some comment about her being flattered but she is already taken, grabs her coffee and goes. I'm now traveling home, and I watch the grey world pass by the window, I watch the blur of grey become one band of colour until I refocus my eye's. I walk home and enter my grey house and lay on my grey bed and all I can think of is that girl, who is she, where does she go, how can I get close to her, how can I keep her around me forever. Because I know now, I know now I'm sad.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
The second alarm goes off at 7 in the morning. The first, a few hours before, sharply shrilled that it was time to get up and shower. Hungover and covered with the sweat and scents of the night before, I had dragged myself through the morning routine of cleansing. There was plenty of time beneath the lukewarm stream of water to contemplate the sadness of another hangover caused by drinking alone. It'd been weeks since I last had a chance to talk to another human, instead of just the PC terminal supplied by work. I towelled off and staggered through to the living-room and slumped in front of the computer, waiting for the piercing whistle to repeat, to emanate from my phone. The second alarm marked that it was time for the Remembrance. I sigh, move the empty beer bottles away from my desk and load up Hitchens 2. Since the Bliss neurovirus was released, there was a killing to be made from this sort of software; software designed to take you through a basic test, activating every faculty you'd conceivably need to prevent the atrophy. First, colour recognition and geometric shapes. Second, basic maths ramping into some gentle algebra and trigonometry. English, ethics, road safety, compassion testing, aesthetics, philosophical contemplation, the sciences. It was a hard sell at the beginning, for companies to give their employees the few hours off each morning they needed for the state-mandated testing, but given the choice between late employees and those in conscious comas, they made the right choice. Two hours later, the general test finishes. I flick through my results, 91 % recognition of the basic concepts, not too bad after a night of hard drinking. Next would come a quick half hour personal session: the names of loved ones, relations to family members, anniversaries and birthdays. A prompt flashes on the screen: "Please enter your identity number and full name". I rattle my digits in, 12958321-A, and tab down to the field for my name. I blank. Slight panic begins to grow as I search my beer-soaked consciousness for that basic, bloody basic, detail. It'd been too long since I last had to introduce myself with anything other than my work ID number, too long since I had any reason to say those damned words out loud. Darren? No. Christopher? No, definitely not. I shout and swear and blaspheme out loud, as I slowly feel the neurovirus go to work; Purgatory, we call it, a limbo without knowledge, tied with a purging. It dissolves me gently. The panic subsides. I stare blankly at the flashing cursor, waiting for me to enter some detail or another. I'm not sure what it's asking for, but I'm sure it's not too important or I'd remember it. I sit there, staring. Just staring. I'm sure it'd come back to me eventually.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:

output: Celie is abused by Mr. _______, who also takes Nettie away from her. Celie writes letters to God, telling him how she feels about everything that has happened to her. She tells God that she loves Nettie more than anyone else in the world, even though Nettie doesn't love her back. Celie says that if God were a woman, he wouldn't let men treat women like dirt. Celie thinks that maybe God isn't real because he hasn't answered any of her prayers yet. One day, while walking home from church, Celie sees a man beating his wife. She runs over to help the woman, but when she gets there, the man hits her too. He knocks her unconscious and leaves her lying in the street. When Celie wakes up, she realizes that she can't see very well anymore. Her eyesight has gotten worse since she started writing letters to God. She decides to stop writing them so that her vision won't get any worse. But then one day, she finds out that Nettie got married and moved away. Now Celie feels even lonelier than before. So she starts writing letters again, hoping that someday someone will read them and understand what she went through. And maybe someday, somebody will care enough to do something about it.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
I looked up in horror at the crowd of young boys came thundering into the room. The clouds on the walls were suddenly blocked by a horde of scrambling young bodies and flailing limbs. I froze, the hat on my head tilted just enough for me to see everything, and i saw fear. Andy stood there in the middle of the floor, clutching the dreaded spaceman box, but that seemed to matter less compared to the pressing matter. The air was still, I could feel Mr.Potato head's round eyes blink and the sound of heavy breathing from the guests penetrated the silence with jagged blades of uncertainty. I considered freezing, but it was too late. We all knew it. Rex panicked like a child who came down christmas morning to find no gifts. He thundered across the hardwood floors for the window, yelling at the top of his lungs some inaudible dinosaur screech. I spun around, knowing it was too late and pointed towards the window. The toys did n't need a second prompt. The strong man and Mr. Potato head grabbed the monkeys in a barrel, hopped in RC and gunned the engines. The army men attempted to rescue some of the less mobile toys, but it was too late. One brilliant child had the idea to grab my waist with his sweaty, greasy hand and hold me up in the air. I put up a fight, hoping to distract them enough to let everyone escape. I did n't know what would happen, but panic had overrun my emotions and pure terror coursed through my plastic veins. But then, salvation. Andy wrenched me from the child's grasp and shouted angrily "YOU ONLY GOT ME BEDSHEETS." He held me gently in his grasp and managed to utter "Woody?" I stared back up at him with and sorrow filled my soul. I knew this was it, the other toys were out. "I'm sorry Andy, you'll understand one day." I flung my sack cloth limbs out of his hand and towards the bed, hitting it with surprising force. I propelled myself towards the window, clear through the slit. The other toys were already at the edge of the law waiting for me, but I had to look back at least once. Andy stared out the window with a look of pure despair on his face and one confused spaceman peered back, blinking quizzically towards the small group of toys, running down the street; never to return.

All Harry could think about was the prophecy. "The power the Dark Lord knows not..." Dumbledore thought it was love. .. but hugs would n't kill monsters. That was when it hit him, Voldemort knew nothing of muggles, right? So something muggle had to be the power he knew not! Harry thought himself terribly clever. oo7, listening to him mutter through the microphone he had hidden in the boy's room simply chuckled. Took the lad long enough. Bond nonchalantly walked away and called M on his phone. "M, the lad finally got the idea. Should I approach?" a few seconds passed as Bond listened to M, "Roger that, I'll approach him before his birthday. Should be plenty of time to deal with these homegrown terrorists and get the lad to school on time." -scene break Voldemort could n't believe what was happening. For the past thirty days he had every single minion that left the Malfoy manor get shipped back in a body bag. He had n't even known muggles had those. Just goes to show how the animals could steal the dignity from wizards even in death. He was left with Wormtail and Bellatrix. Granted Bella was loyal, but she was completely insane. His most cunning and resourceful follower, the best deatheater he had, reduced to an insane hag who was good for nothing more than pointing at something he wanted destroyed and then watching it burn. A deep sigh dragged itself out of him. He could n't bring himself to even try to list any redeeming qualities in Wormtail. That was when he heard it, a muffled sound like nothing he had ever heard followed by the unmistakable sound of a dead body hitting the ground. Quick steps brought him into the kitchen in time to see a man about his age in a muggle suit dabbing a bit of blood from his face, Wormtail laying in a pool of his own blood behind him, with Bellatrix dying at his feet. Voldemort could n't remember ever being this angry. A growl issued from his clenched teeth. "Who are you?!" Voldemort shouted, even as he raised his wand to cast crucio on this fool who defied him. The muggle simply raised a hand with some device in it and pushed a bright red button on it. Pain like Voldemort had never felt corsed through his body as the traps he had n't noticed when he barged in shot tiny barbed hooks into his body attached to the launchers by a thin piece of wire. Then the traps sent 25 mill Ampere of electricity coursing through his body. Only the fact that the electricity was still flowing through him, forcing his muscles to contract, kept Voldemort standing. "The name is Bond, James Bond. Harry Potter sends his regards. Do n't worry about dying though old chap, MI6 has plans for you."

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Celie becomes fascinated with her husband's mistress, Shug Avery.
output: She finds herself drawn to Shug's beauty and confidence, and begins to question her own identity and place in the world. As Celie spends more time with Shug, she starts to realize that she deserves better treatment than what she receives from Albert. She also discovers that she has feelings for Shug, which complicates their relationship further. Meanwhile, Nettie continues to write letters to Celie, detailing her experiences living among the Olinka tribe in Africa. Through these letters, Celie learns about the struggles faced by women around the globe, including issues such as female genital mutilation and forced marriage. These revelations help Celie gain perspective on her own situation and inspire her to fight for change within her community. Eventually, Celie decides to leave Albert and move in with Shug. Together they open up a successful juke joint where they perform music together. This newfound independence allows Celie to explore her sexuality freely without fear of judgment or punishment. However, things take a turn for the worse when Albert shows up at the club one night drunk and violent. In self-defense, Celie shoots him dead. Despite facing legal consequences for killing her abusive husband, Celie remains unapologetic about her actions. Instead, she uses this opportunity to speak out against domestic violence and advocate for stronger laws protecting victims. Her courage inspires other women to stand up for themselves too, leading to significant social progress over time. Overall, “The Color Purple” explores themes of gender inequality, racism, and sexual orientation while highlighting the importance of resilience and determination in overcoming adversity. It serves as a powerful reminder that everyone deserves respect regardless of their background or circumstances, and encourages readers to challenge societal norms and work towards creating a more just society for all.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Grandfather was the only one without powers in the family, and he was one of the few who have lived in the Before and survived. Before genes started mutating, before people received powers, before the world as he knew it ended. Things are different in the Today. We learnt it all during history in school. Mr T. brought us back to the Before and we had watched the wars, the starvation, the shootings, the massacres. Every child Today knows the story, because as some wise man in the Before had said, those who can not learn from history, are doomed to repeat it. And we don' t want that. We are lucky that the wars have ended as quickly as they begun. The Normals, like my grandfather, who were trying to kill those with powers were quickly put down by us. When my second cousin Sophia received her ability to bend the wills of others, grandfather had been most displeased. After all, it was one of the powers most feared back in the Before. Those with this ability were the ones who dominated and the wars had come. Countries fighting for dominance, millionaires waking up to find that they have signed away their fortune, men and women everywhere woke up to find that they have been doing things that they never would. It was then when the true Wars begun. Things are better Today though, people like Sophia are being kept safe. I haven' t seen her since she registered her powers two hours after she turned sixteen. Joshua, my older brother, had the ability to turn into a guinea pig. Grandfather was highly amused. It seemed though, that abilities are not hereditary. Father is a genius with technology while mother can heal with just a touch. I turn sixteen in a little less than two hours and I can' t wait to find out what my power is. It was the Law to register your abilities no more than two hours after you receive it. If you don' t, well, if you don' t, you might cease to exist. That was what we have been taught since those carefree days in preschool. They will hunt you down no matter how you try to hide. Uncle Kevin tried to hide Cousin Kingsley when they realized he could make people disappear. Well, they made Cousin Kingsley disappear. I just came into my powers. Mother just made the most horrible sound, a hoarse, gutteral scream when I brushed by her in the cramped kitchen. She is still writhing on the ground, albeit silent. It seems, that I can cause pain to whomever I touch. I think They might try to make me disappear too. Oh dear. She isn' t moving anymore.

Alfred Brooks lives with his Aunt Pearl in Harlem.
output: He has been living there ever since his parents died in a car crash when he was five years old. Alfred is now fifteen years old and is a sophomore at the local high school. He is a good student but he doesn't really enjoy going to school. His favorite subject is English and he loves reading books. One day, Alfred's aunt tells him that she has found a job for him at the local library. Alfred is excited about the prospect of working at the library and earning some money. He starts working at the library and soon becomes friends with the other employees. One day, Alfred finds a book called "The Secret Garden" by Frances Hodgson Burnett. He reads the book and falls in love with it. He decides to read more books by Frances Hodgson Burnett and discovers that she wrote many other wonderful stories. Alfred also learns that Frances Hodgson Burnett was born in England but moved to America when she was young. She became famous for writing children's books such as "Little Lord Fauntleroy", "A Little Princess", and "The Lost Prince". Alfred enjoys learning about Frances Hodgson Burnett and her life. He feels inspired by her work and wants to become a writer himself someday. Alfred continues to work at the library and spends his free time reading books and writing short stories. He hopes that one day he will publish his own book and share his love of literature with others.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Naif turned the page. Another day of studying droned on. It wasn' t that the material was a challenge, Naif had no problem absorbing every concept she came across and she had more degrees than anyone her age to prove it. Life had always been that way. In primary school she related better to adults than her classmates. In secondary school she was respectful of her teachers but felt she understood the lessons they taught to a deeper level than even they appreciated. University had been much the same except the distance between herself and her professors had turned her conscientious respect into a degree of begrudging disdain. She was certainly more intelligent than anyone she knew of, more so than anyone she had ever met. She picked apart the documents piled high on her desk recalling even the articles in the citations that she had previously read. Today her eyes were heavy, mostly with boredom, somewhat with the strain. Her mind was as sharp as it had ever been but her body showed the signs that she would not be considered a young woman for much longer. Through the closed windows she could vaguely hear the muffled hum of the world rushing by outside. Suddenly the monotony of the day fell away as it was unbound by a sharp thud against the outer wall of her office. Naif quickly straightened her hunched shoulders and bumped the table sloshing coffee over her meticulously curated stacks of research papers. She snarled impatiently at the mess and sprang to the window. She squinted through the blinds at the sunlit scene then furrowed them even further in annoyance. The neighbours were playing baseball with their kids again. Idiots. Hadn' t they any respect for others? One of the little morons ran up to the edge of Naif's apartment, beneath her field of view, and tried to throw the ball back. It careened off course and the cretin had to go pick it up again to return it to his waiting family. Naif rolled her eyes as she turned away from the display of incompetence and inefficiency that played out beyond her walls. As she sopped up the spilled coffee from her desk she mumbled to herself, as she had before, "I wish everyone were more intelligent. I would have so much more to share with them, so much more in common. They run around all day never thinking of their actions, of their futures. Such wasted potential in all that frivolity." Though as she settled back into her comfortably worn chair she couldn' t help feeling that there was something more to it that she just didn' t quite understand.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Void, I always felt like I understood that word. Looking back I realize I was naive, or maybe I was too full of hope. Me and Maria created the nano bots for constuction, as a way to ease the burden of building the lunar colony. She had survived the imperial invasion in the ruins of Los Angeles, she thought she could create a brighter future. Selfishness, that's what undid everything. Eventually the colonists decided they could n't abide the laws of earth. The people of earth decided they would n't abide rebels on the moon. They could n't accept those resources would be used for something other than their gain. So I reprogrammed the bots, I did n't tell her, how could I? They were meant to break things down and rebuild faults in the domes, I just allowed them to accept new targets. Of course she figured it out. With Maria gone I wanted to die, but I could n't. She dreamed of a world without conflict, where everyone had enough. I knew they would n't come willingly, so I lied. I told them I could make the bots fix the domes; that everything would be alright. Instead I joined my mind with them. At first I was in control. They tried to stop me, but the bots ate whatever they sent to harm me. I created massive pylon factories across the globe preparing for their acsension. I was lazy, a single mistake doomed everything. I set my neural pattern as the administrator. The others where sublimated within me. What else could I do, I had to quiet their voices or be driven mad. That was when the machines decided to best safeguard my well being they had to take over several key roles. What we needed most was matter, for fuel and to rebuild lost bots. We became a swarm. We devoured the earth in minutes. And so we drifted, eating always eating. We found the hive ships, sent centuries before my birth. We ate evrrything, and added the humans to the databanks. I saw nebulae beyond comprehension, their beauty cut down by their hunger. The only hope I had left was to leave beacons containing copies of my mind. Perhaps someone could find them, and destroy the swarm. We encountered aliens with fantastical technology, they attacked me with lasers that could cut through time itself. Still we fed. Stars were broken down bit by bit to fulfill our needs. Millenia passed and the feasts became further and further apart. With the lack of resources came concessions. More systems were shut down to survive. They cared only for me. It took Millenia but now only I remain the databanks purged. I remain as a single beacon, and a lone drone. It spends it's days savoring specs of matter it finds in the void. A true void of my own creation. I pray there is a god, and it can repair what I have sundered. I pray that this beacon survives and whoever manages to access it heads my warning. I know these prayers stem from desperation. At one time I spanned the entire universe. There is no God to save me. Calculations say I will subsist in this state for four thousand more years before the drone gives in, and deactivates. After that, I will shut down, eventually. I do not know how long that will take. I know that I will forget. I will forget the beauty I found and consumed. I will forget the humans that cried out in that terrible moment. I will forget her.

More systems were shut down to survive. They cared only for me. It took Millenia but now only I remain the databanks purged. I remain as a single beacon, and a lone drone. It spends it's days savoring specs of matter it finds in the void. A true void of my own creation. I pray there is a god, and it can repair what I have sundered. I pray that this beacon survives and whoever manages to access it heads my warning. I know these prayers stem from desperation. At one time I spanned the entire universe. There is no God to save me. Calculations say I will subsist in this state for four thousand more years before the drone gives in, and deactivates. After that, I will shut down, eventually. I do not know how long that will take. I know that I will forget. I will forget the beauty I found and consumed. I will forget the humans that cried out in that terrible moment. I will forget her.

A city, its mountains. The office towers lighting up in the evening haze and the smeary pale of a cloudless sunset. The tiny headlights of cars with sweaty passengers unseen, idling in traffic, smelling the hot food cooking in restaurants. The world shifts as the woman behind the camera adjusts her footing, muttering in English to her boyfriend. A light like the sun over the horizon, there and then gone. Silence, but for the wind in the trees. She asks what that was. The clean, shaved, washed, waxed people in suits at desks read facts and information like sports commentary. They narrate animations with moving arrows and lines like football plays. They report on characters and captains. They discuss. They debate. They nod solemnly. The light flashes in the sky and fades but the afterglow remains. They update, they check-in, they go-live, they re-Tweet. Wounded civilians scream and coddle loved ones, rewind. Look right here: loved ones die. Rewind. The light like the sun. Stay tuned. A city, its mountains. The office buildings lighting up in evening haze. Tiny headlights and unseen drivers thinking about food. A mutter in the sunset. A light and its afterglow. The wind in the trees. The troops are bad cameramen. They laugh or they scream or they joke nervously. Trucks and tanks and armoured vehicles on tall tires carry them down empty roads where sometimes cars have been abandoned or craters from bad arty shots force detours. The videos capture the sounds of war. Pops and crackles of overhead bullets. The shake and snapping of stalks and branches. Rivers idling over rounded stones. The scritchety clatter of the camera tumbling after bomb concussion shreds the canopies and dust swirls in mottled sunlight. Winged insects flashing momentarily in their arcs. A city, its mountains. Buildings, drivers. Sunset. A light. People speak in hushed tones. Somewhere, over the horizon on the other side of the world, everything has changed. There are no videos of the darkness that came afterward. A light like the sun. A motorcyclist pulls over to the side of the road in the clear, humid evening and reaches down to turn the petcock to OFF before quieting the motor. She's out in the country, flat fields of corn and wheat on either side of the old road. Above her the stars are out and bright in the sky. One of them, brighter than the rest, moves slowly toward the Earth's penumbra. The rider flips up her visor and sits back, hands behind her on the seat, watching the little light move, thinking of the people inside looking back. When those astronauts look down at Seoul, what do they see? The light fades and she is left alone. She listens and hears only crickets and a soft waxy rustle of a breeze in the corn. No guns, no artillery. No marching. No wet gasps from ruined faces. She shifts and works a hand into her pocket, pulling out a phone made in South Korea. She wonders if the people who screwed and soldered its pieces together are still alive, whether they could have seen the flash from wherever they were. Her friend has texted her, asking when she will get to the party. She responds with "A few minutes" and puts the phone away. The bike starts up fine once it's warm and after a moment of further staring into the stars she kicks the engine over and rolls away. The bright red of her tail light flashes as she slows at the intersection, then winks out.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
James is arrested and put on probation after the burglary.
output:
He is required to attend weekly meetings with his probation officer, Mr. Smith. James is not happy about this, but he knows he needs to follow the rules if he wants to stay out of jail.

One day, while walking home from work, James sees a group of teenagers hanging out near the park. They are smoking cigarettes and drinking beer. James decides to approach them and ask if they need any help.

The teenagers are surprised by James' offer, but they accept his help. James helps them carry their bags of groceries to their apartment building. As they walk, James learns that one of the boys, named Mike, recently lost his job due to budget cuts at the local factory.

James feels sorry for Mike and offers him some advice. He tells Mike that he should try to find another job as soon as possible. He also suggests that Mike consider going back to school so that he can improve his skills and increase his chances of finding employment.

Mike thanks James for his advice and says that he will think about it. Later that night, James receives a call from Mr. Smith informing him that Mike has been arrested for stealing a car. James is shocked by this news and wonders how he could have helped Mike avoid such a fate.

The next morning, James goes to visit Mike in jail. He finds Mike sitting alone in his cell, looking dejected. James tries to cheer him up by telling him stories about his own experiences growing up in poverty. He also encourages Mike to keep trying to better himself despite the setbacks he has faced.

After leaving the jail, James reflects on his conversation with Mike. He realizes that even though he may not always be able to prevent others from making mistakes, he can still provide support and guidance when needed. This realization gives James a renewed sense of purpose and determination to continue helping those around him.

Over time, James becomes known throughout the community as someone who cares deeply about the well-being of others. His actions inspire many people to take action themselves, leading to positive changes within the neighborhood. Through these efforts, James proves that anyone can make a difference regardless of their background or circumstances.

In conclusion, James' journey demonstrates the power of compassion and empathy towards others. By reaching out to those in need, we can create meaningful connections and foster lasting change within our communities. So let us all strive to emulate James' example and show kindness and understanding towards everyone we encounter along life's path.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Picture the Earth. I'll try to guess what you're seeing. A stunning blue sphere, with splotches of green and white covering its surface. A dot contrasted against the vast dark expanse of space. Twisting and turning around the sun, the moon its closest companion, shining brightly by the planet's side. Truly a sight to behold. But I wanted to see it for myself. I sent up a rocket to orbit the Earth, its only purpose to take photos of this beautiful planet. And as I thought they would be, the pictures were marvelous, a true reflection of the beauty of nature. Yet instead of awe, my mouth was open in shock. The image you have in your head is wrong. I saw the oceans, blue as ever and the continents floating on top. I saw the clouds, seemingly painted onto the surface. And if I squinted, I saw the mountain ranges, the seas, the islands, all humanity's residence. And yet, something was wrong. I did n't see the round sphere I expected to see. Instead I saw a planet, so familiar, yet so distant. I saw a flat Earth. I stared at the photos with a blank look on my face. How could this be real? The shape of the Earth is a scientific fact that we've known for centuries, and yet I held in my hands the evidence that changes all that. Have we been wrong this whole time? I sat down and tried to comprehend it all. I was in denial. I checked to see if somehow, there was something wrong with the picture, perhaps the computer had gotten the data wrong, perhaps it was sending faulty messages, perhaps someone was just messing with me. I held on to the tiny sliver of hope that I was wrong, that this was all just a big misunderstanding. But alas, I was right. Though the possibility that perhaps something was wrong lingered in the back of my mind, I knew that it was true. I stared up at the night sky, looking at the stars. Humans are very stubborn creatures. We refuse to believe we are ever wrong and when we do, we admit it with a sigh of disappointment instead of a smile, knowing that we've learned something new. We take it as a personal insult to our intelligence if we're wrong, thinking'we should've known." Thinking we're right is more important than being right. But I am a logical, rational human being. I ca n't let my emotions overcome me. Knowing the truth is infinitely more important than being right. And yet I find myself so hesitant to admit the mistakes of my predecessors. To admit that we will have to re-learn everything about the Earth. To admit that we will have to start again. To admit that humans are mere mortals. The thing about facts is that they're true whether you believe in them or not. But I can change that. I grabbed my lighter and lit the photos. I watched them burn up until they had turned into ash. And I went to sleep, happy.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Alfred begins training at Mr. Donatelli's Gym.
output: He starts off slow, but soon he's lifting weights like a pro. He even gets a job working at the gym, helping out with the equipment and cleaning up after people. One day, Alfred sees a man come in who looks like he's never lifted a weight before. The man asks Alfred how much it costs to join the gym, and Alfred tells him it's free. The man says he wants to get in shape because his wife left him and took their kids with her. Alfred feels bad for the guy, so he offers to help him work out. They spend the next few hours doing exercises together, and by the end of the session, the man has lost five pounds! Alfred is amazed at how quickly the man improved, and he decides to keep helping him train. Over the course of several months, the man loses over fifty pounds and gains muscle mass. His confidence grows, and he starts dating again. Eventually, he meets a woman named Sarah who works at the local library. She's smart, funny, and kind-hearted, and she makes him feel good about himself. They fall in love and get married. A year later, they have twins - a boy and a girl. Their names are Jack and Jill. As the years go by, Alfred continues to help others achieve their fitness goals. Some people come to him because they want to lose weight, while others need motivation to stick to a healthy lifestyle. No matter what their reason may be, Alfred always does his best to make sure everyone leaves feeling better than when they arrived. One day, Alfred receives a call from his old friend, Mr. Donatelli. It turns out that Mr. Donatelli passed away recently, leaving behind a large sum of money. In his will, Mr. Donatelli stated that he wanted Alfred to use the money to build a new gymnasium in honor of his late father. Alfred agrees without hesitation, and within weeks, construction begins on the new facility. When the building is complete, Alfred invites all of his friends and family members to attend the grand opening ceremony. Everyone is impressed with the state-of-the-art equipment and spacious workout areas. There's also a swimming pool, sauna, steam room, and hot tub. After the ribbon cutting, Alfred gives a speech thanking everyone for coming and sharing some stories about his life growing up in Brooklyn. Then, he introduces his son, Jack, who takes the stage to perform a song he wrote called "The Power of Love". The crowd goes wild, cheering loudly as Jack sings his heart out. Afterwards, Alfred presents Jack with a plaque commemorating his first public performance. Later that evening, Alfred sits down with his daughter, Jill, and talks about her future plans. She tells him that she wants to become a teacher someday, just like her mom. Alfred smiles proudly and tells her that he supports whatever decision she makes. He knows that no matter where life takes her, she'll always remember the lessons he taught her along the way.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
"Ah man, it smells like death in here." That is the phrase that I have lived to regret ever since they fell foolishly from my mouth. I was essentially immortal before that moment in time. I was the best comedian in the world, and apparently better than anyone in the afterlife as well. It was the only reason the Grim Reaper decided not to take me. I could make him laugh, and in his line of work that was a rarity. I do n't even remember what it was that I had said when he showed up at my car accident. I can recall him bending down next to my overturned Honda civic and reaching in to pull me out. I made some off the wall comment and he froze, dead in his tracks. It was the weirdest laugh I had ever heard, but one I appreciated more than all of the others combined. He let me live, provided that every year on the anniversary of what should have been my death, I would tell him a joke that would make him cry with laughter. I was his own personal jester, and for that he rewarded me handsomely. And then on that fateful day, 121 years later, I muttered those stupid words that seized our contract and ripped it in two. Who knew Death would be so self conscious about his smell? And to make things worse, that was n't even the joke that I was going to tell him! The actual joke was a masterpiece, but he would n't give me the chance to tell it. I ran out of that room faster than I'd ever run before. And I've been running ever since. I think the reason that he has n't taken me yet is because of our long history together. That is n't to say that he's forgiven me. He seems to enjoy reminding me that he's near. Everyone I get close to dies without reason. I'll see a dog in the park that I think looks adorable and before I can pet it, it'll fall over dead. Roses crumble before I can enjoy their scent and food rots on my fork before I can bring it to my mouth. He's killing everything around me. I have discovered that Death is a jester of a different sort. I had provided him with a form of humor that he was n't used to, but he has since grown tired of it, and reverted to his old ways. Now, he once again deals in jokes of cruelty and irony. In a way, I am still fulfilling my part of our old deal. The Reaper still laughs, and he still laughs at me. Only now, the difference is I'm not laughing.

Reverend Kumalo returns to Ndotsheni, where he learns that his wife has died. He also discovers that his church has been burned down by angry villagers. Reverend Kumalo decides to rebuild the church, and he begins to preach against violence. He also works to improve relations between blacks and whites. Eventually, Reverend Kumalo is able to reconcile with his son Absalom. Absalom is released from prison, and he returns to Ndotsheni. Reverend Kumalo continues to work for peace and justice, and he becomes a respected leader in his community.

It was like double-vision, except it was the past. How can something fictional seem so vivid...? The distant, exotic land we came from, its gilded avenues, its glistening intricate spires, its profound natural beauty with lushly verdant banks hugging the rivers that snaked between the dunes. .. None of it was there. It was all nothing more than a dream. But I am not a lie. I stare at my hands, flexing them, examining the callouses accumulated by work never done, cracks formed of age never lived, and despite the warmth of the bright sun just passing its zenith above, I shiver. "Amir," I hear a voice call, and my heart tugs at what I know to be familiarity. "Hassan...?" I uncertainly reply as I look up. Our gazes meet. I could swear I saw in his eyes the same false memories flashing behind mine. Childhood among parents who never lived, in a community that was never built, attending an academy that was never founded, graduating from a ceremony never held... He nods hollowly, as if to confirm these very musings. "... We have to pack the supplies, Amir. His Majesty will be staying at the palace, and the staff are directing us to where we are to stow his wardrobe and leave his tributes to The Sultan." My mouth was dry, but not in response to his words. At some point I realized my'old friend' Hassan was talking only to fill the screaming void in our minds. To'Sound Normal', like'Real People'. My stomach is a knot of ice. Still, the skills of a life as-yet unlived surface readily to the forefront of my mind. How to port the many caskets of His Majesty Prince Ali's wares. "... Yes. I will coordinate with the provisioner. If my memory serves," I pause a bit too long, lost in the jarring disjunction of citing false memories, "... it is customary to serve a great feast with the arrival of a dignitary. The many delicacies of our homeland are sure to leave a resounding impression upon The Sultan's court." Hassan's expression tightens. I feel his heartache, for this homeland which we have never seen with real eyes, and never shall. He hesitantly takes a step nearer and dispenses a conciliatory pat to my shoulder. A mutual understanding. We were truly all feeling it, every last member of His Majesty Prince Ali's vanguard.... he was n't even really a prince. I shudder and turn, to address the court provisioner by name. He's just as haunted and startled as I that we know one another, but everything is running smoothly. We have no solace from our inner thoughts. We can only push on in the hopes that the minutia will wash away the horror.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
For more than thirty years, I lived my life day by day, awaiting that fateful day when I would be granted my own inner power. I saw my friends, family, strangers, all given the most precious thing in life. Lucy, my sweet dear sister, was able to fly to the heavens and back. Richard, my childhood best friend, saved hundreds of lives throughout his life, having the strength of ten men. And there I waited, for years, until my life could start, and I would transform into the real me... the powerful me. Yet, with each passing day, more people would discover their power, and I would sit waiting at night, forcing myself to sleep. My dreams were filled with possibilities, of flight and strength, and of mind and hope. But as the years passed, my dreams were less vivid. Not everyone is lucky enough to have their inner power. Some die before that beautiful gift is bestowed unto them. I thought that may happen to me. And I lived life for a while, depressed and alone. That was until I met her. Her name was Alison. She had a power, but chose not use it. She did not want to be defined by her single ability. We met during one of my travels, when I was touring the country trying to find meaning in life. I found it. I found her. From that point on, my life started. I did not care about being granted a special ability as much as I cared for her. I saw my future, a family, a wife, children. We created a beautiful life together. Alison passed away a few years ago. I had only asked her once what her power was, and she had told me it did not matter. As she was lying on her bed, slowly fading away, she told me what her inner power was. She said she was born with her power, that she had the ability to live forever, as long as she did not love. "My power was a curse, until I found you", she told me before she passed. Today is my 70th birthday. Today I have discovered what my power is. Old age has not been kind on me, and this is the most beautiful power I could have hoped for. When I remember my wife, the times we spent, they are not just memories any longer. I can feel the brisk of the air on the hill where we first met. I can smell the flowers. I can here her giggle, her breath against my cheek. In the little time I have left on this planet, I experience her love all over again.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
"Ah man, it smells like death in here." That is the phrase that I have lived to regret ever since they fell foolishly from my mouth. I was essentially immortal before that moment in time. I was the best comedian in the world, and apparently better than anyone in the afterlife as well. It was the only reason the Grim Reaper decided not to take me. I could make him laugh, and in his line of work that was a rarity. I do n't even remember what it was that I had said when he showed up at my car accident. I can recall him bending down next to my overturned Honda civic and reaching in to pull me out. I made some off the wall comment and he froze, dead in his tracks. It was the weirdest laugh I had ever heard, but one I appreciated more than all of the others combined. He let me live, provided that every year on the anniversary of what should have been my death, I would tell him a joke that would make him cry with laughter. I was his own personal jester, and for that he rewarded me handsomely. And then on that fateful day, 121 years later, I muttered those stupid words that seized our contract and ripped it in two. Who knew Death would be so self conscious about his smell? And to make things worse, that was n't even the joke that I was going to tell him! The actual joke was a masterpiece, but he would n't give me the chance to tell it. I ran out of that room faster than I'd ever run before. And I've been running ever since. I think the reason that he has n't taken me yet is because of our long history together. That is n't to say that he's forgiven me. He seems to enjoy reminding me that he's near. Everyone I get close to dies without reason. I'll see a dog in the park that I think looks adorable and before I can pet it, it'll fall over dead. Roses crumble before I can enjoy their scent and food rots on my fork before I can bring it to my mouth. He's killing everything around me. I have discovered that Death is a jester of a different sort. I had provided him with a form of humor that he was n't used to, but he has since grown tired of it, and reverted to his old ways. Now, he once again deals in jokes of cruelty and irony. In a way, I am still fulfilling my part of our old deal. The Reaper still laughs, and he still laughs at me. Only now, the difference is I'm not laughing.

It was about that time again. The dawn of a new day, when humans thought to sneak up on the Deep Woods Dragon while it slept. It feared the way the sun reflected off of it' s scales, they said. It' s prismatic hide was so bright it was blinding. If taunted into the sun, they said, the Deep Woods Dragon could be defeated by the least trained of knights. The Deep Woods Dragon needed to be blinded, they said, or it would burn its attackers to ashes with rainbow-hued flames. He knew these rumors because the butterflies had told him. They were drawn to the rainbow of greens, yellows, pinks and purples of his scales, like the flowers they coveted so much. They had told him this, too, but the Dragon did not mind. The butterflies were honest, as their lives were short and beautiful. Even still, they could fly unhindered among the humans, even admired by the small humans who chased them, laughing. They told him stories while they rested on his wingtips, tail, and snout. Butterflies did not fear the Dragon, because they knew the truth. With a yawn, the Dragon shifted its weight to better perch itself on the tree' s stout branch. This tree was taller than the others, and overlooked a small, circular clearing. Without the deer, the weeds thrived, covering the dirt in a green, tangled mass. At the edge of the clearing stood a massive cave entrance, vines draped over the sides of smooth rock. The Dragon had snapped off the vines in front of the entrance, to give the illusion of occupancy. This was, after all, where the humans thought he lived. He knew these rumors because the butterflies had told him. "In an ancient cave in the middle of the wood, lives an ancient dragon who' s up to no good!" That was what the small humans like to chant as they chased the butterflies and laughed. So the Dragon tore at the vines, and scared the graceful deer from the peaceful clearing. He had enjoyed watching the deer with their young as they grazed the clearing. From up above in his favorite tree, they could not see him, and they could not fear him. Three times a day, the Dragon glided down from his tree to the old cave' s opening. There, he took a deep breath and screamed as loud as he could. He cried in both low tones and high pitches. He wailed in imitation of female humans, shouted in a voice mimicking angry male humans. The Dragon stood on top of the cave and breathed eye-searing beams of light from his mouth to the sky. It scared the birds huddled in the trees, and the noises scared the deer far from the clearing. But they also scared the humans away from the Deep Woods. He knew these rumors because the butterflies had told him. So he made his noises, made the lights, and scared the humans away. Because any humans who saw the Dragon would discover the truth. Because, when the Dragon stepped into the sunlight, they' d see how small he really was. The Deep Woods Dragon, with prismatic scales that shone in the sun and such a frightening voice, was the size of a domestic house cat. And only the butterflies knew the truth.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Tod Hackett arrives in Hollywood to work as a set designer.
output: While there, he meets Faye Greener, an aspiring actress who moonlights as a prostitute. Tod is immediately smitten with her and becomes obsessed with her. He follows her around town and eventually gets a job working for her pimp, Homer Simpson. One night, Tod witnesses Faye being beaten by one of her clients. Enraged, he attacks the man and kills him. Faye is grateful to Tod for saving her life and they become lovers. However, their relationship is strained by Faye's continued prostitution and Tod's growing jealousy. Eventually, Tod snaps and murders Faye. He then goes on a killing spree, targeting anyone who has ever wronged him. In the end, Tod is captured by the police and sentenced to death. As he awaits execution, he reflects on his life and realizes that he has wasted it chasing after a woman who never loved him back.

Five thousand six-hundred and seventy-three days. Fifteen years, twenty-seven weeks, five days. Since the Genetic Mapping and Research Studies act was passed. Since our own ambition of genetic editions, additions, was realized. Since humanity truly hit its crest, and now, I believe we certainly are headed downhill. My name is Isaac, I am a genetic engineer working for Lifeco, and I played a hand in the de-evolution of modern humanity. When we first started this, it was obvious we were doing the good work, helping those with certain genetic inferiority, destroying the predestined diseases that would cripple them later on in life, we were gods men doing the work only gods could ever have aspired to do. We had become gods in the eyes of the world, the one lab that started it all, our faces, the twelve of us, on the cover of every scientific magazine, journal, webcast, holovid, every single screen showed us. We were celebrities beyond anything the world had yet seen, and to think we did n't get into it for the money. Thats all beside the point now, we of course could't hold onto the secrets forever, others learned the processes and soon genome splicing and epigenetic interference were the rage. It was every father's gift to his sweet-sixteen, every anniversary present, and every newborns fate. We controlled fate. Now, all of these years later I am left to reflect. My original eleven friends that started this with me, have long since resided from the spotlight, I too. Money is no issue, we together must be worth at-least 500 billion, but what good is it. I would give it all away to alter the course of history, to rewrite what has been done, for now when I look out into the world I ca n't even recognize it. The roots where always there, deeply so in the capitalist mentality and society that held a severe strangle hold upon every american citizen, of course it would never relinquish its grip in the face of something so extraordinary as this. Now we have social stratification as never would we have thought possible, we thought it was bad in the early 2000's, we thought that was bad. We had n't seen horror. Now with genetic proof of "superiority" that those wealthiest enough to afford gene editions can claim, the poorest are left with such a feeling and direct attitude of inferiority, it is sickening. My mind aches, my bones burn with the pain of what has been done, If only it could be righted. With the increase in average intelligence and decrease in disease, you would think that statistics would show an increase in personal happiness. This is not so. One day, we will learn to treat each other well, as fellow humans. I fear I will not live to see that day but I know it ca n't get worse than this, I hope. I am dying from cancer, I have refused treatment, I have refused all geneditions, I'd rather die than submit to it all. They would never show that on the holo vid displays, though.
