output:
He begins to spend more time with the people he meets through his job, and less time with his family. His wife, Mary, is worried about him, but she does not want to confront him about it. She knows that Tod is going through a difficult time, and she wants to support him.

One night, Tod comes home late after spending the evening with some of his new friends. Mary is waiting up for him, and she asks him where he has been. Tod tells her that he was just hanging out with some friends, and that he is sorry for being late.

Mary is not convinced by Tod's explanation, and she decides to follow him the next time he goes out. She sees him meeting with a group of people who seem to be involved in illegal activities. She is shocked by what she sees, and she confronts Tod about it.

Tod admits that he has been spending time with criminals, but he insists that he is not involved in any criminal activity himself. He says that he is just trying to understand their world, and that he is not planning to join them.

Mary is not sure whether to believe Tod or not. She loves him, but she is also afraid of what he might be getting himself into. She decides to give him the benefit of the doubt, but she warns him to be careful.

Tod promises to be careful, and he continues to spend time with his new friends. However, he starts to feel like he is losing touch with reality. He begins to question everything he once believed in, and he starts to wonder if he is really happy with his life.

One day, Tod receives a phone call from one of his new friends. The friend tells him that they need his help with a job. Tod agrees to meet them, and he finds himself in the middle of a robbery.

Tod is horrified by what he sees, and he tries to stop the robbery. However, he is outnumbered and overpowered. He is forced to watch as the robbers take the money and escape.

Tod is devastated by what has happened. He realizes that he has made a terrible mistake, and he vows to turn his life around. He returns home to Mary, and he tells her everything that has happened.

Mary is heartbroken, but she forgives Tod. She helps him to get back on track, and they start to rebuild their relationship. Tod learns from his mistakes, and he becomes a better person because of them.

In the end, Tod and Mary are able to find happiness again. They realize that they are stronger together than they are apart, and they vow to never let anything come between them again.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Scientists tried for decades to find out why the telomeres stopped shortening during cell division. Soon enough immortal children grew up and became scientists or participants in studies. They maintained the appearance of a child but had the brain of any other. And after several decades more immortal humans were everywhere, but humanity could n't discover how to replicate the genes or mutations causing the phenomena. It's now over one hundred fifty years since the birth of the first immortal. A young looking girl named Esther sat in a grassy field. Trees skirted the field at her back and in front of her sat a city. She'd seen more in her lifetime than any other human ever had. Several wars, booms in technology so astonishing that soon enough scientists said we were going to be making contact with celestial bodies outside of the solar system, and last of all the introduction of a drug you could take that would change every strand of your DNA. The age at which you took it would be the age you appeared to be for the rest of your life. She had a passion for spreading her gift around so others would n't experience the burdens and pains of aging. But the side effects of the drug did n't manifest for years, sometimes decades. Slowly humanity had changed in an unintended way. Random genes were shut off at inappropriate times. Some people lost their ability to experience emotions. Some people lost control of their muscles. No one that took the drug was free of consequences. Only the truly immortal, those born with the mutation, wished to live their lives for all of time. The population of true immortals was still growing and the population of the population of mortals and mortal turned immortals remained about the same. Groups of mortals rose up trying to keep their way of life going, but many wished for them to give up so humanity could be purified of death. Was it cruel to bring a mortal to life in the world of immortals? Immortals ruled the world and they certainly thought so. After the discovery that the drug had severe negative side effects the immortals wished to ban it as well, and so they did. It was illegal to produce it, sell it, possess it, and above all, illegal to have a child after having taken the drug. Esther had left her lab years early. She had given up on finding why they could n't fix the drug or reverse its effects. She moved out to the country, wishing she had never discovered it. The country was an expensive place to live due to the enormous population size humanity had reached, but she had more money than she would ever need. She walked towards a giant tree in the middle of the field. It was one that had been planted when she was young, it gave her comfort to be with something as old as she was. She thought of humanity and what she hoped to see in the next few centuries of her life. She looked down to her right and left. A small headstone stuck up out of the grass on either side. She placed her hands on both of the stones for a moment before closing her eyes to take a nap. "Goodnight Mum, goodnight Dad," she whispered.

However, he cannot stop thinking about her. He starts writing letters to her, but she never responds. Eventually, he gives up hope of ever seeing her again. Years later, Tod receives a letter from Faye. In the letter, she explains that she has been living in Mexico City for the past ten years. She says that she has married a wealthy man and has two children. She asks Tod if he would like to visit her. Tod agrees and travels to Mexico City. When he arrives, he discovers that Faye is actually dead. Her husband killed her because he found out that she was cheating on him. Tod is devastated by this news. He returns to Los Angeles and continues to write letters to Faye. He hopes that someday she will respond to him. However, she never does. Tod eventually dies alone and forgotten. His body is buried in an unmarked grave. No one knows who he was or what happened to him. The End

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
THE WALL IS BUILT... EVENTUALLY Centipedes slink through smooth gaps in a rotten facade. Moss hides in the shadows and vines creep towards the light. The wall has existed all my life, and all through the lives of my oldest memorable ancestors. It is the lore of our people, that they traveled from distant lands where compassion was an economy, and peace an inescapable truth to seek opportunity. Well, another inescapable truth is that man, even in a place of prosperity, will often succumb to wanderlust. That is the story of these ancestors. Which in a way, is the story of myself. Or at least, why I came to be. They boarded a ship and set forth to the west. For weeks, the sea lay docile beneath their ship. Lazy waves lapped the hull, and steady winds pulled her forward. The travelers, who fancied themselves much more intrepid than they were, laughed among themselves at their own good fortune. "If only the naysayers back home could see the state of things on this veritable pleasure cruise!" they would exclaim defiantly. This trend settled into a routine before long, and such was the new life of the wayfarer. The sun would break the horizon, and they would rise from sleep to great it. Meals were consumed, feet took to dance, and wine was drunk. Unfortunately, even the most steadfast of routines is fleeting in the scheme of life, and one night bad luck finally befell them. A new trend. And one that would last certainly longer than the previous. The captain saw through a glass large clouds of deep black swirling in the distance. Dusk was minutes off, so he took to worry. The coarse was altered, and the ship's path now listed somewhat to the South and away from danger. It was a reasonable precaution, and would have been a perfect solution if the maps were more reliable. They, however, most certainly were not. Therefore, it was not. If smooth seas never made a skillful sailor, it is no surprise that the captain and crew had some serious shortcomings. To blame any single one of them for the wreck would be terribly unfair. The real culprit was hidden somewhere in the barrels of wine and mead stored below deck. And in the habit they had made of good fortune. With bad weather behind, and brisk air above, the crew had mostly joined the passengers within the ships belly. With so many people gathered so closely, either violence or levity are guaranteed, and on this evening the mood kept a lighter tone. Above, in the crows nest, a lonely man listened resentfully as voices sang, and feet stomped to the tune of jovial tunes played by practiced hands. Fiddles, mandolins, and accordions bickered playfully for hours and with each passing minute the weary occupier of the crow's nest grew more bitter. Just before midnight, when a particularly quick tune was met with a particularly rowdy cheer, his mind was made. "Crow's nest be damned! Mead be downed!" The latter part of that statement has sprung from the mouths of men before many a poor decision. And always with the same degree of vigor. Within moments the deck of the ship sat vacant, while the hold was full to burst. Libations continued to flow, while a jagged rocky coast sneaked ever closer.

Meals were consumed, feet took to dance, and wine was drunk. Unfortunately, even the most steadfast of routines is fleeting in the scheme of life, and one night bad luck finally befell them. A new trend. And one that would last certainly longer than the previous. The captain saw through a glass large clouds of deep black swirling in the distance. Dusk was minutes off, so he took to worry. The coarse was altered, and the ship's path now listed somewhat to the South and away from danger. It was a reasonable precaution, and would have been a perfect solution if the maps were more reliable. They, however, most certainly were not. Therefore, it was not. If smooth seas never made a skillful sailor, it is no surprise that the captain and crew had some serious shortcomings. To blame any single one of them for the wreck would be terribly unfair. The real culprit was hidden somewhere in the barrels of wine and mead stored below deck. And in the habit they had made of good fortune. With bad weather behind, and brisk air above, the crew had mostly joined the passengers within the ships belly. With so many people gathered so closely, either violence or levity are guaranteed, and on this evening the mood kept a lighter tone. Above, in the crows nest, a lonely man listened resentfully as voices sang, and feet stomped to the tune of jovial tunes played by practiced hands. Fiddles, mandolins, and accordions bickered playfully for hours and with each passing minute the weary occupier of the crow's nest grew more bitter. Just before midnight, when a particularly quick tune was met with a particularly rowdy cheer, his mind was made. "Crow's nest be damned! Mead be downed!" The latter part of that statement has sprung from the mouths of men before many a poor decision. And always with the same degree of vigor. Within moments the deck of the ship sat vacant, while the hold was full to burst. Libations continued to flow, while a jagged rocky coast sneaked ever closer.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
I have reaped the souls of many over the course of my years as death. Souls of the good, the bad, and everything between have always been sown by another before I pluck them from the Earth at their appropriate time. Even the ones that believe it is n't their time or ask for just one more opportunity to do what they wish, must be taken without question because, well, its just the way my job is. To me, it never mattered where they were at in life. I just carried them over with ease. Never once had experienced trouble in my task as I had even had to pluck sweet children from the arms of their mothers. However, it all changed when I was tasked with taking the soul of David Mckiny. I watched David from the day he entered the Earth, and never before had I seen someone as special as him. He always thought of others first, always trying to help others before even contemplating his own commodities. I approached him on the fateful day at exactly noon. He was old now, no longer in his prime as he was finally about to lose his battle with cancer. I approached him as the hourglass emptied completely to the bottom. I spoke to him," David you must know who I am at this hour." He answered not necessarily speaking to me," If only I had helped more.... If only I could have have had more time! How dreadful to go when so many more need help!" At this moment I found it immensely hard to fulfill my task. I was not met with a man begging for more time only to waste it on fruitless trivialities. I was met with a man who wanted to bring grace to more people. He wished not to make his life better, but only cares to try to improve as many others as possible. I finally brought myself to say," David you have been a good man, but death is one thing which is inevitable, and not even I can grant time when someone is due. You must come along now with me." He allowed his soul to leave his body, a tear running down his face as he did. I extended my arm to him and he obliged. If there is one final peace to the journey is the experience of seeing one's life pass by as I guide them to the next step. I saw, as we walked, countless people who David had helped, most of which he had n't known and would never see again. Every part of me wished to guide him back to his body, but I knew I had a task to fulfill, and I knew I had to complete it. After a long while of walking down the path, we finally came to the gateway where David would continue without my guidance. I never know where the person will go once they enter, but I knew David would go to a place that would have the same passion in death as he did in life. I never had such a hard time seeing someone move on, and I sat a while thinking of how tragic it is for someone like David, genuinely the best kind of person, to be taken from such a cruel world when he one of the few people who deserved to stay. Anyways I found myself contemplating to long, and I moved on to reap the rest of the souls I had to fetch that day.

Tod becomes infatuated with Faye, despite her lack of interest.
output:
He begins to stalk her, following her around campus and watching her every move. One night, Tod follows Faye home and breaks into her apartment. He finds her asleep in bed and watches her for hours, unable to take his eyes off of her.

The next morning, Faye wakes up to find Tod standing over her bed. She screams and tries to run away, but Tod grabs her and holds her down. He tells her that he loves her and wants to be with her forever. Faye struggles against him, but Tod is too strong. He forces himself on her, raping her repeatedly until she passes out from exhaustion.

When Faye wakes up, she finds herself tied to a chair in Tod's basement. He has set up a makeshift altar with candles and flowers, and he is wearing a black robe. He tells Faye that he plans to sacrifice her to the dark gods, and that she will become his eternal bride. Faye pleads with him to let her go, but Tod ignores her cries.

As Tod prepares to kill Faye, she manages to break free from her bonds and attack him. They struggle violently, and Faye eventually gains the upper hand. She stabs Tod multiple times with a knife, killing him instantly. As she stands over his dead body, Faye realizes that she has become something else entirely - a monster capable of unspeakable acts of violence.

Faye flees the scene of the crime, leaving behind a trail of blood and destruction. She knows that she can never return to her normal life, and that she must live in hiding forever. But deep down inside, she feels a sense of satisfaction knowing that she has avenged herself against Tod, and that she has proven herself to be stronger than anyone ever imagined.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
A city, its mountains. The office towers lighting up in the evening haze and the smeary pale of a cloudless sunset. The tiny headlights of cars with sweaty passengers unseen, idling in traffic, smelling the hot food cooking in restaurants. The world shifts as the woman behind the camera adjusts her footing, muttering in English to her boyfriend. A light like the sun over the horizon, there and then gone. Silence, but for the wind in the trees. She asks what that was. The clean, shaved, washed, waxed people in suits at desks read facts and information like sports commentary. They narrate animations with moving arrows and lines like football plays. They report on characters and captains. They discuss. They debate. They nod solemnly. The light flashes in the sky and fades but the afterglow remains. They update, they check-in, they go-live, they re-Tweet. Wounded civilians scream and coddle loved ones, rewind. Look right here: loved ones die. Rewind. The light like the sun. Stay tuned. A city, its mountains. The office buildings lighting up in evening haze. Tiny headlights and unseen drivers thinking about food. A mutter in the sunset. A light and its afterglow. The wind in the trees. The troops are bad cameramen. They laugh or they scream or they joke nervously. Trucks and tanks and armoured vehicles on tall tires carry them down empty roads where sometimes cars have been abandoned or craters from bad arty shots force detours. The videos capture the sounds of war. Pops and crackles of overhead bullets. The shake and snapping of stalks and branches. Rivers idling over rounded stones. The scritchety clatter of the camera tumbling after bomb concussion shreds the canopies and dust swirls in mottled sunlight. Winged insects flashing momentarily in their arcs. A city, its mountains. Buildings, drivers. Sunset. A light. People speak in hushed tones. Somewhere, over the horizon on the other side of the world, everything has changed. There are no videos of the darkness that came afterward. A light like the sun. A motorcyclist pulls over to the side of the road in the clear, humid evening and reaches down to turn the petcock to OFF before quieting the motor. She's out in the country, flat fields of corn and wheat on either side of the old road. Above her the stars are out and bright in the sky. One of them, brighter than the rest, moves slowly toward the Earth's penumbra. The rider flips up her visor and sits back, hands behind her on the seat, watching the little light move, thinking of the people inside looking back. When those astronauts look down at Seoul, what do they see? The light fades and she is left alone. She listens and hears only crickets and a soft waxy rustle of a breeze in the corn. No guns, no artillery. No marching. No wet gasps from ruined faces. She shifts and works a hand into her pocket, pulling out a phone made in South Korea. She wonders if the people who screwed and soldered its pieces together are still alive, whether they could have seen the flash from wherever they were. Her friend has texted her, asking when she will get to the party. She responds with "A few minutes" and puts the phone away. The bike starts up fine once it's warm and after a moment of further staring into the stars she kicks the engine over and rolls away. The bright red of her tail light flashes as she slows at the intersection, then winks out.

Father Jean Marie Latour is assigned to the New Mexico territory by the Vatican.
output: He arrives in Santa Fe in 1851, and finds himself in charge of a diocese that stretches across thousands of miles of desert, including parts of Colorado and Arizona. His first task is to build a cathedral in Santa Fe, which he does with the help of his friend Father Joseph Vaillant. The two men become close friends, and Latour comes to rely on Vaillant's advice and support. However, their friendship is tested when Vaillant falls ill and dies. Latour is devastated by the loss of his friend, and struggles to come to terms with his death. He also faces opposition from some of the local priests, who resent his authority and question his decisions. Despite these challenges, Latour continues to work tirelessly to build up the Catholic Church in the Southwest. He travels extensively throughout the region, visiting remote villages and preaching to the Native American tribes. He also establishes schools and hospitals, and helps to improve living conditions for the poor. Over time, Latour becomes a beloved figure in the community, known for his kindness and compassion. He eventually retires to a small village near Santa Fe, where he spends his final years writing his memoirs. In his later years, Latour reflects on his life and career, and comes to realize that his greatest achievement was not building cathedrals or establishing institutions, but rather helping others to find meaning and purpose in their lives. He dies peacefully in his sleep, surrounded by his family and friends.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
The problem with personality is that so much of it depends on what happened during your life. There are certain things that change you for better or worse. I wish I could say that all the accumulated knowledge, wisdom and memories stay but each time we start again, it's like a reset on most things. Thomas was having another party according to his Facebook update. I remember the last time I was invited to one, he gave me a list of things to bring and I did, except no one else was there. He gave me the location of a lifeguard tower at the beach that they were at, except it did n't actually exist. I have a flask tucked into my jacket pocket on the chair with the potion that will set my plan into motion if I decide to try again. I'm still not sure if this is what I want to do, raising him again and starting over is an impossibility because he might not even be healthy enough to raise me so that I have a chance of repeating our plans again. The thing is, I'm still not sure about how I feel about not letting him know about his genetic predisposition for heart failure this time. I decided a few tries ago that this had too much of a negative impact whenever I told him, no matter how old he was when I did. Too many times I witnessed him going down the wrong path with drugs because of this. He's in college and happy now, not a care in the world. He has a slight idea of our plan this time even though he suspects it's just a story I used to tell to help him cope with being abandoned by his real parents. I've thought about this and if I really wanted to, I could just let him live normally. I could let him find out on his own. I know he's smart and might even figure something out. Medicine has advanced tremendously since we started. Personally, I feel like I've had enough of this life business but I'm not sure if I should make this choice for him. Maybe I was wrong and I ca n't reverse engineer what my friend used to be. He looks at me as a father figure and I guess that's understandable, I'm old enough to be his grandfather by now. So I decide to do what my heart tells me is right. I take the flask that I asked my lawyer to mail to me and pour it into my bedpan until the very last drop is gone.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Latour sets out for Santa Fe with Father Joseph Vaillant.
output: They travel through the desert, stopping at various missions along the way. At each mission, Latour meets with the local priest and discusses their work. He also learns more about the people who live in these remote areas. One day, while traveling through New Mexico, Latour comes across a group of Indians who are celebrating a feast. As he watches them dance around a fire, he realizes that they must be Pueblo Indians. This realization makes him wonder whether or not he can convert any of them to Christianity. When he returns home from his journey, Latour decides to write a book about his experiences. In order to do so, however, he needs some money. To get this money, he goes back to France where he sells several paintings. With the proceeds, he buys land near Albuquerque, New Mexico. On this property, he builds a small church called San Miguel de los Santos Reyes. It becomes known as "the little chapel." Over time, other churches spring up throughout the region. These include Our Lady of Guadalupe Church in Taos, St. Francis Xavier Mission in Gallup, and Holy Cross Parish in Las Cruces. All three parishes eventually become part of the Diocese of El Paso. By 1850, there were over 100 Catholic priests working in New Mexico. Most of these men came from Europe. However, many others were born in America. Some even converted to Catholicism after moving westward. For example, one such person was Fr. Antonio José Martínez y Montoya. Born in Spain, he moved to California when he was young. There, he became involved in politics and later served as governor of Alta California. Later, he returned to Spain and entered the priesthood. Eventually, he ended up serving as bishop of Durango, Mexico. Another important figure in early New Mexican history was Archbishop Jean Baptiste Lamy. A native Frenchman, he arrived in Santa Fe in 1846. His goal was to establish a diocese in New Mexico. Unfortunately, due to political problems between the United States government and the Republic of Texas, he never succeeded. Instead, he spent most of his career trying to improve relations between Catholics and Protestants. During World War II, Archbishop Lamy helped organize relief efforts for refugees fleeing Nazi Germany. After the war, he continued to promote peace among different religious groups. Today, the Archdiocese of Santa Fe includes all of northern New Mexico. Its current archbishop is John Wester. He took office in 2013 following the retirement of Archbishop Michael Sheehan.

output: They have been given a mandate to do so by the Pope himself. Latour is a young priest who has just arrived in New Mexico after spending several years in France. However, they soon discover that the task ahead of them is much more difficult than they anticipated. The people of New Mexico are deeply suspicious of outsiders, and they are particularly wary of priests. In addition, the landscape is harsh and unforgiving, making travel difficult and dangerous. Despite these challenges, Latour and Vaillant remain committed to their cause. They work tirelessly to build relationships with the local community and to spread the word of God. Over time, they make progress, but it is slow going. Eventually, however, their efforts pay off, and the Catholic Church begins to take root in New Mexico. This is due in large part to the dedication and perseverance of Latour and Vaillant. These two men were able to overcome significant obstacles and achieve success where others had failed. Their story is one of determination and faith, and it serves as an inspiration to all who read it.

A city, its mountains. The office towers lighting up in the evening haze and the smeary pale of a cloudless sunset. The tiny headlights of cars with sweaty passengers unseen, idling in traffic, smelling the hot food cooking in restaurants. The world shifts as the woman behind the camera adjusts her footing, muttering in English to her boyfriend. A light like the sun over the horizon, there and then gone. Silence, but for the wind in the trees. She asks what that was. The clean, shaved, washed, waxed people in suits at desks read facts and information like sports commentary. They narrate animations with moving arrows and lines like football plays. They report on characters and captains. They discuss. They debate. They nod solemnly. The light flashes in the sky and fades but the afterglow remains. They update, they check-in, they go-live, they re-Tweet. Wounded civilians scream and coddle loved ones, rewind. Look right here: loved ones die. Rewind. The light like the sun. Stay tuned. A city, its mountains. The office buildings lighting up in evening haze. Tiny headlights and unseen drivers thinking about food. A mutter in the sunset. A light and its afterglow. The wind in the trees. The troops are bad cameramen. They laugh or they scream or they joke nervously. Trucks and tanks and armoured vehicles on tall tires carry them down empty roads where sometimes cars have been abandoned or craters from bad arty shots force detours. The videos capture the sounds of war. Pops and crackles of overhead bullets. The shake and snapping of stalks and branches. Rivers idling over rounded stones. The scritchety clatter of the camera tumbling after bomb concussion shreds the canopies and dust swirls in mottled sunlight. Winged insects flashing momentarily in their arcs. A city, its mountains. Buildings, drivers. Sunset. A light. People speak in hushed tones. Somewhere, over the horizon on the other side of the world, everything has changed. There are no videos of the darkness that came afterward. A light like the sun. A motorcyclist pulls over to the side of the road in the clear, humid evening and reaches down to turn the petcock to OFF before quieting the motor. She's out in the country, flat fields of corn and wheat on either side of the old road. Above her the stars are out and bright in the sky. One of them, brighter than the rest, moves slowly toward the Earth's penumbra. The rider flips up her visor and sits back, hands behind her on the seat, watching the little light move, thinking of the people inside looking back. When those astronauts look down at Seoul, what do they see? The light fades and she is left alone. She listens and hears only crickets and a soft waxy rustle of a breeze in the corn. No guns, no artillery. No marching. No wet gasps from ruined faces. She shifts and works a hand into her pocket, pulling out a phone made in South Korea. She wonders if the people who screwed and soldered its pieces together are still alive, whether they could have seen the flash from wherever they were. Her friend has texted her, asking when she will get to the party. She responds with "A few minutes" and puts the phone away. The bike starts up fine once it's warm and after a moment of further staring into the stars she kicks the engine over and rolls away. The bright red of her tail light flashes as she slows at the intersection, then winks out.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
I've always seen numbers above people. Ever since I was a small child, I began recognizing patterns. Those in power, or with great ambition tended to be higher, while those who were more meek and humble tended to have lower numbers. As Class President, I've had my fair share of meeting people, and I'd never seen a person alive above an 8, including the tyrants of history. Sometimes, peoples numbers would change... those bullies with a 3 or 4 would cower down to a 1 or 2 after I confronted them for harassing others. I was beaten and bruised for years, but they slowly backed down. Of course, when I entered high-school, this was n't the case. There were some who were 5s and 6s, but I could n't stop now. I confronted them and the scars I have today are proof of my goals. I never backed down and kept striving to improve myself in all ways so I could make this world a better place for all of us. I scored near perfect on the University entrance exams, and was in the Tokyo University entrance ceremony when I saw him.... I did n't know his name, but an iridescent white 10 glowed above his head. The fellow next to him was a 0... Both scored perfect on the entrance exam, as they were giving the speech, but they were such opposites. The 10 was clad in suit and tie, with his long brown hair dangling in front of his eyes. The 0 was awkward-looking, he wore over-sized clothes, and it looked like he resented wearing shoes... I left early, and caught his glimpse on the way out. Our eyes caught briefly, and his 10 dropped to a 0... he smiled my way, and I smiled back. I felt calm and serene, something I would never have expected. The awkward 0 looked at me with his dark eyes before sitting down... I felt terror... as his 0 slowly morphed into a dark and smoky 10. I left that experience behind me, but worked even harder to help others; I chose to become a prosecutor... to judge and serve justice to those who were evil. High numbers were a good indicator of evil, and it is my goal to eliminate evil. I regularly judged others based on their numbers, whether they were to be eliminated or not. Then one day, it happened. Those I judged to be evil started dying of heart attacks; sudden deaths flooded the world, and the number of criminals slowly starting reducing. The world called him "Kira"... I called him God, and he soon recognized me as his devout follower, when he shared his power to judge and delete evil from this world. Now I know my ultimate purpose, and whenever I look in the mirror, I'm glad to see a shining halo-like 10 above my head, reminding me of the day I saw the shining 10 on the podium during my University's entrance ceremony all those years ago.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Latour loses most of his possessions in a steamboat wreck in Galveston.
output: He travels by foot to Houston where he meets up with his friend, the Frenchman Jean Laffite. Latour has been hired by the Mexican government to spy on the Americans. He is also looking for his brother, who disappeared in Texas. Latour and Laffite travel to San Antonio de Bexar, where they meet up with the American General Sam Houston. They learn that the Mexicans are planning to attack the Alamo. Latour and Laffite join the Texans in defending the Alamo. They are both killed in the battle. Latour's body is found by his brother, who buries him in the Alamo cemetery. His grave is marked with a simple wooden cross. In the years following the Battle of the Alamo, many legends grew up around the men who died there. One legend tells of a ghostly figure that haunts the Alamo grounds. Some say it is the spirit of Davy Crockett, while others believe it is the ghost of Jim Bowie. Still others claim that it is the ghost of William Barret Travis, the commander of the Texan forces at the Alamo. Whatever its identity, the ghost is said to appear on the anniversary of the battle, carrying a lantern and searching for its lost comrades. Another legend tells of a mysterious light that appears in the sky over the Alamo every year on March 6th, the date of the battle. Some say it is the souls of the dead soldiers rising up to heaven, while others believe it is a sign from God that the Alamo will never fall again. Whatever its meaning, the light is a reminder of the sacrifice made by those who fought and died at the Alamo. The Alamo is a symbol of courage and determination, and its defenders will always be remembered as heroes. Their legacy lives on in the hearts of all Texans, and their memory will never fade away.

The second alarm goes off at 7 in the morning. The first, a few hours before, sharply shrilled that it was time to get up and shower. Hungover and covered with the sweat and scents of the night before, I had dragged myself through the morning routine of cleansing. There was plenty of time beneath the lukewarm stream of water to contemplate the sadness of another hangover caused by drinking alone. It'd been weeks since I last had a chance to talk to another human, instead of just the PC terminal supplied by work. I towelled off and staggered through to the living-room and slumped in front of the computer, waiting for the piercing whistle to repeat, to emanate from my phone. The second alarm marked that it was time for the Remembrance. I sigh, move the empty beer bottles away from my desk and load up Hitchens 2. Since the Bliss neurovirus was released, there was a killing to be made from this sort of software; software designed to take you through a basic test, activating every faculty you'd conceivably need to prevent the atrophy. First, colour recognition and geometric shapes. Second, basic maths ramping into some gentle algebra and trigonometry. English, ethics, road safety, compassion testing, aesthetics, philosophical contemplation, the sciences. It was a hard sell at the beginning, for companies to give their employees the few hours off each morning they needed for the state-mandated testing, but given the choice between late employees and those in conscious comas, they made the right choice. Two hours later, the general test finishes. I flick through my results, 91 % recognition of the basic concepts, not too bad after a night of hard drinking. Next would come a quick half hour personal session: the names of loved ones, relations to family members, anniversaries and birthdays. A prompt flashes on the screen: "Please enter your identity number and full name". I rattle my digits in, 12958321-A, and tab down to the field for my name. I blank. Slight panic begins to grow as I search my beer-soaked consciousness for that basic, bloody basic, detail. It'd been too long since I last had to introduce myself with anything other than my work ID number, too long since I had any reason to say those damned words out loud. Darren? No. Christopher? No, definitely not. I shout and swear and blaspheme out loud, as I slowly feel the neurovirus go to work; Purgatory, we call it, a limbo without knowledge, tied with a purging. It dissolves me gently. The panic subsides. I stare blankly at the flashing cursor, waiting for me to enter some detail or another. I'm not sure what it's asking for, but I'm sure it's not too important or I'd remember it. I sit there, staring. Just staring. I'm sure it'd come back to me eventually.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Chicago wins the bid for the 1893 World's Fair.
output: The city is abuzz with excitement. The fairgrounds are built on the shores of Lake Michigan, and the city prepares for its moment in the spotlight. But then disaster strikes. On October 8th, 1871, the Great Chicago Fire breaks out. The fire destroys much of the city, including the fairgrounds. The fair is cancelled. The city is devastated. But the people of Chicago are resilient. They rebuild. And when the fair finally opens in May of 1893, it is a triumph. The fairgrounds are filled with exhibits from around the world. There are pavilions dedicated to art, science, industry, and agriculture. There are rides and games and food stalls. And there is the Ferris wheel, the tallest structure in the world. The fair is a success. Over 27 million people visit during its six-month run. And when it closes, the city is left with a lasting legacy. The fairgrounds become Jackson Park, one of the largest parks in the city. And the Ferris wheel becomes a symbol of Chicago, a reminder of the city's resilience and determination.

It had been years since Zuccotti Park was free of barbed wire. A large concrete wall surrounded the plaza, a thousand V masks for each revolutionary lost in the fighting so far. You'd mistake Lower Manhattan for Mogadishu if it were n't for the skyscrapers that watched over the fighting. The compound for the Occupy movement was never quiet, the rattle of gunfire or the occasional pained yell as another fighter was brought back from the frontlines. The fighting had become entrenched by the 5th year. For every advance made on Central Park, there were another 50 casualties. Minesweepers had a full time job of clearing paths, just to be shot by a remote gunpod, flying over the metropolitan No Man's Land. Today however seemed different, a lull had settled over the battlefield. All that could be heard was the occasional burst of gunfire or the low hum of the Emergency Broadcast System screens throughout the city. Maybe it was the reverence for the day. 10 years since the revolution began and that first tent and sign was raised in protest. The 99 % had lost many but continued to fight. The 1 % still remained strong, and today they would deliver the final blow. The view screens flickered, the hum of the screens replaced with the anthem of a broken union. The face of the enemy flashed on screen, to address his ailing public.'My fellow Americans. It has been ten years since the seeds of chaos were sown in our great nation. Radicals gathered to destroy our honourable values and throw us into pandemonium. We tried to reason with them, we tried our best to comprehend their hatred and talk them back on the righteous path. But we failed. We showed then mercy and compassion but their hatred festered. They cast the first stone, they took the first life and they continue to poison everything they touch. They have taken our monuments to our strength and our bravery, and defile them with their vile propaganda. I for one, will stand no longer.' The screen changes, showing a diagram of Lower Manhatten. A diagram of a blast zone was overlaid on the top of it.'We must cut out the cancer which has plagued our nation for too long. Mercy has failed, so we will retaliate in the only language these vermin understand. our old metropole will be cleansed and returned to its rightful owners. Justice will be swift and final. We will take back what is rightly ours. God bless America and god have mercy on their souls.'

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Daniel Burnham and John Root are chosen as the fair's architects.
output: Their design calls for a "White City" of neoclassical buildings around a central Court of Honor, inspired by the Champs-Élysées in Paris. The exposition covers more than 600 acres (2.4 km²), including 200 buildings of various architectural styles. The planners include a Midway Plaisance, along with rides and amusements, designed by Frederick Law Olmsted. The fair opens on May 1, 1893, and runs until October 30. During this period, nearly 27 million people attend. The fair introduces several products that later became internationally famous, including Aunt Jemima pancake mix, Juicy Fruit gum, Cracker Jack popcorn confection, Shredded Wheat cereal, and Pabst Blue Ribbon beer. The Ferris Wheel, intended to rival the Eiffel Tower built for the Exposition Universelle two years earlier, proves extremely popular; nearly 1.5 million passengers ride it before it is dismantled. Other attractions include Buffalo Bill's Wild West Show, belly dancers, and a replica of a Moorish palace. The fair also features exhibits from 46 countries, and 65,000 exhibitors. The United States government creates a U.S. Government Building, for three main exhibits: the United States Navy, the United States Army, and the Smithsonian Institution. The United States Post Office Department operates a branch post office in the Government Building, distributes the first-ever commemorative stamp, and sells specially designed postal cards that can be mailed from the fair. The Midway includes carnival rides, among them the original Ferris wheel, built by George Washington Gale Ferris Jr. This wheel was 264 feet (80 m) high and had 36 cars, each of which could accommodate 60 people. The term "midway" for a fair or carnival referred originally to the Midway Plaisance, a strip of park land that still extends south from the Museum of Science and Industry to Jackson Park. The layout of the Chicago Columbian Exposition was, in large part, designed by Daniel Burnham and Frederick Law Olmsted. The World's Congress Auxiliary Building is the only building surviving on-site from the fair. The Palace of Fine Arts (also known as the Art Palace), now housing the Museum of Science and Industry, is the only other building surviving from the fair. In addition, the former Merchant Tailor Building houses the Chicago Public Library's Chinatown Branch. Three other significant buildings survived the fair. The Norway Building was relocated to Lake Geneva, Wisconsin and is currently operated as a museum. The Maine State Building, designed by Charles Sumner Frost, was relocated to the Poland Springs Resort in Maine. The Dutch House is on display at Brookgreen Gardens near Myrtle Beach, South Carolina.

The first time I jumped, I immediately looked up the latest medical journals. They had certainly made significant progress, but it was n't enough. I did n't even take a look around before I jumped again. I checked, again. Success. The cure had been found. It was in clinical trials and was being fast-tracked. Six months, only six months left. I drove like a madman to the hospital. Transferred? What do you mean transferred? I PAID THE BILLS FOR 9 MONTHS BEFORE I LEFT!!! 15 months ago... Oh god. Over a year. I found her. I barely recognized her, except her voice. That angelic voice that kept me going. It was difficult explaining where I'd been. I was gone for so long. She did n't understand, she was just happy to see me. Then the doctor came in. He pulled me aside. No. NO! 1 month, at best. NO! NO! NO! NO! I started to run out of the room, but she could tell. She did n't know what I was doing, but she knew I would n't be back. She pleaded, and it tore my heart apart, but I was doing it for her. When I was done, we could spend the rest of our lives together. I left, I jumped, I landed. I ran to the pharmacy, prescription in hand. The doctor had been confused when I asked for it. Probably thought it was a reaction to his prognosis. A line. There was a line at the pharmacy. It took everything I had not to scream. But then I remembered, I had all the time in the world. Drug in hand, I dialed in the date of her diagnosis. I entered the code and pressed enter. ERROR: Abort, Retry, Fail? What happened next rendered the machine useless... Now! I had to get to her now! I had to cure her right now. I stole a car, I do n't know whose it was, I could n't even tell you what kind or color it was. At some point the police started chasing me. I outran them. At the entrance, security tried to stop me, I outran them. When they told me, my guilt and denial rushed to me at once, I could n't outrun it. I just wanted to spend the rest of my life with her, so I left. She just wanted to spend the rest of her life with me, so she asked me to stay.

Construction of the fair faces numerous obstacles.
output: The most pressing is the lack of funds. The city has already spent more than $100 million on the project, and there are still many expenses to come. The mayor has proposed raising taxes to cover the costs, but this idea has met with strong opposition from the public. Another problem is the location of the fairgrounds. The site chosen by the city is located in a residential area, and many residents are opposed to having such a large event taking place in their neighborhood. Finally, there is the issue of traffic. With so many people expected to attend the fair, the roads leading to the fairgrounds are likely to become very congested. This could cause major delays for those trying to reach the fair, as well as for those who live in the surrounding areas. Despite these challenges, the city remains committed to hosting the fair. Officials believe that it will bring much-needed revenue to the city, and that it will provide a boost to the local economy. They also hope that it will help to promote tourism in the area. Only time will tell whether the fair will be a success or a failure. However, one thing is certain: it will be a memorable event for everyone involved.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
You know those nightmares you had as a child, where you'd be somewhere familiar yet completely alien? As though your home had suddenly become some faraway land, and your only goal was to return home. Well in 2014, that's exactly what happened to everyone in the world. I was on my way to an important business meeting, off to discuss some law, and how my company could avoid it, when it all happened. I checked my watch to see the time, and as I looked up, I saw a blinding flash off in the distance, lighting up the once blue sky in streaks of white. Next, it was followed by an eardrum shattering bang, like a hundred thousand gunshots going off at once. Then, finally, the blast. A wall of rock, stone, dirt and trash and flew towards me, silhouetted by the strange white light. I turned to run, but like a wave washing over the ocean, anything in the path of that wall was thrown like a ragdoll. The last thing I remember was being thrown what felt like miles into the air, and rushing down back into that swirling vortex of light. When I woke, it was night time. Others seemed to be sitting up around me, and the confused look on the faces that surrounded me seemed to speak louder than words that this was not a normal occurrence. I checked my watch, and had a terrible realisation. It was 3 am, and I was ridiculously late for my meeting! I tried to get to my feet, but the second I tried to stand, my legs gave way underneath me. What the hell was going on? After a few minutes I had enough strength to drag myself up by a nearby stair railing. For the first time since waking, I looked around. Something was wrong. As I looked, I saw the once manicured strips of grass and trees had overgrown to ridiculous proportions, and the streets were covered in trash, empty food packages, and bones. Wait what the hell? Upon further inspection, I saw they were human. Jesus Christ, what the hell happened. It was then that I checked my watch again. A neat little feature it had was that it told the time in seconds, minutes, hours, days and years. The blood drained from my face as I saw what I'd missed earlier. 3:04 am. Friday. 13th of June. 2015. As I wondered what the hell was going on, something rustled through the bushes behind me. Something big. As I saw glowing red eyes light the way. Then was the first time I wondered, what left those bones?

Should be plenty of time to deal with these homegrown terrorists and get the lad to school on time." -scene break Voldemort could n't believe what was happening. For the past thirty days he had every single minion that left the Malfoy manor get shipped back in a body bag. He had n't even known muggles had those. Just goes to show how the animals could steal the dignity from wizards even in death. He was left with Wormtail and Bellatrix. Granted Bella was loyal, but she was completely insane. His most cunning and resourceful follower, the best deatheater he had, reduced to an insane hag who was good for nothing more than pointing at something he wanted destroyed and then watching it burn. A deep sigh dragged itself out of him. He could n't bring himself to even try to list any redeeming qualities in Wormtail. That was when he heard it, a muffled sound like nothing he had ever heard followed by the unmistakable sound of a dead body hitting the ground. Quick steps brought him into the kitchen in time to see a man about his age in a muggle suit dabbing a bit of blood from his face, Wormtail laying in a pool of his own blood behind him, with Bellatrix dying at his feet. Voldemort could n't remember ever being this angry. A growl issued from his clenched teeth. "Who are you?!" Voldemort shouted, even as he raised his wand to cast crucio on this fool who defied him. The muggle simply raised a hand with some device in it and pushed a bright red button on it. Pain like Voldemort had never felt corsed through his body as the traps he had n't noticed when he barged in shot tiny barbed hooks into his body attached to the launchers by a thin piece of wire. Then the traps sent 25 mill Ampere of electricity coursing through his body. Only the fact that the electricity was still flowing through him, forcing his muscles to contract, kept Voldemort standing. "The name is Bond, James Bond. Harry Potter sends his regards. Do n't worry about dying though old chap, MI6 has plans for you."

The year is 167 A.R. The air around the deep survival bunker, other than being stuffy, is tense. I enter the observance chamber, and it's a buzz of activity. People huddling around unrecognizable laptops and computers. The days were finally closing in on the hours. Light was imminent. It has been 167 years since the destabilization. 167 years after rogue. Our planet, along with its some 7.8 billion population of people, have been forced to hide, or die trying. Many of us went underground, taking with us seeds and other animals to restart life if possible. We all new the odds of that though. After the first five years of preparation, we went into cryostasis, while a small population elected to stay and try and plot our course through the lonely emptiness of deep space. Needless to say, they succeeded, and they were bloody excited. Our Earth, with its surface now a comfortable -176 degrees Celsius, is on a hopeful course to the Andromeda Galaxy. We are approaching it very fast, but we believe that we will come within orbital distance and speed of at least twenty stars. And so we were awoken. Our planet, after a century of darkness, is starting to receive light from nearby stars. The boffs say that it still is only a full moon of light, but it's a change. Soon, we will pass by a red giant, and very closely. The boffs believe that it will be enough to start thawing out our cold, icy blue planet. The day has arrived. I am standing at the airlock, alongside my expeditionary unit. It's been a few days since we started our slingshot around the red giant, and the surface readings say that the temperature is stabilizing between -19 and 2 degrees. It's still cold, but it will be bearable, especially in our survival gear. We have packed 3 days of food. It's been a while since I've had a military ration pack, but the management thought it would be suitable to have one with our return to the surface. Everyone else has backed skis on their backpacks, but I've got my old snowboard kit with me. It was my passion before I left the surface. I stand here, before the airlock, googles on and pretty much looking like a... Like one of those puffy treats you roast on a stick over fire. I ca n't remember their name. Come to think of it, I hardly remember what fire looks like. The attendant starts the opening sequence from his enclosed booth. I stand at the head of the other 11 men and women. Everyone of them has lost something to the darkness, and everyone of them has determination to reclaim our planet and our lives. The air lock breaks, and a flood of air escapes and pours in. As I shield my eyes from the initial blinding light, I know of the struggle to come. I stand upright, and stare out beyond the layered steel frame. Crisp virgin snow lays beyond us, in our bleak abandoned world. "O brave new world", I mutter to no one reminiscently.

Montag begins to question everything he knows. He returns home and finds Mildred awake. They argue about their lack of communication and their unhappy marriage. Montag leaves the house and walks aimlessly until he comes across a group of homeless people gathered around a campfire. One of them recognizes him as a fireman and invites him to join them. Montag sits down and listens to their stories. He learns that many of them were once successful professionals who lost everything because of the government's censorship policies. They tell him about the time before the war when people could read whatever they wanted without fear of persecution. Montag realizes that these people are more free than he is. He decides to quit his job and live among them. He returns home and packs up his belongings. He says goodbye to Mildred and sets off into the night. He wanders through the city until he reaches the outskirts where there are no houses or buildings. He sees a large bonfire in the distance and heads towards it. When he arrives, he sees hundreds of people dancing around the flames. They welcome him warmly and offer him food and drink. Montag spends several weeks living among the homeless. He learns how to hunt and fish and build shelters. He also reads books that were banned long ago. One day, he hears sirens coming closer. He runs back to the city and hides behind a dumpster. He watches as police officers arrest everyone at the bonfire. Montag feels guilty for leaving them behind. He vows never to forget what happened to them. He returns to his apartment building and finds Mildred waiting for him. She tells him that she reported him missing and that the authorities want to talk to him. Montag refuses to go with her. Instead, he takes her hand and leads her away from the building. They walk together through the streets until they reach the edge of town. There, they find a small cabin hidden in the woods. Inside, they discover a library filled with thousands of books. Montag picks up a book and opens it. He smiles as he reads the title: Fahrenheit 451.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Picture the Earth. I'll try to guess what you're seeing. A stunning blue sphere, with splotches of green and white covering its surface. A dot contrasted against the vast dark expanse of space. Twisting and turning around the sun, the moon its closest companion, shining brightly by the planet's side. Truly a sight to behold. But I wanted to see it for myself. I sent up a rocket to orbit the Earth, its only purpose to take photos of this beautiful planet. And as I thought they would be, the pictures were marvelous, a true reflection of the beauty of nature. Yet instead of awe, my mouth was open in shock. The image you have in your head is wrong. I saw the oceans, blue as ever and the continents floating on top. I saw the clouds, seemingly painted onto the surface. And if I squinted, I saw the mountain ranges, the seas, the islands, all humanity's residence. And yet, something was wrong. I did n't see the round sphere I expected to see. Instead I saw a planet, so familiar, yet so distant. I saw a flat Earth. I stared at the photos with a blank look on my face. How could this be real? The shape of the Earth is a scientific fact that we've known for centuries, and yet I held in my hands the evidence that changes all that. Have we been wrong this whole time? I sat down and tried to comprehend it all. I was in denial. I checked to see if somehow, there was something wrong with the picture, perhaps the computer had gotten the data wrong, perhaps it was sending faulty messages, perhaps someone was just messing with me. I held on to the tiny sliver of hope that I was wrong, that this was all just a big misunderstanding. But alas, I was right. Though the possibility that perhaps something was wrong lingered in the back of my mind, I knew that it was true. I stared up at the night sky, looking at the stars. Humans are very stubborn creatures. We refuse to believe we are ever wrong and when we do, we admit it with a sigh of disappointment instead of a smile, knowing that we've learned something new. We take it as a personal insult to our intelligence if we're wrong, thinking'we should've known." Thinking we're right is more important than being right. But I am a logical, rational human being. I ca n't let my emotions overcome me. Knowing the truth is infinitely more important than being right. And yet I find myself so hesitant to admit the mistakes of my predecessors. To admit that we will have to re-learn everything about the Earth. To admit that we will have to start again. To admit that humans are mere mortals. The thing about facts is that they're true whether you believe in them or not. But I can change that. I grabbed my lighter and lit the photos. I watched them burn up until they had turned into ash. And I went to sleep, happy.

output: He is terrified of the hound because he knows that it has been programmed to kill him. Montag tries to run away from the hound but it catches up to him and attacks him. Montag manages to escape from the hound but he is badly injured. He goes to Faber's house and tells him what happened. Faber gives Montag some medicine to help him heal his wounds. Montag then decides to go back to the fire station and confront Beatty. When Montag arrives at the fire station, he finds that Beatty has already left. Montag then goes to Beatty's house and confronts him. Beatty tells Montag that he is going to arrest him for arson. Montag then kills Beatty and sets fire to his house. Montag then runs away from the city and hides in the countryside. He meets Clarisse McClellan who helps him to hide from the authorities. Montag then decides to join the resistance movement against the government. He becomes a member of the underground network of book lovers who are fighting against the censorship laws. Montag then starts to read books again and he realizes how much he loves reading. He also starts to question the government's policies and he begins to doubt their motives. Montag then decides to leave the resistance movement and return to the city. He wants to live a normal life again and he does not want to get involved in any more violence. However, when he returns to the city, he finds that things have changed. The government has become even more oppressive and the people are living in fear. Montag then decides to fight back against the government. He joins forces with other rebels and they start to plan a revolution. They manage to overthrow the government and restore democracy to the country. Montag then becomes a teacher and he teaches children about the importance of freedom and knowledge. He also writes a book about his experiences during the revolution. The book becomes a bestseller and it inspires many people to stand up for their rights. Montag then retires from teaching and he spends his days reading books and enjoying his freedom. He dies peacefully in his sleep at the age of ninety-five.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Void, I always felt like I understood that word. Looking back I realize I was naive, or maybe I was too full of hope. Me and Maria created the nano bots for constuction, as a way to ease the burden of building the lunar colony. She had survived the imperial invasion in the ruins of Los Angeles, she thought she could create a brighter future. Selfishness, that's what undid everything. Eventually the colonists decided they could n't abide the laws of earth. The people of earth decided they would n't abide rebels on the moon. They could n't accept those resources would be used for something other than their gain. So I reprogrammed the bots, I did n't tell her, how could I? They were meant to break things down and rebuild faults in the domes, I just allowed them to accept new targets. Of course she figured it out. With Maria gone I wanted to die, but I could n't. She dreamed of a world without conflict, where everyone had enough. I knew they would n't come willingly, so I lied. I told them I could make the bots fix the domes; that everything would be alright. Instead I joined my mind with them. At first I was in control. They tried to stop me, but the bots ate whatever they sent to harm me. I created massive pylon factories across the globe preparing for their acsension. I was lazy, a single mistake doomed everything. I set my neural pattern as the administrator. The others where sublimated within me. What else could I do, I had to quiet their voices or be driven mad. That was when the machines decided to best safeguard my well being they had to take over several key roles. What we needed most was matter, for fuel and to rebuild lost bots. We became a swarm. We devoured the earth in minutes. And so we drifted, eating always eating. We found the hive ships, sent centuries before my birth. We ate evrrything, and added the humans to the databanks. I saw nebulae beyond comprehension, their beauty cut down by their hunger. The only hope I had left was to leave beacons containing copies of my mind. Perhaps someone could find them, and destroy the swarm. We encountered aliens with fantastical technology, they attacked me with lasers that could cut through time itself. Still we fed. Stars were broken down bit by bit to fulfill our needs. Millenia passed and the feasts became further and further apart. With the lack of resources came concessions. More systems were shut down to survive. They cared only for me. It took Millenia but now only I remain the databanks purged. I remain as a single beacon, and a lone drone. It spends it's days savoring specs of matter it finds in the void. A true void of my own creation. I pray there is a god, and it can repair what I have sundered. I pray that this beacon survives and whoever manages to access it heads my warning. I know these prayers stem from desperation. At one time I spanned the entire universe. There is no God to save me. Calculations say I will subsist in this state for four thousand more years before the drone gives in, and deactivates. After that, I will shut down, eventually. I do not know how long that will take. I know that I will forget. I will forget the beauty I found and consumed. I will forget the humans that cried out in that terrible moment. I will forget her.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Montag and the firemen burn books at an old woman's house.
output: Montag watches the woman refuse to leave her home and her books, choosing instead to light a match and perish in the flames. Captain Beatty tells Montag that he should go home and rest because he looks unwell. Montag goes home and hides his stolen book under his pillow. He lies in bed, unable to sleep, and then decides to call in sick to work. When Mildred wakes up, she tries to convince him to go to work, but he refuses. He asks her if she remembers anything about meeting each other ten years ago, but she does not remember much. He also asks her why she swallowed all those sleeping pills last year, but she cannot recall doing such a thing. Montag realizes that Mildred has become completely desensitized to life. He takes out the book he stole and shows it to her, telling her that he wants to read it. She becomes upset and threatens to call Captain Beatty. Montag locks the bedroom door and forces Mildred to sit down and listen while he reads Dover Beach by Matthew Arnold. She cries and begs him to stop reading, but he continues until he finishes the poem. Then he tells her that he plans to memorize many different poems and stories so that he can pass them along to others. He says that he hopes to start a revolution against the government and its censorship of literature. Mildred runs away from him, screaming for help. Montag chases after her, but she escapes into the street. He returns home and calls Captain Beatty, who arrives shortly thereafter. Beatty tells Montag that he knows about the book and warns him not to try to hide any more books. He says that if Montag does not return to work tomorrow morning, he will report him to the authorities. Montag agrees to go back to work, but he secretly vows to continue stealing books and learning as much as possible. He begins to feel guilty about burning books, especially since he now understands how important they are. He wonders whether he might be able to use his knowledge to change society for the better. Meanwhile, Clarisse McClellan disappears without explanation. Her family assumes that she ran off with some boy, but Montag suspects otherwise. One day, while walking through town, he sees a man wearing a strange mask. The man approaches Montag and introduces himself as Professor Faber. He explains that he used to teach English Literature at a nearby university, but he was fired because he refused to teach students how to write propaganda. Now he works as a janitor at the local library. He offers to help Montag learn more about books and encourages him to keep reading. Montag accepts his offer and starts visiting the library regularly. Over time, he develops a close friendship with Professor Faber. Together, they discuss philosophy, politics, religion, science, art, music, history, and many other topics. They even share their thoughts on love and marriage. As Montag learns more about the world around him, he becomes increasingly dissatisfied with his job as a fireman. He feels trapped by his routine and longs for freedom. One night, he sneaks out of his apartment and walks through the city streets. He comes across a group of teenagers playing basketball. They invite him to join them, and he gladly accepts. For once, he enjoys himself and forgets about his troubles. However, when he returns home later that evening, he discovers that Mildred has reported him missing to the police. The next morning, Montag receives a visit from two policemen. They inform him that he has been accused of arson and murder. Apparently, someone witnessed him setting fire to a pile of books outside his apartment building. Montag denies committing any crimes, but the officers insist that he must turn himself in immediately. Desperate, Montag turns to Professor Faber for advice. Faber suggests that Montag flee the country and seek refuge elsewhere. He provides Montag with fake identification papers and money, and helps him escape through a secret passage leading underground. Once safely hidden away, Montag reflects upon his situation. He realizes that he made a terrible mistake by becoming a fireman. He resolves to never again allow anyone to dictate what he thinks or believes. From now on, he will live according to his own principles and values. He decides to dedicate his life to fighting injustice and oppression wherever he finds it. And thus ends Part One of Fahrenheit 451.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
It was about that time again. The dawn of a new day, when humans thought to sneak up on the Deep Woods Dragon while it slept. It feared the way the sun reflected off of it' s scales, they said. It' s prismatic hide was so bright it was blinding. If taunted into the sun, they said, the Deep Woods Dragon could be defeated by the least trained of knights. The Deep Woods Dragon needed to be blinded, they said, or it would burn its attackers to ashes with rainbow-hued flames. He knew these rumors because the butterflies had told him. They were drawn to the rainbow of greens, yellows, pinks and purples of his scales, like the flowers they coveted so much. They had told him this, too, but the Dragon did not mind. The butterflies were honest, as their lives were short and beautiful. Even still, they could fly unhindered among the humans, even admired by the small humans who chased them, laughing. They told him stories while they rested on his wingtips, tail, and snout. Butterflies did not fear the Dragon, because they knew the truth. With a yawn, the Dragon shifted its weight to better perch itself on the tree' s stout branch. This tree was taller than the others, and overlooked a small, circular clearing. Without the deer, the weeds thrived, covering the dirt in a green, tangled mass. At the edge of the clearing stood a massive cave entrance, vines draped over the sides of smooth rock. The Dragon had snapped off the vines in front of the entrance, to give the illusion of occupancy. This was, after all, where the humans thought he lived. He knew these rumors because the butterflies had told him. "In an ancient cave in the middle of the wood, lives an ancient dragon who' s up to no good!" That was what the small humans like to chant as they chased the butterflies and laughed. So the Dragon tore at the vines, and scared the graceful deer from the peaceful clearing. He had enjoyed watching the deer with their young as they grazed the clearing. From up above in his favorite tree, they could not see him, and they could not fear him. Three times a day, the Dragon glided down from his tree to the old cave' s opening. There, he took a deep breath and screamed as loud as he could. He cried in both low tones and high pitches. He wailed in imitation of female humans, shouted in a voice mimicking angry male humans. The Dragon stood on top of the cave and breathed eye-searing beams of light from his mouth to the sky. It scared the birds huddled in the trees, and the noises scared the deer far from the clearing. But they also scared the humans away from the Deep Woods. He knew these rumors because the butterflies had told him. So he made his noises, made the lights, and scared the humans away. Because any humans who saw the Dragon would discover the truth. Because, when the Dragon stepped into the sunlight, they' d see how small he really was. The Deep Woods Dragon, with prismatic scales that shone in the sun and such a frightening voice, was the size of a domestic house cat. And only the butterflies knew the truth.

I have reaped the souls of many over the course of my years as death. Souls of the good, the bad, and everything between have always been sown by another before I pluck them from the Earth at their appropriate time. Even the ones that believe it is n't their time or ask for just one more opportunity to do what they wish, must be taken without question because, well, its just the way my job is. To me, it never mattered where they were at in life. I just carried them over with ease. Never once had experienced trouble in my task as I had even had to pluck sweet children from the arms of their mothers. However, it all changed when I was tasked with taking the soul of David Mckiny. I watched David from the day he entered the Earth, and never before had I seen someone as special as him. He always thought of others first, always trying to help others before even contemplating his own commodities. I approached him on the fateful day at exactly noon. He was old now, no longer in his prime as he was finally about to lose his battle with cancer. I approached him as the hourglass emptied completely to the bottom. I spoke to him," David you must know who I am at this hour." He answered not necessarily speaking to me," If only I had helped more.... If only I could have have had more time! How dreadful to go when so many more need help!" At this moment I found it immensely hard to fulfill my task. I was not met with a man begging for more time only to waste it on fruitless trivialities. I was met with a man who wanted to bring grace to more people. He wished not to make his life better, but only cares to try to improve as many others as possible. I finally brought myself to say," David you have been a good man, but death is one thing which is inevitable, and not even I can grant time when someone is due. You must come along now with me." He allowed his soul to leave his body, a tear running down his face as he did. I extended my arm to him and he obliged. If there is one final peace to the journey is the experience of seeing one's life pass by as I guide them to the next step. I saw, as we walked, countless people who David had helped, most of which he had n't known and would never see again. Every part of me wished to guide him back to his body, but I knew I had a task to fulfill, and I knew I had to complete it. After a long while of walking down the path, we finally came to the gateway where David would continue without my guidance. I never know where the person will go once they enter, but I knew David would go to a place that would have the same passion in death as he did in life. I never had such a hard time seeing someone move on, and I sat a while thinking of how tragic it is for someone like David, genuinely the best kind of person, to be taken from such a cruel world when he one of the few people who deserved to stay. Anyways I found myself contemplating to long, and I moved on to reap the rest of the souls I had to fetch that day.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
The problem with personality is that so much of it depends on what happened during your life. There are certain things that change you for better or worse. I wish I could say that all the accumulated knowledge, wisdom and memories stay but each time we start again, it's like a reset on most things. Thomas was having another party according to his Facebook update. I remember the last time I was invited to one, he gave me a list of things to bring and I did, except no one else was there. He gave me the location of a lifeguard tower at the beach that they were at, except it did n't actually exist. I have a flask tucked into my jacket pocket on the chair with the potion that will set my plan into motion if I decide to try again. I'm still not sure if this is what I want to do, raising him again and starting over is an impossibility because he might not even be healthy enough to raise me so that I have a chance of repeating our plans again. The thing is, I'm still not sure about how I feel about not letting him know about his genetic predisposition for heart failure this time. I decided a few tries ago that this had too much of a negative impact whenever I told him, no matter how old he was when I did. Too many times I witnessed him going down the wrong path with drugs because of this. He's in college and happy now, not a care in the world. He has a slight idea of our plan this time even though he suspects it's just a story I used to tell to help him cope with being abandoned by his real parents. I've thought about this and if I really wanted to, I could just let him live normally. I could let him find out on his own. I know he's smart and might even figure something out. Medicine has advanced tremendously since we started. Personally, I feel like I've had enough of this life business but I'm not sure if I should make this choice for him. Maybe I was wrong and I ca n't reverse engineer what my friend used to be. He looks at me as a father figure and I guess that's understandable, I'm old enough to be his grandfather by now. So I decide to do what my heart tells me is right. I take the flask that I asked my lawyer to mail to me and pour it into my bedpan until the very last drop is gone.
