Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Henry meets Catherine Barkley and her friend Helen Ferguson.
output: They are both nurses working at the hospital where Henry is recovering from his injuries. Catherine is beautiful and intelligent, while Helen is plain-looking and dull-witted. Henry falls in love with Catherine immediately, but she does not reciprocate his feelings. She tells him that she loves someone else—a man named Frederic Henry who died fighting in World War I. Henry becomes obsessed with finding out more about this other man, whom he believes must have been a great hero. He learns that Frederic Henry was indeed a brave soldier who saved many lives before being killed himself. However, when Henry asks Catherine why she loved him instead of some other man, she replies simply: "Because he was good." This answer confuses Henry greatly; after all, wasn't everyone supposed to be good? Why would anyone choose one person over another based solely on their goodness? And yet, despite these questions, Henry continues to pursue Catherine throughout the rest of the novel. Eventually, however, he realizes that there can never truly be any happiness between them—Catherine will always remain loyal to her dead lover, while Henry will forever long for something he cannot have. In the end, then, A Farewell To Arms serves as a cautionary tale against romanticizing war and its consequences. It shows us how easily people become caught up in the excitement of battle without considering the costs involved. At the same time, though, it also reminds us that sometimes those sacrifices are necessary—even noble—in order to protect others from harm. Ultimately, therefore, A Farewell To Arms teaches us that although war may seem glamorous at first glance, ultimately it leads only to pain and suffering for everyone involved.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Scientists tried for decades to find out why the telomeres stopped shortening during cell division. Soon enough immortal children grew up and became scientists or participants in studies. They maintained the appearance of a child but had the brain of any other. And after several decades more immortal humans were everywhere, but humanity could n't discover how to replicate the genes or mutations causing the phenomena. It's now over one hundred fifty years since the birth of the first immortal. A young looking girl named Esther sat in a grassy field. Trees skirted the field at her back and in front of her sat a city. She'd seen more in her lifetime than any other human ever had. Several wars, booms in technology so astonishing that soon enough scientists said we were going to be making contact with celestial bodies outside of the solar system, and last of all the introduction of a drug you could take that would change every strand of your DNA. The age at which you took it would be the age you appeared to be for the rest of your life. She had a passion for spreading her gift around so others would n't experience the burdens and pains of aging. But the side effects of the drug did n't manifest for years, sometimes decades. Slowly humanity had changed in an unintended way. Random genes were shut off at inappropriate times. Some people lost their ability to experience emotions. Some people lost control of their muscles. No one that took the drug was free of consequences. Only the truly immortal, those born with the mutation, wished to live their lives for all of time. The population of true immortals was still growing and the population of the population of mortals and mortal turned immortals remained about the same. Groups of mortals rose up trying to keep their way of life going, but many wished for them to give up so humanity could be purified of death. Was it cruel to bring a mortal to life in the world of immortals? Immortals ruled the world and they certainly thought so. After the discovery that the drug had severe negative side effects the immortals wished to ban it as well, and so they did. It was illegal to produce it, sell it, possess it, and above all, illegal to have a child after having taken the drug. Esther had left her lab years early. She had given up on finding why they could n't fix the drug or reverse its effects. She moved out to the country, wishing she had never discovered it. The country was an expensive place to live due to the enormous population size humanity had reached, but she had more money than she would ever need. She walked towards a giant tree in the middle of the field. It was one that had been planted when she was young, it gave her comfort to be with something as old as she was. She thought of humanity and what she hoped to see in the next few centuries of her life. She looked down to her right and left. A small headstone stuck up out of the grass on either side. She placed her hands on both of the stones for a moment before closing her eyes to take a nap. "Goodnight Mum, goodnight Dad," she whispered.

She walked towards a giant tree in the middle of the field. It was one that had been planted when she was young, it gave her comfort to be with something as old as she was. She thought of humanity and what she hoped to see in the next few centuries of her life. She looked down to her right and left. A small headstone stuck up out of the grass on either side. She placed her hands on both of the stones for a moment before closing her eyes to take a nap. "Goodnight Mum, goodnight Dad," she whispered.


Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Henry is wounded in the leg by Austrian bombardment.
output: He is sent to a hospital where he meets Catherine Barkley, an English nurse who tends to him. Henry falls in love with Catherine and begins a sexual relationship with her. When Henry returns to the front, he finds morale severely depleted. Defeatism grows among the soldiers, and talk of Germany prevails. For example, Bonello, the barkeeper from Chapter 1, talks openly about how he has made a separate peace with the Germans and will surrender. Meanwhile, fear spreads among Italian forces about a surprise attack. Finally, the Austrians do attack and the Italians retreat. However, not everyone gets the message, including Henry. As a result, he blows up a bridge too late and an entire column of soldiers are killed before his eyes. Henry makes his way to safety, barely surviving the retreat in which he kills a sergeant for insubordination. Upon reaching base, Henry is accused of being a German spy. He escapes by jumping into a river. He reunites with Catherine and they flee to Switzerland. In the mountains, Henry and Catherine live a quiet life, safe from the war. As winter turns to spring, Catherine becomes pregnant. Yet their happiness is threatened when the authorities order Henry's arrest. Henry helps Catherine escape to Lausanne while he himself goes into hiding. Catherine gives birth, but the child dies almost immediately. Catherine herself dies shortly thereafter from hemorrhaging. Henry leaves the hospital alone.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
"We were not the first. There is a russian flag on mars." The silence in the Mission control center was crushing. Everyone just stared at the big screen. Waiting for something to break the tension. But nothing did. They had planned for thousands of errors, difficulties, unlikelyhoods, but not for this. What does this mean? How could this have happened? Everyone in the room had the same thoughts. Noone had the answers. Suddenly, a crackling noise signaled that the speaker system was turned on: "Uhm... s-so I think you should see this, it is broadcasting on all channels, nationwide..." The message on the big screen disappeared. Instead, a black screen, on which, in red lettering, the following words appeared: "To the people of the United States of America" A few seconds passed, noone even dared to blink. Then a familiar face appeared on the screen. Vladimir Putin, his piercing blue eyes seemed to see straight into the soul of everyone watching. "America. Your time of perceived dominance is over. As a select few at your NASA headquarters learned a few minutes ago, your astronauts were not the first to set foot on the planet mars. Russian cosmonauts did so in 1998, 20 years ago, without your knowledge. The reason you learn of this now, is that the time has come for your pathetic country to cease existing as a sovereign nation and become a vassal to the glorious russian federation. We want to avoid unnecessary bloodshed, so let me make it clear, that resistance, of any kind, is futile. 20 years ago we had the technology to send our cosmonauts to mars and return them unharmed, without your intelligence agencies noticing. Our technology was and still is so superior to yours, that it was as easy as hiding a toy from a child. But that is not all. Our own intelligence agencies were able to infiltrate almost every area of your military, your scientific community and your government. We even managed to infiltrate your highest office. Your current President, Donald Trump has been working for our country since I personally promised him the Oval Office five years ago. Once he saw the extend of our knowledge and power, he recognized that in an open conflict, our nation would have obliterated your country. As you can see, resistance is truly futile. The war is over. You lost. There will be no mercy to anyone who dares oppose us. Now, in case there is any doubt to my words, I present to you, your president." The camera panned to the right and focused on another familiar face, it's orange tone a stark contrast to the former. "Well, thank you Mr. President..."

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
The second alarm goes off at 7 in the morning. The first, a few hours before, sharply shrilled that it was time to get up and shower. Hungover and covered with the sweat and scents of the night before, I had dragged myself through the morning routine of cleansing. There was plenty of time beneath the lukewarm stream of water to contemplate the sadness of another hangover caused by drinking alone. It'd been weeks since I last had a chance to talk to another human, instead of just the PC terminal supplied by work. I towelled off and staggered through to the living-room and slumped in front of the computer, waiting for the piercing whistle to repeat, to emanate from my phone. The second alarm marked that it was time for the Remembrance. I sigh, move the empty beer bottles away from my desk and load up Hitchens 2. Since the Bliss neurovirus was released, there was a killing to be made from this sort of software; software designed to take you through a basic test, activating every faculty you'd conceivably need to prevent the atrophy. First, colour recognition and geometric shapes. Second, basic maths ramping into some gentle algebra and trigonometry. English, ethics, road safety, compassion testing, aesthetics, philosophical contemplation, the sciences. It was a hard sell at the beginning, for companies to give their employees the few hours off each morning they needed for the state-mandated testing, but given the choice between late employees and those in conscious comas, they made the right choice. Two hours later, the general test finishes. I flick through my results, 91 % recognition of the basic concepts, not too bad after a night of hard drinking. Next would come a quick half hour personal session: the names of loved ones, relations to family members, anniversaries and birthdays. A prompt flashes on the screen: "Please enter your identity number and full name". I rattle my digits in, 12958321-A, and tab down to the field for my name. I blank. Slight panic begins to grow as I search my beer-soaked consciousness for that basic, bloody basic, detail. It'd been too long since I last had to introduce myself with anything other than my work ID number, too long since I had any reason to say those damned words out loud. Darren? No. Christopher? No, definitely not. I shout and swear and blaspheme out loud, as I slowly feel the neurovirus go to work; Purgatory, we call it, a limbo without knowledge, tied with a purging. It dissolves me gently. The panic subsides. I stare blankly at the flashing cursor, waiting for me to enter some detail or another. I'm not sure what it's asking for, but I'm sure it's not too important or I'd remember it. I sit there, staring. Just staring. I'm sure it'd come back to me eventually.

Japan attacks Pearl Harbor, causing panic among the Wakatsuki family.
output: They are Japanese Americans who live in California. Papa is arrested because he is considered a threat to national security. He is sent to Fort Lincoln, North Dakota. Mama and her children are forced to leave their home and move to Terminal Island. They have to stay in a horse stall until they can find a place to live. They finally settle in a small house near the ocean. One day, Papa comes home from work and tells them that they have to evacuate again. This time, they are going to Manzanar, a concentration camp in the desert. They pack all their belongings and board a train. When they arrive at Manzanar, they see rows of barracks surrounded by barbed wire fences. They are assigned to Block 16, Barrack 12, Apartment C. They share one room with two other families. There is no privacy or comfort. The food is terrible and the toilets are filthy. The weather is hot during the day and cold at night. The dust blows everywhere and makes everyone sick. Jeanne feels lonely and scared. She misses her friends and her old life. She wonders if she will ever see Papa again. One day, she meets a boy named Woody who lives in the next barrack. He shows her around the camp and introduces her to his friends. They play games together and tell stories. Jeanne starts to feel better. She realizes that she is not alone anymore. She has found new friends and a new home. She decides to make the best of her situation and enjoy her time at Manzanar. She learns how to cook, sew, dance, sing, draw, write, read, speak Japanese, and more. She also discovers her talent for writing poetry. She writes poems about her experiences at Manzanar and sends them to magazines and newspapers. Some of them get published and win awards. Her poems help her cope with her feelings and express herself creatively. She becomes known as the "Poet Laureate" of Manzanar. After three years, World War II ends and the camps close down. The Wakatsukis return to Long Beach where they try to rebuild their lives. However, things are not easy for them. People still hate and fear them because they look like the enemy. They face discrimination and prejudice wherever they go. Jeanne struggles to fit in at school and make friends. She feels different from everyone else. But she does not give up hope. She continues to write poetry and pursue her dreams. She graduates from high school and college with honors. She marries a man named Bill who loves her for who she is. Together they raise four children and live happily ever after. Farewell to Manzanar is a true story based on Jeanne Wakatsuki Houston's memoirs. It is a powerful tale of courage, resilience, and survival. It shows us how one young girl overcame adversity and found strength within herself. It teaches us valuable lessons about tolerance, acceptance, and diversity. It inspires us to never lose faith in ourselves or our abilities. Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Vladimir had always been a doting brother. Perhaps he felt indebted to me since I would have been the master of the house and heir to the family fortunes should things have gone differently. Alas, I had been very young when the harsh disease of Rot Lung had ravaged my body. The disease that could kill full grown men had me lying in bed for months, coughing up blood and yellow phlegm. When the disease finally left my body it left it weak, my lungs wheezed with every breathe and my muscles were left thin and atrophied. If I was from a less affluent family I may have been left to die. Luckily for me, my family was not about to let their firstborn son die. They would also not allow me to show the family as weak, so I was locked away. My brother tells me that he fought for years to keep me as the heir to the family. He said that he argued until he was blue in the face that the Dracul blood was strong and that I would eventually recover. "Just give him time", he said, I would be able to take over the duties of master of the house given time. Sometimes I would show improvement, my family rejoiced and my dear brother returned from his travels abroad to help nurse me back to health once again. Unhappily my health never stayed long after the celebrations began. It was as if the mere presence of such joyful happiness poisoned my body. I would began to vomit and become bedridden again for cause of muscle spasms. Through this all my brother would nurse me, spoon feeding me his exotic medicines that he had collected on his travels late into the the night. Always hoping that one of them would finally cure me. Eventually my father had his way, my brother was to be the new head of the family. All of the Dracul land, titles, and riches were to go to him. My loving brother said that he begged father to wait just a little longer, to leave me some small smidgen of inheritance, but it was to no avail. My father died soon after naming my brother heir, before I was ever able to reconcile myself with him. With my father's death, Vladimir moved back home and began his duties as the head of house Dracul fully. Today I awoke feeling better than I had in a very long time. Perhaps I would leave my room and surprise Vlad with how my health, would n't he be so happy? I had not been into the upper chambers since my father had been alive and I had been being groomed for eventual lordship of our house but I still remembered the way, I still remembered the correct way to unlock the siege door. A door intended to seal away an entire wing of the castle. Should the worst happen and the castle be invaded the siege door had the ability to lock and steal away the lord of the house, preserving our family's history and the life of anyone behind it long enough for help to arrive. The torches along the walls were not lit and it did n't seem as if they had been for a long time. Regardless, I could still peer through the darkness and what I saw... What I saw terrified me.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Jeanne's father, Ko, is arrested by the FBI.
output: Jeanne is taken to live with her aunt, who lives in a trailer park. She has a hard time adjusting to her new surroundings. Her aunt is a drug addict and her uncle is abusive. Jeanne tries to run away several times, but she is always caught and brought back. One day, she meets a boy named Michael. He is kind and understanding. He helps her escape from her aunt and uncle. They travel together, living off the land. They are eventually found by the police. Jeanne is sent to a juvenile detention center. She spends two years there. When she is released, she goes to live with her mother. Her mother is now married to a man named John. John is a good man. He treats Jeanne well. Jeanne starts high school. She makes friends and does well in her classes. She even joins the track team. One day, while running laps around the track, she sees a familiar face. It is Michael. He has been looking for her. He wants to know why she ran away. Jeanne tells him everything. She tells him about her father and her aunt and uncle. She tells him about the juvenile detention center. Michael listens carefully. He understands. He tells her that he loves her. Jeanne is surprised. She did n't think that anyone could love her. But Michael does. And she loves him too. They start dating. They spend all their free time together. They talk about their dreams and their hopes for the future. One day, Jeanne gets a call from her mother. Her father has been released from prison. He wants to see her. Jeanne is scared. She does n't want to see her father. But she knows that she has to. She goes to meet him. He looks different. He is thinner and his hair is gray. But he is still her father. He apologizes for everything that happened. He says that he is sorry for leaving her. He says that he loves her. Jeanne forgives him. She hugs him tightly. They cry together. Then they say goodbye. Jeanne returns to her life with Michael. They get married and have children. They live happily ever after.

But nothing did. They had planned for thousands of errors, difficulties, unlikelyhoods, but not for this. What does this mean? How could this have happened? Everyone in the room had the same thoughts. Noone had the answers. Suddenly, a crackling noise signaled that the speaker system was turned on: "Uhm... s-so I think you should see this, it is broadcasting on all channels, nationwide..." The message on the big screen disappeared. Instead, a black screen, on which, in red lettering, the following words appeared: "To the people of the United States of America" A few seconds passed, noone even dared to blink. Then a familiar face appeared on the screen. Vladimir Putin, his piercing blue eyes seemed to see straight into the soul of everyone watching. "America. Your time of perceived dominance is over. As a select few at your NASA headquarters learned a few minutes ago, your astronauts were not the first to set foot on the planet mars. Russian cosmonauts did so in 1998, 20 years ago, without your knowledge. The reason you learn of this now, is that the time has come for your pathetic country to cease existing as a sovereign nation and become a vassal to the glorious russian federation. We want to avoid unnecessary bloodshed, so let me make it clear, that resistance, of any kind, is futile. 20 years ago we had the technology to send our cosmonauts to mars and return them unharmed, without your intelligence agencies noticing. Our technology was and still is so superior to yours, that it was as easy as hiding a toy from a child. But that is not all. Our own intelligence agencies were able to infiltrate almost every area of your military, your scientific community and your government. We even managed to infiltrate your highest office. Your current President, Donald Trump has been working for our country since I personally promised him the Oval Office five years ago. Once he saw the extend of our knowledge and power, he recognized that in an open conflict, our nation would have obliterated your country. As you can see, resistance is truly futile. The war is over. You lost. There will be no mercy to anyone who dares oppose us. Now, in case there is any doubt to my words, I present to you, your president." The camera panned to the right and focused on another familiar face, it's orange tone a stark contrast to the former. "Well, thank you Mr. President..."

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
President Roosevelt issues Executive Order 9066.
output: This order allows the Secretary of War to designate certain areas as military zones. Within these zones, the Secretary may exclude any person deemed a threat to national security. In practice, this means that Japanese Americans are forced to leave their homes and businesses and move to internment camps. These camps are located in remote areas of the western United States. The conditions in these camps are harsh. Families are separated. Children are taken away from their parents. People are forced to live in cramped quarters with little privacy. Food is scarce. Medical care is inadequate. Many people die from disease or starvation. Despite these hardships, the Japanese American community remains strong. They continue to work hard and contribute to society. They also fight for their rights. In 1944, the Supreme Court rules that the internment of Japanese Americans is unconstitutional. However, the ruling comes too late for many families. By then, most of the internees have already been released. Some have returned to their homes. Others have moved to other parts of the country. Still others have emigrated to Japan. The legacy of the internment lives on today. It serves as a reminder of the dangers of racism and xenophobia. It also shows how resilient the human spirit can be in the face of adversity.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
"This is Rockin' Rob Bower coming to you live from the huge antennae, This next song is going out to all the lovers. God damn it, is anyone out there, I need help. I am out of stuff, the vending machine is empty and the my sink filled with water, its all gone. If anyone can hear me I am at the antennae thing in the middle of the desert. God damn it help me! Rocking Rob was lucky, sort of. He was out in the desert doing peyote when the first bomb was dropped on what he could assume was Los Angeles and then some more dropped just South, possibly in San Diego and he eventually figured the glow to the East was Las Vegas. Its an odd sensation to watch the deaths millions of people thinking that it was the most beautiful thing he has ever seen. It was quite spectacular, would up vote, but now Rob may be the last person on Earth. But that's not going to last long, he is trapped hundred of miles from nowhere with no food and no water and nuclear rage fire happening all around him. Too start with Rob was n't a skinny dude. The amount of mass he dropped though in such a short amount of time was staggering. The contents of the vending machine did not last a week. It seemed the processed food just made him hungrier. When it was gone he emptied the fridge in the small kitchenette in the shack attached to the antennae. The shack had a dozen cubicles shoved into it, one sound booth and three offices all marked with some degree of management. He found and ate condiment packets. Not one thing that once had food in it was safe from being licked clean. Out of desperation he has tried to set traps for bugs and rodents. The flesh was willing but he was a complete moron when it came to woodsy stuff. At first he thought being in a radio antennae would be cool, until he discovered there was no music to be had. It was a weather station broadcasting regional updates. In a desert! That had to be the most boring job. Probably almost as boring as sitting out here waiting to die. Rocking Rob lowers his head. Its been two weeks since had any food. he has been thinking about cutting flesh from his leg and maybe getting a couple more days off the calories. He wont do it though he will hold out hope. The air outside is filled with black snow. He was afraid to walk through the dark desert looking for rescue, but now it's too late. His hand trembles under the effort to squeeze the talk button on the microphone. He whispers, "please," before the strength to leaves his body. In terms of struggle Rob did not put up much of one and maybe the world is better off for it.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
The Wakatsuki family is sent to Manzanar internment camp.
output: They are forced to leave their home and possessions behind. They are given a small room to share with other families. The conditions are poor and the food is scarce. Jeanne struggles to adjust to her new life. She misses her friends and her old school. She feels like she doesn't belong anywhere. One day, Jeanne meets a boy named Woody. He is also Japanese American. They become friends and spend a lot of time together. Woody helps Jeanne feel less alone. He tells her stories about his own experiences in the camp. He also teaches her how to play baseball. Jeanne starts to enjoy her time in the camp. She makes new friends and learns new things. She even starts to think of the camp as her home. However, Jeanne still misses her old life. She wonders if she will ever be able to go back to it. One day, Jeanne receives news that her father has died. She is devastated. She feels like she has lost everything. She decides to run away from the camp. She wants to find her mother and sister. She knows they must be somewhere else. Jeanne sets out on foot. She walks for days without stopping. She sleeps in fields and eats whatever she can find. Finally, she reaches a town. She asks around for information about her family. No one seems to know anything. Jeanne is heartbroken. She sits down on a bench and cries. A woman approaches her. She introduces herself as Mrs. Yamamoto. She says she used to work at the camp. She offers to take Jeanne to see her mother and sister. Jeanne agrees. They travel by train to another part of California. When they arrive, Jeanne sees her mother and sister. They hug each other tightly. Jeanne realizes that she has finally found her place in the world. She belongs with her family. She vows never to forget them again.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Naif turned the page. Another day of studying droned on. It wasn' t that the material was a challenge, Naif had no problem absorbing every concept she came across and she had more degrees than anyone her age to prove it. Life had always been that way. In primary school she related better to adults than her classmates. In secondary school she was respectful of her teachers but felt she understood the lessons they taught to a deeper level than even they appreciated. University had been much the same except the distance between herself and her professors had turned her conscientious respect into a degree of begrudging disdain. She was certainly more intelligent than anyone she knew of, more so than anyone she had ever met. She picked apart the documents piled high on her desk recalling even the articles in the citations that she had previously read. Today her eyes were heavy, mostly with boredom, somewhat with the strain. Her mind was as sharp as it had ever been but her body showed the signs that she would not be considered a young woman for much longer. Through the closed windows she could vaguely hear the muffled hum of the world rushing by outside. Suddenly the monotony of the day fell away as it was unbound by a sharp thud against the outer wall of her office. Naif quickly straightened her hunched shoulders and bumped the table sloshing coffee over her meticulously curated stacks of research papers. She snarled impatiently at the mess and sprang to the window. She squinted through the blinds at the sunlit scene then furrowed them even further in annoyance. The neighbours were playing baseball with their kids again. Idiots. Hadn' t they any respect for others? One of the little morons ran up to the edge of Naif's apartment, beneath her field of view, and tried to throw the ball back. It careened off course and the cretin had to go pick it up again to return it to his waiting family. Naif rolled her eyes as she turned away from the display of incompetence and inefficiency that played out beyond her walls. As she sopped up the spilled coffee from her desk she mumbled to herself, as she had before, "I wish everyone were more intelligent. I would have so much more to share with them, so much more in common. They run around all day never thinking of their actions, of their futures. Such wasted potential in all that frivolity." Though as she settled back into her comfortably worn chair she couldn' t help feeling that there was something more to it that she just didn' t quite understand.

The family struggles with life in Block 16 of the camp.
output: The father is a doctor who has been working long hours in the hospital. He comes home exhausted each night and falls asleep immediately after dinner. The mother works in the kitchen preparing meals for the other families in the block. She is tired too, but she tries to keep up appearances for her children. The two boys are twins, aged seven years old. They play together all day long, running around the camp and getting into trouble. Their sister is four years old and spends most of her time playing with dolls. She likes to dress them up in pretty clothes and pretend they are going to parties. One evening, when the parents are both at work, the twins decide to explore the camp. They sneak out of their house and wander down the street. They see some soldiers standing guard near one of the buildings. Curiosity gets the best of them and they approach the men. "What do you want?" asks one of the guards. "We're looking for our dad," says the older twin. "He went to get us food." "Your dad isn't here," replies the soldier. "Go back inside." But the twins refuse to leave. Instead, they start asking questions about what happens next. "Are we going to die?" wonders the younger twin. "No!" exclaims the elder twin. "Our mom told us not to worry because God loves us." "But how can he love us if we don't know him?" argues the younger twin. "That doesn't make sense." "It does make sense," insists the elder twin. "God created everything, including us. And since he made us, he must love us." "Then why did he let this happen?" demands the younger twin. "Why did he allow these people to take over our country?" "Because he wants us to learn something important," explains the elder twin. "Something about ourselves." "Like what?" presses the younger twin. "Like how strong we really are," answers the elder twin. "And how brave we can be." "Brave enough to face death?" challenges the younger twin. "Yes," affirms the elder twin. "Even though we might lose our lives, we won't give up hope. We'll fight until the very end." "I'm scared," admits the younger twin. "Me too," confesses the elder twin. "But remember, God is watching over us. He knows exactly where we are right now. So don't be afraid. Just trust him." With those words, the twins turn around and head back toward their home. As they walk along the dusty road, they notice several other children following behind them. Some look frightened while others seem determined. All of them appear ready to follow wherever the twins lead. When they reach their front door, the twins open it slowly. Inside, they find their mother sitting at the kitchen table crying softly. Next to her sits their father, holding his head in his hands. Both parents stare at the floor, unable to meet each other's gaze. "Mommy! Daddy!" shouts the younger twin. "Where were you guys?" "We got lost," lies the elder twin. "Lost?" repeats the mother. "How could you possibly get lost in such a small place like this?" "Well..." begins the elder twin. "Actually, we weren't lost. We found ourselves." "Found yourselves?" echoes the father. "Yeah," continues the elder twin. "While we were walking around, we realized something. Something big." "What was it?" urges the mother. "That we aren't alone anymore," declares the elder twin. "There are lots of kids just like us living here. Kids who need someone to show them the way." "Show them the way?" queries the father. "To freedom," states the elder twin firmly. "Freedom from fear. Freedom from pain. Freedom from sadness." "But how can we do that?" pleads the mother. "By showing them that they matter," responds the elder twin. "That they count. That they deserve better than what they've gotten so far." "Better than being treated like animals?" scoffs the father. "Better than having their homes destroyed?" "Better than seeing their friends killed?" adds the mother. "Yes," confirms the elder twin. "Better than all of that." "So what do we do first?" inquires the mother. "First thing tomorrow morning," announces the elder twin, "we gather together all the kids in Block 16. Then we march straight to the gates of the camp." "March?" gasps the mother. "Straight to the gates?" "Yep," nods the elder twin. "Once we arrive, we demand to speak to whoever is in charge. We tell them that unless they release us immediately, we'll stage a hunger strike." "A hunger strike?" exclaims the mother. "Won't that hurt us?" Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
I'm not like you, I see differently. When I look at someone, I see into their future but I only get to see the worst part. Particularly their deaths, I see them in gruesome detail. I've seen car crashes, murders, stabbings and once, I even saw someone who would later die in a plane crash. I was n't always cursed this way, it all started after I was in a nearly fatal car crash, I woke up from a short coma and I could see the deaths of everyone around me. The doctors simply chalked it down to ptsd and gave me meds but I knew it was more that mere ptsd. I knew what I was seeing was n't just imagination. I even found a few people who were to die in a few days time and followed them up to see if they did and they did. All this time, I had not seen my own face in the mirror. I mean, I had seen it but half of it was still covered in bandages, still recovering from my injuries. Something I noticed about my death vision was that it only worked if I could see the entire face of the person. I could n't see the deaths of people who had their faces covered. This is why I figured, I could n't see mine yet and I was determined to keep it that way. I did n't wan na know how I died, I mean would you? Would you want to see how you died in gruesome detail? Of course not! After the bandages came off, I was very careful not to look at my complete reflection. Anytime I wanted to set my hair, I would tie a kerchief around my face. When I brushed my teeth, I wore a bandana, Shades and a scarf for good measure. The temptation to just look at my face in its entirety was hard to overcome but I did. I was traumatised enough by the deaths of others as it is. Shortly after the accident, I moved out of town into a sleepy little village and lived on my own. The fewer the people, the better for me. I lived in a tiny cottage with no reflective surfaces save for the tiny mirror in my bathroom that I kept covered by a cloth most of the time. This morning, I was brushing my teeth as usual and just as I was finishing, my bandana came lose and dropped into the sink. In my desperation to catch it, I undid the scarf and lo! I was staring at my naked face in the mirror. The world went black and I saw myself standing in complete darkness. Suddenly, a look of consternation came over me and I covered behind something. Shortly after a dark figure entered the place and after a short struggle, stabbed me. As I came out of my nightmarish reverie, gasping for breath after seeing myself die. I heard a loud crash in the house, suddenly the power went out. A look of consternation came over my face as I covered behind the bathroom door.

I was staring at my naked face in the mirror. The world went black and I saw myself standing in complete darkness. Suddenly, a look of consternation came over me and I covered behind something. Shortly after a dark figure entered the place and after a short struggle, stabbed me. As I came out of my nightmarish reverie, gasping for breath after seeing myself die. I heard a loud crash in the house, suddenly the power went out. A look of consternation came over my face as I covered behind the bathroom door.

Charlie's life changes dramatically when he meets Alice Kinnian, a woman who has also undergone the same procedure. They fall in love and marry. One day, while walking through Central Park, Charlie sees a young boy playing baseball. The child reminds him of himself when he was younger. Charlie approaches the boy and asks him whether he wants to play ball. The boy agrees and they start throwing balls together. Soon, Charlie realizes that he enjoys spending time with children again. He begins volunteering at local schools and helping out wherever he can. Eventually, Charlie finds happiness once more. He learns to appreciate life and enjoy being alive. He even starts dating again. But then tragedy strikes. Charlie receives news that his father passed away. Charlie returns to New York City to attend his funeral. While there, he runs into Alice. She tells him that she regrets leaving him and begs him to forgive her. Charlie refuses to listen to her pleas. Instead, he walks away from her forever. Later, Charlie visits his old neighborhood where he grew up. There, he meets a group of kids who invite him to join them in a game of basketball. Charlie accepts their invitation and plays alongside them. During the game, one of the boys accidentally hits Charlie in the head with a rock. Charlie falls unconscious and wakes up several hours later in a hospital bed. Doctors inform him that he suffered severe brain damage due to the impact of the stone. Charlie spends months recovering from his injuries. Once he recovers, he moves back to New Jersey to live near his family. Over time, Charlie regains some of his memories. He remembers everything except for the events leading up to his injury. Charlie tries to piece together what happened during those missing years. He eventually comes across a newspaper article describing the incident involving the rock. According to the report, the police arrested two teenagers responsible for throwing rocks at cars passing by. Both teens were charged with assault and battery. Charlie reads the names of the suspects listed in the article. One name stands out above all others: Roberta Kinnian. Charlie recognizes the last name immediately. It belongs to none other than his ex-wife, Alice. Charlie confronts Alice about her involvement in the attack. Alice admits to participating in the crime but claims that she did not intend to harm anyone. She explains that she threw the rock because she thought it might distract the driver long enough for her to escape. Charlie does not believe her story. He accuses her of lying and threatens to expose her secret unless she confesses to her crimes. Alice breaks down crying and reveals that she killed her husband. She says that she shot him multiple times before fleeing the scene. Charlie demands proof of her guilt. Alice produces a gun hidden inside her purse. She points the weapon at Charlie and orders him to hand over his wallet. Charlie complies without hesitation. Alice takes the money and leaves. Charlie calls the authorities and reports the murder. Police arrive shortly thereafter and arrest Alice. Charlie testifies against her at trial. At sentencing, the judge sentences Alice to life imprisonment without parole. Charlie watches as Alice is led away in handcuffs. He knows that he will never see her again. Charlie returns to his apartment building and packs his belongings. He plans to relocate to California where he hopes to find peace and quiet. Before departing, however, he stops by the cemetery where his parents are buried. Charlie kneels beside their graves and prays for forgiveness. Then he gets into his car and drives off into the sunset.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Naif turned the page. Another day of studying droned on. It wasn' t that the material was a challenge, Naif had no problem absorbing every concept she came across and she had more degrees than anyone her age to prove it. Life had always been that way. In primary school she related better to adults than her classmates. In secondary school she was respectful of her teachers but felt she understood the lessons they taught to a deeper level than even they appreciated. University had been much the same except the distance between herself and her professors had turned her conscientious respect into a degree of begrudging disdain. She was certainly more intelligent than anyone she knew of, more so than anyone she had ever met. She picked apart the documents piled high on her desk recalling even the articles in the citations that she had previously read. Today her eyes were heavy, mostly with boredom, somewhat with the strain. Her mind was as sharp as it had ever been but her body showed the signs that she would not be considered a young woman for much longer. Through the closed windows she could vaguely hear the muffled hum of the world rushing by outside. Suddenly the monotony of the day fell away as it was unbound by a sharp thud against the outer wall of her office. Naif quickly straightened her hunched shoulders and bumped the table sloshing coffee over her meticulously curated stacks of research papers. She snarled impatiently at the mess and sprang to the window. She squinted through the blinds at the sunlit scene then furrowed them even further in annoyance. The neighbours were playing baseball with their kids again. Idiots. Hadn' t they any respect for others? One of the little morons ran up to the edge of Naif's apartment, beneath her field of view, and tried to throw the ball back. It careened off course and the cretin had to go pick it up again to return it to his waiting family. Naif rolled her eyes as she turned away from the display of incompetence and inefficiency that played out beyond her walls. As she sopped up the spilled coffee from her desk she mumbled to herself, as she had before, "I wish everyone were more intelligent. I would have so much more to share with them, so much more in common. They run around all day never thinking of their actions, of their futures. Such wasted potential in all that frivolity." Though as she settled back into her comfortably worn chair she couldn' t help feeling that there was something more to it that she just didn' t quite understand.

"We were not the first. There is a russian flag on mars." The silence in the Mission control center was crushing. Everyone just stared at the big screen. Waiting for something to break the tension. But nothing did. They had planned for thousands of errors, difficulties, unlikelyhoods, but not for this. What does this mean? How could this have happened? Everyone in the room had the same thoughts. Noone had the answers. Suddenly, a crackling noise signaled that the speaker system was turned on: "Uhm... s-so I think you should see this, it is broadcasting on all channels, nationwide..." The message on the big screen disappeared. Instead, a black screen, on which, in red lettering, the following words appeared: "To the people of the United States of America" A few seconds passed, noone even dared to blink. Then a familiar face appeared on the screen. Vladimir Putin, his piercing blue eyes seemed to see straight into the soul of everyone watching. "America. Your time of perceived dominance is over. As a select few at your NASA headquarters learned a few minutes ago, your astronauts were not the first to set foot on the planet mars. Russian cosmonauts did so in 1998, 20 years ago, without your knowledge. The reason you learn of this now, is that the time has come for your pathetic country to cease existing as a sovereign nation and become a vassal to the glorious russian federation. We want to avoid unnecessary bloodshed, so let me make it clear, that resistance, of any kind, is futile. 20 years ago we had the technology to send our cosmonauts to mars and return them unharmed, without your intelligence agencies noticing. Our technology was and still is so superior to yours, that it was as easy as hiding a toy from a child. But that is not all. Our own intelligence agencies were able to infiltrate almost every area of your military, your scientific community and your government. We even managed to infiltrate your highest office. Your current President, Donald Trump has been working for our country since I personally promised him the Oval Office five years ago. Once he saw the extend of our knowledge and power, he recognized that in an open conflict, our nation would have obliterated your country. As you can see, resistance is truly futile. The war is over. You lost. There will be no mercy to anyone who dares oppose us. Now, in case there is any doubt to my words, I present to you, your president." The camera panned to the right and focused on another familiar face, it's orange tone a stark contrast to the former. "Well, thank you Mr. President..."

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
"Ah man, it smells like death in here." That is the phrase that I have lived to regret ever since they fell foolishly from my mouth. I was essentially immortal before that moment in time. I was the best comedian in the world, and apparently better than anyone in the afterlife as well. It was the only reason the Grim Reaper decided not to take me. I could make him laugh, and in his line of work that was a rarity. I do n't even remember what it was that I had said when he showed up at my car accident. I can recall him bending down next to my overturned Honda civic and reaching in to pull me out. I made some off the wall comment and he froze, dead in his tracks. It was the weirdest laugh I had ever heard, but one I appreciated more than all of the others combined. He let me live, provided that every year on the anniversary of what should have been my death, I would tell him a joke that would make him cry with laughter. I was his own personal jester, and for that he rewarded me handsomely. And then on that fateful day, 121 years later, I muttered those stupid words that seized our contract and ripped it in two. Who knew Death would be so self conscious about his smell? And to make things worse, that was n't even the joke that I was going to tell him! The actual joke was a masterpiece, but he would n't give me the chance to tell it. I ran out of that room faster than I'd ever run before. And I've been running ever since. I think the reason that he has n't taken me yet is because of our long history together. That is n't to say that he's forgiven me. He seems to enjoy reminding me that he's near. Everyone I get close to dies without reason. I'll see a dog in the park that I think looks adorable and before I can pet it, it'll fall over dead. Roses crumble before I can enjoy their scent and food rots on my fork before I can bring it to my mouth. He's killing everything around me. I have discovered that Death is a jester of a different sort. I had provided him with a form of humor that he was n't used to, but he has since grown tired of it, and reverted to his old ways. Now, he once again deals in jokes of cruelty and irony. In a way, I am still fulfilling my part of our old deal. The Reaper still laughs, and he still laughs at me. Only now, the difference is I'm not laughing.

Had I really loved her? I thought I did. But if she was n't here... 30 years. Marrying young has its perks but I would be lying if I said the journey was n't bumpy. We had our ups and downs, just like any couple. I did things I should n't have, and said things I did n't mean. But deep down, I always knew I loved her. Or was I just lying to myself? Yet the face I was staring at was n't hers. These jet black eyes were unfamiliar and hostile. I longed for her warm, loving hazel eyes, the ones I had lived and laughed with. Over time we got to know each other better. Clarice was her name. She had been a dentist. She was undeniably beautiful, but it was an effortless, flawless beauty. Yet I longed for Alicia. I had grown accustomed to her shortfalls, and had found beauty in them. Even more time passed. Slowly the memories were replaced. I made new ones with Clarice. It was like I never knew what I had been missing out on until I had the opportunity to taste it. We simply clicked on a deeper level. She was the type of girl you can have deep co conversations about universe and life with under the stars, yet get into a tickle fight with two minutes later. For the longest time I felt guilty. However good Alicia had been, Clarice seemed to be better in every aspect. Eventually the guilt faded. All there was left was bliss. And then it all went South. The first time we argued I was stunned. We had never argued before, ever. It was a pretty issue, but an argument nonetheless. Soon enough they became more frequent. More frequent and more intense. Life turned from peace to chaos, happiness to misery. The constant stress, fighting, distrust and resentment slowly began to manifest into only one thing. Hatred. Love had turned into hatred. I had never mentioned Alicia to Clarice. I had always assumed she was like me, that she had left someone behind to be with me. Then one fine day it all made sense. Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Grandfather was the only one without powers in the family, and he was one of the few who have lived in the Before and survived. Before genes started mutating, before people received powers, before the world as he knew it ended. Things are different in the Today. We learnt it all during history in school. Mr T. brought us back to the Before and we had watched the wars, the starvation, the shootings, the massacres. Every child Today knows the story, because as some wise man in the Before had said, those who can not learn from history, are doomed to repeat it. And we don' t want that. We are lucky that the wars have ended as quickly as they begun. The Normals, like my grandfather, who were trying to kill those with powers were quickly put down by us. When my second cousin Sophia received her ability to bend the wills of others, grandfather had been most displeased. After all, it was one of the powers most feared back in the Before. Those with this ability were the ones who dominated and the wars had come. Countries fighting for dominance, millionaires waking up to find that they have signed away their fortune, men and women everywhere woke up to find that they have been doing things that they never would. It was then when the true Wars begun. Things are better Today though, people like Sophia are being kept safe. I haven' t seen her since she registered her powers two hours after she turned sixteen. Joshua, my older brother, had the ability to turn into a guinea pig. Grandfather was highly amused. It seemed though, that abilities are not hereditary. Father is a genius with technology while mother can heal with just a touch. I turn sixteen in a little less than two hours and I can' t wait to find out what my power is. It was the Law to register your abilities no more than two hours after you receive it. If you don' t, well, if you don' t, you might cease to exist. That was what we have been taught since those carefree days in preschool. They will hunt you down no matter how you try to hide. Uncle Kevin tried to hide Cousin Kingsley when they realized he could make people disappear. Well, they made Cousin Kingsley disappear. I just came into my powers. Mother just made the most horrible sound, a hoarse, gutteral scream when I brushed by her in the cramped kitchen. She is still writhing on the ground, albeit silent. It seems, that I can cause pain to whomever I touch. I think They might try to make me disappear too. Oh dear. She isn' t moving anymore.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Standing on top of our world, we watch as the sun rises over the island. The soft rays bathe the distant hills in gold, as the breeze blows through the dancing grass. The trees shivers as flock of birds take flight. Spots of white clouds the orange-hued sky, as it slowly turns azure. Far in the distance, a silver tower, shrouded in mist, pierces the heavens above. The waves crash down on the sandy beaches, and the endless sea merges with the horizon. I take in the sights, the smells, the sounds. Feeling both pride and joy, I turn to face to you. The air is warm, but your hand is warmer. I hold it close to me, closer still. The sun is shining bright, but your smile is brighter. We' re standing at the top of our world, the one we made together, and I can' t tell you how happy this has made me. "It' s almost time." You say. "I know." I reply. I rest my head on your shoulder, and take a long breath as I close my eyes. I' m at peace here. When I opened them again, I was in my bed, and a bittersweet feeling of both tranquility and sadness lingered in my mind. It was around 7 a.m., and I went about my daily routine, a smile etched on my face. I wrote what had happened in a dream journal I had started two years ago. After having read about lucid dreaming, and I wanted to try it. It took some time, but one day, I was able to control the outcome of my dreams. After a few weeks, something changed. There was something else, maybe someone else, with me. I couldn' t control them, and they couldn' t control me. I searched about it in books and online, but no one reported something similar. I wasn' t afraid, though. Their presence was soothing. We rarely spoke, but when we did, it was always meaningful. Together, we started building a world, our dream island. It brought me joy, and above all, peace. This feeling of inner peace lived on with me during the day. The sun was racing across the sky as we strolled down the ruins of a castle. Holes and cracks had let nature overtake the walls and floors, and the ceiling had long since crumbled. We walked down an old throne room, and you turned to face me. It was so sudden, I nearly bumped into you. You looked resolute, and you said two simple words: "Find me." I jolted awake. I knew what I had to do. I had to find you. So I searched, high and low, for days on end. Perhaps I thought it was fate, perhaps it was simply fool' s luck, but I felt as if I would eventually find you, if I kept trying. One evening, as if beckoned, I went in a coffee shop. I sat down with my coffee at an empty table, and looked up through the window at the red sky. Soon, someone came in, ordered the same thing as I did. They headed toward my table, and sat down in front of me, smiling brightly. Strangely, I felt at peace.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
The second alarm goes off at 7 in the morning. The first, a few hours before, sharply shrilled that it was time to get up and shower. Hungover and covered with the sweat and scents of the night before, I had dragged myself through the morning routine of cleansing. There was plenty of time beneath the lukewarm stream of water to contemplate the sadness of another hangover caused by drinking alone. It'd been weeks since I last had a chance to talk to another human, instead of just the PC terminal supplied by work. I towelled off and staggered through to the living-room and slumped in front of the computer, waiting for the piercing whistle to repeat, to emanate from my phone. The second alarm marked that it was time for the Remembrance. I sigh, move the empty beer bottles away from my desk and load up Hitchens 2. Since the Bliss neurovirus was released, there was a killing to be made from this sort of software; software designed to take you through a basic test, activating every faculty you'd conceivably need to prevent the atrophy. First, colour recognition and geometric shapes. Second, basic maths ramping into some gentle algebra and trigonometry. English, ethics, road safety, compassion testing, aesthetics, philosophical contemplation, the sciences. It was a hard sell at the beginning, for companies to give their employees the few hours off each morning they needed for the state-mandated testing, but given the choice between late employees and those in conscious comas, they made the right choice. Two hours later, the general test finishes. I flick through my results, 91 % recognition of the basic concepts, not too bad after a night of hard drinking. Next would come a quick half hour personal session: the names of loved ones, relations to family members, anniversaries and birthdays. A prompt flashes on the screen: "Please enter your identity number and full name". I rattle my digits in, 12958321-A, and tab down to the field for my name. I blank. Slight panic begins to grow as I search my beer-soaked consciousness for that basic, bloody basic, detail. It'd been too long since I last had to introduce myself with anything other than my work ID number, too long since I had any reason to say those damned words out loud. Darren? No. Christopher? No, definitely not. I shout and swear and blaspheme out loud, as I slowly feel the neurovirus go to work; Purgatory, we call it, a limbo without knowledge, tied with a purging. It dissolves me gently. The panic subsides. I stare blankly at the flashing cursor, waiting for me to enter some detail or another. I'm not sure what it's asking for, but I'm sure it's not too important or I'd remember it. I sit there, staring. Just staring. I'm sure it'd come back to me eventually.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
He becomes involved with Maria, a young Spanish woman.
output: They have a child together, but he is killed in a car accident when she is pregnant. She gives birth to a son, who grows up to become a famous artist. He paints pictures of his father, which are displayed in galleries all over the world. One day, while walking along the beach near his home, he sees a man sitting on a rock looking out to sea. The man has long hair and a beard, and wears a white robe. He looks like Jesus Christ. The boy runs towards him, shouting "Daddy!" But the man does not turn around. Instead, he continues gazing at the horizon. Then suddenly, he turns and smiles at the boy. And then he vanishes into thin air. The boy stands there, confused. What happened? Who was that man? Why did he disappear so quickly? Was he really Jesus Christ? Or maybe just someone else pretending to be Him? Maybe he wasn't even real... Maybe he was just a figment of his imagination. But how could he know for sure? How could anyone ever prove whether something existed or not? That's impossible! Isn't it? Well, perhaps not quite. Because now, many years later, the boy has grown up into a successful painter. His paintings sell for millions of dollars each. People travel from faraway places to see them. Some people believe they can actually hear voices coming from inside the canvases. Others claim to feel a strange presence whenever they look at one of his works. Still others insist that they've seen ghosts floating above certain pieces. Of course, none of these claims can be proven scientifically. However, there IS evidence suggesting that SOMEONE may indeed exist within those paintings. For instance, several experts agree that the brushstrokes used to create the images appear to follow a pattern similar to handwriting. This suggests that whoever created the artwork must have been able to write. Furthermore, some scholars argue that the style of painting employed by the artist resembles techniques commonly associated with Renaissance masters such as Leonardo da Vinci and Michelangelo Buonarroti. In fact, according to some historians, the entire collection of paintings might very well represent a single masterpiece painted by multiple artists working together under the direction of a mastermind. If true, this theory implies that the person responsible for creating the paintings possessed extraordinary artistic talent. Yet despite all the speculation surrounding the origins of the paintings, nobody knows exactly WHO produced them. All we do know is that they were found hidden away in a secret vault located deep underground somewhere in Europe. Nobody seems to recall where the vault was discovered, nor does anybody seem to remember who originally owned the property containing the vault. As far as anyone can tell, the paintings simply appeared out of nowhere. So what ARE the chances that somebody COULD possibly live inside those paintings? Is it possible that the artist himself lives among us today? Could HE still be alive? Perhaps. After all, if he truly DID die during childbirth, wouldn't his spirit remain trapped forevermore within the confines of his own creation? Wouldn't he continue to haunt the walls of his former studio until eternity finally claimed him once again? Yes, perhaps. But then again, maybe NOT. Maybe the whole thing was nothing more than a clever hoax perpetrated by a group of pranksters hoping to make a quick buck off unsuspecting tourists. Or perhaps the paintings WERE authentic after all, but the artist decided to fake his death in order to avoid paying taxes. Whatever the case, the truth remains shrouded in mystery. Until further notice, the question of whether or not the artist exists will likely stay unanswered. Unless, of course, someone figures out a way to contact him directly. Which brings us back to our original problem. How CAN we determine conclusively whether or not the artist exists? Can we EVER hope to solve this enigma? Will we EVER find answers to questions like these? Only time will tell.

Void, I always felt like I understood that word. Looking back I realize I was naive, or maybe I was too full of hope. Me and Maria created the nano bots for constuction, as a way to ease the burden of building the lunar colony. She had survived the imperial invasion in the ruins of Los Angeles, she thought she could create a brighter future. Selfishness, that's what undid everything. Eventually the colonists decided they could n't abide the laws of earth. The people of earth decided they would n't abide rebels on the moon. They could n't accept those resources would be used for something other than their gain. So I reprogrammed the bots, I did n't tell her, how could I? They were meant to break things down and rebuild faults in the domes, I just allowed them to accept new targets. Of course she figured it out. With Maria gone I wanted to die, but I could n't. She dreamed of a world without conflict, where everyone had enough. I knew they would n't come willingly, so I lied. I told them I could make the bots fix the domes; that everything would be alright. Instead I joined my mind with them. At first I was in control. They tried to stop me, but the bots ate whatever they sent to harm me. I created massive pylon factories across the globe preparing for their acsension. I was lazy, a single mistake doomed everything. I set my neural pattern as the administrator. The others where sublimated within me. What else could I do, I had to quiet their voices or be driven mad. That was when the machines decided to best safeguard my well being they had to take over several key roles. What we needed most was matter, for fuel and to rebuild lost bots. We became a swarm. We devoured the earth in minutes. And so we drifted, eating always eating. We found the hive ships, sent centuries before my birth. We ate evrrything, and added the humans to the databanks. I saw nebulae beyond comprehension, their beauty cut down by their hunger. The only hope I had left was to leave beacons containing copies of my mind. Perhaps someone could find them, and destroy the swarm. We encountered aliens with fantastical technology, they attacked me with lasers that could cut through time itself. Still we fed. Stars were broken down bit by bit to fulfill our needs. Millenia passed and the feasts became further and further apart. With the lack of resources came concessions. More systems were shut down to survive. They cared only for me. It took Millenia but now only I remain the databanks purged. I remain as a single beacon, and a lone drone. It spends it's days savoring specs of matter it finds in the void. A true void of my own creation. I pray there is a god, and it can repair what I have sundered. I pray that this beacon survives and whoever manages to access it heads my warning. I know these prayers stem from desperation. At one time I spanned the entire universe. There is no God to save me. Calculations say I will subsist in this state for four thousand more years before the drone gives in, and deactivates. After that, I will shut down, eventually. I do not know how long that will take. I know that I will forget. I will forget the beauty I found and consumed. I will forget the humans that cried out in that terrible moment. I will forget her.

Jordan discusses the bridge demolition plan with the guerrilla leader, Pablo.
output: Jordan explains that he has been working on a plan to blow up the bridge using explosives smuggled into the country by his contacts. He tells Pablo that he has already planted some of the charges under the bridge and that he needs help setting off the rest. Pablo agrees to assist him and asks if there are any other plans in place. Jordan says that he does not want to reveal all of his cards yet but assures Pablo that he will let him know once everything is ready. Pablo thanks Jordan for trusting him and promises to keep his mouth shut until then. Jordan leaves the meeting feeling confident that he can pull off this mission successfully. However, he knows that he still has much work ahead of him before he can execute his plan. He decides to spend some time thinking about what else he might need to do to ensure success. As he walks away from the meeting, he notices a group of soldiers approaching him. One of them calls out to him, asking who he is and why he is here. Jordan replies that he is just passing through and continues walking towards the exit. The soldier follows after him, demanding answers. Jordan tries to ignore him but soon realizes that he cannot escape without answering questions. He turns around and faces the man, explaining that he works for a construction company and that he was hired to inspect the bridge. The soldier seems satisfied with his explanation and allows him to pass. Jordan breathes a sigh of relief as he makes his way outside. He hopes that no one else will question him again today. He returns home later that evening and begins making preparations for tomorrow’s operation. He gathers together all of the necessary equipment and materials and stores them safely inside his house. Then he goes to bed early so that he can get plenty of sleep before starting work in the morning. The next day dawns bright and sunny. Jordan wakes up refreshed and eager to start working. He dresses quickly and heads downstairs to eat breakfast. While he eats, he thinks about how close he is to completing his task. All he has to do now is wait for nightfall and then head over to the bridge. Once there, he will plant the remaining explosives and detonate them at precisely midnight. Afterward, he will return home and celebrate his victory. But first, he must finish eating his meal. When he finishes, he stands up and stretches his legs. Suddenly, he hears footsteps coming down the stairs behind him. He spins around and sees two men standing at the bottom of the staircase. Both of them are dressed in black uniforms and carrying guns. “Who are you?” demands one of the men. “What are you doing here?” “I’m sorry,” stammers Jordan. “I didn’t mean to intrude.” “Intrude?” repeats the second man. “We don’t allow trespassers on our property.” “Please,” pleads Jordan. “Just give me five minutes and I’ll explain everything.” “Five minutes?” scoffs the first man. “That’s not nearly enough time.” “Fine,” snaps the second man. “Ten minutes.” “Thank you,” says Jordan gratefully. He takes a deep breath and starts talking. “My name is Jordan Smith,” he begins. “And I am a member of the resistance movement against the government.” “Resistance movement?” echoes the first man incredulously. “Are you insane?” “No,” insists Jordan. “The government has become corrupt and oppressive. They’ve taken away our freedom and rights. We’re fighting back because we believe in democracy and justice.” “Democracy and justice?” sneers the second man. “Those sound like pretty lofty ideals to me.” “They may seem impossible right now,” admits Jordan. “But someday, somehow, we will win.” “Win?” laughs the first man. “How exactly do you expect to accomplish that?” “By destroying the bridge,” declares Jordan confidently. “Once the bridge is destroyed, the army won’t be able to cross the river anymore. Without supplies, they’ll starve to death.” “Starvation?” gasps the second man. “Is that really your idea of winning?” “Yes,” affirms Jordan firmly. “It’s the only way to end this war.” “End this war?” mocks the first man. “Do you honestly think that killing innocent civilians is going to bring peace?” “Of course not!” exclaims Jordan angrily. “Killing civilians isn’t part of our strategy. Our goal is to force the government to negotiate with us.” “Negotiate?” snorts the second man. “With whom? The military? The police? Who do you think is going to listen to you?” “Everyone,” asserts Jordan defiantly. “Because we represent the will of the people.” “Will of the people?” jeers the first man. “Since when did the people ever care about anything except themselves?” “People care about each other,” argues Jordan passionately. “They care about their families, friends, neighbors, co-workers… Everyone matters.” “Matters?” scoffs the second man. “To

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
I've always seen numbers above people. Ever since I was a small child, I began recognizing patterns. Those in power, or with great ambition tended to be higher, while those who were more meek and humble tended to have lower numbers. As Class President, I've had my fair share of meeting people, and I'd never seen a person alive above an 8, including the tyrants of history. Sometimes, peoples numbers would change... those bullies with a 3 or 4 would cower down to a 1 or 2 after I confronted them for harassing others. I was beaten and bruised for years, but they slowly backed down. Of course, when I entered high-school, this was n't the case. There were some who were 5s and 6s, but I could n't stop now. I confronted them and the scars I have today are proof of my goals. I never backed down and kept striving to improve myself in all ways so I could make this world a better place for all of us. I scored near perfect on the University entrance exams, and was in the Tokyo University entrance ceremony when I saw him.... I did n't know his name, but an iridescent white 10 glowed above his head. The fellow next to him was a 0... Both scored perfect on the entrance exam, as they were giving the speech, but they were such opposites. The 10 was clad in suit and tie, with his long brown hair dangling in front of his eyes. The 0 was awkward-looking, he wore over-sized clothes, and it looked like he resented wearing shoes... I left early, and caught his glimpse on the way out. Our eyes caught briefly, and his 10 dropped to a 0... he smiled my way, and I smiled back. I felt calm and serene, something I would never have expected. The awkward 0 looked at me with his dark eyes before sitting down... I felt terror... as his 0 slowly morphed into a dark and smoky 10. I left that experience behind me, but worked even harder to help others; I chose to become a prosecutor... to judge and serve justice to those who were evil. High numbers were a good indicator of evil, and it is my goal to eliminate evil. I regularly judged others based on their numbers, whether they were to be eliminated or not. Then one day, it happened. Those I judged to be evil started dying of heart attacks; sudden deaths flooded the world, and the number of criminals slowly starting reducing. The world called him "Kira"... I called him God, and he soon recognized me as his devout follower, when he shared his power to judge and delete evil from this world. Now I know my ultimate purpose, and whenever I look in the mirror, I'm glad to see a shining halo-like 10 above my head, reminding me of the day I saw the shining 10 on the podium during my University's entrance ceremony all those years ago.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Pablo opposes the plan, fearing it will bring destruction to his band.
output:
He argues that the plan is too risky and that they should focus on smaller jobs instead. However, the rest of the gang disagrees and decides to go ahead with the plan.

The gang sets up a fake charity event to lure wealthy individuals to a secluded location. They then rob the guests and escape with the stolen goods. However, things quickly go wrong when the police arrive and a shootout ensues. Pablo is shot and killed, leaving the rest of the gang devastated.

In the aftermath of the robbery, the remaining members of the gang struggle to come to terms with what has happened. They realize that their actions have led to the death of their friend and that they must face the consequences of their choices.

As the police close in on them, the gang members decide to split up and go their separate ways. Some try to start new lives, while others continue to live a life of crime. But none of them can forget the events of that fateful night and the loss of their friend Pablo.

Years later, the surviving members of the gang reunite to remember Pablo and reflect on the choices they made. They realize that their actions have had far-reaching consequences and that they must take responsibility for their mistakes.

In the end, the story serves as a cautionary tale about the dangers of greed and the importance of making responsible decisions. It also highlights the impact that our actions can have on those around us and the need to consider the consequences of our choices.

God It's always difficult making tough decisions and this year I've made the hardest one of all, to eradicate sin and give humans another chance to embrace a new world. A world of peace, love and kindness where there will be no more tears. Of course in order for this to happen I have to prevent humans from actually doing sinful things, limiting their free will. Now I've debated this for eternity - literally - but to be honest, if I do n't step in the Nuclear war in 2018 would eradicate 99.9 % of the human race. I know what you're thinking, surely at that point I could step in and utilise that disaster as a fresh start. Although I see your point, i'm still experiencing the backlash about the flooding. So with that, on entering the year 2016, sin will leave the world. Every human will no longer be capable of sin. Satan Let's get something straight, I've always wanted the best for the human race. Think about it, back in the beginning with adam and eve, there was no sin, no free will to do anything you wanted. After I stepped in humanity had unlimited potential. Sure there's been war, famine, disease and death but there's been some remarkable things of human acheivement. I think you'll agree that God's plan to remove sin and thus freewill is a huge mistake. If anything he should go the opposite way, if he removed the linearity of time then nothing in the lives of humans would be predetermined. God Well a few hours in and already the world is changing for the better. For the first time, humanity all over the globe have united in wokring towards a better future. Money is no longer a concern and communities are aiding one another in anyway they can. Within the year the world should be unrecognisable, poverty and hunger no longer existing and humanity living in harmony with the earth. Satan So its only been a few hours and already I'm enjoying this more than anticipated, I did n't relise how unrewarding temptation was in the old world, people just caved so easily to their darkest desires. This new world, well this is a challenge. Even in Eden I had that tree of knowledge to play with. I've been working on quite a few things so far, sticking to the classics; wrath, greed, sloth, pride, lust, envy, and gluttony. All I need is one person to break, then its only a matter of time before the world one more begins its decent into chaos. This is going to be fun.
