Howard Roark is expelled from the Stanton Institute of Technology.
output: He goes to New York City and works for Henry Cameron, a disgraced architect whom Roark admires. Meanwhile, Roark's popular yet insecure schoolmate Peter Keating also moves to the city and works for the prestigious architectural firm Francon & Heyer. Roark and Cameron create beautiful work, but their projects rarely receive recognition, whereas Keating's ability to flatter and please brings him impressive but insubstantial success. Eventually, Keating rises to become chief designer of the firm, but his dependence on Roark's ideas exposes his lack of originality. In the meantime, Roark develops a close friendship with Austen Heller, a newspaper magnate and outspoken individualist. One day, Roark is introduced to Dominique Francon, a young woman who writes a popular architecture column for another paper. They are immediately attracted to each other, but Roark soon leaves the city for a contract in Connecticut. Dominique, having tried and failed to sabotage Roark's chances of getting the commission, tracks him down. She promises not to write about the construction project, but urges him to complete it as quickly as possible so that she can forget about him and the feelings he stirs in her. Roark returns early to find that a rival architect has been brought in to modify his design. He indignantly smashes the model of the revised building, then quits the business altogether. Dominique eventually meets and marries Keating, who is still dependent on Roark for designs. Dominique takes advantage of Keating's insecurities and convinces him to ask Roark to design Cortlandt Homes, a public housing project. Keating promises the board of the housing project that he will closely supervise Roark, so that the resulting edifice shall conform to the traditional style the board wants. However, Keating is distracted by his infatuation with Toohey's niece Catherine Halsey, allowing Roark to design Cortlandt as he sees fit. When Roark's austere, minimalist style offends the housing board's sensibilities, Toohey urges Keating to alter Roark's design. Roark agrees to resign the project when he learns of Keating's intention to make changes, but is shocked to learn that Keating does not plan to follow through on his promise to restore Roark's vision. Roark confronts Keating and offers him a choice: give up the contract and persuade the board to accept Roark's design or Roark will sue the company and cause great scandal. Keating begs for mercy, but Roark will not yield. That evening, Roark sneaks onto the construction site, drills into the support beams and dynamites Cortlandt Homes. The resulting scandal leads to a high-profile trial, in which Roark acts as his own attorney. To the astonishment of the courtroom, Roark makes no defense against the charges and the jury finds him guilty. However, Austen Heller warns Roark that media sensationalism will lead to a harsh sentence unless Roark allows him to arrange a strong legal defense team. Roark consents, and his attorneys not only win his acquittal but arrange for him to design a skyscraper that will be New York's tallest building. Dominique divorces Keating and marries Roark. Keating's dependence on Roark and Toohey becomes absolute—he must rely on them respectively for architectural ideas and protection from scandal. Toohey uses Keating as a pawn in a scheme to gain total control of the architectural industry by creating a Council of American Builders, ostensibly a group formed to solve the industry's problems, but in reality an instrument for setting architectural standards. Ellsworth Toohey is revealed to be both a socialist and a nihilist who teaches that everyone must serve others, and that an individual's value comes only from selfless service to society. He trains disciples such as Peter Keating to spread his influence for his own enrichment. Toohey habitually sows conflict amongst allies to weaken their resolve. Toohey believes that Howard Roark, his antithesis, is his deadliest enemy, but Toohey's greatest nemesis proves to be Gail Wynand, a wealthy newspaper mogul who uses cynicism and bribery to advance his business interests. Wynand is So convinced of people's inherent depravity that he may be said to consider himself the smartest person in the world for having achieved financial dominance. Wynand and Roark become fast friends until Wynand discovers that his wife Dominique loves Roark. Wynand therefore orders the Banner's journalists to smear Roark's career. At the same time, Wynand's wife Dominique, who fears a future in which Roark might be harmed or limited by the mediocre mass of humanity, agrees to marry Wynand (even though she does not love him) after Roark agrees that such an arrangement could benefit their future together. Later, Wynand decides to build a home for himself and his wife. He demands of Roark that the house be built only for him, and that it never be duplicated elsewhere. Roark

Five thousand six-hundred and seventy-three days. Fifteen years, twenty-seven weeks, five days. Since the Genetic Mapping and Research Studies act was passed. Since our own ambition of genetic editions, additions, was realized. Since humanity truly hit its crest, and now, I believe we certainly are headed downhill. My name is Isaac, I am a genetic engineer working for Lifeco, and I played a hand in the de-evolution of modern humanity. When we first started this, it was obvious we were doing the good work, helping those with certain genetic inferiority, destroying the predestined diseases that would cripple them later on in life, we were gods men doing the work only gods could ever have aspired to do. We had become gods in the eyes of the world, the one lab that started it all, our faces, the twelve of us, on the cover of every scientific magazine, journal, webcast, holovid, every single screen showed us. We were celebrities beyond anything the world had yet seen, and to think we did n't get into it for the money. Thats all beside the point now, we of course could't hold onto the secrets forever, others learned the processes and soon genome splicing and epigenetic interference were the rage. It was every father's gift to his sweet-sixteen, every anniversary present, and every newborns fate. We controlled fate. Now, all of these years later I am left to reflect. My original eleven friends that started this with me, have long since resided from the spotlight, I too. Money is no issue, we together must be worth at-least 500 billion, but what good is it. I would give it all away to alter the course of history, to rewrite what has been done, for now when I look out into the world I ca n't even recognize it. The roots where always there, deeply so in the capitalist mentality and society that held a severe strangle hold upon every american citizen, of course it would never relinquish its grip in the face of something so extraordinary as this. Now we have social stratification as never would we have thought possible, we thought it was bad in the early 2000's, we thought that was bad. We had n't seen horror. Now with genetic proof of "superiority" that those wealthiest enough to afford gene editions can claim, the poorest are left with such a feeling and direct attitude of inferiority, it is sickening. My mind aches, my bones burn with the pain of what has been done, If only it could be righted. With the increase in average intelligence and decrease in disease, you would think that statistics would show an increase in personal happiness. This is not so. One day, we will learn to treat each other well, as fellow humans. I fear I will not live to see that day but I know it ca n't get worse than this, I hope. I am dying from cancer, I have refused treatment, I have refused all geneditions, I'd rather die than submit to it all. They would never show that on the holo vid displays, though.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Roark goes to work for Henry Cameron.
output: He works hard and learns much. He also meets another young architect named Peter Keating who is very talented but lacks Roarks passion for architecture. They become friends despite their differences. Eventually they both graduate from college and go off into different directions. Peter becomes successful while Roark struggles to find employment. However he does manage to land some small jobs here and there. One day he gets called by a wealthy client who wants him to design her new house. She tells him she loves his style and offers him $10 million dollars if he designs her dream home. Roark accepts the offer without hesitation. As he begins designing the house he realizes how much he hates working for someone else. So instead of finishing the project he decides to quit and start his own firm. His former boss tries to stop him but fails miserably. Soon after leaving his old job he starts getting more clients than ever before. People love his unique approach to architecture and want him to build their homes. Before long he has built several houses and made millions of dollars. But then tragedy strikes. A fire breaks out at one of his buildings killing everyone inside including himself. Everyone blames him for the accident saying he should've known better. Some say he deliberately set the building ablaze because he hated being rich. Others claim he was just careless and didn't care about anyone except making money. Either way he ends up losing everything he worked so hard for. Years pass and Roark lives alone in poverty. Then one night he hears a knock on his door. Its none other than Howard Roarke! He explains that hes been watching over him all along and knew exactly what happened. Hes come back to help him rebuild his life. Together they form a partnership and create a whole new type of architecture. Their creations are unlike anything anyone has ever seen. And once again people flock to them wanting to hire them to construct their homes. Over time they make billions of dollars and become famous worldwide. Finally Roark feels happy again. He knows he'll never forget what happened to him but he also knows he cant let it define him anymore. Instead he chooses to move forward and enjoy his newfound success.

I have reaped the souls of many over the course of my years as death. Souls of the good, the bad, and everything between have always been sown by another before I pluck them from the Earth at their appropriate time. Even the ones that believe it is n't their time or ask for just one more opportunity to do what they wish, must be taken without question because, well, its just the way my job is. To me, it never mattered where they were at in life. I just carried them over with ease. Never once had experienced trouble in my task as I had even had to pluck sweet children from the arms of their mothers. However, it all changed when I was tasked with taking the soul of David Mckiny. I watched David from the day he entered the Earth, and never before had I seen someone as special as him. He always thought of others first, always trying to help others before even contemplating his own commodities. I approached him on the fateful day at exactly noon. He was old now, no longer in his prime as he was finally about to lose his battle with cancer. I approached him as the hourglass emptied completely to the bottom. I spoke to him," David you must know who I am at this hour." He answered not necessarily speaking to me," If only I had helped more.... If only I could have have had more time! How dreadful to go when so many more need help!" At this moment I found it immensely hard to fulfill my task. I was not met with a man begging for more time only to waste it on fruitless trivialities. I was met with a man who wanted to bring grace to more people. He wished not to make his life better, but only cares to try to improve as many others as possible. I finally brought myself to say," David you have been a good man, but death is one thing which is inevitable, and not even I can grant time when someone is due. You must come along now with me." He allowed his soul to leave his body, a tear running down his face as he did. I extended my arm to him and he obliged. If there is one final peace to the journey is the experience of seeing one's life pass by as I guide them to the next step. I saw, as we walked, countless people who David had helped, most of which he had n't known and would never see again. Every part of me wished to guide him back to his body, but I knew I had a task to fulfill, and I knew I had to complete it. After a long while of walking down the path, we finally came to the gateway where David would continue without my guidance. I never know where the person will go once they enter, but I knew David would go to a place that would have the same passion in death as he did in life. I never had such a hard time seeing someone move on, and I sat a while thinking of how tragic it is for someone like David, genuinely the best kind of person, to be taken from such a cruel world when he one of the few people who deserved to stay. Anyways I found myself contemplating to long, and I moved on to reap the rest of the souls I had to fetch that day.

"Ah man, it smells like death in here." That is the phrase that I have lived to regret ever since they fell foolishly from my mouth. I was essentially immortal before that moment in time. I was the best comedian in the world, and apparently better than anyone in the afterlife as well. It was the only reason the Grim Reaper decided not to take me. I could make him laugh, and in his line of work that was a rarity. I do n't even remember what it was that I had said when he showed up at my car accident. I can recall him bending down next to my overturned Honda civic and reaching in to pull me out. I made some off the wall comment and he froze, dead in his tracks. It was the weirdest laugh I had ever heard, but one I appreciated more than all of the others combined. He let me live, provided that every year on the anniversary of what should have been my death, I would tell him a joke that would make him cry with laughter. I was his own personal jester, and for that he rewarded me handsomely. And then on that fateful day, 121 years later, I muttered those stupid words that seized our contract and ripped it in two. Who knew Death would be so self conscious about his smell? And to make things worse, that was n't even the joke that I was going to tell him! The actual joke was a masterpiece, but he would n't give me the chance to tell it. I ran out of that room faster than I'd ever run before. And I've been running ever since. I think the reason that he has n't taken me yet is because of our long history together. That is n't to say that he's forgiven me. He seems to enjoy reminding me that he's near. Everyone I get close to dies without reason. I'll see a dog in the park that I think looks adorable and before I can pet it, it'll fall over dead. Roses crumble before I can enjoy their scent and food rots on my fork before I can bring it to my mouth. He's killing everything around me. I have discovered that Death is a jester of a different sort. I had provided him with a form of humor that he was n't used to, but he has since grown tired of it, and reverted to his old ways. Now, he once again deals in jokes of cruelty and irony. In a way, I am still fulfilling my part of our old deal. The Reaper still laughs, and he still laughs at me. Only now, the difference is I'm not laughing.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Roark is fired from Francon's firm for refusing to conform.
output: He goes to New York City where he works for Henry Cameron, a disgraced architect whom Roark reveres. They work together for several years until Cameron retires, and Roark opens his own office. But prospective clients are put off by Roark's unbending individualism and uncompromising principles, and he struggles financially. Dominique leaves Wynand after he betrays his principles, and she returns to her family's estate in the Hudson Valley. One day, while horseback riding, she encounters Roark surveying the site. She puts her horse through its paces for Roark, who watches appreciatively; however, she falls from her horse and lands at Roark's feet, too injured to move. He carries her back to her house, where she revives. When she attempts to force herself on him sexually, he refuses. Dominique invites Roark to wait for her in the drawing room, where she plays the piano for him. Later, she tells him that she does not want him to pursue her, but he tells her that they will meet again. Roark closes his business and leaves town. He takes a job in a granite quarry owned by Roger Enright. While there, he meets Steven Mallory, a talented sculptor whom Roark helps to complete a commission for another client. Roark also becomes acquainted with Mike Donnigan, a rough-hewn laborer with a passion for music. Roark and Dominique rekindle their relationship, and eventually marry. However, Dominique remains conflicted about her love for Roark, believing that he will ultimately fail due to his unwillingness to compromise. She tries to undermine his career by convincing Peter Keating to design a building for which Roark had submitted plans. Keating agrees, but only if Roark allows him to put his name on the project. Roark reluctantly agrees, knowing that this will allow him to continue working. Meanwhile, Toohey convinces Ellsworth Toohey to write a scathing review of the building, which causes public opinion to turn against it. As a result, Roark loses most of his commissions. Desperate for money, he accepts a job designing a housing project for low-income families. However, he soon realizes that the project is being sabotaged by government officials who are opposed to modern architecture. Frustrated, Roark dynamites the nearly completed building rather than see it built according to someone else's vision. He is arrested and tried for vandalism, but acquitted thanks to testimony from Dominique and other witnesses. Afterward, Roark decides to leave New York and start fresh elsewhere. He moves to Colorado, where he designs a new home for himself and Dominique. There, they finally find happiness together.

"Corner-Cutting" I was worried about the efficiency of the engram compression, or the integrity of my telomeres. I did n't want my cells to age super-fast, or my mind to gradually decay into noise data. But those were n't the issue. What I should have paid attention to was resolution. It started on the fifth "respawn". Everything had been going fine up to then - incurable disease, radiation burns, blunt force trauma, blood loss. Horribly dead, safely alive, rinse, repeat. Then I noticed something odd. It was n't immediately noticeable. It might have been happening in previous lives, in even less conspicuous ways, but I found it on my nose. A voxel. It was disconcerting, but not terribly so. A little extra skin and an odd right-angle was n't something to make me question my latest biological vehicle, but I did wonder what would happen if it had happened in, say, my eye. A bullet through the head and I was back in the machine. After the standard checks, I tried to find a superficial voxel somewhere. This time it was a whole cube of extra skin on my upper arm, a few millimeters across. Now I started wondering if voxels could go missing instead of being added - and I started wondering if they could be missing internally. The tests continued. This time I was dropped unceremoniously into a small vat of fluoroantimonic acid - I barely had time to register pain before I chemically ceased to exist. When I woke up, voxels were the first thing I checked for. Nothing on my face, or my arms... But on my side there was a large raised spot, with right-angled edges. But there was little time to worry about my volumetric resolution - the next test was explosive. Alive again, I looked for voxellation. To my growing concern, it was spreading. Like square tumors, the voxels showed up in patches on my arms, legs, and torso. I hoped they would n't reach my... Higher-resolution areas. After the decompression test, the voxels were in all sorts of places. I started to feel like a combination of human and LEGO. They were n't impeding me in any way, but it was bizarre having irregular rectangular growths all over. They were pretty obvious from even a glance, but the tests continued. Death by rapid incineration. Voxels on my shins. Death by a laser through the heart. Voxels on my back. Death by electrocution. Voxels on my shoulders. I was still functioning perfectly - the voxels did n't seem to be happening to anything inside me. After a while I got used to them - I formed a habit of checking where my voxel patches had randomly generated with each "respawn". Eventually it had to happen. I awoke and found it mechanically difficult to extricate myself from the machine. A cursory examination revealed that my entire exterior surface was voxellated to a resolution of three millimeters. There was a fuss, and argument, and huddled discussion. Eventually someone noticed me standing around being extraordinarily Cartesian and told me to get back into the machine. It was just like dying - at least, like the particularly quick deaths. When I woke up, I had my contours back - you could say my resolution was molecular. It was refreshing not to have to worry about being compared to an old videogame. I did notice I weighed rather less than I seemed to remember - but I decided not to worry about it.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Roark opens his own office but struggles to find clients.
output: He is approached by Peter Keating who offers him a job as a draftsman in his firm. Roark refuses and continues to work alone. He meets Dominique Francon, a young woman who is fascinated by his work. She becomes his lover and muse. Roark designs several buildings that are praised for their beauty and innovation. However, he also faces criticism and opposition from traditionalists who consider his style too radical. One of his most controversial projects is the Enright House, a residential building commissioned by Gail Wynand, a wealthy newspaper magnate. Wynand admires Roark's talent and hires him without seeing any of his previous works. He gives him complete freedom to design whatever he wants, as long as it reflects his vision. Roark creates a masterpiece that combines modernism and classicism, using concrete and glass to create a harmonious balance between form and function. The Enright House becomes one of the most iconic buildings in New York City, attracting visitors from all over the world. However, it also sparks a heated debate among architects and critics, some of whom accuse Roark of violating the principles of architecture and aesthetics. Some even call him a traitor to his profession and demand that he be expelled from the Institute of American Architects. Roark ignores the controversy and continues to pursue his artistic ideals. He forms a close friendship with Henry Cameron, an elderly architect who has been marginalized by the establishment for his unconventional views. Cameron mentors Roark and encourages him to follow his passion for creating original and meaningful art. Roark also meets Ellsworth Toohey, a charismatic journalist who writes columns for Wynand's newspapers. Toohey pretends to admire Roark's work and invites him to join his circle of influential friends. However, Roark soon realizes that Toohey is actually a manipulative and hypocritical man who seeks to control others through flattery and deceit. He exposes Toohey's true nature in front of his followers, causing them to turn against him. Toohey vows revenge on Roark and plots to destroy his reputation and career. He uses his influence in the media to spread lies and rumors about Roark, portraying him as a selfish and arrogant artist who cares only about himself. He also convinces other architects to boycott Roark's projects and refuse to collaborate with him. Roark finds himself isolated and ostracized by the architectural community. He loses many of his clients and commissions, forcing him to take on smaller and less prestigious jobs. He also suffers personal losses, such as the death of Cameron and the betrayal of Dominique, who marries another man out of spite. Despite these setbacks, Roark remains faithful to his principles and refuses to compromise his artistic integrity. He continues to design buildings that express his individuality and creativity, regardless of public opinion or professional recognition. He also finds new allies and supporters, such as Austen Heller, a lawyer who defends him against legal challenges; Steven Mallory, a sculptor who shares his vision; and Mike Donnigan, a contractor who respects his skill. Together, they form a network of independent artists who challenge the status quo and defy the authority of the mainstream culture. Roark's final project is the Cortlandt Homes, a housing complex for low-income families. He accepts the commission from a government agency that promises him full artistic freedom and funding. However, he soon discovers that the agency has lied to him and intends to alter his design according to political pressures and bureaucratic regulations. Roark refuses to cooperate and decides to take drastic action. He blows up the unfinished building with dynamite, destroying his own creation rather than letting it be corrupted by others. He is arrested and charged with vandalism and sabotage. His trial becomes a national sensation, attracting attention from both admirers and detractors. Roark uses the opportunity to deliver a powerful speech defending his actions and explaining his philosophy of life. He argues that every person has the right to live according to their own values and goals, without sacrificing themselves for the sake of others or society. He also criticizes the collectivist mentality that seeks to impose conformity and mediocrity on everyone, stifling individual expression and achievement. Roark's speech inspires many people who share his ideals and admire his courage. They rally behind him and support him during his ordeal. Among them are Dominique, who realizes her mistake and returns to him; Wynand, who recognizes his own hypocrisy and redeems himself; and Toohey, who admits defeat and acknowledges Roark's superiority. Roark is acquitted by the jury and hailed as a hero by the public. He resumes his career as an architect and enjoys widespread acclaim and success. He also reunites with Dominique and marries her, living happily ever after. The Fountainhead ends with a symbolic image of Roark standing atop a skyscraper he designed, looking down at the city below him. He represents the triumph of the individual over the collective, the spirit of independence over the tyranny of conformity. He embodies the essence of Objectivism, Ayn Rand's philosophy that celebrates reason, egoism, capitalism

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
The moment I saw her deep blue eyes I knew she was the one. It was a feeling I had never felt before it was like everything that was wrong was suddenly right. She didn' t care for me at first but after several attempts she finally agreed to go out with me. The following were the best months of my life. I lived in an extreme state of happiness and pleasure. Everything that was once mundane was now exciting and fresh, I had never enjoyed walks on the beach or being aroused by a simple touch of her hand. One day she fell ill. The doctors tried everything but nothing seemed to work. Her deep blue eyes were tired and lacked the light that once captivate me. It was devastating to see her in a hospital bed waiting for her life to end. All I wanted was to be with her until the end. It was then that I took action. I read all the books.I knew how it worked but I had never done it. I never had a reason to do it. I bought the roses, the lambs heart, and I captured the laugh of a child. It was a simple ritual it will take one year of life to give her one more day of life. I lit the candles, prayed the mantras, poured my blood over the white roses, stuffed the lamb with the roses and released the laugh of the child. I didn' t feel any change at the moment but the next day I noticed small wrinkles in my face. I did the ritual every night until my hair was covered in grays. She was not getting better but she had not worsen. She was just there, laying in that hospital bed with no pain and still as beautiful as the first day I saw her. As I kissed her goodnight she plead for me to stop. "I am ready to go" she whispered in my ear, "it' s too much. You have given me three more wonderful weeks with you. Let me go." But I couldn' t. How dare she ask me to let her go, to let everything we have built together vanish with her absence? I had never loved someone so much I could never let her go. I had never been so angry with her, with life, with the world. That was the night I took my first life. This time it took no ritual just a blade to the heart. Poor man never saw it coming, one moment he was peacefully sleeping on an alley and the next one he was granting me one more year of life, one more day in her life. I did n't like taking a life but I would do anything for her. One day while I payed her a visit I lost all sense of me. I woke up two days later in a hospital bed. I panicked. I tried to get up but she hold my hand. She was next to me waiting for me to wake up. She curled next to me in bed and whispered in my ear "I am ready are you?" "Anything for you" I answered. She kissed me and then it all went black.

I was treated like I was special the second I was born. # 1. The last of the children born on Earth, to a middle-class family in the heart of New York. I was supposed to be the talisman, the last hope for humanity. I was supposed to lead us into the stars and break the genetic disease that ravaged our planet. I was supposed to find a cure and make it possible to continue the human race again. So the prophecy foretold, in that huge book held deep within the vaults of the UN Building, the last surviving testament the Great Leader himself. I was supposed to be the second coming of him, he who had found the disease eating our DNA, he who had brought the world together under one almighty, omniscient umbrella. I was supposed to be him incarnate once again. Time went by and I failed at every turn. I was reviled. I could n't do math well enough; anatomy confused me. How was I supposed to find a cure for the disease when I could n't even name the parts of a cell? Riots ensued. "We're all going to die! Humanity is doomed!" My parents and the few advisers that remained to keep them safe tried their hardest to educate me, to let me fulfill my destiny. They tried to save the human race. The crowds got Dad first. When they came, in the middle of the night on Halloween, my parents thought it was the last two kids in New York besides myself, trick-or-treating despite the fact that they were almost fifteen each. They shot Dad in the chest, for producing the doom of humanity. Mom screamed and Dr. Evans shouted for us to run. Dr. Muller went with us while Evans held the back door against the mob. We ran for two weeks in Mom's sedan, keeping me hidden from view. I was n't allowed to leave the back seat, and I could n't take off my sweatshirt, even in the middle of Texas. It was only after the miracle birth of # 0 that we were safe. From the deep jungle of the Amazon came the true Inheritor of the Great Leader. She cracked the disease by the time she was 5. She gave humanity it's first commercial space fleet and colonies by 10. By 15, she was granted the title of Queen of Earth. And me? I will always be remembered as the Great Failure. The Great Pretender. The Church of the Queen still wants me hung for being the false Chosen One. So I had no choice. I ran. Into the depths of space, I ran. Somewhere, lost out in the stars, where no one could find me, where no one could look at that permanent scar on my wrist, that horrible # 1. It's lonely out here, but it's better to be lonely than dead.

All Harry could think about was the prophecy. "The power the Dark Lord knows not..." Dumbledore thought it was love. .. but hugs would n't kill monsters. That was when it hit him, Voldemort knew nothing of muggles, right? So something muggle had to be the power he knew not! Harry thought himself terribly clever. oo7, listening to him mutter through the microphone he had hidden in the boy's room simply chuckled. Took the lad long enough. Bond nonchalantly walked away and called M on his phone. "M, the lad finally got the idea. Should I approach?" a few seconds passed as Bond listened to M, "Roger that, I'll approach him before his birthday. Should be plenty of time to deal with these homegrown terrorists and get the lad to school on time." -scene break Voldemort could n't believe what was happening. For the past thirty days he had every single minion that left the Malfoy manor get shipped back in a body bag. He had n't even known muggles had those. Just goes to show how the animals could steal the dignity from wizards even in death. He was left with Wormtail and Bellatrix. Granted Bella was loyal, but she was completely insane. His most cunning and resourceful follower, the best deatheater he had, reduced to an insane hag who was good for nothing more than pointing at something he wanted destroyed and then watching it burn. A deep sigh dragged itself out of him. He could n't bring himself to even try to list any redeeming qualities in Wormtail. That was when he heard it, a muffled sound like nothing he had ever heard followed by the unmistakable sound of a dead body hitting the ground. Quick steps brought him into the kitchen in time to see a man about his age in a muggle suit dabbing a bit of blood from his face, Wormtail laying in a pool of his own blood behind him, with Bellatrix dying at his feet. Voldemort could n't remember ever being this angry. A growl issued from his clenched teeth. "Who are you?!" Voldemort shouted, even as he raised his wand to cast crucio on this fool who defied him. The muggle simply raised a hand with some device in it and pushed a bright red button on it. Pain like Voldemort had never felt corsed through his body as the traps he had n't noticed when he barged in shot tiny barbed hooks into his body attached to the launchers by a thin piece of wire. Then the traps sent 25 mill Ampere of electricity coursing through his body. Only the fact that the electricity was still flowing through him, forcing his muscles to contract, kept Voldemort standing. "The name is Bond, James Bond. Harry Potter sends his regards. Do n't worry about dying though old chap, MI6 has plans for you."

Just goes to show how the animals could steal the dignity from wizards even in death. He was left with Wormtail and Bellatrix. Granted Bella was loyal, but she was completely insane. His most cunning and resourceful follower, the best deatheater he had, reduced to an insane hag who was good for nothing more than pointing at something he wanted destroyed and then watching it burn. A deep sigh dragged itself out of him. He could n't bring himself to even try to list any redeeming qualities in Wormtail. That was when he heard it, a muffled sound like nothing he had ever heard followed by the unmistakable sound of a dead body hitting the ground. Quick steps brought him into the kitchen in time to see a man about his age in a muggle suit dabbing a bit of blood from his face, Wormtail laying in a pool of his own blood behind him, with Bellatrix dying at his feet. Voldemort could n't remember ever being this angry. A growl issued from his clenched teeth. "Who are you?!" Voldemort shouted, even as he raised his wand to cast crucio on this fool who defied him. The muggle simply raised a hand with some device in it and pushed a bright red button on it. Pain like Voldemort had never felt corsed through his body as the traps he had n't noticed when he barged in shot tiny barbed hooks into his body attached to the launchers by a thin piece of wire. Then the traps sent 25 mill Ampere of electricity coursing through his body. Only the fact that the electricity was still flowing through him, forcing his muscles to contract, kept Voldemort standing. "The name is Bond, James Bond. Harry Potter sends his regards. Do n't worry about dying though old chap, MI6 has plans for you."

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Standing on top of our world, we watch as the sun rises over the island. The soft rays bathe the distant hills in gold, as the breeze blows through the dancing grass. The trees shivers as flock of birds take flight. Spots of white clouds the orange-hued sky, as it slowly turns azure. Far in the distance, a silver tower, shrouded in mist, pierces the heavens above. The waves crash down on the sandy beaches, and the endless sea merges with the horizon. I take in the sights, the smells, the sounds. Feeling both pride and joy, I turn to face to you. The air is warm, but your hand is warmer. I hold it close to me, closer still. The sun is shining bright, but your smile is brighter. We' re standing at the top of our world, the one we made together, and I can' t tell you how happy this has made me. "It' s almost time." You say. "I know." I reply. I rest my head on your shoulder, and take a long breath as I close my eyes. I' m at peace here. When I opened them again, I was in my bed, and a bittersweet feeling of both tranquility and sadness lingered in my mind. It was around 7 a.m., and I went about my daily routine, a smile etched on my face. I wrote what had happened in a dream journal I had started two years ago. After having read about lucid dreaming, and I wanted to try it. It took some time, but one day, I was able to control the outcome of my dreams. After a few weeks, something changed. There was something else, maybe someone else, with me. I couldn' t control them, and they couldn' t control me. I searched about it in books and online, but no one reported something similar. I wasn' t afraid, though. Their presence was soothing. We rarely spoke, but when we did, it was always meaningful. Together, we started building a world, our dream island. It brought me joy, and above all, peace. This feeling of inner peace lived on with me during the day. The sun was racing across the sky as we strolled down the ruins of a castle. Holes and cracks had let nature overtake the walls and floors, and the ceiling had long since crumbled. We walked down an old throne room, and you turned to face me. It was so sudden, I nearly bumped into you. You looked resolute, and you said two simple words: "Find me." I jolted awake. I knew what I had to do. I had to find you. So I searched, high and low, for days on end. Perhaps I thought it was fate, perhaps it was simply fool' s luck, but I felt as if I would eventually find you, if I kept trying. One evening, as if beckoned, I went in a coffee shop. I sat down with my coffee at an empty table, and looked up through the window at the red sky. Soon, someone came in, ordered the same thing as I did. They headed toward my table, and sat down in front of me, smiling brightly. Strangely, I felt at peace.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Charles begins to visit Sarah secretly, becoming increasingly intrigued by her.
output: He finds himself drawn to her beauty and intelligence, and soon falls deeply in love with her. However, he knows that his family would never approve of their relationship, and so he keeps it hidden from them. As Charles spends more time with Sarah, he becomes aware of the dangers she faces as a woman living alone in London. He worries about her safety, especially after hearing rumors of a serial killer targeting young women in the area. Despite these concerns, Charles continues to see Sarah, unable to resist the pull of their connection. One night, while walking home from Sarah's house, Charles hears a scream coming from an alleyway nearby. Without hesitation, he rushes towards the sound, determined to help whoever may be in trouble. What he discovers there changes everything. In the dim light of the alley, Charles sees a man attacking a young woman. Without thinking, he leaps forward and tackles the attacker, knocking him to the ground. The woman thanks Charles profusely before running off into the night. Shaken but unharmed, Charles returns home, where he tells his parents about what happened. His father is furious, accusing Charles of putting himself in danger unnecessarily. But Charles stands firm, insisting that he did what any decent person would have done. Over the next few months, Charles continues to visit Sarah regularly, despite his family's disapproval. He also takes steps to protect her, installing locks on her doors and windows and encouraging her to carry pepper spray. Meanwhile, the police continue to search for the serial killer, who seems to be targeting prostitutes and other vulnerable women. Then one day, tragedy strikes. A body is found near Sarah's house - another victim of the killer. Charles is devastated, knowing that he could have prevented this if only he'd been there sooner. Determined not to let anything happen to Sarah, he decides to move in with her temporarily until the killer is caught. At first, things go well between them. They spend every moment together, talking late into the night and exploring each other's minds. But gradually, tensions start to rise. Sarah feels suffocated by Charles' constant presence, while he struggles to understand why she doesn't appreciate his efforts to keep her safe. Eventually, their differences become too much to bear, and they decide to part ways. Heartbroken, Charles leaves London behind and moves back to his hometown. Years pass, and although he tries to forget about Sarah, he can't shake the memory of their brief time together. Finally, after many years apart, Charles receives word that Sarah has died suddenly. Grief-stricken, he travels back to London to attend her funeral. There, among the mourners, he spots a familiar face - the woman whose life he saved all those years ago. She approaches him tentatively, unsure whether he'll remember her. But when he does, tears spring to his eyes. "Thank you," she says softly. "For saving me." And then, without warning, she leans forward and kisses him gently on the cheek. For a moment, Charles is transported back to those early days with Sarah, when everything seemed possible. But reality quickly sets in, and he realizes that nothing can bring her back now. With heavy heart, he bids farewell to the city that once held such promise for him, vowing never to return.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
I'm not like you, I see differently. When I look at someone, I see into their future but I only get to see the worst part. Particularly their deaths, I see them in gruesome detail. I've seen car crashes, murders, stabbings and once, I even saw someone who would later die in a plane crash. I was n't always cursed this way, it all started after I was in a nearly fatal car crash, I woke up from a short coma and I could see the deaths of everyone around me. The doctors simply chalked it down to ptsd and gave me meds but I knew it was more that mere ptsd. I knew what I was seeing was n't just imagination. I even found a few people who were to die in a few days time and followed them up to see if they did and they did. All this time, I had not seen my own face in the mirror. I mean, I had seen it but half of it was still covered in bandages, still recovering from my injuries. Something I noticed about my death vision was that it only worked if I could see the entire face of the person. I could n't see the deaths of people who had their faces covered. This is why I figured, I could n't see mine yet and I was determined to keep it that way. I did n't wan na know how I died, I mean would you? Would you want to see how you died in gruesome detail? Of course not! After the bandages came off, I was very careful not to look at my complete reflection. Anytime I wanted to set my hair, I would tie a kerchief around my face. When I brushed my teeth, I wore a bandana, Shades and a scarf for good measure. The temptation to just look at my face in its entirety was hard to overcome but I did. I was traumatised enough by the deaths of others as it is. Shortly after the accident, I moved out of town into a sleepy little village and lived on my own. The fewer the people, the better for me. I lived in a tiny cottage with no reflective surfaces save for the tiny mirror in my bathroom that I kept covered by a cloth most of the time. This morning, I was brushing my teeth as usual and just as I was finishing, my bandana came lose and dropped into the sink. In my desperation to catch it, I undid the scarf and lo! I was staring at my naked face in the mirror. The world went black and I saw myself standing in complete darkness. Suddenly, a look of consternation came over me and I covered behind something. Shortly after a dark figure entered the place and after a short struggle, stabbed me. As I came out of my nightmarish reverie, gasping for breath after seeing myself die. I heard a loud crash in the house, suddenly the power went out. A look of consternation came over my face as I covered behind the bathroom door.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Sarah confides in Charles about her loneliness and despair.
output: She tells him she has been feeling depressed lately because she feels like she does n't have any friends. Sarah says she wishes she could find someone to talk to who understands her. Charles listens attentively and offers his support. He tells Sarah he knows exactly how she feels because he used to feel the same way when he first arrived at the school. Charles explains that he felt isolated and alone until he met some new friends. He encourages Sarah to try making new friends too. Sarah thanks Charles for listening to her and promises to think about what he said. Later that day, Sarah decides to take Charles ' advice and starts talking to other students during lunch break. She introduces herself to several girls sitting nearby and asks them questions about themselves. One girl named Emily seems particularly friendly and invites Sarah to join her group of friends. Sarah accepts the invitation and spends the rest of the week hanging out with Emily and her friends. Over time, Sarah begins to enjoy spending time with these girls and realizes she actually enjoys being social again. By the end of the month, Sarah has made many new friends and no longer feels so lonely. She credits Charles for helping her overcome her shyness and encouraging her to make new friends. Sarah also learns valuable lessons about friendship and communication through her interactions with Charles and her new friends. These experiences help shape her character and prepare her for future challenges in life.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
I never had any friend, not really surprising I guess. I learnt to not not judge people, we all have something scary or disgusting in our past but seeing it makes it really hard to socialize with anyone. I work as a detective, a private one, the kind that always know if someone is guilty. I was on wandering in a public hospital in order to find if yes or no Mr.wallace was lying to his daughter about his treatement. This was going to be a day that would change me for the rest of my life, as I walked through a corridor, heading to the hospital's archives room, something caught my eyes in a patient room, I stopped instantly and thought I was going crazy. in this room, there was an elder woman, probably 80, with her family, I was so confused by what I saw, or rather by what I did n't saw, I stayed at the door for what could have been hours before her family said goodbye to "Lucy", and left. I smiled, in fact I even laughed like never before, a nurse looked at me with a worried expression. I calmed myself and entered the room. She looked at me, just a bit surprised and I sat on the chair, close to her bed and asked probably sounding completely insane: -" How did you do?" my voice was trembling "never lied? never cheated? never hated someone? it's impossible..." my voice was completely broken and I felt tears on my face and my hands. She smiled back at me "what are you talking about young man? you should n't cry here! it's rude, I'm the one who is old and trapped here, go out and enjoy life" I did go out. It was so frustrating, what could I have said? I was waiting to meet someone like her pretty much since i was born, and all I could feel was hate, all my life I thought This someone COULD NOT exist and yet here was she.... I forgot about Mr.Wallace, I walked in the streets for some times. I stopped myself in front of a shop window, looked at my reflexion. They were here, all my sins, I could see them as clearly as on anyone else. A sad smile on my face, I went home, wrote this letter. My heart is heavy and my head even more, I need to end this.

Mikael Blomkvist is convicted of libel against Hans-Erik Wennerstrom.
output: He is sentenced to three months in prison and ordered to pay hefty damages. The verdict effectively destroys his professional reputation. Meanwhile, Lisbeth Salander has returned from abroad and notices Mikael's legal troubles in the press. She hacks into his computer and reads the correspondence between him and Erika Berger regarding the Wennerstrom affair. She also discovers that he has been investigating the disappearance of Harriet Vanger forty years earlier. Lisbeth decides to investigate both cases herself. She breaks into Wennerstrom's apartment and steals documents proving that he is a corrupt businessman. She then sends these documents anonymously to Mikael. Mikael uses the information to write an exposé of Wennerstrom, which is published in Millennium magazine. The article causes a sensation and restores Mikael's reputation. At the same time, Lisbeth solves the mystery of Harriet Vanger's disappearance. She discovers that Harriet was murdered by her brother Martin, who is now the CEO of the Vanger Corporation. Lisbeth confronts Martin and forces him to confess to the murder. She then kills him in self-defense. Mikael and Lisbeth become lovers. However, their relationship is complicated by the fact that Lisbeth is a ward of the state and is under the supervision of a guardian named Holger Palmgren. Palmgren is concerned about Lisbeth's mental health and wants her to undergo psychiatric treatment. Lisbeth refuses and runs away from home. She eventually returns to Stockholm and moves in with Mikael. The two of them continue to investigate crimes together. In the second book of the trilogy, The Girl Who Played with Fire, Lisbeth is accused of murdering three people. She goes on the run and is pursued by the police and the media. Mikael tries to clear her name, but he is hindered by the fact that Lisbeth does not trust him enough to tell him everything she knows. Eventually, Lisbeth is captured and put on trial. She is found guilty and sentenced to life in prison. However, she escapes from custody and goes into hiding. In the third book of the trilogy, The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet's Nest, Lisbeth is still on the run. She is being hunted by the Swedish Security Service (Säpo), who want to silence her because she knows too much about their illegal activities. Mikael continues to try to help her, but he is also targeted by Säpo. The two of them must fight for their lives as they try to expose the corruption within the Swedish government. The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo is a gripping thriller that will keep readers hooked until the very end. The characters are well-developed and the plot is full of twists and turns. If you're looking for a page-turner, this is the book for you!

I looked up in horror at the crowd of young boys came thundering into the room. The clouds on the walls were suddenly blocked by a horde of scrambling young bodies and flailing limbs. I froze, the hat on my head tilted just enough for me to see everything, and i saw fear. Andy stood there in the middle of the floor, clutching the dreaded spaceman box, but that seemed to matter less compared to the pressing matter. The air was still, I could feel Mr.Potato head's round eyes blink and the sound of heavy breathing from the guests penetrated the silence with jagged blades of uncertainty. I considered freezing, but it was too late. We all knew it. Rex panicked like a child who came down christmas morning to find no gifts. He thundered across the hardwood floors for the window, yelling at the top of his lungs some inaudible dinosaur screech. I spun around, knowing it was too late and pointed towards the window. The toys did n't need a second prompt. The strong man and Mr. Potato head grabbed the monkeys in a barrel, hopped in RC and gunned the engines. The army men attempted to rescue some of the less mobile toys, but it was too late. One brilliant child had the idea to grab my waist with his sweaty, greasy hand and hold me up in the air. I put up a fight, hoping to distract them enough to let everyone escape. I did n't know what would happen, but panic had overrun my emotions and pure terror coursed through my plastic veins. But then, salvation. Andy wrenched me from the child's grasp and shouted angrily "YOU ONLY GOT ME BEDSHEETS." He held me gently in his grasp and managed to utter "Woody?" I stared back up at him with and sorrow filled my soul. I knew this was it, the other toys were out. "I'm sorry Andy, you'll understand one day." I flung my sack cloth limbs out of his hand and towards the bed, hitting it with surprising force. I propelled myself towards the window, clear through the slit. The other toys were already at the edge of the law waiting for me, but I had to look back at least once. Andy stared out the window with a look of pure despair on his face and one confused spaceman peered back, blinking quizzically towards the small group of toys, running down the street; never to return.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Blomkvist receives a mysterious job offer from Henrik Vanger.
output: Vanger is the patriarch of the wealthy Vanger family, which owns a large industrial corporation. He lives on Hedeby Island, near the town of Hedestad in northern Sweden. Forty years ago, Harriet, Vanger's niece, disappeared without a trace. Local police have made little effort to solve the case as almost everyone believes she drowned, committed suicide, or otherwise died accidentally. Vanger, however, is convinced that someone in his family murdered her. He offers Blomkvist a year's employment documenting the Vanger family history, as well as providing evidence that will allow him to identify Harriet's killer. Blomkvist takes the job, partly because he hopes to unearth the scandalous truth behind the Vangers' corrupt financial activities. He moves onto the island and begins his research. As he digs deeper into the Vanger family's past, he discovers a number of disturbing facts. For example, he learns that Harriet's brother Martin was a member of the Nazi party during World War II. He also finds out that several members of the Vanger clan were involved in illegal business dealings. These discoveries lead Blomkvist to suspect that Harriet may not have been killed after all. Instead, he thinks she might have faked her own death so she could escape from her abusive father. To prove his theory, Blomkvist enlists the help of Lisbeth Salander, a skilled computer hacker who works for Milton Security. Together they investigate the Vanger family further, uncovering more secrets along the way. Eventually they discover that Harriet is alive and living under a new identity in Australia. She reveals that she fled Sweden because her father sexually abused her when she was younger. With this information, Blomkvist confronts Henrik Vanger, demanding answers. However, before he can get any further, Henrik suffers a heart attack and dies. His son, Hans-Erik, takes over control of the company and orders Blomkvist to leave immediately. Before leaving, Blomkvist manages to steal some important documents relating to the Vanger family's shady business practices. Once back in Stockholm, Blomkvist publishes these documents online, exposing the Vangers' corruption to the world. This causes a huge scandal, leading to the downfall of the entire Vanger empire. In the end, Blomkvist decides to stay in Sweden and continue working as a journalist. Meanwhile, Lisbeth returns to her old life as a freelance investigator. They remain friends, although their relationship remains platonic.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
I never had any friend, not really surprising I guess. I learnt to not not judge people, we all have something scary or disgusting in our past but seeing it makes it really hard to socialize with anyone. I work as a detective, a private one, the kind that always know if someone is guilty. I was on wandering in a public hospital in order to find if yes or no Mr.wallace was lying to his daughter about his treatement. This was going to be a day that would change me for the rest of my life, as I walked through a corridor, heading to the hospital's archives room, something caught my eyes in a patient room, I stopped instantly and thought I was going crazy. in this room, there was an elder woman, probably 80, with her family, I was so confused by what I saw, or rather by what I did n't saw, I stayed at the door for what could have been hours before her family said goodbye to "Lucy", and left. I smiled, in fact I even laughed like never before, a nurse looked at me with a worried expression. I calmed myself and entered the room. She looked at me, just a bit surprised and I sat on the chair, close to her bed and asked probably sounding completely insane: -" How did you do?" my voice was trembling "never lied? never cheated? never hated someone? it's impossible..." my voice was completely broken and I felt tears on my face and my hands. She smiled back at me "what are you talking about young man? you should n't cry here! it's rude, I'm the one who is old and trapped here, go out and enjoy life" I did go out. It was so frustrating, what could I have said? I was waiting to meet someone like her pretty much since i was born, and all I could feel was hate, all my life I thought This someone COULD NOT exist and yet here was she.... I forgot about Mr.Wallace, I walked in the streets for some times. I stopped myself in front of a shop window, looked at my reflexion. They were here, all my sins, I could see them as clearly as on anyone else. A sad smile on my face, I went home, wrote this letter. My heart is heavy and my head even more, I need to end this.

Blomkvist agrees to investigate the disappearance of Harriet Vanger.
output: He moves into a cottage on the island where the Vangers live. He meets Lisbeth Salander, a computer hacker who has done research on him. Blomkvist hires her to help him with the investigation. They discover that Harriet's uncle, Gottfried, was a Nazi sympathizer during World War II. They also learn that Harriet's father, Henrik, was involved in a business deal with Gottfried that went sour. Henrik believes that Gottfried killed Harriet because he knew too much about the business deal. Blomkvist and Salander continue their investigation and eventually uncover evidence that proves that Gottfried did kill Harriet. They confront Gottfried and he confesses to the murder. The police arrest Gottfried and charge him with Harriet's murder. Blomkvist and Salander return to Stockholm. Blomkvist writes a book about the case and it becomes a bestseller. Salander returns to her job as a computer hacker. One night, while working late, she receives a phone call from a man named Zalachenko. He tells her that he knows who she is and that he wants to meet her. Salander agrees to meet him. When they meet, Zalachenko reveals that he is her father. He explains that he was a Soviet spy who defected to Sweden during the Cold War. He says that he was forced to leave behind his wife and child when he fled Russia. He asks Salander to forgive him for abandoning her. Salander refuses to forgive him and leaves. Later, she learns that Zalachenko has been murdered. She suspects that her half-brother, Nils Bjurman, may have been responsible for the murder. She decides to investigate further. She discovers that Bjurman is a corrupt lawyer who has been blackmailing clients. She also learns that he has been sexually abusing women. Salander decides to take revenge on Bjurman. She breaks into his apartment and ties him up. She then proceeds to torture him until he confesses to everything. She then kills him. Afterwards, she goes to the police station and turns herself in. She is arrested and charged with murder. However, due to lack of evidence, she is released on bail. She returns to her apartment and finds that it has been ransacked. She realizes that someone must have known about her plan to kill Bjurman. She begins to suspect that her former employer, Milton Security, may have been involved. She contacts Blomkvist and tells him about her suspicions. Together, they decide to investigate Milton Security. They discover that the company is run by a group of corrupt businessmen who are involved in illegal activities such as money laundering and arms dealing. They also learn that the company has connections to the Russian mafia. Blomkvist and Salander decide to expose Milton Security. They write a book about the company and its illegal activities. The book becomes a bestseller and causes a scandal. The owners of Milton Security are arrested and charged with various crimes. The company is shut down. Blomkvist and Salander become famous for their work. They receive numerous awards and accolades. They also become wealthy. However, they remain haunted by the events of the past. They both struggle with guilt and regret over the things they have done. In the end, they realize that they can never truly escape their pasts. They accept this and move on with their lives.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
We attack immediately at sundown, once their solar power cells are no longer generating power and they are instead using stored power. Forcing the enemy to rely on finite reserves is a good strategy. From our intel gathering and scouting missions we know the machines' first response will be to send two robots per every identified threat. Not a bad bit of logic on their part. The wolves were able to acquire video of some of the human assaults. We can confirm each localized machine hub will have, at minimum, 50000 robot responders. Luckily, we have some numbers. The machines decided not to bury the dead or finish off the wounded humans but to ship them away from the machine hubs. The wolf and bat armies grew after each human battle. Intel reports also bolstered our confidence that the robots would have diminished ability to fend off our armies. The machines graciously eliminated silver from any of their infrastructure, preferring either denser or more conductive metal depending on the situation. The machines also eliminated religion from their human cattle, ending the scourge of crosses or other offending accoutrements. Also, the machines removed unnecessary costs in generating food for their human cattle, including flavorings such as garlic. We've coordinated our attack with other armies across the world. Tonight's sunset heralds our initial assault, beginning in the pacific and escalating westward as the sun's influence retreats behind the horizon. We have factored in failure to our first battle. Armies will retreat north to arctic regions taking advantage of the extended nights. Getting our allies from the southern hemisphere to agree that we should retake the northern hemisphere first was hard, the logistics of getting them north of the equator to join our armies was doubly so. We've drawn up a general strategy for every localized unit to follow, leaving room for them to improvise should any unforeseen complications arise. At sunset, send 50000 foot soldiers to each hub. Once the robots stop pouring out of the hub we set off EMPs. The humans discovered this only gained them around 30 seconds of disorientation within the robots. Immediately following the EMPs we electrify the magnets we've buried in the ground. A functioning robot can not be immobilized by a magnet. A disoriented one, however will be more susceptible. After that we fight. A hopefully diminished robot army will now be fighting what they will perceive as humans an large dogs. That's where our superhuman strength, speed, agility, and healing capabilities will come into play. During the ground assault a smaller team is to sever all outside communications from each hub. Disrupted communications should at least slow down global coordination with other hubs. We wanted to take out their communications before each assault, however the machines' penchant for redundancy and underground infrastructure proved cumbersome. It was decided to utilize the distraction of our infantry attacks as the opportunity to get around access issues. Watching the seconds tick by waiting for our signal to move should be nothing compared to the centuries I've been hiding underground waiting to resurface. Sadly this is not the case. I'm comforted by thoughts of global supremacy should we succeed. I'm not looking forward to the inevitable Werewolf/Vampire war that will take place after our victory over the machines. We'll have to deal with that problem when it comes, I suppose. For right now it's time to transform into a wolf. I've got some metal to munch.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Lisbeth Salander is introduced as a skilled hacker with a troubled past.
output:
She has a history of being abused and neglected, which has led her to develop a strong sense of independence and self-reliance. Despite her difficult upbringing, Lisbeth is highly intelligent and resourceful, making her a valuable asset to those who seek her help.

One day, Lisbeth receives a request from Mikael Blomkvist, a journalist who is investigating a high-profile murder case. He believes that Lisbeth's hacking skills could be useful in uncovering information that could lead to the killer's identity.

Lisbeth agrees to help Mikael, and together they begin to investigate the case. They soon discover that the murder is connected to a larger conspiracy involving powerful individuals who are willing to do anything to protect their secrets.

As they delve deeper into the investigation, Lisbeth and Mikael find themselves in danger. They are pursued by dangerous criminals who will stop at nothing to keep their secrets hidden.

Despite the risks, Lisbeth remains determined to uncover the truth. She uses her hacking skills to gain access to sensitive information and track down leads that others might miss.

As the investigation progresses, Lisbeth begins to form a bond with Mikael. They work closely together, relying on each other's strengths to overcome obstacles and stay ahead of their enemies.

Eventually, Lisbeth and Mikael uncover the truth behind the murder and expose the corrupt individuals responsible. Their actions bring justice to the victim's family and put an end to the conspiracy.

In the aftermath of the investigation, Lisbeth reflects on her experiences. She realizes that she has grown stronger and more confident through her work with Mikael. She also recognizes the importance of standing up for what is right, even in the face of great danger.

Overall, Lisbeth Salander is a complex character who is driven by a desire for justice and a need to prove herself. Her intelligence and resourcefulness make her a formidable opponent, while her troubled past gives her a unique perspective on the world. Through her journey, she learns the value of teamwork and the importance of standing up for what is right, even when it means putting herself in harm's way.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Salander becomes the victim of abuse by her guardian Nils Bjurman.
output: When Salander refuses to perform sexual favors for him, he rapes her. In retaliation, Salander uses a taser to subdue Bjurman and tattoos him on his stomach, reading: "I am a sadistic pig, a pervert, and a rapist." She also steals his laptop computer, which contains evidence of his crimes against her. Salander then blackmails Bjurman into granting her control of her own finances. Meanwhile, Blomkvist has begun investigating the disappearance of Harriet Vanger, who vanished on Children's Day in 1966. The case has remained unsolved for decades, and Henrik Vanger, Harriet's uncle and CEO of the Vanger Corporation, suspects that a member of his own family murdered her. He hires Blomkvist to investigate. Blomkvist moves to the Vanger estate and begins working with Salander, who provides research assistance. They discover that Harriet had been compiling a list of names of young women before her disappearance; these women were later found murdered after being tortured. Salander hacks into the computers of several members of the Vanger family and discovers that Martin Vanger, Harriet's brother, is a serial killer who has been murdering women for years. Blomkvist confronts Martin, who confesses to the murders and reveals that he killed Harriet because she discovered his secret. Martin attempts to kill Blomkvist, but Salander intervenes and kills Martin. Blomkvist and Salander expose the Vanger family's secrets to the public, leading to the downfall of the corporation. Salander leaves Sweden and travels to Gibraltar, where she lives under an assumed name. Blomkvist continues to work as a journalist and writes a book about the Vanger case. The novel ends with Salander returning to Sweden and reuniting with Blomkvist.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Jonas feels apprehensive about the Ceremony of Twelve.
output:
He has always been a good student, but he knows that his future depends on the Assignment he receives today. As he waits for his turn, Jonas thinks about his friends Asher and Fiona. They both seem excited about their Assignments, but Jonas wonders if they truly understand the significance of the day.

When Jonas' name is called, he steps forward nervously. The Chief Elder begins to speak, but Jonas can barely hear her over the pounding of his own heart. Finally, the Chief Elder announces Jonas' Assignment: Receiver of Memory.

Jonas is stunned. He had never even considered such a prestigious role. But as he listens to the Chief Elder describe the responsibilities of the Receiver, Jonas realizes that he is uniquely qualified for the position.

As Jonas leaves the Auditorium, he is filled with a sense of purpose. He knows that he must use his new knowledge wisely, and he is determined to do just that.

In the days that follow, Jonas meets with the Giver, the previous Receiver of Memory. The Giver helps Jonas to access the memories of the community, and Jonas is amazed by what he learns.

He sees the beauty of nature, the joy of love, and the pain of loss. He also witnesses the horrors of war and the cruelty of humanity.

But through it all, Jonas remains hopeful. He believes that there is goodness in the world, and he is determined to find it.

One day, while exploring the memories, Jonas comes across a memory of a young boy named Gabriel. Gabriel is different from the other children in the community; he is full of energy and curiosity.

Jonas is immediately drawn to Gabriel, and he decides to help him escape from the community. With the help of the Giver, Jonas creates a plan to smuggle Gabriel out of the community and into the unknown.

On the night of the escape, Jonas and Gabriel say goodbye to the Giver. Then, they set off into the darkness, unsure of what lies ahead.

But Jonas is confident that they will find a better life beyond the boundaries of the community. And as they journey into the unknown, Jonas holds onto hope that they will find happiness together.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
The problem with personality is that so much of it depends on what happened during your life. There are certain things that change you for better or worse. I wish I could say that all the accumulated knowledge, wisdom and memories stay but each time we start again, it's like a reset on most things. Thomas was having another party according to his Facebook update. I remember the last time I was invited to one, he gave me a list of things to bring and I did, except no one else was there. He gave me the location of a lifeguard tower at the beach that they were at, except it did n't actually exist. I have a flask tucked into my jacket pocket on the chair with the potion that will set my plan into motion if I decide to try again. I'm still not sure if this is what I want to do, raising him again and starting over is an impossibility because he might not even be healthy enough to raise me so that I have a chance of repeating our plans again. The thing is, I'm still not sure about how I feel about not letting him know about his genetic predisposition for heart failure this time. I decided a few tries ago that this had too much of a negative impact whenever I told him, no matter how old he was when I did. Too many times I witnessed him going down the wrong path with drugs because of this. He's in college and happy now, not a care in the world. He has a slight idea of our plan this time even though he suspects it's just a story I used to tell to help him cope with being abandoned by his real parents. I've thought about this and if I really wanted to, I could just let him live normally. I could let him find out on his own. I know he's smart and might even figure something out. Medicine has advanced tremendously since we started. Personally, I feel like I've had enough of this life business but I'm not sure if I should make this choice for him. Maybe I was wrong and I ca n't reverse engineer what my friend used to be. He looks at me as a father figure and I guess that's understandable, I'm old enough to be his grandfather by now. So I decide to do what my heart tells me is right. I take the flask that I asked my lawyer to mail to me and pour it into my bedpan until the very last drop is gone.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Jonas' family talks about their feelings and dreams.
output: Jonas is surprised to learn that his mother does not dream. She says she never has. His father explains that some people don't dream, and that it doesn't mean anything bad. Jonas asks if he can go to the House of the Old to see Fiona. His father agrees, but warns him not to ask any questions. When Jonas arrives at the House of the Old, he finds Fiona sitting alone in her room. She seems sad and lonely. Jonas sits next to her and takes her hand. He tells her that he misses her, and that he wishes she could come back home with him. Fiona smiles sadly and says that she would love to come back home, but she knows that she can't. She tells Jonas that she loves him very much, and that she hopes he will always remember her. Jonas promises to remember her forever. As he leaves the House of the Old, Jonas feels a deep sadness inside himself. He realizes that he will never see Fiona again, and that he will miss her every day for the rest of his life. But he also knows that he must move on, and that he must continue living his own life without her. Jonas returns home and goes to bed early. That night, he dreams of Fiona. In his dream, she is young and beautiful again. They are together in a field of flowers, laughing and playing. It is a wonderful dream, and Jonas wakes up feeling happy and content. He knows that he will always carry Fiona in his heart, and that she will always be a part of him. Even though she is gone, she will never truly leave him. And that is enough for Jonas. He knows that he will be okay, and that he will find happiness again someday. For now, he will simply cherish the memory of Fiona, and hold onto the hope that they will meet again in another life.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
The moment I saw her deep blue eyes I knew she was the one. It was a feeling I had never felt before it was like everything that was wrong was suddenly right. She didn' t care for me at first but after several attempts she finally agreed to go out with me. The following were the best months of my life. I lived in an extreme state of happiness and pleasure. Everything that was once mundane was now exciting and fresh, I had never enjoyed walks on the beach or being aroused by a simple touch of her hand. One day she fell ill. The doctors tried everything but nothing seemed to work. Her deep blue eyes were tired and lacked the light that once captivate me. It was devastating to see her in a hospital bed waiting for her life to end. All I wanted was to be with her until the end. It was then that I took action. I read all the books.I knew how it worked but I had never done it. I never had a reason to do it. I bought the roses, the lambs heart, and I captured the laugh of a child. It was a simple ritual it will take one year of life to give her one more day of life. I lit the candles, prayed the mantras, poured my blood over the white roses, stuffed the lamb with the roses and released the laugh of the child. I didn' t feel any change at the moment but the next day I noticed small wrinkles in my face. I did the ritual every night until my hair was covered in grays. She was not getting better but she had not worsen. She was just there, laying in that hospital bed with no pain and still as beautiful as the first day I saw her. As I kissed her goodnight she plead for me to stop. "I am ready to go" she whispered in my ear, "it' s too much. You have given me three more wonderful weeks with you. Let me go." But I couldn' t. How dare she ask me to let her go, to let everything we have built together vanish with her absence? I had never loved someone so much I could never let her go. I had never been so angry with her, with life, with the world. That was the night I took my first life. This time it took no ritual just a blade to the heart. Poor man never saw it coming, one moment he was peacefully sleeping on an alley and the next one he was granting me one more year of life, one more day in her life. I did n't like taking a life but I would do anything for her. One day while I payed her a visit I lost all sense of me. I woke up two days later in a hospital bed. I panicked. I tried to get up but she hold my hand. She was next to me waiting for me to wake up. She curled next to me in bed and whispered in my ear "I am ready are you?" "Anything for you" I answered. She kissed me and then it all went black.
