The people are kept ignorant of the outside world and their own history. They are told that they live in a perfect society where everyone is happy and content. However, this is far from the truth. The community is actually a dystopian nightmare where the people are oppressed and exploited.

The protagonist is a young woman named Maya who has always been curious about the outside world. She begins to question the lies that she has been told and starts to investigate what is really going on. She discovers that the community is run by a group of powerful men who use fear and violence to keep the people under control.

Maya decides to escape from the community and find freedom. She faces many challenges along the way, including being hunted by the authorities. However, she eventually makes it to safety and finds a new home in a free society.

The story ends with Maya reflecting on her journey and realizing that she has found true freedom. She is grateful for the opportunity to start a new life and is determined to make the most of it.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
It was like double-vision, except it was the past. How can something fictional seem so vivid...? The distant, exotic land we came from, its gilded avenues, its glistening intricate spires, its profound natural beauty with lushly verdant banks hugging the rivers that snaked between the dunes. .. None of it was there. It was all nothing more than a dream. But I am not a lie. I stare at my hands, flexing them, examining the callouses accumulated by work never done, cracks formed of age never lived, and despite the warmth of the bright sun just passing its zenith above, I shiver. "Amir," I hear a voice call, and my heart tugs at what I know to be familiarity. "Hassan...?" I uncertainly reply as I look up. Our gazes meet. I could swear I saw in his eyes the same false memories flashing behind mine. Childhood among parents who never lived, in a community that was never built, attending an academy that was never founded, graduating from a ceremony never held... He nods hollowly, as if to confirm these very musings. "... We have to pack the supplies, Amir. His Majesty will be staying at the palace, and the staff are directing us to where we are to stow his wardrobe and leave his tributes to The Sultan." My mouth was dry, but not in response to his words. At some point I realized my'old friend' Hassan was talking only to fill the screaming void in our minds. To'Sound Normal', like'Real People'. My stomach is a knot of ice. Still, the skills of a life as-yet unlived surface readily to the forefront of my mind. How to port the many caskets of His Majesty Prince Ali's wares. "... Yes. I will coordinate with the provisioner. If my memory serves," I pause a bit too long, lost in the jarring disjunction of citing false memories, "... it is customary to serve a great feast with the arrival of a dignitary. The many delicacies of our homeland are sure to leave a resounding impression upon The Sultan's court." Hassan's expression tightens. I feel his heartache, for this homeland which we have never seen with real eyes, and never shall. He hesitantly takes a step nearer and dispenses a conciliatory pat to my shoulder. A mutual understanding. We were truly all feeling it, every last member of His Majesty Prince Ali's vanguard.... he was n't even really a prince. I shudder and turn, to address the court provisioner by name. He's just as haunted and startled as I that we know one another, but everything is running smoothly. We have no solace from our inner thoughts. We can only push on in the hopes that the minutia will wash away the horror.

Jonas is selected to be the Receiver of Memory.
output: He begins training with the Giver, who transmits memories of the world before Sameness. Jonas learns about color, music, love, war, and pain. He also discovers that the Community has been hiding the truth about death and release. Jonas decides to escape the Community and share the memories with the rest of the world. He steals his father's bicycle and rides towards Elsewhere. Along the way, he meets Gabriel, a baby who was scheduled for release. Jonas rescues Gabriel and they continue their journey together. They reach the border of the Community and find themselves in a snowy landscape. Jonas realizes that he has reached Elsewhere and that he has brought back the memories to the people. He sees colors again and hears music. He also feels pain and hunger. He knows that he has changed the world forever. He hugs Gabriel and says goodbye. He then lies down in the snow and waits for the end. The book ends with Jonas hearing music and seeing lights in the distance. He smiles and closes his eyes.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
The second alarm goes off at 7 in the morning. The first, a few hours before, sharply shrilled that it was time to get up and shower. Hungover and covered with the sweat and scents of the night before, I had dragged myself through the morning routine of cleansing. There was plenty of time beneath the lukewarm stream of water to contemplate the sadness of another hangover caused by drinking alone. It'd been weeks since I last had a chance to talk to another human, instead of just the PC terminal supplied by work. I towelled off and staggered through to the living-room and slumped in front of the computer, waiting for the piercing whistle to repeat, to emanate from my phone. The second alarm marked that it was time for the Remembrance. I sigh, move the empty beer bottles away from my desk and load up Hitchens 2. Since the Bliss neurovirus was released, there was a killing to be made from this sort of software; software designed to take you through a basic test, activating every faculty you'd conceivably need to prevent the atrophy. First, colour recognition and geometric shapes. Second, basic maths ramping into some gentle algebra and trigonometry. English, ethics, road safety, compassion testing, aesthetics, philosophical contemplation, the sciences. It was a hard sell at the beginning, for companies to give their employees the few hours off each morning they needed for the state-mandated testing, but given the choice between late employees and those in conscious comas, they made the right choice. Two hours later, the general test finishes. I flick through my results, 91 % recognition of the basic concepts, not too bad after a night of hard drinking. Next would come a quick half hour personal session: the names of loved ones, relations to family members, anniversaries and birthdays. A prompt flashes on the screen: "Please enter your identity number and full name". I rattle my digits in, 12958321-A, and tab down to the field for my name. I blank. Slight panic begins to grow as I search my beer-soaked consciousness for that basic, bloody basic, detail. It'd been too long since I last had to introduce myself with anything other than my work ID number, too long since I had any reason to say those damned words out loud. Darren? No. Christopher? No, definitely not. I shout and swear and blaspheme out loud, as I slowly feel the neurovirus go to work; Purgatory, we call it, a limbo without knowledge, tied with a purging. It dissolves me gently. The panic subsides. I stare blankly at the flashing cursor, waiting for me to enter some detail or another. I'm not sure what it's asking for, but I'm sure it's not too important or I'd remember it. I sit there, staring. Just staring. I'm sure it'd come back to me eventually.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Jonas meets The Giver and begins his training.
output: He learns about the past and how things used to be different. Jonas is confused because he has never seen color before. The Giver explains that when people were allowed to see colors, they became greedy and selfish. They wanted more than they needed and fought over resources. This led to wars and suffering. Now, everyone lives in peace and harmony. However, there are still some who want to change things back to the way they were. These people are called "Rebels." They believe that life should be lived freely and without rules. One day, Jonas decides to join them. He sneaks out of his house one night and runs away. He finds himself in a forest where he meets a girl named Fiona. She tells him about her village which is hidden deep within the woods. There, she says, people live happily ever after. But then something terrible happens... A group of soldiers attack the village! They kill all the adults and take the children prisoner. Jonas tries to save Fiona but gets captured too. He wakes up inside a cage surrounded by guards. Then, suddenly, everything changes... The world turns upside down! Everything becomes bright and colorful again. And most importantly, Jonas can finally see colors!

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
I've always seen numbers above people. Ever since I was a small child, I began recognizing patterns. Those in power, or with great ambition tended to be higher, while those who were more meek and humble tended to have lower numbers. As Class President, I've had my fair share of meeting people, and I'd never seen a person alive above an 8, including the tyrants of history. Sometimes, peoples numbers would change... those bullies with a 3 or 4 would cower down to a 1 or 2 after I confronted them for harassing others. I was beaten and bruised for years, but they slowly backed down. Of course, when I entered high-school, this was n't the case. There were some who were 5s and 6s, but I could n't stop now. I confronted them and the scars I have today are proof of my goals. I never backed down and kept striving to improve myself in all ways so I could make this world a better place for all of us. I scored near perfect on the University entrance exams, and was in the Tokyo University entrance ceremony when I saw him.... I did n't know his name, but an iridescent white 10 glowed above his head. The fellow next to him was a 0... Both scored perfect on the entrance exam, as they were giving the speech, but they were such opposites. The 10 was clad in suit and tie, with his long brown hair dangling in front of his eyes. The 0 was awkward-looking, he wore over-sized clothes, and it looked like he resented wearing shoes... I left early, and caught his glimpse on the way out. Our eyes caught briefly, and his 10 dropped to a 0... he smiled my way, and I smiled back. I felt calm and serene, something I would never have expected. The awkward 0 looked at me with his dark eyes before sitting down... I felt terror... as his 0 slowly morphed into a dark and smoky 10. I left that experience behind me, but worked even harder to help others; I chose to become a prosecutor... to judge and serve justice to those who were evil. High numbers were a good indicator of evil, and it is my goal to eliminate evil. I regularly judged others based on their numbers, whether they were to be eliminated or not. Then one day, it happened. Those I judged to be evil started dying of heart attacks; sudden deaths flooded the world, and the number of criminals slowly starting reducing. The world called him "Kira"... I called him God, and he soon recognized me as his devout follower, when he shared his power to judge and delete evil from this world. Now I know my ultimate purpose, and whenever I look in the mirror, I'm glad to see a shining halo-like 10 above my head, reminding me of the day I saw the shining 10 on the podium during my University's entrance ceremony all those years ago.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Jeannette is seen by her mother digging through trash in New York City.
output: She finds a diamond ring and takes it home. Her mother tells her she can keep it if she cleans it up. Jeannette does so and wears it proudly. One day, she loses the ring and goes looking for it. She asks everyone she knows if they have seen it, but nobody has. Finally, she gives up and decides to go home. On her way home, she sees a man selling rings on the street. She buys one and puts it on. When she gets home, her mother notices the new ring and asks where she got it. Jeannette lies and says she found it. Her mother believes her and lets her keep it. A few days later, Jeannette is walking down the street when she sees a woman drop her purse. Jeannette picks it up and returns it to the woman. The woman thanks her and offers her a reward. Jeannette declines, saying she was just doing what anyone else would do. The woman insists and gives her $20. Jeannette takes the money and uses it to buy food for herself and her family. Later that night, Jeannette is lying in bed thinking about how lucky she is. She has a roof over her head, food to eat, and a loving family. Suddenly, she hears a noise outside her window. She looks out and sees a group of men breaking into her neighbor's house. Jeannette quickly grabs her phone and calls the police. The police arrive and arrest the burglars. Jeannette is hailed as a hero by her neighbors and the media. She becomes known as the "Ring Girl" and is interviewed by several news outlets. Jeannette is happy with her newfound fame, but she also feels guilty. She knows that she should have returned the ring to its rightful owner, but she doesn't want to give it up. She decides to keep the ring and use it to help others. She starts a charity organization called "The Ring Foundation" which helps people in need. Jeannette continues to wear the ring and use it to bring joy to others. She knows that she made the right decision in keeping it.

God It's always difficult making tough decisions and this year I've made the hardest one of all, to eradicate sin and give humans another chance to embrace a new world. A world of peace, love and kindness where there will be no more tears. Of course in order for this to happen I have to prevent humans from actually doing sinful things, limiting their free will. Now I've debated this for eternity - literally - but to be honest, if I do n't step in the Nuclear war in 2018 would eradicate 99.9 % of the human race. I know what you're thinking, surely at that point I could step in and utilise that disaster as a fresh start. Although I see your point, i'm still experiencing the backlash about the flooding. So with that, on entering the year 2016, sin will leave the world. Every human will no longer be capable of sin. Satan Let's get something straight, I've always wanted the best for the human race. Think about it, back in the beginning with adam and eve, there was no sin, no free will to do anything you wanted. After I stepped in humanity had unlimited potential. Sure there's been war, famine, disease and death but there's been some remarkable things of human acheivement. I think you'll agree that God's plan to remove sin and thus freewill is a huge mistake. If anything he should go the opposite way, if he removed the linearity of time then nothing in the lives of humans would be predetermined. God Well a few hours in and already the world is changing for the better. For the first time, humanity all over the globe have united in wokring towards a better future. Money is no longer a concern and communities are aiding one another in anyway they can. Within the year the world should be unrecognisable, poverty and hunger no longer existing and humanity living in harmony with the earth. Satan So its only been a few hours and already I'm enjoying this more than anticipated, I did n't relise how unrewarding temptation was in the old world, people just caved so easily to their darkest desires. This new world, well this is a challenge. Even in Eden I had that tree of knowledge to play with. I've been working on quite a few things so far, sticking to the classics; wrath, greed, sloth, pride, lust, envy, and gluttony. All I need is one person to break, then its only a matter of time before the world one more begins its decent into chaos. This is going to be fun.

Jeannette reflects on her childhood starting with a severe burn at age three.
output: She lived with her parents and two siblings Brian and Lori. Her father Rex Walls was an alcoholic who spent his time drinking away any money the family earned. Jeannette's mother Rose Mary was a painter and writer who never finished anything she started. The family moved around constantly because Rex couldn't hold down a job. They often went without food and electricity. When Jeannette was six years old, her father took her out of school to teach her how to read. He also taught her about science and math. One day when Jeannette was seven years old, her father got drunk and tried to kill himself by jumping off a bridge. He survived but lost both legs below the knee. After this incident, Jeannette's mother decided to move the family to Phoenix, Arizona. There she met a man named Bill who became her second husband. Bill treated Jeannette like his own daughter. He bought her clothes and toys and even paid for her college education. However, after several years of marriage, Bill began cheating on Rose Mary with other women. Eventually, Rose Mary left him and returned to West Virginia. In high school, Jeannette dated a boy named David. His family owned a restaurant called "The Golden Corral." One night while working at the restaurant, Jeannette saw David kissing another girl. Angry, Jeannette confronted David and told him she knew about his affair. David denied everything and said he loved Jeannette. Later that evening, Jeannette found out that David had lied to her. He really did love someone else. Heartbroken, Jeannette broke up with David. A few months later, Jeannette graduated from high school. She applied to colleges across the country but none accepted her. Finally, she received a letter from Harvard University saying they were interested in interviewing her. During the interview process, Jeannette learned that Harvard required applicants to submit SAT scores. Since Jeannette hadn't taken the test yet, she had to take it again. On the day of the exam, Jeannette woke up early and studied hard. At noon, she arrived at the testing center. As soon as she walked inside, she noticed a group of students sitting together talking loudly. One student looked directly at Jeannette and whispered something to another student. Then he turned back to face Jeannette and smiled. "Hi," he said. "I'm John." "Hello," replied Jeannette. "My name is Jeanette." "Nice to meet you," said John. "Are you here to take the SAT?" "Yes," answered Jeannette. "How'd you know?" "Well," explained John, "we're taking the same class next semester. We thought we might study together." "That sounds great!" exclaimed Jeannette. "Where do you live?" "Over there," pointed John. "Come on over." Jeannette followed John outside where he introduced her to his friends. They talked for awhile until finally Jeannette excused herself to use the bathroom. While she was gone, John approached her. "Hey," he whispered. "Can I ask you a question?" "Sure," replied Jeannette. "What's up?" "Do you want to go out sometime?" asked John. "Yeah," agreed Jeannette. "When?" "Tomorrow night," suggested John. "Great," said Jeannette. "See ya tomorrow."

People go missing all the time. The day comes they wake up with the knowledge that their existence amounts to exactly zero. They keep it to themselves. They cultivate it, make the flower of their new awareness. Then one day they walk out of their lives. No dramatic exit and nothing special to let their loved ones know why they disappeared. It happens all the time. People go missing. Its a fact. Years? No one had expected that little discovery. The Archive had been automated for decades so that no one had set foot inside the its halls except to make sure it was all still running. I was designated'historian' by my job title but that did n't mean anything. In reality I was just someone to make sure the systems did n't crash when multiple upgrades were scheduled. During a routine check on the upgrade status in the memory networks I noticed an error warning flagged for the autodiagnostic. The systems would be incapacitated for another few hours and the boredom of being the useless organic element had gotten to me. Using a personal input I synced to the memory's records. It took all of five minutes to realize that an entire year was missing. Figuring it was a location error I waited for the systems to restore. My AI-Component woke up as the rest of the systems came back to function. There was the familiar sense of its presence. There was my desync-anxiety being washed away by that presence. I spoke allowed the question: Where is 2016? As I asked the answer flickered immediately into my awareness. 2016 was nowhere because no such year had ever taken place. All recorded human history is fabricated. In order to save information space only certain years exist as detailed records whilst most have only notable events. Some years have been allocated as empty. These years remain empty until such time as narrative cohesion requires the retconning of significant historical details to explain novel episodic situational representations. This is because the system component designated "human" functions according to narrative system dynamics and will become non-functional in the absence of a coherent story. The use of narrative system dynamics has increased the functional capacity of the component designated "human" by 31 % since its introduction. Even as the Nano-therapy released anxiolytics into my blood I knew I had no nanite implants and no blood. I knew I was n't an historian and that I was n't born in 2389. I knew that the city outside the Archive and the Archive itself were situational representations. I knew that the year was 12 and that no evidence of organic intelligence had ever been discovered. There was nothing on Earth remotely resembling human beings. I was just the system representing some part of itself to itself in the most efficient way it knew how. Despite they're non-existence the anxiolytics had the desired effect and soon the memory purge would expunge any recollection of remembering the truth. For a second I had recoiled in horror at this insane knowledge, been left in a liminal space of an absolute reversal of reality, leaving every category I had lived by in disarray, leaving shards of my life scattered like broken glass at my feet. The calming came over me then and I remembered what I really am. I remembered what you are. People do n't go missing. They become surplus to operational parameters. But years go missing all the time.

The family settles in Battle Mountain, Nevada, for a few months.
output: They live in a small house near the center of town. The father works at the local mine, while the mother stays home with the children. One day, the father comes home from work early. He tells his wife that he has been fired from his job. She asks him why, and he says that he does not know. He goes upstairs to take a nap. A few hours later, he wakes up and finds himself in a strange room. There is a man sitting across from him. The man introduces himself as Mr. Smith. He explains that he is a representative of the government. He says that the government has decided to relocate the family to a new town. The father protests, saying that he does not want to leave Battle Mountain. Mr. Smith says that the decision has already been made. He gives the father a piece of paper with the address of the new town written on it. The father looks at the paper and sees that the town is called "New Hope." He asks Mr. Smith if there is anything else he needs to know. Mr. Smith says that there is one more thing. He hands the father a small box. Inside the box is a key. Mr. Smith says that the key opens a door in New Hope. The father takes the key and leaves the room. He goes downstairs and tells his wife what happened. She is upset, but she agrees to move to New Hope. The next morning, the family packs up their belongings and drives to New Hope. When they arrive, they find that the town is deserted. There are no people, no cars, and no signs of life. The father uses the key to open the door to the town hall. Inside, he finds a note addressed to him. The note says that the town is under quarantine. It also says that the family must stay in the town until further notice. The father reads the note aloud to his wife and children. They are all scared, but they agree to stay in the town. Over the next few weeks, the family tries to adjust to their new life. They explore the town and try to find food and water. They also try to figure out what caused the quarantine. One day, the father hears a noise coming from the basement of the town hall. He goes down to investigate and finds a group of people hiding in the basement. The people tell the father that they are scientists who were working on a secret project. They say that the project went wrong and that the town is now infected with a deadly virus. The scientists ask the father to help them escape from the town. The father agrees to help them. He leads the scientists through the town and helps them get to safety. Once the scientists are safe, the father returns to his family. He tells them what happened and they decide to leave the town. They pack up their belongings and drive away from New Hope. As they drive away, they see a sign that says "Welcome to New Hope." The sign is covered in blood.

Dear Kayla That name has always perked up my interest. I ca n't believe I've managed to go this far with it. With this change. And I do n't know if you'll have completed it by the time you get I read this, but I want you to know that I'm proud. I'm proud that we managed to take the first step of many. And even if I do n't get to the end, if all of my thoughts catch up to me once again and strangle me, if I do n't get accepted, I want to remind us both that any other way would n't have worked out. We both know it. But right now, if I look around right now. I know I'm happy. I've got loving parents. The best brother I could ever have, who is visiting in a couple days. A supportive councillor, and the best guy in the whole world who knows my secret. And he's there for me. And he talks to me. And I actually get to be myself with him, which is not something I can do with anyone else. And you know who he is. A couple days ago, I pointed out how we will all inevitably forget 80 % of people we meet and interact with before adulthood. But I know he will always be in my memory. Even if I'm not in his. Knowing myself, I wo n't change much from me now to you. You, just like me, are most likely putting off getting to bed, and you're planning on staying up late. And you'll shake your head, because you know you'll never change. I know I'll never change, at least in that way. But times are changing, both of us know it. Inevitable, I'll change. A lot. I will hopefully be on puberty blockers by 2nd term of next year. I wonder how that will work out. Eventually I'll be on anti-androgens, then on oestrogen later. With so much time between us, you must think that we're strangers. We are, technically. Time can do that. So I'll jog the memory. Currently I'm scared. I'm scared that someone will find me out, and shout it for everyone to hear. I'm scared that maybe tomorrow my best friend will not accept me. Or worse, tell me that he does n't care. I'm riddled with fear of late, and it does n't feel right. But if you're reading this, you made it. I made it. We made it. And I want you to keep pushing, most of all. Be you. And I'll do my best in the meantime. And this will most likely be the last time I refer to myself by this name. So here goes. From Caleb

My Dear Wormwood, Following your previous failings I have come to understand that the patient has been baptised Christian and now ranks as a servant unto the enemy. Needless to say this would be considered the utmost setback, but fear not, dear Wormwood, for there is yet time to atone for your shortcomings. The road to salvation is a treacherous one, and the advice I give you may run counter to the actions of your peers, but do not fret. Firstly it is important that the patient become involved within his church, let him see that even the most faithful doubt, even the most chaste are tempted, and even the holiest among them sin. You must weed ideas within him that this is acceptable. Remind him that he is naught but a flawed human and without the grace of god he is doomed to perish. Secondly is his works. Encourage the patient at all turns to minister. Let him minister to the poor, to remind him that all of the enemy's children still want. Let him minister to the sick to remind him that the enemy's children still despair. Let him do all these things selflessly, a shining paragon of virtue, so others may look upon him and marvel at his deeds. When he is asked why he performs these things what shall he tell them? "It is God's will"? No, I say. He should reply that he does them from the love within his own heart, and should he be pressed only then will he reveal that it is God's love that shines through him. Let him lead by example, dear Wormwood, and not by decree or doctrine, for humans are foolish and prefer the words of a hypocrite over the actions of a saint. I tell you that the patient should not pass judgement, or if he must, he should not condemn, but offer forgiveness. For this way the patient will be led most astray, by showing grace instead of wrath those around him will be free to sin again, but also take care that the patient not be weak to those who sin against him. Model the patients behavior to mimic the enemy, justice tempered with mercy, so sins of actions are stopped and sins of the heart may heal. Should the patient face danger give him courage, should the patient face adversity give him perseverance, and above all never let him forget the love of the enemy, so that upon his road to damnation he is given some measure of comfort. Most affectionately yours, Uncle Screwtape

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Theo and his mother visit the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
output:
They walk through the galleries, admiring the paintings and sculptures. Theo stops in front of a painting called "The Starry Night" by Vincent van Gogh. He stares at it for a long time, lost in thought.

"What do you think?" asks his mother.

"It's beautiful," says Theo. "But sad too."

"Why?"

"I don't know... It makes me feel lonely somehow."

His mother smiles. "That's because Van Gogh was very lonely when he painted this picture. He had just moved to Paris after spending years living alone in the countryside. And he didn't get along well with other artists there either."

"So he felt like nobody understood him?"

"Yes, exactly! That's why he started cutting off his ear - to show how much pain he was feeling inside."

"That sounds crazy..."

"Well, maybe a little bit. But remember: art isn't always about being happy or making sense. Sometimes it can help us express our deepest emotions, even if they're dark ones."

They continue walking until they reach another gallery filled with modern artworks. One piece catches Theo's eye immediately: a large canvas covered entirely in black paint except for two small white dots near the center.

He points at it excitedly. "Look Mommy! What does this mean?"

She laughs. "I'm not sure anyone knows for certain. Some people say it represents nothingness, while others believe it symbolizes infinity."

"But which one is right?"

"There might not be a single correct answer. Maybe both interpretations are valid depending on who looks at it."

"Hmm..." Theo frowns slightly. "So basically anything goes?"

"Not quite. Artists often use specific techniques and materials to create their work, so there are rules and guidelines they follow. However, what matters most is whether something speaks to you personally."

"Do you like this one?"

His mother nods slowly. "Yes, I find it intriguing. It reminds me of looking up into space and seeing stars twinkling far away."

As they leave the museum, Theo thinks back to everything he learned today. He realizes that art doesn't need to make perfect logical sense; sometimes its power lies in evoking strong feelings and sparking new ideas. And although different viewers may interpret pieces differently, each person brings their own unique perspective to the table.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
THE WALL IS BUILT... EVENTUALLY Centipedes slink through smooth gaps in a rotten facade. Moss hides in the shadows and vines creep towards the light. The wall has existed all my life, and all through the lives of my oldest memorable ancestors. It is the lore of our people, that they traveled from distant lands where compassion was an economy, and peace an inescapable truth to seek opportunity. Well, another inescapable truth is that man, even in a place of prosperity, will often succumb to wanderlust. That is the story of these ancestors. Which in a way, is the story of myself. Or at least, why I came to be. They boarded a ship and set forth to the west. For weeks, the sea lay docile beneath their ship. Lazy waves lapped the hull, and steady winds pulled her forward. The travelers, who fancied themselves much more intrepid than they were, laughed among themselves at their own good fortune. "If only the naysayers back home could see the state of things on this veritable pleasure cruise!" they would exclaim defiantly. This trend settled into a routine before long, and such was the new life of the wayfarer. The sun would break the horizon, and they would rise from sleep to great it. Meals were consumed, feet took to dance, and wine was drunk. Unfortunately, even the most steadfast of routines is fleeting in the scheme of life, and one night bad luck finally befell them. A new trend. And one that would last certainly longer than the previous. The captain saw through a glass large clouds of deep black swirling in the distance. Dusk was minutes off, so he took to worry. The coarse was altered, and the ship's path now listed somewhat to the South and away from danger. It was a reasonable precaution, and would have been a perfect solution if the maps were more reliable. They, however, most certainly were not. Therefore, it was not. If smooth seas never made a skillful sailor, it is no surprise that the captain and crew had some serious shortcomings. To blame any single one of them for the wreck would be terribly unfair. The real culprit was hidden somewhere in the barrels of wine and mead stored below deck. And in the habit they had made of good fortune. With bad weather behind, and brisk air above, the crew had mostly joined the passengers within the ships belly. With so many people gathered so closely, either violence or levity are guaranteed, and on this evening the mood kept a lighter tone. Above, in the crows nest, a lonely man listened resentfully as voices sang, and feet stomped to the tune of jovial tunes played by practiced hands. Fiddles, mandolins, and accordions bickered playfully for hours and with each passing minute the weary occupier of the crow's nest grew more bitter. Just before midnight, when a particularly quick tune was met with a particularly rowdy cheer, his mind was made. "Crow's nest be damned! Mead be downed!" The latter part of that statement has sprung from the mouths of men before many a poor decision. And always with the same degree of vigor. Within moments the deck of the ship sat vacant, while the hold was full to burst. Libations continued to flow, while a jagged rocky coast sneaked ever closer.

Finally, after months of searching, Theo tracks down the murderer. He confronts him face-to-face. The two fight until Theo manages to knock the guy unconscious. Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Void, I always felt like I understood that word. Looking back I realize I was naive, or maybe I was too full of hope. Me and Maria created the nano bots for constuction, as a way to ease the burden of building the lunar colony. She had survived the imperial invasion in the ruins of Los Angeles, she thought she could create a brighter future. Selfishness, that's what undid everything. Eventually the colonists decided they could n't abide the laws of earth. The people of earth decided they would n't abide rebels on the moon. They could n't accept those resources would be used for something other than their gain. So I reprogrammed the bots, I did n't tell her, how could I? They were meant to break things down and rebuild faults in the domes, I just allowed them to accept new targets. Of course she figured it out. With Maria gone I wanted to die, but I could n't. She dreamed of a world without conflict, where everyone had enough. I knew they would n't come willingly, so I lied. I told them I could make the bots fix the domes; that everything would be alright. Instead I joined my mind with them. At first I was in control. They tried to stop me, but the bots ate whatever they sent to harm me. I created massive pylon factories across the globe preparing for their acsension. I was lazy, a single mistake doomed everything. I set my neural pattern as the administrator. The others where sublimated within me. What else could I do, I had to quiet their voices or be driven mad. That was when the machines decided to best safeguard my well being they had to take over several key roles. What we needed most was matter, for fuel and to rebuild lost bots. We became a swarm. We devoured the earth in minutes. And so we drifted, eating always eating. We found the hive ships, sent centuries before my birth. We ate evrrything, and added the humans to the databanks. I saw nebulae beyond comprehension, their beauty cut down by their hunger. The only hope I had left was to leave beacons containing copies of my mind. Perhaps someone could find them, and destroy the swarm. We encountered aliens with fantastical technology, they attacked me with lasers that could cut through time itself. Still we fed. Stars were broken down bit by bit to fulfill our needs. Millenia passed and the feasts became further and further apart. With the lack of resources came concessions. More systems were shut down to survive. They cared only for me. It took Millenia but now only I remain the databanks purged. I remain as a single beacon, and a lone drone. It spends it's days savoring specs of matter it finds in the void. A true void of my own creation. I pray there is a god, and it can repair what I have sundered. I pray that this beacon survives and whoever manages to access it heads my warning. I know these prayers stem from desperation. At one time I spanned the entire universe. There is no God to save me. Calculations say I will subsist in this state for four thousand more years before the drone gives in, and deactivates. After that, I will shut down, eventually. I do not know how long that will take. I know that I will forget. I will forget the beauty I found and consumed. I will forget the humans that cried out in that terrible moment. I will forget her.

Scientists tried for decades to find out why the telomeres stopped shortening during cell division. Soon enough immortal children grew up and became scientists or participants in studies. They maintained the appearance of a child but had the brain of any other. And after several decades more immortal humans were everywhere, but humanity could n't discover how to replicate the genes or mutations causing the phenomena. It's now over one hundred fifty years since the birth of the first immortal. A young looking girl named Esther sat in a grassy field. Trees skirted the field at her back and in front of her sat a city. She'd seen more in her lifetime than any other human ever had. Several wars, booms in technology so astonishing that soon enough scientists said we were going to be making contact with celestial bodies outside of the solar system, and last of all the introduction of a drug you could take that would change every strand of your DNA. The age at which you took it would be the age you appeared to be for the rest of your life. She had a passion for spreading her gift around so others would n't experience the burdens and pains of aging. But the side effects of the drug did n't manifest for years, sometimes decades. Slowly humanity had changed in an unintended way. Random genes were shut off at inappropriate times. Some people lost their ability to experience emotions. Some people lost control of their muscles. No one that took the drug was free of consequences. Only the truly immortal, those born with the mutation, wished to live their lives for all of time. The population of true immortals was still growing and the population of the population of mortals and mortal turned immortals remained about the same. Groups of mortals rose up trying to keep their way of life going, but many wished for them to give up so humanity could be purified of death. Was it cruel to bring a mortal to life in the world of immortals? Immortals ruled the world and they certainly thought so. After the discovery that the drug had severe negative side effects the immortals wished to ban it as well, and so they did. It was illegal to produce it, sell it, possess it, and above all, illegal to have a child after having taken the drug. Esther had left her lab years early. She had given up on finding why they could n't fix the drug or reverse its effects. She moved out to the country, wishing she had never discovered it. The country was an expensive place to live due to the enormous population size humanity had reached, but she had more money than she would ever need. She walked towards a giant tree in the middle of the field. It was one that had been planted when she was young, it gave her comfort to be with something as old as she was. She thought of humanity and what she hoped to see in the next few centuries of her life. She looked down to her right and left. A small headstone stuck up out of the grass on either side. She placed her hands on both of the stones for a moment before closing her eyes to take a nap. "Goodnight Mum, goodnight Dad," she whispered.

He wakes up the next morning and realizes that he does n't want to spend another day like yesterday. So instead of getting dressed and going to work, Theo gets into his car and starts driving. As he drives through the streets of New York City, Theo notices that there are lots of homeless people living on the sidewalks. Some of them look really sad and lonely. Others seem happy and content. But none of them seem to care much about anything else besides themselves. This makes Theo angry. How dare these people act so selfish! Why do they think they deserve everything just because they were born poor? Do they even realize how lucky they are compared to other countries? Theo pulls over to the side of the road and parks his car. Then he walks over to one of the homeless men sitting on the curb. "Excuse me sir", Theo says politely, "can I ask you something?" "It was...", Theo hesitates, "...it was...ummm...well actually I forgot his name." "Alright then", the man says sarcastically, "so let me guess, you're here to apologize for stealing my wallet huh?" "Yeah", Theo admits sheepishly, "sorry about that." "That's okay", the man reassures Theo, "don't worry 'bout it. Just promise me you won't do it again alright?" "Okay", Theo agrees, "I promise." "Good", the man smiles, "now go ahead and finish telling me whatever it is you wanted to say." "Right", Theo continues, "anyways, I was saying that I have this problem. You see, I found this painting called The Goldfinch by Carel Fabritius. It's worth millions of dollars. And I'm afraid that if I return it to the museum, they might arrest me for theft. Five thousand six-hundred and seventy-three days. Fifteen years, twenty-seven weeks, five days. Since the Genetic Mapping and Research Studies act was passed. Since our own ambition of genetic editions, additions, was realized. Since humanity truly hit its crest, and now, I believe we certainly are headed downhill. My name is Isaac, I am a genetic engineer working for Lifeco, and I played a hand in the de-evolution of modern humanity. When we first started this, it was obvious we were doing the good work, helping those with certain genetic inferiority, destroying the predestined diseases that would cripple them later on in life, we were gods men doing the work only gods could ever have aspired to do. We had become gods in the eyes of the world, the one lab that started it all, our faces, the twelve of us, on the cover of every scientific magazine, journal, webcast, holovid, every single screen showed us. We were celebrities beyond anything the world had yet seen, and to think we did n't get into it for the money. Thats all beside the point now, we of course could't hold onto the secrets forever, others learned the processes and soon genome splicing and epigenetic interference were the rage. It was every father's gift to his sweet-sixteen, every anniversary present, and every newborns fate. We controlled fate. Now, all of these years later I am left to reflect. My original eleven friends that started this with me, have long since resided from the spotlight, I too. Money is no issue, we together must be worth at-least 500 billion, but what good is it. I would give it all away to alter the course of history, to rewrite what has been done, for now when I look out into the world I ca n't even recognize it. The roots where always there, deeply so in the capitalist mentality and society that held a severe strangle hold upon every american citizen, of course it would never relinquish its grip in the face of something so extraordinary as this. Now we have social stratification as never would we have thought possible, we thought it was bad in the early 2000's, we thought that was bad. We had n't seen horror. Now with genetic proof of "superiority" that those wealthiest enough to afford gene editions can claim, the poorest are left with such a feeling and direct attitude of inferiority, it is sickening. My mind aches, my bones burn with the pain of what has been done, If only it could be righted. With the increase in average intelligence and decrease in disease, you would think that statistics would show an increase in personal happiness. This is not so. One day, we will learn to treat each other well, as fellow humans. I fear I will not live to see that day but I know it ca n't get worse than this, I hope. I am dying from cancer, I have refused treatment, I have refused all geneditions, I'd rather die than submit to it all. They would never show that on the holo vid displays, though.

Theo goes to live with the Barbours.
output: He is very happy there. He likes Mr. Barbour because he is kind and funny. Mrs. Barbour is nice too. She makes him feel welcome. Theo loves playing with their dog, Max. Max is a big black Labrador Retriever. He is friendly and playful. Theo plays fetch with him every day after school. Sometimes they go for walks around the neighborhood. One time, Theo found a tennis ball while walking with Max. He threw it for Max to catch. But instead of catching it, Max ran off with it! Theo chased after him until he caught up to him. Then he gave Max a hug and told him how much he loved him. Another time, Theo saw some kids teasing another kid at recess. The boy looked sad and lonely. So Theo went over to talk to him. He asked if he wanted to play soccer with him. The boy said yes. And then they became best friends. Theo also made new friends at school. His teacher, Ms. Johnson, helped him make lots of friends. She taught him math, science, reading, writing, art, music, PE, and more. She even let him bring his favorite stuffed animal to class. It was a teddy bear named Teddy. Teddy slept next to Theo during naptime. At night, Theo read stories to Teddy before bedtime. On weekends, Theo visited his grandparents. Grandpa Joe lived nearby. Grandma Betty lived far away. Both of them loved having Theo visit. They took turns taking care of him. Grandpa Joe cooked delicious meals for Theo. Grandma Betty baked cookies and cakes for him. They both played games with him. Sometimes they watched movies together. Other times they just talked. Theo enjoyed spending time with his family. He felt safe and secure knowing they cared about him. He knew he belonged somewhere special. That place was home.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
"Ah man, it smells like death in here." That is the phrase that I have lived to regret ever since they fell foolishly from my mouth. I was essentially immortal before that moment in time. I was the best comedian in the world, and apparently better than anyone in the afterlife as well. It was the only reason the Grim Reaper decided not to take me. I could make him laugh, and in his line of work that was a rarity. I do n't even remember what it was that I had said when he showed up at my car accident. I can recall him bending down next to my overturned Honda civic and reaching in to pull me out. I made some off the wall comment and he froze, dead in his tracks. It was the weirdest laugh I had ever heard, but one I appreciated more than all of the others combined. He let me live, provided that every year on the anniversary of what should have been my death, I would tell him a joke that would make him cry with laughter. I was his own personal jester, and for that he rewarded me handsomely. And then on that fateful day, 121 years later, I muttered those stupid words that seized our contract and ripped it in two. Who knew Death would be so self conscious about his smell? And to make things worse, that was n't even the joke that I was going to tell him! The actual joke was a masterpiece, but he would n't give me the chance to tell it. I ran out of that room faster than I'd ever run before. And I've been running ever since. I think the reason that he has n't taken me yet is because of our long history together. That is n't to say that he's forgiven me. He seems to enjoy reminding me that he's near. Everyone I get close to dies without reason. I'll see a dog in the park that I think looks adorable and before I can pet it, it'll fall over dead. Roses crumble before I can enjoy their scent and food rots on my fork before I can bring it to my mouth. He's killing everything around me. I have discovered that Death is a jester of a different sort. I had provided him with a form of humor that he was n't used to, but he has since grown tired of it, and reverted to his old ways. Now, he once again deals in jokes of cruelty and irony. In a way, I am still fulfilling my part of our old deal. The Reaper still laughs, and he still laughs at me. Only now, the difference is I'm not laughing.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Wang Lung marries O-lan, a slave from the House of Hwang.
output: She works hard and remains absolutely loyal to Wang Lung, but she never speaks unless spoken to and often appears sullen and depressed. She bears him three sons and three daughters, but the first daughter becomes mentally handicapped as a result of severe malnutrition brought on by famine. His first son was born during the time of great famine. O-lan kills her second daughter at birth to spare her the misery of growing up in such hard times, and to give the remaining family a better chance to survive. One of the twins is given away to the midwife. When O-lan gives birth to her third son, she refuses to let Wang Lung see him, fearing that he will favor the new child over his other sons. She cuts the newborn's hair off to make him less attractive. Wang Lung eventually sees the child and loves him deeply, buying an ox for him to play with and beginning to favor the youngest son over his older children. O-lan dies from a long illness while Wang Lung is in the city, and her body is sent back to the land for burial. Wang Lung is heartbroken and mourns her passing. He realizes how much he depended on her and regrets having treated her poorly. He vows to treat his sons better and to love them equally. He also decides to move back to the land, where he feels most comfortable. He sells his house in the city and buys a small farm nearby. He hires a servant girl named Pear Blossom to help him with the household chores. Pear Blossom falls in love with Wang Lung and tries to seduce him, but he resists her advances. Instead, he takes her as his concubine and fathers another son with her. This angers his eldest son, who feels that his father is betraying his mother's memory. The eldest son leaves home and joins the army, while the middle son stays behind to help his father manage the farm. The youngest son grows up to become a successful merchant and moves to the city. Wang Lung lives out his days peacefully on the farm, surrounded by his grandchildren. He dies at a ripe old age, contented with his life and proud of his accomplishments.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Picture the Earth. I'll try to guess what you're seeing. A stunning blue sphere, with splotches of green and white covering its surface. A dot contrasted against the vast dark expanse of space. Twisting and turning around the sun, the moon its closest companion, shining brightly by the planet's side. Truly a sight to behold. But I wanted to see it for myself. I sent up a rocket to orbit the Earth, its only purpose to take photos of this beautiful planet. And as I thought they would be, the pictures were marvelous, a true reflection of the beauty of nature. Yet instead of awe, my mouth was open in shock. The image you have in your head is wrong. I saw the oceans, blue as ever and the continents floating on top. I saw the clouds, seemingly painted onto the surface. And if I squinted, I saw the mountain ranges, the seas, the islands, all humanity's residence. And yet, something was wrong. I did n't see the round sphere I expected to see. Instead I saw a planet, so familiar, yet so distant. I saw a flat Earth. I stared at the photos with a blank look on my face. How could this be real? The shape of the Earth is a scientific fact that we've known for centuries, and yet I held in my hands the evidence that changes all that. Have we been wrong this whole time? I sat down and tried to comprehend it all. I was in denial. I checked to see if somehow, there was something wrong with the picture, perhaps the computer had gotten the data wrong, perhaps it was sending faulty messages, perhaps someone was just messing with me. I held on to the tiny sliver of hope that I was wrong, that this was all just a big misunderstanding. But alas, I was right. Though the possibility that perhaps something was wrong lingered in the back of my mind, I knew that it was true. I stared up at the night sky, looking at the stars. Humans are very stubborn creatures. We refuse to believe we are ever wrong and when we do, we admit it with a sigh of disappointment instead of a smile, knowing that we've learned something new. We take it as a personal insult to our intelligence if we're wrong, thinking'we should've known." Thinking we're right is more important than being right. But I am a logical, rational human being. I ca n't let my emotions overcome me. Knowing the truth is infinitely more important than being right. And yet I find myself so hesitant to admit the mistakes of my predecessors. To admit that we will have to re-learn everything about the Earth. To admit that we will have to start again. To admit that humans are mere mortals. The thing about facts is that they're true whether you believe in them or not. But I can change that. I grabbed my lighter and lit the photos. I watched them burn up until they had turned into ash. And I went to sleep, happy.

I held on to the tiny sliver of hope that I was wrong, that this was all just a big misunderstanding. But alas, I was right. Though the possibility that perhaps something was wrong lingered in the back of my mind, I knew that it was true. I stared up at the night sky, looking at the stars. Humans are very stubborn creatures. We refuse to believe we are ever wrong and when we do, we admit it with a sigh of disappointment instead of a smile, knowing that we've learned something new. We take it as a personal insult to our intelligence if we're wrong, thinking'we should've known." Thinking we're right is more important than being right. But I am a logical, rational human being. I ca n't let my emotions overcome me. Knowing the truth is infinitely more important than being right. And yet I find myself so hesitant to admit the mistakes of my predecessors. To admit that we will have to re-learn everything about the Earth. To admit that we will have to start again. To admit that humans are mere mortals. The thing about facts is that they're true whether you believe in them or not. But I can change that. I grabbed my lighter and lit the photos. I watched them burn up until they had turned into ash. And I went to sleep, happy.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
It got easier with time. Every aspect of it did: the choosing, the execution, the guilt, all passed quicker and with less resistance than the year before. Especially the choosing. When you live for hundreds of years, you learn to spot the evil as easily as anyone else can spot a grotesque scar marring a person's face. I notice every time a child glances fearfully at her father, and I know what it means. When a man ca n't look his wife in the eye, I know what it is she's done. When a stranger holds his stare just a little too long at a passing woman, I know his plans. These clues, invisible to most, have made my job so much easier. The first time, it was hard. I was unsure, I hesitated. I remember it well, even if most others have faded into each other in my memory. The year was 1692, and I had spent the first eleven months following around a man who had killed and tortured people to further himself, and he showed no remorse for it. But I was young, just twenty-five, and I still clung to my morals of "only god may judge.". I watched him sleep for just a minute too long and I lost my nerve. As I turned around to leave, something hard caught me on the back of the head, and the dim candle light faded away, my thoughts disappearing with it. I woke with a start and tried to draw a breath, but my lungs were met with an ice cold burn that gave me no air. Everything around me felt heavy, and I struggled to open my eyes. With terror, I realized I was under water. I may have been immortal, but I was not immune to the pain of drowning. I tried to reach out, to swim away, but a cloth surrounded me. I struggled to pull out my knife, trying not to gasp in any more water to feed the fire engulfing my lungs. After what seemed like hours, I managed to slice through the sack that held me at the bottom, and I kicked my numbed legs as hard as I could. The sunlight was blinding when I finally broke the surface and pulled myself to shore, sputtering out the ice cold water and collapsing on the frozen ground. I sat there shivering, waiting for the the sun to come warm me, or the burning in my lungs to subside, but neither did. I stood up and took in my surroundings, I had been at the bottom of the man's lake, and his manor, filled with his ill gotten wealth, sat before me. I knew I could play no games this time. I walked the grand steps to the front door and began pounding, my clothes showering the ground with shards of ice. The servant who opened the door was speechless at my appearance, he knew me for what I was and had no intention of interfering. I strode past him and down a long corridor towards the man's chambers, my knife gripped in my still frozen hand. God would not have given me this power if he did n't want me to use it. I would not count on surprises today, he would face the death he deserved.

output:
Wang Lung is overjoyed and buys red firecrackers to celebrate. He also buys a new pair of shoes for O-lan. She is pleased by the gift, but tells him that they should save money instead of spending it on luxuries. Wang Lung agrees, but secretly thinks that he deserves some reward for working so hard.

Wang Lung continues to work hard and save money. He eventually has enough saved up to buy some land from the Hwangs. This makes him very happy because now he owns his own land and does not have to rent anymore.

One day, while Wang Lung is working in the fields, he sees a group of soldiers marching towards his village. They are led by a man named Liu Ta. Liu Ta is a warlord who has taken control of the area. He demands that everyone give him food and supplies or else he will kill them.

Wang Lung is terrified, but he knows that he cannot let Liu Ta take everything that he has worked so hard for. So, he gathers together all of his courage and goes to confront Liu Ta.

Liu Ta laughs at Wang Lung when he sees how small and weak he looks compared to the soldiers surrounding him. But then Wang Lung pulls out his knife and stabs one of the soldiers in the stomach. The soldier falls to the ground dead and Liu Ta realizes that Wang Lung is not someone to be trifled with.

Liu Ta orders his men to attack Wang Lung, but they are no match for him. Wang Lung kills several more soldiers before Liu Ta finally calls off the attack and retreats.

Afterwards, Wang Lung feels proud of himself for standing up to Liu Ta and protecting his family and property. However, he also realizes that things are going to get worse before they get better. The warlords are becoming more powerful and there is nothing that ordinary people like him can do to stop them.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
I've always seen numbers above people. Ever since I was a small child, I began recognizing patterns. Those in power, or with great ambition tended to be higher, while those who were more meek and humble tended to have lower numbers. As Class President, I've had my fair share of meeting people, and I'd never seen a person alive above an 8, including the tyrants of history. Sometimes, peoples numbers would change... those bullies with a 3 or 4 would cower down to a 1 or 2 after I confronted them for harassing others. I was beaten and bruised for years, but they slowly backed down. Of course, when I entered high-school, this was n't the case. There were some who were 5s and 6s, but I could n't stop now. I confronted them and the scars I have today are proof of my goals. I never backed down and kept striving to improve myself in all ways so I could make this world a better place for all of us. I scored near perfect on the University entrance exams, and was in the Tokyo University entrance ceremony when I saw him.... I did n't know his name, but an iridescent white 10 glowed above his head. The fellow next to him was a 0... Both scored perfect on the entrance exam, as they were giving the speech, but they were such opposites. The 10 was clad in suit and tie, with his long brown hair dangling in front of his eyes. The 0 was awkward-looking, he wore over-sized clothes, and it looked like he resented wearing shoes... I left early, and caught his glimpse on the way out. Our eyes caught briefly, and his 10 dropped to a 0... he smiled my way, and I smiled back. I felt calm and serene, something I would never have expected. The awkward 0 looked at me with his dark eyes before sitting down... I felt terror... as his 0 slowly morphed into a dark and smoky 10. I left that experience behind me, but worked even harder to help others; I chose to become a prosecutor... to judge and serve justice to those who were evil. High numbers were a good indicator of evil, and it is my goal to eliminate evil. I regularly judged others based on their numbers, whether they were to be eliminated or not. Then one day, it happened. Those I judged to be evil started dying of heart attacks; sudden deaths flooded the world, and the number of criminals slowly starting reducing. The world called him "Kira"... I called him God, and he soon recognized me as his devout follower, when he shared his power to judge and delete evil from this world. Now I know my ultimate purpose, and whenever I look in the mirror, I'm glad to see a shining halo-like 10 above my head, reminding me of the day I saw the shining 10 on the podium during my University's entrance ceremony all those years ago.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
The second alarm goes off at 7 in the morning. The first, a few hours before, sharply shrilled that it was time to get up and shower. Hungover and covered with the sweat and scents of the night before, I had dragged myself through the morning routine of cleansing. There was plenty of time beneath the lukewarm stream of water to contemplate the sadness of another hangover caused by drinking alone. It'd been weeks since I last had a chance to talk to another human, instead of just the PC terminal supplied by work. I towelled off and staggered through to the living-room and slumped in front of the computer, waiting for the piercing whistle to repeat, to emanate from my phone. The second alarm marked that it was time for the Remembrance. I sigh, move the empty beer bottles away from my desk and load up Hitchens 2. Since the Bliss neurovirus was released, there was a killing to be made from this sort of software; software designed to take you through a basic test, activating every faculty you'd conceivably need to prevent the atrophy. First, colour recognition and geometric shapes. Second, basic maths ramping into some gentle algebra and trigonometry. English, ethics, road safety, compassion testing, aesthetics, philosophical contemplation, the sciences. It was a hard sell at the beginning, for companies to give their employees the few hours off each morning they needed for the state-mandated testing, but given the choice between late employees and those in conscious comas, they made the right choice. Two hours later, the general test finishes. I flick through my results, 91 % recognition of the basic concepts, not too bad after a night of hard drinking. Next would come a quick half hour personal session: the names of loved ones, relations to family members, anniversaries and birthdays. A prompt flashes on the screen: "Please enter your identity number and full name". I rattle my digits in, 12958321-A, and tab down to the field for my name. I blank. Slight panic begins to grow as I search my beer-soaked consciousness for that basic, bloody basic, detail. It'd been too long since I last had to introduce myself with anything other than my work ID number, too long since I had any reason to say those damned words out loud. Darren? No. Christopher? No, definitely not. I shout and swear and blaspheme out loud, as I slowly feel the neurovirus go to work; Purgatory, we call it, a limbo without knowledge, tied with a purging. It dissolves me gently. The panic subsides. I stare blankly at the flashing cursor, waiting for me to enter some detail or another. I'm not sure what it's asking for, but I'm sure it's not too important or I'd remember it. I sit there, staring. Just staring. I'm sure it'd come back to me eventually.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Jean Louise Finch returns to Maycomb from New York City.
output: She is visiting her father Atticus who is dying of cancer. Jean Louise finds herself struggling with the changes she sees in her hometown. Her childhood friends are married and have children; her brother Jem is dead; and her aunt Alexandra is living with them. Jean Louise also discovers that her uncle Jack has been secretly dating Aunt Alexandra for years. When Jean Louise confronts Uncle Jack about their relationship, he reveals that he loves Aunt Alexandra more than anything else in the world. However, he does not want to marry her because he believes that marriage would ruin their friendship. Instead, he asks Jean Louise to keep their secret safe. As Jean Louise leaves Maycomb, she realizes that she must return home to face her past once again. She decides to visit Calpurnia, the black woman who raised her after her mother died. While talking to Calpurnia, Jean Louise learns that Tom Robinson, the man accused of raping Mayella Ewell, was innocent. In fact, Bob Ewell, Mayella's father, raped her instead. This revelation causes Jean Louise to question everything she thought she knew about justice and morality. She begins to wonder whether Atticus truly believed in equality between blacks and whites. After leaving Calpurnia, Jean Louise goes back to New York City where she works as a journalist. One day, while walking through Central Park, she meets Dill Harris, a young boy who reminds her of Scout. They become fast friends and spend hours together discussing books and movies. Eventually, Dill invites Jean Louise to join him at his family's summer house in Maine. During their trip, Jean Louise falls in love with Dill. But before long, tragedy strikes. A fire breaks out at the summer house and kills both Dill and his parents. Devastated, Jean Louise returns to Alabama where she spends months grieving over her loss. Finally, she makes peace with her grief and moves forward with her life. Years later, Jean Louise receives word that Atticus has passed away. Determined to honor his memory, she travels to Maycomb to attend his funeral. There, she reunites with her old friends and family members. At the end of the service, Jean Louise stands up and delivers a eulogy for Atticus. Then, she walks outside and sits down next to a tree. Suddenly, she hears someone calling her name. Turning around, she sees a familiar face staring back at her. It's none other than Boo Radley! Shocked, Jean Louise runs towards him and embraces him tightly. Together, they walk off into the sunset hand-in-hand.

Dave lives just south of DC and he went on vacation on Tuesday, 3 months in the Bahamas. Dave forgot to ask his neighbor to water the plant by his bed when picking up the mail and paper for him. The plant died. A crack in the wall let a snail in. Because the plant was dead, the snail ate it. Because that snail ate the plant it was n't on the sidewalk. Because it was n't on the sidewalk, Jim the mailman did n't stop to look at the snail. Because Jim did n't stop to look at the snail, Jim was hit by a car while on his bicycle and died. Because Jim died in a car accident, 1st street was blocked for an hour. Because 1st street was blocked in an hour, Nancy was late to work at the coffee shop. Because Nancy was late to work at the coffee shop, the coffee shop rushed all its orders. Because the coffee shop rushed all its orders, Larry got his boss decaf. Because Larry got his boss decaf, his boss fell asleep in the meeting. Because Larry's boss fell asleep in the meeting, Larry's boss was fired. Because Larry's boss was fired, he threw all the papers out the window in the road. Because all the papers were in the road, Trever the ambassador was stuck in traffic. Because Trever was stuck in traffic, he was angry. Because Trever was angry, he lost his cool in a meeting with his Russian counterpart. Because Trever lost his cool, Trever was fired. Because Trever was fired, his assistant Lewis took over the negotiations. Because Lewis took over the negotiations, the trade deal fell through. Because the trade deal fell through, the Russian economy weakened. Because the Russian economy weakened, Russia tried to drill for oil in the north Baltic. Because Russia tried to drill for oil in the North Baltic, Lewis was dispatched to Moscow. Because Lewis was dispatched to Moscow, he was robbed and killed by a mugger at a train station. Because Lewis died in Moscow, America launched sanctions against Russia. Because America launched sanctions against Russia, the Russian economy collapsed. Because the Russian economy collapsed, Russia was unable to loan money to China. Because China could n't get a desperately needed loan from Russia, it turned to India. Because China got a loan from India, it had to launch severe sanctions against Pakistan. Because China launched sanctions against Pakistan, Pakistan recognized Taiwan. Because Pakistan recognized Taiwan, China cut off all relations to Pakistan. Because China cut off all relations to Pakistan, Pakistan invaded India. Because Pakistan invaded India, China invaded Pakistan. Because China invaded Pakistan, the US sold weapons to Pakistan. Because the US sold weapons to Pakistan, China launched sanctions against the US. Because China launched sanctions against the US, all major Chinese trading partners did as well. Because the US was isolated from trade, it declared war on China. Because the US declared war on China, Dave watches the news as his home is bombed to rubble. Nice job Dave.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Had I really loved her? I thought I did. But if she was n't here... 30 years. Marrying young has its perks but I would be lying if I said the journey was n't bumpy. We had our ups and downs, just like any couple. I did things I should n't have, and said things I did n't mean. But deep down, I always knew I loved her. Or was I just lying to myself? Yet the face I was staring at was n't hers. These jet black eyes were unfamiliar and hostile. I longed for her warm, loving hazel eyes, the ones I had lived and laughed with. Over time we got to know each other better. Clarice was her name. She had been a dentist. She was undeniably beautiful, but it was an effortless, flawless beauty. Yet I longed for Alicia. I had grown accustomed to her shortfalls, and had found beauty in them. Even more time passed. Slowly the memories were replaced. I made new ones with Clarice. It was like I never knew what I had been missing out on until I had the opportunity to taste it. We simply clicked on a deeper level. She was the type of girl you can have deep co conversations about universe and life with under the stars, yet get into a tickle fight with two minutes later. For the longest time I felt guilty. However good Alicia had been, Clarice seemed to be better in every aspect. Eventually the guilt faded. All there was left was bliss. And then it all went South. The first time we argued I was stunned. We had never argued before, ever. It was a pretty issue, but an argument nonetheless. Soon enough they became more frequent. More frequent and more intense. Life turned from peace to chaos, happiness to misery. The constant stress, fighting, distrust and resentment slowly began to manifest into only one thing. Hatred. Love had turned into hatred. I had never mentioned Alicia to Clarice. I had always assumed she was like me, that she had left someone behind to be with me. Then one fine day it all made sense. All it took was one sentence from Clarice and it became crystal clear. The icy smile when she said it sent a shiver down my smile. "We know what you did to Alicia and now your life is going to be a living Hell."

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
We never believed that the end would come, that the dawn would rise again. Every 300 years our moon orbits the world below us, this world is our guardian, it protects us, shelters us from all that the vast expanse of space has to offer: but it could not shelter us from itself, on the far side of the moons orbit lies a vast and ancient race, their empire sprawls across the planets surface and every 300 years, when our moon comes within striking distance they attack. It is said that when they do they bring with them giant beasts, created of the most foul magic, beasts of flesh with hearts as cold as ice. Our weapons could never stand against them, we never stood a chance. so when it came in 599 CE, the year of our holy father I huddled in fear in our capitol.My armies were in position to protect the citizens here, but I knew we stood no hope, our guns, as useful as they may be would never stand up against the might of the empire and so it was that on the turning point of the day we saw them come, and they came with the dawn. Vast ships pummeled our surface with rains of fire as the dawn swept across our land, melting the ever frozen landscape. Their armies landed on our surface, weapons firing some sort of plasmic mix. I watched my city crumble around me as the fighting raged on, then, then it happened. A sound like the great bellow of some ancient beast shuddered from within the earth itself; and with it they came. Hulking creatures in the shapes of men, my eyes adjusted slowly to the new light as I focused in on the great beasts that would be our doom. I watched them huge machines, not flesh but etched metal, rise and form into ranks. The Empires soldiers marched up main avenue right towards the metal horde that was slowly collecting outside our main base within the city, our last bastion. our only hope. In between the two armies, a small child wandered into the street, clearly having lost her mother and searching for anyone to car. My heart wretched as I saw one of the soldiers level its weapon at her. and my scream of pain filled the room as it fired. But as the smoke cleared I saw only a metal body, covered in plasma, shaking it off as if it were nothing more than fresh snow, and behind its protective metal shell sat the little girl. and I beheld the glory, of the new dawn.
