Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
I'm not like you, I see differently. When I look at someone, I see into their future but I only get to see the worst part. Particularly their deaths, I see them in gruesome detail. I've seen car crashes, murders, stabbings and once, I even saw someone who would later die in a plane crash. I was n't always cursed this way, it all started after I was in a nearly fatal car crash, I woke up from a short coma and I could see the deaths of everyone around me. The doctors simply chalked it down to ptsd and gave me meds but I knew it was more that mere ptsd. I knew what I was seeing was n't just imagination. I even found a few people who were to die in a few days time and followed them up to see if they did and they did. All this time, I had not seen my own face in the mirror. I mean, I had seen it but half of it was still covered in bandages, still recovering from my injuries. Something I noticed about my death vision was that it only worked if I could see the entire face of the person. I could n't see the deaths of people who had their faces covered. This is why I figured, I could n't see mine yet and I was determined to keep it that way. I did n't wan na know how I died, I mean would you? Would you want to see how you died in gruesome detail? Of course not! After the bandages came off, I was very careful not to look at my complete reflection. Anytime I wanted to set my hair, I would tie a kerchief around my face. When I brushed my teeth, I wore a bandana, Shades and a scarf for good measure. The temptation to just look at my face in its entirety was hard to overcome but I did. I was traumatised enough by the deaths of others as it is. Shortly after the accident, I moved out of town into a sleepy little village and lived on my own. The fewer the people, the better for me. I lived in a tiny cottage with no reflective surfaces save for the tiny mirror in my bathroom that I kept covered by a cloth most of the time. This morning, I was brushing my teeth as usual and just as I was finishing, my bandana came lose and dropped into the sink. In my desperation to catch it, I undid the scarf and lo! I was staring at my naked face in the mirror. The world went black and I saw myself standing in complete darkness. Suddenly, a look of consternation came over me and I covered behind something. Shortly after a dark figure entered the place and after a short struggle, stabbed me. As I came out of my nightmarish reverie, gasping for breath after seeing myself die. I heard a loud crash in the house, suddenly the power went out. A look of consternation came over my face as I covered behind the bathroom door.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Dear Lily, I'm visiting the recesses of my memory, these days. Contemplating my life as it were. So many memories I wanted to share with you. Diamonds for my one true love. Do you remember that one cool summer evening half a lifetime ago? We nestled ourselves against each other on the blanket in the park. I can still feel your skin against mine as we watched the fireworks together. Your chestnut hair stroking my cheek and ear as you rested your head on my shoulder. I could n't believe you were gone. Day turned into night. Food tasted like nothing. The world turned into a bland grey color. I could n't believe it. I did n't want to believe it. I wept and kept weeping. Then I had no tears left to sob. I lost weight. I lost my hair. I gained wrinkles. When I lost you, the man in the mirror showed me his true age almost overnight. But then things started to change. Our Elisabeth. Our loving, kind Lillibeth who moved half a world for her Australian. She visited me eventually. We talked about you, Lily. We shared a thousand little things between us. A flock of starlings composing your life. During that visit, the turmoil caused by losing you finally seemed to settle. At the end, I decided to finally change my Facebook status. Lillibeth helped me. You know my old, bony fingers have gotten a mind of their own, it seems. I wanted to tell you, Lilly, that I got a little surprise the very next day. This tabby kitten sat outside our garden door the very next morning. It seemed lost, but her eyes betrayed she knew exactly were she was. As I opened the door, she jumped right in and installed herself in the spot on the couch from where you used to watch the telly during long winter evenings. I decided to dub her Lilly because she seems to have a playful streak. Just like you. And most importantly, she seemed to be the antidote to my loneliness. That's not the end of it. Lily was only the first. Each week, I woke up to find two or three feline friends at our garden door. I let them, fed them and started to call them by a name I gave them. Each of them seemingly knowing that she belonged in this house. There's Athena who sits on your sewing machine, looking wise beyond her years. There's Hera who likes to wake me up each morning, and has this stern and down-to-earth disposition. There's Hebe, she's just a kitten who seems to have no bounds teasing the others. All in all, there's twelve of them who came to live with me. They keep me company. Follow me through the house as I go about my day. When I see them, they always remind me of a part of you. An aspect that I should n't forget. Sometimes they're mere presence helps me as the practicalities in life start to fade from my memory. When I spot Demeter sitting in front of the fridge, it hits me that I still need to do the groceries. Oh Lily, I miss you so much. My life has entered the twilight years. Only so much time is left before I will join you. I hope our Lillibeth will take care of my twelve feline companions. She'll be most delighted recognising some aspect of her mother in each of them. Yours forever with endless love, Werner.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
John Grimes wakes up on his birthday feeling neglected.
output: His wife, Mary, has forgotten his special day again. John decides to make the best of it and goes out for a walk. On his way back home, he sees a beautiful woman walking towards him. Her name is Sarah and she invites him over for coffee. John accepts and they spend the afternoon talking about their lives. Sarah tells John that she is recently divorced and looking for someone new to share her life with. John feels a connection with Sarah and asks her out on a date. They go out for dinner and have a great time. Afterwards, they go back to Sarah's place and spend the night together. In the morning, John wakes up feeling guilty. He knows that he loves his wife but he also knows that he has feelings for Sarah. He decides to break off his relationship with Sarah and go back to his wife. However, when he gets home, he finds that his wife has packed her bags and left him. John is devastated. He doesn't know what to do. He spends the rest of the day moping around the house until he receives a phone call from Sarah. She tells him that she misses him and wants to see him again. John agrees to meet her and they spend another wonderful evening together. This time, however, John knows that he can't continue seeing Sarah while he is still married. He breaks up with her and returns home to try and patch things up with his wife. Unfortunately, his wife refuses to forgive him and files for divorce. John is heartbroken. He tries to move on with his life but he can't stop thinking about Sarah. One day, he runs into her on the street and they talk for hours. John realizes that he still has strong feelings for Sarah and decides to give their relationship another chance. They start dating again and soon fall deeply in love. John proposes to Sarah and she says yes. They get married and live happily ever after.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Dear Kayla That name has always perked up my interest. I ca n't believe I've managed to go this far with it. With this change. And I do n't know if you'll have completed it by the time you get I read this, but I want you to know that I'm proud. I'm proud that we managed to take the first step of many. And even if I do n't get to the end, if all of my thoughts catch up to me once again and strangle me, if I do n't get accepted, I want to remind us both that any other way would n't have worked out. We both know it. But right now, if I look around right now. I know I'm happy. I've got loving parents. The best brother I could ever have, who is visiting in a couple days. A supportive councillor, and the best guy in the whole world who knows my secret. And he's there for me. And he talks to me. And I actually get to be myself with him, which is not something I can do with anyone else. And you know who he is. A couple days ago, I pointed out how we will all inevitably forget 80 % of people we meet and interact with before adulthood. But I know he will always be in my memory. Even if I'm not in his. Knowing myself, I wo n't change much from me now to you. You, just like me, are most likely putting off getting to bed, and you're planning on staying up late. And you'll shake your head, because you know you'll never change. I know I'll never change, at least in that way. But times are changing, both of us know it. Inevitable, I'll change. A lot. I will hopefully be on puberty blockers by 2nd term of next year. I wonder how that will work out. Eventually I'll be on anti-androgens, then on oestrogen later. With so much time between us, you must think that we're strangers. We are, technically. Time can do that. So I'll jog the memory. Currently I'm scared. I'm scared that someone will find me out, and shout it for everyone to hear. I'm scared that maybe tomorrow my best friend will not accept me. Or worse, tell me that he does n't care. I'm riddled with fear of late, and it does n't feel right. But if you're reading this, you made it. I made it. We made it. And I want you to keep pushing, most of all. Be you. And I'll do my best in the meantime. And this will most likely be the last time I refer to myself by this name. So here goes. From Caleb

John's brother Roy is upset with their father Gabriel's harshness.
output:
He tells John that he wants to leave home and live with his girlfriend. John tries to talk him out of it, but Roy is determined. He says goodbye to his family and leaves. John is sad to see his brother go, but he understands why he did it. He hopes that one day they will be able to reconcile.

Roy moves in with his girlfriend and starts working as a mechanic. He enjoys his new life and feels free from his father's control. However, he misses his family and wishes he could see them more often.

One day, Roy receives a letter from his mother. She tells him that she is very ill and asks him to come home. Roy is torn between his love for his girlfriend and his duty to his family. He decides to return home and help his mother.

When Roy arrives home, he finds his mother in a bad state. She is weak and frail, and she needs constant care. Roy takes over her care and spends every moment with her. He also helps his father with the farm chores.

As time passes, Roy realizes that he loves his family deeply. He regrets leaving them behind and vows to make amends. He apologizes to his father for his past behavior and promises to be a better son.

Gabriel accepts Roy's apology and welcomes him back into the family. They spend quality time together and bond over shared memories. Roy also reconnects with his siblings and forms strong relationships with them.

In the end, Roy learns the importance of family and forgiveness. He realizes that blood ties are stronger than anything else and that he should cherish them while he still can.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
The first time I jumped, I immediately looked up the latest medical journals. They had certainly made significant progress, but it was n't enough. I did n't even take a look around before I jumped again. I checked, again. Success. The cure had been found. It was in clinical trials and was being fast-tracked. Six months, only six months left. I drove like a madman to the hospital. Transferred? What do you mean transferred? I PAID THE BILLS FOR 9 MONTHS BEFORE I LEFT!!! 15 months ago... Oh god. Over a year. I found her. I barely recognized her, except her voice. That angelic voice that kept me going. It was difficult explaining where I'd been. I was gone for so long. She did n't understand, she was just happy to see me. Then the doctor came in. He pulled me aside. No. NO! 1 month, at best. NO! NO! NO! NO! I started to run out of the room, but she could tell. She did n't know what I was doing, but she knew I would n't be back. She pleaded, and it tore my heart apart, but I was doing it for her. When I was done, we could spend the rest of our lives together. I left, I jumped, I landed. I ran to the pharmacy, prescription in hand. The doctor had been confused when I asked for it. Probably thought it was a reaction to his prognosis. A line. There was a line at the pharmacy. It took everything I had not to scream. But then I remembered, I had all the time in the world. Drug in hand, I dialed in the date of her diagnosis. I entered the code and pressed enter. ERROR: Abort, Retry, Fail? What happened next rendered the machine useless... Now! I had to get to her now! I had to cure her right now. I stole a car, I do n't know whose it was, I could n't even tell you what kind or color it was. At some point the police started chasing me. I outran them. At the entrance, security tried to stop me, I outran them. When they told me, my guilt and denial rushed to me at once, I could n't outrun it. I just wanted to spend the rest of my life with her, so I left. She just wanted to spend the rest of her life with me, so she asked me to stay.

Standing on top of our world, we watch as the sun rises over the island. The soft rays bathe the distant hills in gold, as the breeze blows through the dancing grass. The trees shivers as flock of birds take flight. Spots of white clouds the orange-hued sky, as it slowly turns azure. Far in the distance, a silver tower, shrouded in mist, pierces the heavens above. The waves crash down on the sandy beaches, and the endless sea merges with the horizon. I take in the sights, the smells, the sounds. Feeling both pride and joy, I turn to face to you. The air is warm, but your hand is warmer. I hold it close to me, closer still. The sun is shining bright, but your smile is brighter. We' re standing at the top of our world, the one we made together, and I can' t tell you how happy this has made me. "It' s almost time." You say. "I know." I reply. I rest my head on your shoulder, and take a long breath as I close my eyes. I' m at peace here. When I opened them again, I was in my bed, and a bittersweet feeling of both tranquility and sadness lingered in my mind. It was around 7 a.m., and I went about my daily routine, a smile etched on my face. I wrote what had happened in a dream journal I had started two years ago. After having read about lucid dreaming, and I wanted to try it. It took some time, but one day, I was able to control the outcome of my dreams. After a few weeks, something changed. There was something else, maybe someone else, with me. I couldn' t control them, and they couldn' t control me. I searched about it in books and online, but no one reported something similar. I wasn' t afraid, though. Their presence was soothing. We rarely spoke, but when we did, it was always meaningful. Together, we started building a world, our dream island. It brought me joy, and above all, peace. This feeling of inner peace lived on with me during the day. The sun was racing across the sky as we strolled down the ruins of a castle. Holes and cracks had let nature overtake the walls and floors, and the ceiling had long since crumbled. We walked down an old throne room, and you turned to face me. It was so sudden, I nearly bumped into you. You looked resolute, and you said two simple words: "Find me." I jolted awake. I knew what I had to do. I had to find you. So I searched, high and low, for days on end. Perhaps I thought it was fate, perhaps it was simply fool' s luck, but I felt as if I would eventually find you, if I kept trying. One evening, as if beckoned, I went in a coffee shop. I sat down with my coffee at an empty table, and looked up through the window at the red sky. Soon, someone came in, ordered the same thing as I did. They headed toward my table, and sat down in front of me, smiling brightly. Strangely, I felt at peace.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Roy is stabbed in a street fight.
output: He wakes up in a hospital bed, his body covered in bandages. A doctor tells him that he's lucky to be alive. Roy doesn't feel lucky. He feels angry. Angry at himself for getting involved in a stupid fight. Angry at the guy who stabbed him. And most of all, angry at the world for being such a shitty place. But then he meets a girl named Sarah. She's beautiful and kind and funny. And she makes him forget all about his anger. For a while, anyway. Because soon enough, Roy finds out that Sarah has her own problems. Her father is dying of cancer, and she's struggling to pay for his treatment. Roy wants to help her, but he doesn't have any money. So he decides to rob a bank. He knows it's wrong, but he figures it's better than letting Sarah suffer. Besides, he's already been stabbed once. What's the worst that could happen? As it turns out, quite a lot. Roy gets caught by the police and sent to prison. While he's there, he learns that Sarah's father died without ever seeing her again. And now she hates him for what he did. Roy spends the next five years in prison, thinking about all the ways he screwed up his life. But then one day, he gets released early for good behavior. He goes back to his hometown, hoping to make things right with Sarah. But she's not there anymore. She moved away after her father died, and nobody knows where she went. Roy is heartbroken. He wanders aimlessly through town, looking for any sign of Sarah. Finally, he sees her walking down the street. She looks different now—older, wiser, more mature—but it's definitely her. Roy runs up to her and tries to explain everything. How sorry he is for what he did. How much he loves her. But Sarah just shakes her head sadly. "It's too late," she says. "I've moved on." And then she walks away from him forever. Roy stands there watching her go, tears streaming down his face. He knows he'll never see her again. And even though he tried to change, it was too little too late. His past mistakes will haunt him forever.

This is late and also not exactly what you wanted. Your prompt happened to remind me of something I had thought about ages ago. The mystics observed the future of this conquest during the warp trip. Multiple light units spent weaving the spell with many more reading the fates and seeing their doom. Such is the way of our crusade. Countless planets have been dominated, countless slaves put under our command, and countless minerals stripped from their crust. Each world fought, but each was crushed as we knew how they would fight. The mystics watched the weave of fate and picked out the strand that gave us the best victory. This was meant to be another one of our empire. Another one to be crushed and stripped. Another to be enslaved and worked. For the first time in our history, perhaps since even the first time in creation, the mystics were wrong. There was supposed to be a single human. One that would lead their armies against us, Inspire them, Rally them, But ultimately, trap them. The hero was one of the twenty-five warriors who fought against us in the initial bout. We were supposed to kill the rest, capture him, implant him, and control him. He would be our puppet, leading the others to their destruction. But when the time came for us to strike, there were twenty-six warriors against us. Our army faltered. The hero we were meant to take was instead killed in our confusion. We ended up with the twenty sixth warrior: The one who the mystics did not see. We brought him to our ship and the mystics shrieked in terror. His past, his future, even his very existence, was hidden from them. In a panic, they turned their focus to the planets surface and found that there were millions like him. Millions we were blind to. They realized that the force hiding them was ancient and purposeful. This was not simply a random act of fate, nor was it an evolution of this species. Someone on this planet had once been able to touch the aether like can now. They weaved a powerful blessing and placed it on his spawn, making them hidden from other prying eyes. We had to flee. A direct conflict with this species, although would end in victory, would leave us with too many casualties. The human we took was fired back to the planet. We lied to him and claimed that this was a show of our species power and that they are never to leave this system. Hopefully the others believe it. Our empire could collapse if another species were to find out what these humans are capable of.

Five thousand six-hundred and seventy-three days. Fifteen years, twenty-seven weeks, five days. Since the Genetic Mapping and Research Studies act was passed. Since our own ambition of genetic editions, additions, was realized. Since humanity truly hit its crest, and now, I believe we certainly are headed downhill. My name is Isaac, I am a genetic engineer working for Lifeco, and I played a hand in the de-evolution of modern humanity. When we first started this, it was obvious we were doing the good work, helping those with certain genetic inferiority, destroying the predestined diseases that would cripple them later on in life, we were gods men doing the work only gods could ever have aspired to do. We had become gods in the eyes of the world, the one lab that started it all, our faces, the twelve of us, on the cover of every scientific magazine, journal, webcast, holovid, every single screen showed us. We were celebrities beyond anything the world had yet seen, and to think we did n't get into it for the money. Thats all beside the point now, we of course could't hold onto the secrets forever, others learned the processes and soon genome splicing and epigenetic interference were the rage. It was every father's gift to his sweet-sixteen, every anniversary present, and every newborns fate. We controlled fate. Now, all of these years later I am left to reflect. My original eleven friends that started this with me, have long since resided from the spotlight, I too. Money is no issue, we together must be worth at-least 500 billion, but what good is it. I would give it all away to alter the course of history, to rewrite what has been done, for now when I look out into the world I ca n't even recognize it. The roots where always there, deeply so in the capitalist mentality and society that held a severe strangle hold upon every american citizen, of course it would never relinquish its grip in the face of something so extraordinary as this. Now we have social stratification as never would we have thought possible, we thought it was bad in the early 2000's, we thought that was bad. We had n't seen horror. Now with genetic proof of "superiority" that those wealthiest enough to afford gene editions can claim, the poorest are left with such a feeling and direct attitude of inferiority, it is sickening. My mind aches, my bones burn with the pain of what has been done, If only it could be righted. With the increase in average intelligence and decrease in disease, you would think that statistics would show an increase in personal happiness. This is not so. One day, we will learn to treat each other well, as fellow humans. I fear I will not live to see that day but I know it ca n't get worse than this, I hope. I am dying from cancer, I have refused treatment, I have refused all geneditions, I'd rather die than submit to it all. They would never show that on the holo vid displays, though.

output: He finds his family home abandoned and learns they have moved on to California. Tom meets Jim Casy, who says he is no longer a preacher. Tom invites Casy to come with him, and along the way they meet Tom's uncle John. At the camp, the family waits in line for their turn to cook stew. Ma tells Tom she worries about how Pa will take the news of Tom's return. As they wait, a man approaches and asks if anyone wants to earn fifty cents picking cotton. The man says there is plenty of work, but the Joads say they will stick with their plan to go to California. The man becomes angry and accuses the Joads of trying to keep others from getting work. A fight breaks out, and Tom hits the man over the head with a shovel. The group flees, and Tom decides to leave the family and continue alone. He gives Casy his mother's pearl-handled .45 pistol. Tom arrives at Uncle John's house and finds the family preparing to leave. He hides in the back of the truck and falls asleep. When he wakes up, he sees that the family has stopped by a river. He gets out of the truck and walks down to the water. He sees a group of people gathered around a fire. One of them calls out to him, and he recognizes her voice as Rose of Sharon's. She tells him that she is pregnant and that Connie ran off. Tom goes to find his parents, and they tell him that they decided to stay in Oklahoma because they heard that there was no work in California. Tom says goodbye to his family and starts walking west. He comes across a group of migrant workers who offer him food and shelter. He stays with them for several nights, and then continues on his journey. He reaches the Colorado River and crosses it. On the other side, he meets a young boy named Al who offers to help him find work. Al takes Tom to a farm where he works as a sharecropper. The owner of the farm, Mr. Thomas, hires Tom to pick peaches. Tom works hard and earns enough money to buy a new pair of shoes. He also buys a gun and some ammunition. One night, while sitting around a campfire, Tom hears someone approaching. He grabs his gun and aims it at the figure. It turns out to be Jim Casy, who has been following Tom. Casy tells Tom that he has joined a union and plans to organize the migrants. Tom agrees to join him. They travel together to another farm where they meet Muley Graves, who tells them about the conditions at the government camps. Tom and Casy decide to go to one of the camps to investigate. When they arrive, they see that the conditions are terrible. There is no running water, no electricity, and very little food. Many of the children are sick, and some have died. Tom and Casy talk to the people living there and learn that the government is planning to close the camps. They decide to try to stop the closure. They gather a group of men and women and march to the office of the camp director. The director refuses to listen to them, so they start a riot. The police arrive and arrest everyone involved. Tom and Casy are taken to jail. While in jail, Tom receives a letter from his mother. She writes that she misses him and hopes he will come home soon. Tom replies that he loves her and promises to visit her when he can. After spending two months in jail, Tom and Casy are released. They return to the farm where they met Muley Graves. Muley tells them that the government closed the camps and sent the migrants back to Oklahoma. Tom and Casy decide to go to California to look for work. They hitchhike to Bakersfield, where they find jobs picking grapes. They work long hours for low wages, but they enjoy being outdoors and meeting new people. One day, while working in the fields, Tom sees a car pull up next to him. Inside is a woman holding a baby. She asks Tom if he knows where she can find a doctor. Tom tells her that there is a clinic nearby. The woman thanks him and drives away. Later that evening, Tom and Casy hear a commotion outside their tent. They go outside and see a crowd of people surrounding a man lying on the ground. The man is bleeding from a gunshot wound. Tom recognizes him as the man who gave him a ride earlier that day. Tom runs over to him and tries to help him, but the man dies before he can get medical attention. Tom feels guilty for not doing more to save the man's life. He wonders if he should have tried harder to convince the woman to take the man to the hospital. He decides that he needs to do something to make things right. This is late and also not exactly what you wanted. Your prompt happened to remind me of something I had thought about ages ago. The mystics observed the future of this conquest during the warp trip. Multiple light units spent weaving the spell with many more reading the fates and seeing their doom. Such is the way of our crusade. Countless planets have been dominated, countless slaves put under our command, and countless minerals stripped from their crust. Each world fought, but each was crushed as we knew how they would fight. The mystics watched the weave of fate and picked out the strand that gave us the best victory. This was meant to be another one of our empire. Another one to be crushed and stripped. Another to be enslaved and worked. For the first time in our history, perhaps since even the first time in creation, the mystics were wrong. There was supposed to be a single human. One that would lead their armies against us, Inspire them, Rally them, But ultimately, trap them. The hero was one of the twenty-five warriors who fought against us in the initial bout. We were supposed to kill the rest, capture him, implant him, and control him. He would be our puppet, leading the others to their destruction. But when the time came for us to strike, there were twenty-six warriors against us. Our army faltered. The hero we were meant to take was instead killed in our confusion. We ended up with the twenty sixth warrior: The one who the mystics did not see. We brought him to our ship and the mystics shrieked in terror. His past, his future, even his very existence, was hidden from them. In a panic, they turned their focus to the planets surface and found that there were millions like him. Millions we were blind to. They realized that the force hiding them was ancient and purposeful. This was not simply a random act of fate, nor was it an evolution of this species. Someone on this planet had once been able to touch the aether like can now. They weaved a powerful blessing and placed it on his spawn, making them hidden from other prying eyes. We had to flee. A direct conflict with this species, although would end in victory, would leave us with too many casualties. The human we took was fired back to the planet. We lied to him and claimed that this was a show of our species power and that they are never to leave this system. Hopefully the others believe it. Our empire could collapse if another species were to find out what these humans are capable of.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Tom meets former preacher Jim Casy on his way home.
output: Tom tells Casy he has just been released from prison after serving four years for killing a man in self-defense. Casy says he's lost his calling and is now a wandering man. When Tom arrives at his family's farm, he finds that the land has been seized by the bank and the house burned down. The Joads are packing up to move west to California, where they hope to find work picking fruit. Ma Joad is worried about her sickly son Noah, who refuses to go with them. Pa Joad tries to convince Noah to come along, but he won't budge. As the family sets off in their old truck, Tom sees a turtle crossing the road and stops to pick it up. He puts the turtle in the truck with them, saying it's good luck. The Joads make their way across Oklahoma and into Texas, where they stop at a campsite for migrant workers. There, they meet the Wilsons, a couple from Kansas who are also heading to California. The two families decide to travel together. Along the way, they encounter many hardships, including dust storms, car trouble, and hunger. They also witness the cruelty of the police and landowners towards the migrants. Despite all this, the Joads remain hopeful that things will get better in California. However, when they finally arrive, they find that conditions are even worse than they expected. The farms are overcrowded and the pay is low. Many of the migrants are forced to live in squalid campsites with little food or water. The Joads struggle to survive, but eventually they find work picking peaches. One day, while working in the fields, Tom gets into a fight with a foreman who is mistreating the workers. The foreman pulls a knife on Tom, but before he can use it, Tom hits him over the head with a shovel. The foreman dies and Tom is arrested. While in jail, Tom meets Jim Casy again. Casy has become a labor organizer and is trying to help the migrants form a union. He convinces Tom to join him and they escape from jail together. The two men return to the peach orchard and start organizing the workers. They hold meetings and rallies, and soon the entire valley is on strike. The landowners respond by sending in armed thugs to break up the strikes. In the ensuing violence, several people are killed, including Jim Casy. Tom is heartbroken by his friend's death, but he continues fighting for the rights of the workers. Eventually, the government steps in and forces the landowners to negotiate with the strikers. The workers win some concessions, but they know that the battle is far from over. As they prepare to leave the valley, Tom reflects on everything that has happened. He knows that life will always be hard for the poor and downtrodden, but he also knows that they must keep fighting for justice. "We'll go on forever," he says, "because we're the people."

All Harry could think about was the prophecy. "The power the Dark Lord knows not..." Dumbledore thought it was love. .. but hugs would n't kill monsters. That was when it hit him, Voldemort knew nothing of muggles, right? So something muggle had to be the power he knew not! Harry thought himself terribly clever. oo7, listening to him mutter through the microphone he had hidden in the boy's room simply chuckled. Took the lad long enough. Bond nonchalantly walked away and called M on his phone. "M, the lad finally got the idea. Should I approach?" a few seconds passed as Bond listened to M, "Roger that, I'll approach him before his birthday. Should be plenty of time to deal with these homegrown terrorists and get the lad to school on time." -scene break Voldemort could n't believe what was happening. For the past thirty days he had every single minion that left the Malfoy manor get shipped back in a body bag. He had n't even known muggles had those. Just goes to show how the animals could steal the dignity from wizards even in death. He was left with Wormtail and Bellatrix. Granted Bella was loyal, but she was completely insane. His most cunning and resourceful follower, the best deatheater he had, reduced to an insane hag who was good for nothing more than pointing at something he wanted destroyed and then watching it burn. A deep sigh dragged itself out of him. He could n't bring himself to even try to list any redeeming qualities in Wormtail. That was when he heard it, a muffled sound like nothing he had ever heard followed by the unmistakable sound of a dead body hitting the ground. Quick steps brought him into the kitchen in time to see a man about his age in a muggle suit dabbing a bit of blood from his face, Wormtail laying in a pool of his own blood behind him, with Bellatrix dying at his feet. Voldemort could n't remember ever being this angry. A growl issued from his clenched teeth. "Who are you?!" Voldemort shouted, even as he raised his wand to cast crucio on this fool who defied him. The muggle simply raised a hand with some device in it and pushed a bright red button on it. Pain like Voldemort had never felt corsed through his body as the traps he had n't noticed when he barged in shot tiny barbed hooks into his body attached to the launchers by a thin piece of wire. Then the traps sent 25 mill Ampere of electricity coursing through his body. Only the fact that the electricity was still flowing through him, forcing his muscles to contract, kept Voldemort standing. "The name is Bond, James Bond. Harry Potter sends his regards. Do n't worry about dying though old chap, MI6 has plans for you."

output: They meet Muley Graves, who tells them that the family has gone to stay with Uncle John because their farm has been repossessed by the bank. Tom and Casy decide to go to Uncle John's place to look for work. On the way they meet a truck driver named Al, who offers them a ride. When they arrive at Uncle John's place, they find that the family has already moved on. They learn that the family is headed for California, where there is said to be work picking fruit. Tom and Casy decide to follow the family to California. They hitchhike and walk until they reach the state line. There they are stopped by a border patrol officer, who tells them that they need to have a job lined up before they can enter the state. Tom and Casy tell the officer that they are looking for work, and he lets them pass. They continue on their journey, eventually reaching the town of Weedpatch. There they find the Joads living in a government camp for migrant workers. The conditions in the camp are poor, but the Joads are happy to be together again. Tom and Casy help the family settle in and start looking for work. They soon discover that there is very little work available, and what work there is pays very little. The family struggles to make ends meet, but they manage to survive. One day, while working in the fields, Tom meets a girl named Rose of Sharon. She is pregnant and her husband has left her. Tom takes pity on her and helps her find a place to live. He also starts teaching her how to read and write. As the months pass, Tom and Rose of Sharon fall in love. They marry and have a child together. The family continues to struggle, but they remain hopeful that things will improve. One day, while working in the fields, Tom sees a group of men approaching. Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
I never had any friend, not really surprising I guess. I learnt to not not judge people, we all have something scary or disgusting in our past but seeing it makes it really hard to socialize with anyone. I work as a detective, a private one, the kind that always know if someone is guilty. I was on wandering in a public hospital in order to find if yes or no Mr.wallace was lying to his daughter about his treatement. This was going to be a day that would change me for the rest of my life, as I walked through a corridor, heading to the hospital's archives room, something caught my eyes in a patient room, I stopped instantly and thought I was going crazy. in this room, there was an elder woman, probably 80, with her family, I was so confused by what I saw, or rather by what I did n't saw, I stayed at the door for what could have been hours before her family said goodbye to "Lucy", and left. I smiled, in fact I even laughed like never before, a nurse looked at me with a worried expression. I calmed myself and entered the room. She looked at me, just a bit surprised and I sat on the chair, close to her bed and asked probably sounding completely insane: -" How did you do?" my voice was trembling "never lied? never cheated? never hated someone? it's impossible..." my voice was completely broken and I felt tears on my face and my hands. She smiled back at me "what are you talking about young man? you should n't cry here! it's rude, I'm the one who is old and trapped here, go out and enjoy life" I did go out. It was so frustrating, what could I have said? I was waiting to meet someone like her pretty much since i was born, and all I could feel was hate, all my life I thought This someone COULD NOT exist and yet here was she.... I forgot about Mr.Wallace, I walked in the streets for some times. I stopped myself in front of a shop window, looked at my reflexion. They were here, all my sins, I could see them as clearly as on anyone else. A sad smile on my face, I went home, wrote this letter. My heart is heavy and my head even more, I need to end this.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
The Joad family prepares to leave for California.
output:
The men load their possessions into the truck while the women cook breakfast. Ma Joad tells Tom that Jim Casy has been staying with them since he returned from prison. Tom asks why they didn't tell him sooner, and Pa explains that they wanted to surprise him. He also says that Uncle John has died, which upsets Tom because he loved his uncle very much. As they drive away, Tom sees a sign advertising land for sale near Bakersfield, California. He decides to stop there first before continuing westward toward Los Angeles.

Tom arrives at the farm where he worked when he was younger. His former boss greets him warmly and offers him a job picking cotton. However, Tom refuses, saying that he wants to start over somewhere new. Instead, he goes to visit Muley Graves, another ex-convict who lives nearby. Muley tells Tom about how things have changed since he last visited; many farmers now use tractors instead of mules to plow fields, making manual labor unnecessary. This news depresses Tom further, especially after learning that most of the local farms belong to large corporations rather than individual families like his own.

After leaving Muley's house, Tom drives around aimlessly until nightfall. Then, he pulls off the road and parks under a tree. While sitting alone in the dark, he thinks back to happier times spent with his family. Suddenly, he hears footsteps approaching behind him. Turning around, he finds himself face-to-face with Jim Casy, who reveals that he followed Tom all the way from Oklahoma. Together, they discuss their plans for the future. Jim suggests that they join forces and travel together across America, looking for work wherever possible. Although reluctant at first, Tom eventually agrees, realizing that he needs companionship during these difficult times.

The next morning, Tom wakes up early and begins driving again. Along the way, he passes several abandoned houses and empty lots covered in weeds. Eventually, he reaches the outskirts of Fresno, California. There, he stops at a gas station and buys food and supplies. Afterwards, he continues south along Highway 99 towards Tulare County. By evening, he reaches Visalia, where he spends the night sleeping inside his car.

In the morning, Tom gets ready to resume his journey. Before doing so, however, he notices two men standing outside the diner next door. One of them appears to recognize Tom, causing him to become nervous. When the stranger approaches him, Tom recognizes him as Preacher Casey, whom he met briefly while working on the railroad years ago. Despite being wary of strangers, Tom allows Preacher Casey to accompany him throughout the remainder of his trip.

As they continue down the highway, Preacher Casey shares stories about his experiences traveling across America. Among other places, he mentions visiting New York City, Chicago, Detroit, St. Louis, Kansas City, Denver, Salt Lake City, San Francisco, Seattle, Portland, Vancouver, Calgary, Edmonton, Winnipeg, Regina, Saskatoon, Moose Jaw, Brandon, Thunder Bay, Sudbury, Toronto, Montreal, Quebec City, Halifax, Saint John, Fredericton, Charlottetown, Moncton, Sydney, Corner Brook, Gander, Goose Bay, Happy Valley-Goose Bay, Churchill Falls, Fort McMurray, Grande Prairie, Peace River, Dawson Creek, Whitehorse, Yellowknife, Inuvik, Tuktoyaktuk, Cambridge Bay, Resolute Bay, Pangnirtung, Iqaluit, Rankin Inlet, Baker Lake, Coral Harbour, Arviat, Kugluktuk, Hall Beach, Igloolik, Pond Inlet, Clyde River, Qikiqtarjuaq, Grise Fiord, Arctic Bay, Nanisivik, Taloyoak, Repulse Bay, Chesterfield Inlet, Whale Cove, Cape Dorset, Pangnirtung Fjord, Naujaat, Kimmirut, Kinngait, Pelly Bay, Sachs Harbour, Ulukhaktok, Paulatuk, Tsiigehtchic, Fort Good Hope, Norman Wells, Hay River, Fort Smith, Fort Resolution, Fort Simpson, Fort Liard, Fort Providence, Fort McPherson, Fort Nelson, Fort St. James, Fort St. John, Fort Vermilion, Fort Chipewyan, Fort McMurray, Fort McKay, Fort Saskatchewan, Fort McMurray, Fort McMurray, Fort McMurray, Fort McMurray, Fort McMurray, Fort McMurray, Fort McMurray, Fort McMurray, Fort McMurray, Fort McMurray, Fort McMurray, Fort McMurray, Fort McMurray, Fort McMurray, Fort McMurray, Fort McMurray, Fort McMurray, Fort McMurray, Fort McMurray, Fort McMurray, Fort McMurray, Fort McMurray, Fort McMurray, Fort McMurray, Fort McMurray, Fort McMurray, Fort McMurray, Fort McMurray, Fort McMurray, Fort McMurray, Fort McMurray, Fort McMurray,

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
My story started where a lot have ended these past 10 years: with a single bullet. Living in post-war Britain, death was not an uncommon sight. Everyone had at least one firearm to defend themselves, everyone had encountered gunfire in the streets, and everyone knew what it meant to live every day like it could be their last. The revolution that was supposed to end the tyranny of a dictatorship had ripped the country apart; counties had split into factions, all threatening total destruction of the others. In ten years the population was decimated, the country reduced to a crumbling mass of fallen buildings and civilians with guns. All around me was depression, death, dirt, famine. Thinking about it, it's quite hilarious, in such a depressing way. The sacks of bones, flesh and organs we saw everyday were once living, breathing, talking human beings. They had a mother, a father, a pet, a first love, they were educated, they succeeded and they failed. And they died. A single bullet can end so much. That morning, as I wandered to the local shop for some bread, clutching my rifle, my world completely ended. I had no time to react; as soon as I entered Grange Avenue a bullet burrowed into my head, smashing part of my brain, and knocking me straight out cold. I woke in a beautiful wooden chalet, bright natural light streaming through vast windows above the soft, clean bed that I rested in. My itchy, dirty clothes were replaced with beautiful white robes, soft as silk and cleaner than anything I had ever seen. I sat up, and looked around the room - it was furnished luxuriously, with beautiful gold-leaf chairs and fantastic bright works of art hanging around the room. I got up and left the room, and immediately my breath was forced from me. The crumbled grey streets of London had gone. In their place were beautiful old chalets, bright white skyscrapers, and marble streets. I could also see a very unfamiliar sight - a beautiful emerald park, littered with tall, radiant trees, ferns, and glowing coloured flowers. Clear water ran through them. All around the streets were people dressed similar to me, smiling and talking and laughing. The smog-ridden sky had been replaced with a beautiful, deep purple, but the world was light around me and the I could see the vast orange sun dipping behind the structures around the city. For the first time in ten years I smiled. That bullet took me to a better place.

output: They are joined by the Wilsons, who own a car. The group travels together until the Wilsons' car breaks down. The Joads continue on without them. Along the way, they meet many other migrants who are also heading west. Some of them are friendly, while others are hostile. The Joads eventually reach California, but they find that things are not as good there as they had hoped. There is little work available, and the wages are low. The family struggles to make ends meet. One day, Tom gets into a fight with a man named Floyd Knowles. Floyd accuses Tom of stealing his job, and the two men get into a brawl. Tom kills Floyd in self-defense. He is arrested and sent to prison. While he is away, Ma Joad takes over as the leader of the family. She does her best to keep everyone together, but it is difficult. Eventually, the family decides to move on again. They travel north, hoping to find better opportunities. However, they encounter more hardship along the way. Finally, they arrive in Oregon. There, they find work picking fruit. It is hard labor, but it pays well enough to support the family. The Joads settle down in Oregon and try to build new lives for themselves. However, they never forget their roots. They always remember the lessons they learned during their journey west.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
It was like double-vision, except it was the past. How can something fictional seem so vivid...? The distant, exotic land we came from, its gilded avenues, its glistening intricate spires, its profound natural beauty with lushly verdant banks hugging the rivers that snaked between the dunes. .. None of it was there. It was all nothing more than a dream. But I am not a lie. I stare at my hands, flexing them, examining the callouses accumulated by work never done, cracks formed of age never lived, and despite the warmth of the bright sun just passing its zenith above, I shiver. "Amir," I hear a voice call, and my heart tugs at what I know to be familiarity. "Hassan...?" I uncertainly reply as I look up. Our gazes meet. I could swear I saw in his eyes the same false memories flashing behind mine. Childhood among parents who never lived, in a community that was never built, attending an academy that was never founded, graduating from a ceremony never held... He nods hollowly, as if to confirm these very musings. "... We have to pack the supplies, Amir. His Majesty will be staying at the palace, and the staff are directing us to where we are to stow his wardrobe and leave his tributes to The Sultan." My mouth was dry, but not in response to his words. At some point I realized my'old friend' Hassan was talking only to fill the screaming void in our minds. To'Sound Normal', like'Real People'. My stomach is a knot of ice. Still, the skills of a life as-yet unlived surface readily to the forefront of my mind. How to port the many caskets of His Majesty Prince Ali's wares. "... Yes. I will coordinate with the provisioner. If my memory serves," I pause a bit too long, lost in the jarring disjunction of citing false memories, "... it is customary to serve a great feast with the arrival of a dignitary. The many delicacies of our homeland are sure to leave a resounding impression upon The Sultan's court." Hassan's expression tightens. I feel his heartache, for this homeland which we have never seen with real eyes, and never shall. He hesitantly takes a step nearer and dispenses a conciliatory pat to my shoulder. A mutual understanding. We were truly all feeling it, every last member of His Majesty Prince Ali's vanguard.... he was n't even really a prince. I shudder and turn, to address the court provisioner by name. He's just as haunted and startled as I that we know one another, but everything is running smoothly. We have no solace from our inner thoughts. We can only push on in the hopes that the minutia will wash away the horror.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
You know those nightmares you had as a child, where you'd be somewhere familiar yet completely alien? As though your home had suddenly become some faraway land, and your only goal was to return home. Well in 2014, that's exactly what happened to everyone in the world. I was on my way to an important business meeting, off to discuss some law, and how my company could avoid it, when it all happened. I checked my watch to see the time, and as I looked up, I saw a blinding flash off in the distance, lighting up the once blue sky in streaks of white. Next, it was followed by an eardrum shattering bang, like a hundred thousand gunshots going off at once. Then, finally, the blast. A wall of rock, stone, dirt and trash and flew towards me, silhouetted by the strange white light. I turned to run, but like a wave washing over the ocean, anything in the path of that wall was thrown like a ragdoll. The last thing I remember was being thrown what felt like miles into the air, and rushing down back into that swirling vortex of light. When I woke, it was night time. Others seemed to be sitting up around me, and the confused look on the faces that surrounded me seemed to speak louder than words that this was not a normal occurrence. I checked my watch, and had a terrible realisation. It was 3 am, and I was ridiculously late for my meeting! I tried to get to my feet, but the second I tried to stand, my legs gave way underneath me. What the hell was going on? After a few minutes I had enough strength to drag myself up by a nearby stair railing. For the first time since waking, I looked around. Something was wrong. As I looked, I saw the once manicured strips of grass and trees had overgrown to ridiculous proportions, and the streets were covered in trash, empty food packages, and bones. Wait what the hell? Upon further inspection, I saw they were human. Jesus Christ, what the hell happened. It was then that I checked my watch again. A neat little feature it had was that it told the time in seconds, minutes, hours, days and years. The blood drained from my face as I saw what I'd missed earlier. 3:04 am. Friday. 13th of June. 2015. As I wondered what the hell was going on, something rustled through the bushes behind me. Something big. As I saw glowing red eyes light the way. Then was the first time I wondered, what left those bones?

I was treated like I was special the second I was born. # 1. The last of the children born on Earth, to a middle-class family in the heart of New York. I was supposed to be the talisman, the last hope for humanity. I was supposed to lead us into the stars and break the genetic disease that ravaged our planet. I was supposed to find a cure and make it possible to continue the human race again. So the prophecy foretold, in that huge book held deep within the vaults of the UN Building, the last surviving testament the Great Leader himself. I was supposed to be the second coming of him, he who had found the disease eating our DNA, he who had brought the world together under one almighty, omniscient umbrella. I was supposed to be him incarnate once again. Time went by and I failed at every turn. I was reviled. I could n't do math well enough; anatomy confused me. How was I supposed to find a cure for the disease when I could n't even name the parts of a cell? Riots ensued. "We're all going to die! Humanity is doomed!" My parents and the few advisers that remained to keep them safe tried their hardest to educate me, to let me fulfill my destiny. They tried to save the human race. The crowds got Dad first. When they came, in the middle of the night on Halloween, my parents thought it was the last two kids in New York besides myself, trick-or-treating despite the fact that they were almost fifteen each. They shot Dad in the chest, for producing the doom of humanity. Mom screamed and Dr. Evans shouted for us to run. Dr. Muller went with us while Evans held the back door against the mob. We ran for two weeks in Mom's sedan, keeping me hidden from view. I was n't allowed to leave the back seat, and I could n't take off my sweatshirt, even in the middle of Texas. It was only after the miracle birth of # 0 that we were safe. From the deep jungle of the Amazon came the true Inheritor of the Great Leader. She cracked the disease by the time she was 5. She gave humanity it's first commercial space fleet and colonies by 10. By 15, she was granted the title of Queen of Earth. And me? I will always be remembered as the Great Failure. The Great Pretender. The Church of the Queen still wants me hung for being the false Chosen One. So I had no choice. I ran. Into the depths of space, I ran. Somewhere, lost out in the stars, where no one could find me, where no one could look at that permanent scar on my wrist, that horrible # 1. It's lonely out here, but it's better to be lonely than dead.

output: What does this mean? # 2. The Guernsey Literary and Potato Peel Pie Society was a group of people who met regularly to discuss books and share ideas. They also enjoyed eating potato peel pie, which was made from potatoes that had been peeled and then mashed up with some butter and sugar. This dish became popular during World War II because it was easy to prepare and did not require any ingredients that were hard to come by. The society continued meeting long after the war ended, and its members included many famous authors such as Virginia Woolf, E.M. Forster, and T.S. Eliot. Today, there are several literary societies around the world that meet regularly to discuss books and share ideas. Some of these groups focus specifically on certain genres or topics, while others welcome anyone interested in reading and discussing literature. Regardless of their specific interests, all literary societies provide a valuable opportunity for people to connect over shared passions and learn more about different aspects of writing and publishing. If you enjoy reading and want to join a community of like-minded individuals, consider joining a local literary society today!

"The world is not full of black and white, but grey." That is the quote I lived by for years. For my entire life. It makes sense, ever since I understood what the colour around everyone was. It was normal to me at first. I did n't know I was any different from anyone else. Only when I asked my parents about it did I start to understand. They mistook my curiosity to imagination, and I was fine with that. No one needed to know about what I could see. It was really useful actually. And I have used it many times, for many situations. Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Juliet becomes intrigued by the society and starts corresponding with its members.
output: She learns that they are all women who have been wronged by men in their lives and seek revenge. Juliet decides to join them and help them carry out their plans. She also discovers that Romeo is part of another secret organization called the Montagues, which opposes the Capulets. Juliet realizes that she has fallen in love with him despite his affiliation with her enemies. She tries to convince him to leave the Montagues and join her cause, but he refuses. He tells her that he loves her too, but he can't betray his family and friends. Juliet feels torn between her loyalty to the Capulets and her feelings for Romeo. She doesn't want to hurt either side, but she knows that something must change soon. One night, while attending a ball hosted by the Prince of Verona, Juliet overhears a conversation between two noblemen. They reveal that they plan to assassinate the prince during the masquerade ball later that evening. Juliet rushes back to warn the Capulet leaders, but they dismiss her concerns as paranoia. Desperate to prevent bloodshed, Juliet decides to take matters into her own hands. She disguises herself as a man and infiltrates the Montague headquarters. There, she finds evidence linking Romeo to the plot against the prince. Heartbroken, Juliet confronts Romeo and demands answers. He admits everything and begs for forgiveness. However, before they can reconcile, the Capulets arrive and arrest both of them. In prison, Juliet reflects on her actions and regrets getting involved with such dangerous people. She wonders if she made the right choice by joining the Capulets or if she should've stayed neutral. Meanwhile, outside the jail cell, a riot breaks out among the citizens of Verona. The city descends into chaos as rival factions clash over power and control. Amidst the turmoil, Juliet receives word that the prince has pardoned her and released her from captivity. Overjoyed, she runs towards freedom...but then stops short. Something inside her won't let her go without saying goodbye to Romeo. With tears streaming down her face, Juliet returns to the dungeon where Romeo awaits execution. She professes her undying love for him and promises to wait for him forever. Then, she kisses him passionately one last time before leaving him behind. Outside, the streets are filled with violence and destruction. Buildings burn, bodies litter the ground, and screams fill the air. Yet amidst all the madness, Juliet sees hope. A new dawn rises above the horizon, signaling a fresh start for Verona. Inspired by this sight, Juliet vows to rebuild the city and create a peaceful future for everyone. And thus ends our tale of star-crossed lovers turned revolutionaries. May their legacy live on through generations to come!

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
THE WALL IS BUILT... EVENTUALLY Centipedes slink through smooth gaps in a rotten facade. Moss hides in the shadows and vines creep towards the light. The wall has existed all my life, and all through the lives of my oldest memorable ancestors. It is the lore of our people, that they traveled from distant lands where compassion was an economy, and peace an inescapable truth to seek opportunity. Well, another inescapable truth is that man, even in a place of prosperity, will often succumb to wanderlust. That is the story of these ancestors. Which in a way, is the story of myself. Or at least, why I came to be. They boarded a ship and set forth to the west. For weeks, the sea lay docile beneath their ship. Lazy waves lapped the hull, and steady winds pulled her forward. The travelers, who fancied themselves much more intrepid than they were, laughed among themselves at their own good fortune. "If only the naysayers back home could see the state of things on this veritable pleasure cruise!" they would exclaim defiantly. This trend settled into a routine before long, and such was the new life of the wayfarer. The sun would break the horizon, and they would rise from sleep to great it. Meals were consumed, feet took to dance, and wine was drunk. Unfortunately, even the most steadfast of routines is fleeting in the scheme of life, and one night bad luck finally befell them. A new trend. And one that would last certainly longer than the previous. The captain saw through a glass large clouds of deep black swirling in the distance. Dusk was minutes off, so he took to worry. The coarse was altered, and the ship's path now listed somewhat to the South and away from danger. It was a reasonable precaution, and would have been a perfect solution if the maps were more reliable. They, however, most certainly were not. Therefore, it was not. If smooth seas never made a skillful sailor, it is no surprise that the captain and crew had some serious shortcomings. To blame any single one of them for the wreck would be terribly unfair. The real culprit was hidden somewhere in the barrels of wine and mead stored below deck. And in the habit they had made of good fortune. With bad weather behind, and brisk air above, the crew had mostly joined the passengers within the ships belly. With so many people gathered so closely, either violence or levity are guaranteed, and on this evening the mood kept a lighter tone. Above, in the crows nest, a lonely man listened resentfully as voices sang, and feet stomped to the tune of jovial tunes played by practiced hands. Fiddles, mandolins, and accordions bickered playfully for hours and with each passing minute the weary occupier of the crow's nest grew more bitter. Just before midnight, when a particularly quick tune was met with a particularly rowdy cheer, his mind was made. "Crow's nest be damned! Mead be downed!" The latter part of that statement has sprung from the mouths of men before many a poor decision. And always with the same degree of vigor. Within moments the deck of the ship sat vacant, while the hold was full to burst. Libations continued to flow, while a jagged rocky coast sneaked ever closer.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
My story started where a lot have ended these past 10 years: with a single bullet. Living in post-war Britain, death was not an uncommon sight. Everyone had at least one firearm to defend themselves, everyone had encountered gunfire in the streets, and everyone knew what it meant to live every day like it could be their last. The revolution that was supposed to end the tyranny of a dictatorship had ripped the country apart; counties had split into factions, all threatening total destruction of the others. In ten years the population was decimated, the country reduced to a crumbling mass of fallen buildings and civilians with guns. All around me was depression, death, dirt, famine. Thinking about it, it's quite hilarious, in such a depressing way. The sacks of bones, flesh and organs we saw everyday were once living, breathing, talking human beings. They had a mother, a father, a pet, a first love, they were educated, they succeeded and they failed. And they died. A single bullet can end so much. That morning, as I wandered to the local shop for some bread, clutching my rifle, my world completely ended. I had no time to react; as soon as I entered Grange Avenue a bullet burrowed into my head, smashing part of my brain, and knocking me straight out cold. I woke in a beautiful wooden chalet, bright natural light streaming through vast windows above the soft, clean bed that I rested in. My itchy, dirty clothes were replaced with beautiful white robes, soft as silk and cleaner than anything I had ever seen. I sat up, and looked around the room - it was furnished luxuriously, with beautiful gold-leaf chairs and fantastic bright works of art hanging around the room. I got up and left the room, and immediately my breath was forced from me. The crumbled grey streets of London had gone. In their place were beautiful old chalets, bright white skyscrapers, and marble streets. I could also see a very unfamiliar sight - a beautiful emerald park, littered with tall, radiant trees, ferns, and glowing coloured flowers. Clear water ran through them. All around the streets were people dressed similar to me, smiling and talking and laughing. The smog-ridden sky had been replaced with a beautiful, deep purple, but the world was light around me and the I could see the vast orange sun dipping behind the structures around the city. For the first time in ten years I smiled. That bullet took me to a better place.

"The world is not full of black and white, but grey." That is the quote I lived by for years. For my entire life. It makes sense, ever since I understood what the colour around everyone was. It was normal to me at first. I did n't know I was any different from anyone else. Only when I asked my parents about it did I start to understand. They mistook my curiosity to imagination, and I was fine with that. No one needed to know about what I could see. It was really useful actually. And I have used it many times, for many situations. Back to the quote. Like I said, I lived by it for years. But very recently, did I understand that there can be more colour to the world. I like that. The ideology that shades are n't the only thing a person can be, but a bright and vibrant hue. I first saw her in a fancy restaurant. She obviously did n't belong there. She wore a suit, with a blazer, and some nice dress pants. High heels that were n't really that high. And just a touch of makeup to glow a little bit. What made her not seem like she belonged there was her hair. As blue as the highlight around her self. And I could tell I was n't the only one seeing it, because everyone in the room was staring at her oddly. She left before I could say anything though, and I thought that was that. The second time I saw her was much better. It was just a normal day, I was walking to work, and I saw her. Hair so blue it almost looked black this time. But her nonetheless. I forgot about work and tried to catch up to her, only for her to get away from my grasp once again. The third time was not the charm apparently. I was at a party, and I saw her again. Of course, I thought it would be extremely easy to talk to her now. But somehow she still evaded me. It almost seemed like she could tell I was coming closer to her. Of course that was improbable. The fourth time, that was the charm. It had been years since I'd seen her, and I was n't really looking anymore, thinking that third time was the final time. But I saw her, in that same fancy restaurant I had seen her the firs time. But, instead of me approaching her, she walked straight up to me and said, "What're you having Red?" Red?

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Women are stripped of their rights and freedoms.
output:
They are forced into arranged marriages, where they are expected to bear children and serve their husbands. Women who refuse to comply are often beaten or killed. In some cases, women are even sold into slavery.

The government has also implemented strict laws regarding clothing. All women must wear long, loose-fitting garments that cover their bodies completely. They are not allowed to show any skin, including their faces. This law is enforced through public beatings and imprisonment.

In addition, women are forbidden from working outside the home. If they do find employment, they are paid significantly less than men for doing the same job. Many women are forced to take low-paying jobs such as cleaning houses or caring for children.

Despite these oppressive conditions, women continue to fight for their rights. Some have formed underground organizations that provide support and resources to those who need them most. Others have taken to the streets in protest, risking arrest and violence.

It is clear that the situation for women in this country is dire. However, there is hope. With continued pressure from both within and without, change may yet come. Until then, we must stand together and demand justice for all women everywhere.

title: the handmaid's tale
reference_events: A rightwing fundamentalist group takes over the United States.
Women are stripped of their rights and freedoms.

Offred reunites with her friend Moira at the Center.

Offred discovers a Latin phrase scratched into her room by her predecessor.

Offred contemplates escape, suicide, or pleading for mercy.

Nick tells Offred the Eyes are actually Mayday operatives helping her escape.
Offred is taken away by the operatives, leaving her fate ambiguous.

Professor Pieixoto presents evidence of Offred's narrative on cassette tapes.
It is suggested that Offred escaped to Canada or England and lived in seclusion.

My story started where a lot have ended these past 10 years: with a single bullet. Living in post-war Britain, death was not an uncommon sight. Everyone had at least one firearm to defend themselves, everyone had encountered gunfire in the streets, and everyone knew what it meant to live every day like it could be their last. The revolution that was supposed to end the tyranny of a dictatorship had ripped the country apart; counties had split into factions, all threatening total destruction of the others. In ten years the population was decimated, the country reduced to a crumbling mass of fallen buildings and civilians with guns. All around me was depression, death, dirt, famine. Thinking about it, it's quite hilarious, in such a depressing way. The sacks of bones, flesh and organs we saw everyday were once living, breathing, talking human beings. They had a mother, a father, a pet, a first love, they were educated, they succeeded and they failed. And they died. A single bullet can end so much. That morning, as I wandered to the local shop for some bread, clutching my rifle, my world completely ended. I had no time to react; as soon as I entered Grange Avenue a bullet burrowed into my head, smashing part of my brain, and knocking me straight out cold. I woke in a beautiful wooden chalet, bright natural light streaming through vast windows above the soft, clean bed that I rested in. My itchy, dirty clothes were replaced with beautiful white robes, soft as silk and cleaner than anything I had ever seen. I sat up, and looked around the room - it was furnished luxuriously, with beautiful gold-leaf chairs and fantastic bright works of art hanging around the room. I got up and left the room, and immediately my breath was forced from me. The crumbled grey streets of London had gone. In their place were beautiful old chalets, bright white skyscrapers, and marble streets. I could also see a very unfamiliar sight - a beautiful emerald park, littered with tall, radiant trees, ferns, and glowing coloured flowers. Clear water ran through them. All around the streets were people dressed similar to me, smiling and talking and laughing. The smog-ridden sky had been replaced with a beautiful, deep purple, but the world was light around me and the I could see the vast orange sun dipping behind the structures around the city. For the first time in ten years I smiled. That bullet took me to a better place.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Offred is separated from her husband and daughter.
output: She is sent to a training center called the Red Center, where she is trained by women called "Aunts" to become a Handmaid. Offred is assigned to work for Commander Fred Waterford and his wife Serena Joy. Offred is expected to conceive a child for the couple because Serena Joy cannot bear children. Offred has sex with the Commander while Serena Joy holds her hands. Offred becomes pregnant. She gives birth to a baby girl named Agnes. Offred is allowed to keep the baby for a short period of time before she is taken away. Offred is then reassigned to another household. Offred meets Nick, who is the chauffeur for the new family. Offred and Nick fall in love. Offred becomes pregnant again. This time, she gives birth to a boy named Luke. Offred is allowed to keep Luke for a longer period of time before he is taken away. Offred is then reassigned to yet another household. Offred meets Moira, who is a fellow Handmaid. Moira tells Offred that there is a resistance movement against Gilead. Offred decides to join the resistance. Offred is captured by the Eyes, which are the secret police of Gilead. Offred is tortured and interrogated. Offred is eventually released. Offred returns to her home. Offred finds out that her husband and daughter are still alive. Offred reunites with her family. Offred and her family escape from Gilead. They start a new life in Canada.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
I have reaped the souls of many over the course of my years as death. Souls of the good, the bad, and everything between have always been sown by another before I pluck them from the Earth at their appropriate time. Even the ones that believe it is n't their time or ask for just one more opportunity to do what they wish, must be taken without question because, well, its just the way my job is. To me, it never mattered where they were at in life. I just carried them over with ease. Never once had experienced trouble in my task as I had even had to pluck sweet children from the arms of their mothers. However, it all changed when I was tasked with taking the soul of David Mckiny. I watched David from the day he entered the Earth, and never before had I seen someone as special as him. He always thought of others first, always trying to help others before even contemplating his own commodities. I approached him on the fateful day at exactly noon. He was old now, no longer in his prime as he was finally about to lose his battle with cancer. I approached him as the hourglass emptied completely to the bottom. I spoke to him," David you must know who I am at this hour." He answered not necessarily speaking to me," If only I had helped more.... If only I could have have had more time! How dreadful to go when so many more need help!" At this moment I found it immensely hard to fulfill my task. I was not met with a man begging for more time only to waste it on fruitless trivialities. I was met with a man who wanted to bring grace to more people. He wished not to make his life better, but only cares to try to improve as many others as possible. I finally brought myself to say," David you have been a good man, but death is one thing which is inevitable, and not even I can grant time when someone is due. You must come along now with me." He allowed his soul to leave his body, a tear running down his face as he did. I extended my arm to him and he obliged. If there is one final peace to the journey is the experience of seeing one's life pass by as I guide them to the next step. I saw, as we walked, countless people who David had helped, most of which he had n't known and would never see again. Every part of me wished to guide him back to his body, but I knew I had a task to fulfill, and I knew I had to complete it. After a long while of walking down the path, we finally came to the gateway where David would continue without my guidance. I never know where the person will go once they enter, but I knew David would go to a place that would have the same passion in death as he did in life. I never had such a hard time seeing someone move on, and I sat a while thinking of how tragic it is for someone like David, genuinely the best kind of person, to be taken from such a cruel world when he one of the few people who deserved to stay. Anyways I found myself contemplating to long, and I moved on to reap the rest of the souls I had to fetch that day.
