Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Offred is taken to the Rachel and Leah Re-Education Center.
output: She is given a new name: Offred. The Handmaids are taught to obey the Commanders and bear children for them. They are also taught to hate other women. Offred is assigned to Commander Fred Waterford and his wife Serena Joy. Offred has flashbacks of her previous life with her husband Luke and daughter Hannah. She remembers how she used to work as a librarian and how she loved reading books. Now, she is not allowed to read anything except the Bible. One day, Offred meets Ofglen, another Handmaid. They become friends and share secrets. Ofglen tells Offred about Mayday, a resistance group that helps Handmaids escape. Offred decides to join Mayday. She starts stealing things from the Commander's house and hiding them under her mattress. One night, Offred sneaks out of the house and goes to meet Ofglen. They walk through the city together and talk about their plans to escape. Suddenly, they hear sirens and see flashing lights. They run away and hide in an alleyway. A few minutes later, they hear footsteps approaching. It's Nick, the Commander's driver. He takes them to a safe house where they meet Moira, another Handmaid who escaped. Moira tells them about the Colonies, where Handmaids are sent if they fail to conceive. The Colonies are full of toxic waste and radiation. No one ever comes back alive. Offred realizes that she needs to get pregnant soon or else she'll be sent to the Colonies. She asks Nick to impregnate her. He agrees and they have sex. A few weeks later, Offred finds out that she's pregnant. She's happy but scared at the same time. She knows that she won't be able to keep the baby. She'll have to give it up to the Commander and his Wife. One day, Offred sees Ofglen being arrested by the Eyes. She doesn't know what happened to her friend. Later, she learns that Ofglen committed suicide. Offred feels guilty for not helping her friend. She wonders if she should try to escape too. But then she thinks about her unborn child. She decides to stay and hope for the best. Months pass by and Offred gives birth to a healthy baby girl. The Commander names her Agnes. Offred loves her daughter very much but she knows that she can't keep her forever. One day, the Commander calls Offred into his office. He tells her that he wants to send her to the Colonies. Offred begs him to let her stay but he refuses. He says that she's useless now that she's given birth. Offred is devastated. She doesn't want to die in the Colonies. She tries to think of a way to escape but she can't come up with anything. Then, she hears a noise outside. It's Nick. He's here to rescue her. He tells her that he's part of Mayday and that he's going to take her to Canada. Offred is relieved. She thanks Nick and follows him out of the house. They drive away from Gilead and towards freedom.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
It was like double-vision, except it was the past. How can something fictional seem so vivid...? The distant, exotic land we came from, its gilded avenues, its glistening intricate spires, its profound natural beauty with lushly verdant banks hugging the rivers that snaked between the dunes. .. None of it was there. It was all nothing more than a dream. But I am not a lie. I stare at my hands, flexing them, examining the callouses accumulated by work never done, cracks formed of age never lived, and despite the warmth of the bright sun just passing its zenith above, I shiver. "Amir," I hear a voice call, and my heart tugs at what I know to be familiarity. "Hassan...?" I uncertainly reply as I look up. Our gazes meet. I could swear I saw in his eyes the same false memories flashing behind mine. Childhood among parents who never lived, in a community that was never built, attending an academy that was never founded, graduating from a ceremony never held... He nods hollowly, as if to confirm these very musings. "... We have to pack the supplies, Amir. His Majesty will be staying at the palace, and the staff are directing us to where we are to stow his wardrobe and leave his tributes to The Sultan." My mouth was dry, but not in response to his words. At some point I realized my'old friend' Hassan was talking only to fill the screaming void in our minds. To'Sound Normal', like'Real People'. My stomach is a knot of ice. Still, the skills of a life as-yet unlived surface readily to the forefront of my mind. How to port the many caskets of His Majesty Prince Ali's wares. "... Yes. I will coordinate with the provisioner. If my memory serves," I pause a bit too long, lost in the jarring disjunction of citing false memories, "... it is customary to serve a great feast with the arrival of a dignitary. The many delicacies of our homeland are sure to leave a resounding impression upon The Sultan's court." Hassan's expression tightens. I feel his heartache, for this homeland which we have never seen with real eyes, and never shall. He hesitantly takes a step nearer and dispenses a conciliatory pat to my shoulder. A mutual understanding. We were truly all feeling it, every last member of His Majesty Prince Ali's vanguard.... he was n't even really a prince. I shudder and turn, to address the court provisioner by name. He's just as haunted and startled as I that we know one another, but everything is running smoothly. We have no solace from our inner thoughts. We can only push on in the hopes that the minutia will wash away the horror.

output: They talk about their lives before Gilead and how they ended up here. Offred tells Moira about her husband Luke and daughter Hannah, who she hasn't seen since they fled to Canada. Moira reveals that she tried to escape once but was caught and brought back. She also says that she knows someone who might be able to help them get out again. Offred agrees to go along with Moira's plan, even though she doesn't want to leave without finding out what happened to Luke and Hannah. The next day, Offred goes through the motions of being a Handmaid while secretly planning her escape. She meets with Moira and learns that the person who can help them is named Ofglen. Ofglen used to be a Martha (a servant) but now works as a spy for Mayday, a resistance group fighting against Gilead. Ofglen gives Offred instructions on how to contact Mayday when she gets outside the city walls. That night, Offred sneaks into Commander Waterford's office and steals his car keys. Then she drives to the edge of town and waits for Ofglen to pick her up. When Ofglen arrives, she leads Offred to a safe house where other members of Mayday are waiting. One of them is Nick, the driver who helped Offred escape from the Red Center. Another is Janine, a former Handmaid who was forced to give birth to a child fathered by a Commander. And finally, there's Aunt Lydia, the woman who trained Offred and the other Handmaids. Aunt Lydia explains that she joined Mayday because she couldn't stand watching innocent women suffer anymore. Together, they make plans to overthrow Gilead and restore freedom to everyone.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
We never believed that the end would come, that the dawn would rise again. Every 300 years our moon orbits the world below us, this world is our guardian, it protects us, shelters us from all that the vast expanse of space has to offer: but it could not shelter us from itself, on the far side of the moons orbit lies a vast and ancient race, their empire sprawls across the planets surface and every 300 years, when our moon comes within striking distance they attack. It is said that when they do they bring with them giant beasts, created of the most foul magic, beasts of flesh with hearts as cold as ice. Our weapons could never stand against them, we never stood a chance. so when it came in 599 CE, the year of our holy father I huddled in fear in our capitol.My armies were in position to protect the citizens here, but I knew we stood no hope, our guns, as useful as they may be would never stand up against the might of the empire and so it was that on the turning point of the day we saw them come, and they came with the dawn. Vast ships pummeled our surface with rains of fire as the dawn swept across our land, melting the ever frozen landscape. Their armies landed on our surface, weapons firing some sort of plasmic mix. I watched my city crumble around me as the fighting raged on, then, then it happened. A sound like the great bellow of some ancient beast shuddered from within the earth itself; and with it they came. Hulking creatures in the shapes of men, my eyes adjusted slowly to the new light as I focused in on the great beasts that would be our doom. I watched them huge machines, not flesh but etched metal, rise and form into ranks. The Empires soldiers marched up main avenue right towards the metal horde that was slowly collecting outside our main base within the city, our last bastion. our only hope. In between the two armies, a small child wandered into the street, clearly having lost her mother and searching for anyone to car. My heart wretched as I saw one of the soldiers level its weapon at her. and my scream of pain filled the room as it fired. But as the smoke cleared I saw only a metal body, covered in plasma, shaking it off as if it were nothing more than fresh snow, and behind its protective metal shell sat the little girl. and I beheld the glory, of the new dawn.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Skeeter returns to her family's cotton plantation and finds her maid Constantine has left.
output: She asks her mother why she left and her mother tells her that Constantine had been stealing things from the house. Skeeter doesn't believe her and goes to see Constantine's daughter Aibileen who works as a maid for another white woman. Aibileen tells her that Constantine was fired because she refused to use the bathroom inside the house. Skeeter decides to write a book about the lives of black maids working for white families in Jackson, Mississippi. She interviews several women including Minny, who works for Miss Hilly Holbrook, the president of the Junior League. Minny tells her how Miss Hilly treats her badly and makes her eat food out of the garbage can. Skeeter also talks to Yule May Crookley, who worked for Miss Leefolt before she died. Yule May tells her how Miss Leefolt used to beat her and make her sleep outside in the rain. Skeeter writes down everything she hears and publishes her book under the pseudonym "Eugenia Phelan". The book becomes very popular among both blacks and whites. However, many people are angry at Skeeter for writing such a controversial book. Some even accuse her of being racist herself. One night while walking home alone, Skeeter gets attacked by three young black men. They call her names and threaten to rape her. Luckily, a police officer arrives just in time to save her. Later, Skeeter learns that the attackers were actually hired by Miss Hilly to scare her away from publishing her book. Despite all these obstacles, Skeeter continues to fight for justice and equality for everyone regardless of skin color.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Naif turned the page. Another day of studying droned on. It wasn' t that the material was a challenge, Naif had no problem absorbing every concept she came across and she had more degrees than anyone her age to prove it. Life had always been that way. In primary school she related better to adults than her classmates. In secondary school she was respectful of her teachers but felt she understood the lessons they taught to a deeper level than even they appreciated. University had been much the same except the distance between herself and her professors had turned her conscientious respect into a degree of begrudging disdain. She was certainly more intelligent than anyone she knew of, more so than anyone she had ever met. She picked apart the documents piled high on her desk recalling even the articles in the citations that she had previously read. Today her eyes were heavy, mostly with boredom, somewhat with the strain. Her mind was as sharp as it had ever been but her body showed the signs that she would not be considered a young woman for much longer. Through the closed windows she could vaguely hear the muffled hum of the world rushing by outside. Suddenly the monotony of the day fell away as it was unbound by a sharp thud against the outer wall of her office. Naif quickly straightened her hunched shoulders and bumped the table sloshing coffee over her meticulously curated stacks of research papers. She snarled impatiently at the mess and sprang to the window. She squinted through the blinds at the sunlit scene then furrowed them even further in annoyance. The neighbours were playing baseball with their kids again. Idiots. Hadn' t they any respect for others? One of the little morons ran up to the edge of Naif's apartment, beneath her field of view, and tried to throw the ball back. It careened off course and the cretin had to go pick it up again to return it to his waiting family. Naif rolled her eyes as she turned away from the display of incompetence and inefficiency that played out beyond her walls. As she sopped up the spilled coffee from her desk she mumbled to herself, as she had before, "I wish everyone were more intelligent. I would have so much more to share with them, so much more in common. They run around all day never thinking of their actions, of their futures. Such wasted potential in all that frivolity." Though as she settled back into her comfortably worn chair she couldn' t help feeling that there was something more to it that she just didn' t quite understand.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Skeeter lands a job writing a housekeeping advice column.
output: He is excited because he has always wanted to write and this seems like a good opportunity. However, when he starts working on the column, he realizes that he doesn't know anything about housekeeping. He tries to fake it, but eventually gets caught and fired. Skeeter is devastated and decides to give up on his dream of being a writer. But then one day, while cleaning his room, he comes across an old notebook filled with stories he wrote when he was younger. He reads through them and realizes that he still loves writing. So he decides to start writing again, this time focusing on what he knows best: himself. And thus begins Skeeter's journey towards becoming a successful author.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
I looked up in horror at the crowd of young boys came thundering into the room. The clouds on the walls were suddenly blocked by a horde of scrambling young bodies and flailing limbs. I froze, the hat on my head tilted just enough for me to see everything, and i saw fear. Andy stood there in the middle of the floor, clutching the dreaded spaceman box, but that seemed to matter less compared to the pressing matter. The air was still, I could feel Mr.Potato head's round eyes blink and the sound of heavy breathing from the guests penetrated the silence with jagged blades of uncertainty. I considered freezing, but it was too late. We all knew it. Rex panicked like a child who came down christmas morning to find no gifts. He thundered across the hardwood floors for the window, yelling at the top of his lungs some inaudible dinosaur screech. I spun around, knowing it was too late and pointed towards the window. The toys did n't need a second prompt. The strong man and Mr. Potato head grabbed the monkeys in a barrel, hopped in RC and gunned the engines. The army men attempted to rescue some of the less mobile toys, but it was too late. One brilliant child had the idea to grab my waist with his sweaty, greasy hand and hold me up in the air. I put up a fight, hoping to distract them enough to let everyone escape. I did n't know what would happen, but panic had overrun my emotions and pure terror coursed through my plastic veins. But then, salvation. Andy wrenched me from the child's grasp and shouted angrily "YOU ONLY GOT ME BEDSHEETS." He held me gently in his grasp and managed to utter "Woody?" I stared back up at him with and sorrow filled my soul. I knew this was it, the other toys were out. "I'm sorry Andy, you'll understand one day." I flung my sack cloth limbs out of his hand and towards the bed, hitting it with surprising force. I propelled myself towards the window, clear through the slit. The other toys were already at the edge of the law waiting for me, but I had to look back at least once. Andy stared out the window with a look of pure despair on his face and one confused spaceman peered back, blinking quizzically towards the small group of toys, running down the street; never to return.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Skeeter seeks help from Aibileen, a black maid, for her column.
output:
She is told that she can not write about the maids' experiences because they are afraid of losing their jobs. Skeeter decides to write a book about the maids' lives instead. She interviews several maids, including Minny Jackson, who tells her about how she was fired after being accused of stealing silverware. Skeeter also learns about the Jim Crow laws that segregate blacks and whites in Mississippi. She becomes determined to expose these injustices in her book.

Aibileen agrees to help Skeeter with her project, but she warns her that it will be dangerous. They start interviewing more maids, including Yule May Davis, who tells them about how she was beaten by her employer when she tried to quit. Skeeter realizes that she needs to get more information if she wants to make her book successful.

She goes to visit Hilly Holbrook, a white woman who is known for being racist. Hilly refuses to talk to Skeeter, but she does give her some advice: "If you want people to listen to you, you have to speak their language."

Skeeter takes this advice to heart and starts writing her book in a way that will appeal to both blacks and whites. She includes stories about the hardships faced by black maids as well as positive examples of interracial friendship. Her book becomes a bestseller and helps change attitudes towards race relations in America.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
My story started where a lot have ended these past 10 years: with a single bullet. Living in post-war Britain, death was not an uncommon sight. Everyone had at least one firearm to defend themselves, everyone had encountered gunfire in the streets, and everyone knew what it meant to live every day like it could be their last. The revolution that was supposed to end the tyranny of a dictatorship had ripped the country apart; counties had split into factions, all threatening total destruction of the others. In ten years the population was decimated, the country reduced to a crumbling mass of fallen buildings and civilians with guns. All around me was depression, death, dirt, famine. Thinking about it, it's quite hilarious, in such a depressing way. The sacks of bones, flesh and organs we saw everyday were once living, breathing, talking human beings. They had a mother, a father, a pet, a first love, they were educated, they succeeded and they failed. And they died. A single bullet can end so much. That morning, as I wandered to the local shop for some bread, clutching my rifle, my world completely ended. I had no time to react; as soon as I entered Grange Avenue a bullet burrowed into my head, smashing part of my brain, and knocking me straight out cold. I woke in a beautiful wooden chalet, bright natural light streaming through vast windows above the soft, clean bed that I rested in. My itchy, dirty clothes were replaced with beautiful white robes, soft as silk and cleaner than anything I had ever seen. I sat up, and looked around the room - it was furnished luxuriously, with beautiful gold-leaf chairs and fantastic bright works of art hanging around the room. I got up and left the room, and immediately my breath was forced from me. The crumbled grey streets of London had gone. In their place were beautiful old chalets, bright white skyscrapers, and marble streets. I could also see a very unfamiliar sight - a beautiful emerald park, littered with tall, radiant trees, ferns, and glowing coloured flowers. Clear water ran through them. All around the streets were people dressed similar to me, smiling and talking and laughing. The smog-ridden sky had been replaced with a beautiful, deep purple, but the world was light around me and the I could see the vast orange sun dipping behind the structures around the city. For the first time in ten years I smiled. That bullet took me to a better place.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Aibileen mourns the loss of her son while caring for her white employer's child.
output: She is hired by Skeeter Phelan, a young white woman who has recently moved back home after graduating from Ole Miss University to write stories from the point of view of "the help". Aibileen agrees to tell her story under the condition of anonymity. Minny Jackson, Aibileen's best friend, is short-tempered and full of sass, but she is also warm-hearted and loves her children dearly. She is fired from her most recent job after using her employer's toilet (which was forbidden) and then retaliates by baking her a pie made with her own feces. Celia Foote hires Minny despite being warned against it by Hilly Holbrook, the town's socialite. Celia is ostracized by the other women because of her lower-class background and lack of refinement. She is desperate to fit in with the high society ladies, especially Hilly. However, Celia proves herself to be a kind person when she stands up for Minny and defends her against Hilly's accusations. Skeeter begins writing articles about the experiences of black maids working for white families in Jackson, Mississippi during the Civil Rights Movement. Her work attracts attention from both sides of the racial divide. Some people praise her for bringing attention to the plight of African Americans while others criticize her for stirring up trouble between blacks and whites. As more maids come forward to share their stories, tensions rise within the community. Eventually, Hilly discovers what Skeeter has been doing and tries to stop her by spreading rumors about her character. This leads to a confrontation between the two women which ends with Hilly slapping Skeeter across the face. Despite this setback, Skeeter continues to publish her book and becomes a successful author. Meanwhile, Aibileen decides to leave her job as a maid and pursue a career as a writer. She moves away from Jackson and starts over again in New York City. There she meets another former maid named Louvenia who helps her adjust to life outside of Mississippi. Together they form a support group called "The Help" where they discuss issues related to race relations and civil rights. Over time, the members of the group grow closer together and develop strong friendships. One day, Aibileen receives news that her daughter has given birth to a baby girl. She returns home to celebrate the occasion with her family and friends. During the party, she learns that her husband has been killed in Vietnam. Devastated by his death, she turns to alcohol to cope with her grief. Later, she attends a meeting of the NAACP where she meets Martin Luther King Jr.. Inspired by his speech, she joins the organization and dedicates herself to fighting for equality. Years later, Aibileen visits her old neighborhood and finds that things haven't changed much since she left. Many of the houses are still boarded up and abandoned. But there is hope. A new generation of activists is rising up to continue the fight for justice. And although she may never see her dream realized, Aibileen knows that she played a small part in making history happen.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
It was like double-vision, except it was the past. How can something fictional seem so vivid...? The distant, exotic land we came from, its gilded avenues, its glistening intricate spires, its profound natural beauty with lushly verdant banks hugging the rivers that snaked between the dunes. .. None of it was there. It was all nothing more than a dream. But I am not a lie. I stare at my hands, flexing them, examining the callouses accumulated by work never done, cracks formed of age never lived, and despite the warmth of the bright sun just passing its zenith above, I shiver. "Amir," I hear a voice call, and my heart tugs at what I know to be familiarity. "Hassan...?" I uncertainly reply as I look up. Our gazes meet. I could swear I saw in his eyes the same false memories flashing behind mine. Childhood among parents who never lived, in a community that was never built, attending an academy that was never founded, graduating from a ceremony never held... He nods hollowly, as if to confirm these very musings. "... We have to pack the supplies, Amir. His Majesty will be staying at the palace, and the staff are directing us to where we are to stow his wardrobe and leave his tributes to The Sultan." My mouth was dry, but not in response to his words. At some point I realized my'old friend' Hassan was talking only to fill the screaming void in our minds. To'Sound Normal', like'Real People'. My stomach is a knot of ice. Still, the skills of a life as-yet unlived surface readily to the forefront of my mind. How to port the many caskets of His Majesty Prince Ali's wares. "... Yes. I will coordinate with the provisioner. If my memory serves," I pause a bit too long, lost in the jarring disjunction of citing false memories, "... it is customary to serve a great feast with the arrival of a dignitary. The many delicacies of our homeland are sure to leave a resounding impression upon The Sultan's court." Hassan's expression tightens. I feel his heartache, for this homeland which we have never seen with real eyes, and never shall. He hesitantly takes a step nearer and dispenses a conciliatory pat to my shoulder. A mutual understanding. We were truly all feeling it, every last member of His Majesty Prince Ali's vanguard.... he was n't even really a prince. I shudder and turn, to address the court provisioner by name. He's just as haunted and startled as I that we know one another, but everything is running smoothly. We have no solace from our inner thoughts. We can only push on in the hopes that the minutia will wash away the horror.

Skeeter is inspired to write a book from the perspective of black maids.
output: She interviews Aibileen Clark, Minny Jackson, and other maids. They tell her stories about their lives working for white families. Skeeter writes down their stories and publishes them in a book called "The Help". The book becomes a bestseller and changes people's attitudes towards race relations in America. However, some people don't like the book because they think it makes white people look bad. One day, Hilly Holbrook (a racist woman) finds out that Skeeter wrote the book. She gets angry and tries to get revenge on Skeeter. She spreads rumors about Skeeter being a communist and a lesbian. This causes problems for Skeeter at work and school. Eventually, Skeeter decides to move away from Mississippi. She moves to New York City and starts writing articles for magazines. Her career takes off and she becomes famous. Meanwhile, back in Mississippi, things start changing slowly. More blacks are allowed to vote and go to integrated schools. Some whites even start treating blacks better. In conclusion, "The Help" shows how one person can make a difference by speaking up against injustice. It also shows how society can change over time when enough people stand together for what's right.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
It started happening before I was born. My grandfather tells me that it started before he was born too. All we know is that, when you reach the age of 25, a letter appears. No one's quite sure how. It just shows up. Some people never open theirs, they're too afraid to know. If you try to throw it away, it'll come back. If you burn or tear it, a new one is sent. At first everyone thought it was a prank. Date, time, location and cause of death? How would anybody know such a thing? But then, the first person scheduled to die, did. Hit by the same bus mentioned, on the same street, at the same time, on the same day. Just days later, the second was shot by a mugger. It was becoming clear that this was real. Fast-forward to now. My 25th birthday. I have the letter. I've already made my mind up that I'll want to know. But my hands shake as I open the letter. What if I only have a few days left? What if I'm going to die today? I swallow, and take the piece of paper out of the envelope. Blank. Both sides, blank. I hold it up against the light. Still nothing. I try to think what else I could do, but it is completely and utterly blank. What could that mean? Am I immortal? Should I already be dead? Is my death alone unfixed? What kind of person gets a blank death letter? I walk out to where the rest of my family is gathered. 25th birthdays are usually sombre events, even for those who do n't open their letters. I look at them all uncertainly. My grandfather, who knows that he has days left, although he wo n't tell us how many, shuffles over, and asks, "Well, want to share?" Numbly, I hand him the envelope with the blank piece of paper in it. He takes it out, and the shock of it gives him a heart attack. As we wait for the ambulance, he slips away. He was the only one of that generation left, and he had celebrated his 100th birthday a month ago. He'd known, for 75 years that he was going to die on this day, at the time he did. He just did n't tell us when, because his letter had given the location'At Your Grandson's 25th Birthday Party'. We obviously needed to start preparing for his cremation, but everyone seemed very interested in my blank letter. Nobody came up with any real answers, there was n't even a whisper about blank death letters on the internet. Eventually, one of my cousins who did n't like me very much said that we could test whether I was immortal. "Try it, and I test whether you are." I usually would n't have been so snappy, but I'd just received a blank death letter, and my grandfather had just died. I was a little bit shaken up, to say the least. Everyone kept arguing over what we could do. Eventually, I could n't take it anymore, so I made my excuses and left. I walked home, not really paying much attention to my surroundings, and just as I was crossing the road in front of my house, the van hit me. As I came to a rest, the death letter which had been knocked out of my jacket, fluttered down onto me, now displaying the number 1.

Ultimately, Moses comes to realize that he must accept responsibility for his own happiness and well-being. He cannot rely on others to provide him with a sense of purpose or fulfillment. This realization leads Moses to a more positive outlook on life, and he begins to see possibilities for growth and change. The novel ends with Moses feeling hopeful about the future and ready to face whatever challenges may come his way.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
You know those nightmares you had as a child, where you'd be somewhere familiar yet completely alien? As though your home had suddenly become some faraway land, and your only goal was to return home. Well in 2014, that's exactly what happened to everyone in the world. I was on my way to an important business meeting, off to discuss some law, and how my company could avoid it, when it all happened. I checked my watch to see the time, and as I looked up, I saw a blinding flash off in the distance, lighting up the once blue sky in streaks of white. Next, it was followed by an eardrum shattering bang, like a hundred thousand gunshots going off at once. Then, finally, the blast. A wall of rock, stone, dirt and trash and flew towards me, silhouetted by the strange white light. I turned to run, but like a wave washing over the ocean, anything in the path of that wall was thrown like a ragdoll. The last thing I remember was being thrown what felt like miles into the air, and rushing down back into that swirling vortex of light. When I woke, it was night time. Others seemed to be sitting up around me, and the confused look on the faces that surrounded me seemed to speak louder than words that this was not a normal occurrence. I checked my watch, and had a terrible realisation. It was 3 am, and I was ridiculously late for my meeting! I tried to get to my feet, but the second I tried to stand, my legs gave way underneath me. What the hell was going on? After a few minutes I had enough strength to drag myself up by a nearby stair railing. For the first time since waking, I looked around. Something was wrong. As I looked, I saw the once manicured strips of grass and trees had overgrown to ridiculous proportions, and the streets were covered in trash, empty food packages, and bones. Wait what the hell? Upon further inspection, I saw they were human. Jesus Christ, what the hell happened. It was then that I checked my watch again. A neat little feature it had was that it told the time in seconds, minutes, hours, days and years. The blood drained from my face as I saw what I'd missed earlier. 3:04 am. Friday. 13th of June. 2015. As I wondered what the hell was going on, something rustled through the bushes behind me. Something big. As I saw glowing red eyes light the way. Then was the first time I wondered, what left those bones?

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Herzog retreats to his country home in Massachusetts.
output: He is visited by his friend, Dr. Jameson, who has come to help him with his research. Herzog tells Jameson that he has been working on a new theory of evolution, which he calls "the theory of the superman." According to this theory, there are two types of people in the world: the weak and the strong. The weak are those who are content to live their lives according to the rules set down by society. They are the ones who follow the herd, who do what they are told, and who never question authority. The strong, on the other hand, are those who have the courage to break free from the herd and forge their own paths. They are the ones who challenge authority, who think for themselves, and who are willing to take risks. Herzog believes that the strong are the ones who will survive and thrive in the future, while the weak will perish. He also believes that the strong are the ones who will create a new race of supermen, who will be able to overcome any obstacle and achieve greatness. Jameson is skeptical of Herzog's theory, but he agrees to help him test it out. Together, they travel to Africa, where they plan to study the behavior of the native tribes. However, things quickly go awry. The natives are hostile and uncooperative, and Herzog and Jameson find themselves in danger. They are forced to flee, and they end up stranded in the middle of the jungle. As they struggle to survive, Herzog begins to realize that his theory may not be as sound as he thought. He starts to doubt himself, and he wonders if he is really one of the strong. Meanwhile, Jameson becomes increasingly frustrated with Herzog's lack of progress. He wants to leave Africa and return to civilization, but Herzog refuses to give up. Eventually, Jameson decides to take matters into his own hands. He leaves Herzog alone in the jungle and returns to America. Herzog is devastated by Jameson's betrayal, but he is determined to prove his theory. He continues to study the natives, and he eventually comes to understand them better. He realizes that they are not as primitive as he thought, and he learns to respect them. In the end, Herzog is able to return to America and share his findings with the world. His theory of the superman is met with skepticism, but he remains convinced that it is true. He knows that he is one of the strong, and he is confident that he can make a difference in the world.

It was like double-vision, except it was the past. How can something fictional seem so vivid...? The distant, exotic land we came from, its gilded avenues, its glistening intricate spires, its profound natural beauty with lushly verdant banks hugging the rivers that snaked between the dunes. .. None of it was there. It was all nothing more than a dream. But I am not a lie. I stare at my hands, flexing them, examining the callouses accumulated by work never done, cracks formed of age never lived, and despite the warmth of the bright sun just passing its zenith above, I shiver. "Amir," I hear a voice call, and my heart tugs at what I know to be familiarity. "Hassan...?" I uncertainly reply as I look up. Our gazes meet. I could swear I saw in his eyes the same false memories flashing behind mine. Childhood among parents who never lived, in a community that was never built, attending an academy that was never founded, graduating from a ceremony never held... He nods hollowly, as if to confirm these very musings. "... We have to pack the supplies, Amir. His Majesty will be staying at the palace, and the staff are directing us to where we are to stow his wardrobe and leave his tributes to The Sultan." My mouth was dry, but not in response to his words. At some point I realized my'old friend' Hassan was talking only to fill the screaming void in our minds. To'Sound Normal', like'Real People'. My stomach is a knot of ice. Still, the skills of a life as-yet unlived surface readily to the forefront of my mind. How to port the many caskets of His Majesty Prince Ali's wares. "... Yes. I will coordinate with the provisioner. If my memory serves," I pause a bit too long, lost in the jarring disjunction of citing false memories, "... it is customary to serve a great feast with the arrival of a dignitary. The many delicacies of our homeland are sure to leave a resounding impression upon The Sultan's court." Hassan's expression tightens. I feel his heartache, for this homeland which we have never seen with real eyes, and never shall. He hesitantly takes a step nearer and dispenses a conciliatory pat to my shoulder. A mutual understanding. We were truly all feeling it, every last member of His Majesty Prince Ali's vanguard.... he was n't even really a prince. I shudder and turn, to address the court provisioner by name. He's just as haunted and startled as I that we know one another, but everything is running smoothly. We have no solace from our inner thoughts. We can only push on in the hopes that the minutia will wash away the horror.
